(b)  to make and adopt such reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary to carry out the duties of the Retiree Health Care Board and activities of the Retiree Health Care Trust, including and rules and regulations necessary to preserve the status of the Trust under Section 115 of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended, or under successor or related provisions of law; 
(c)  to create and maintain the records of the Retiree Health Care Trust, including all meeting agenda and minutes; 
(d)  to retain such clerical or administrative personnel to perform whatever administrative activities are required in the proper operation related to investments and funding of the Retiree Health Care Trust. The Board may utilize City staff for such functions; and 
(e)  to make and execute contracts. 
(2)  The Retiree Health Care Board shall make distributions from the Retiree Health Care Trust assets pursuant to a written notification of the amount from the Plan Administrator of the Health Care Plan. Distributions may be made more frequently than once per year, but in no case shall the aggregate amount distributed to the Health Care Plan in any fiscal year exceed the estimated health care costs for that year. Distributions pursuant to this Section shall be made from the income of the Retiree Health Care Trust and, to the extent that the income is insufficient, from the corpus of the Retiree Health Care Trust. 
(3)  If the Retiree Health Care Board undertakes to defend any litigation arising in connection with the Retiree Health Care Trust, the City, to the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, shall indemnify the Board and Retiree Health Care Trust against their actual costs, expenses and liabilities (including, without limitation, reasonable and actual attorneys' fees and expenses incurred) relating thereto and to be primarily liable for such payments; provided however, that the City shall not indemnify the Board for any litigation arising from any actions that are determined by a court of competent jurisdiction to be fraudulent, in bad faith, illegal or grossly negligent. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12-961 - Sec. 11.INVESTMENT. 
(1)  The Retiree Health Care Board shall be the trustee of the Retiree Health Care Trust and shall have the authority to carry out the purposes of the Retiree Health Care Trust, including, but not limited to: 
(a)  invest and reinvest the assets of the Retiree Health Care Trust subject to the terms, conditions, limitations and restrictions imposed by the State of Michigan on the investments of public employee retirement systems by the Public Employee Retirement System Investment Act, 1965 P.A. 314, as amended (MCL 38.1132 et seq.). In exercising its discretionary authority with respect to the management of the Retiree Health Care Trust, the Retiree Health Care Board shall be an investment fiduciary and shall act with the care, skill, prudence and diligence under circumstances then prevailing, that a prudent person, acting in a similar capacity and familiar with those matters would use in the conduct of a similar enterprise with similar aims. This shall include diversifying the assets of the Retiree Health Care Trust so as to minimize the risk of large losses, unless under the circumstances it appears prudent not to do so. 
Subject to the foregoing, the Retiree Health Care Board shall have the following rights, powers and duties with respect to the assets of the Retiree Health Care Trust: 
i.  to retain, manage, improve, repair, operate and control all property, real or personal, at any time comprising part of the Trust; 
ii.  to manage, sell, contract to sell, grant options to purchase, convey, exchange, partition, lease for any term, and otherwise dispose of the Trust from time to time and in such manner, for such consideration, and upon such terms and conditions as the Board, in its discretion, shall determine; 
iii.  to retain all or any part of the Trust in the form in which such assets were received or acquired by the Retiree Health Care Board; 
iv.  to hold all or part of the Trust in cash or in bank accounts without the necessity of investing the same; 
v.  to vote any corporate stock either in person or by proxy for any purpose; to exercise or sell any stock subscription or conversion right; to participate in voting trusts; to consent to, take any action in connection with, and receive and retain any securities resulting from, any merger, consolidation, reorganization, readjustment of the financial structure, liquidation, sale, lease or other organization the securities of which may constitute a portion of the Trust; 
vi.  to keep property in the name of a nominee with or without disclosure of any fiduciary relationship; to have evidence of ownership of any security maintained in the records of a Federal Reserve Bank under the Federal Reserve Book Entry System; to deposit funds in any bank or trust company; to carry in the name of the Retiree Health Care Trust or the nominee or nominees of the Retiree Health Care Trust and with or without the designation of fiduciary capacity, or to hold in bearer form, securities or other property which are required or permitted to be registered; and to cause any securities to be held by a depository corporation of which the Retiree Health Care Trust shall be a member or be an agent under a safekeeping contract; provided, however, that the books and records of the Retiree Health Care Trust shall at all times show that such investments are part of the Trust; 
vii.  to take any action with respect to conserving or realizing upon the value of any property in the Retiree Health Care Trust; to collect, pay, contest, compromise or abandon demands of or against the Trust; 
viii.  to litigate, defend, compromise, settle, abandon, or submit to arbitration on such terms as the Retiree Health Care Board determines, any claims in favor of or against the Retiree Health Care Trust; 
ix.  to employ such agents, experts, investment fiduciaries, legal counsel and other persons or entities deemed by the Retiree Health Care Board to be necessary or proper for the administration and management of the Retiree Health Care Trust; to rely and act on information and advice furnished by such agents, experts, investment fiduciaries, legal counsel, and other persons or entities; and to pay their reasonable expenses and compensation for services to the Board from the Retiree Health Care Trust. 
x.  to transfer to an investment fiduciary (as defined at MCL 38.1132c(l)), the authority and accompanying duty to direct the investment and management of all or a portion of the Retiree Health Care Trust, provided that such an investment fiduciary shall acknowledge in writing fiduciary status with respect to the Trust; and 
xi.  to make, execute, and deliver any and all such instruments in writing as shall be necessary or proper to carry out any power, right, duty or obligation of the Board of Trustees or any disposition whatsoever of the Retiree Health Care Trust, and to perform any and all acts which in the judgment of the Board is necessary or desirable for the proper and advantageous administration of the Trust. 
xii.  to the extent provided by law, the Retiree Health Care Board may commingle the investment of the Trust assets with other funds. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.962 - Sec. 12.BOARD MEETINGS. 
(1)  The Retiree Health Care Board shall meet at least once per calendar quarter. The Retiree Health Care Board shall determine the time for the regular meetings of the Trustees and the place or places where such meetings shall be held. 
(2)  Notice and conduct of all meetings of the Retiree Health Care Board, both regular and special, shall be given in accordance with applicable law including the Open Meetings Act (MCL §15.261 et seq.) 
(3)  The Retiree Health Care Board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. Four (4) Trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the Retiree Health Care Board. Each Trustee shall be entitled to one vote on each question before the Retiree Health Care Board and at least four (4) concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision of the Retiree Health Care Board. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.963 - Sec. 13.COMPENSATION. 
    All Trustees shall serve without compensation as members of the Retiree Health Care Board, except that Trustees who are City employees shall suffer no loss in compensation on account of their services as Trustees. Trustees may also be reimbursed by the Trust for reasonable and necessary costs and expenses in performing their duties as Trustees. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.964 - Sec. 14.BOARD LIABILITIES. 
(1)  The Retiree Health Care Board's responsibilities and liabilities shall be subject to the following limitations and other limitations as set forth in the Trust: 
(2)  The Retiree Health Care Board shall have no duties other than those expressly set forth in this Trust and those imposed on the Retiree Health Care Board by applicable law. 
(3)  The Retiree Health Care Board and Trust Administrator shall be responsible only for money and property actually received by the Retiree Health Care Board, and then only to the extent described in this Trust. 
(4)  The Retiree Health Care Board and Trust Administrator shall not be responsible for the correctness of any determination of payments or disbursements from the Plan. 
(5)  The Retiree Health Care Board and Trust Administrator shall have no liability for the acts or omissions of any (a) investment advisor; (b) insurance company; (c) investment fund; or (d) independent contractor. 
(6)  In the event of any suit brought against the Trustees or Trust Administrator arising out of the acts within the scope and powers and duties of the Trustees or Trust Administrator, or in the event of any lawsuit brought by the Trustees, the cost of defense or prosecution of such lawsuit shall be charged to the Trust, and shall be paid directly from the Trust, provided such costs are not incurred by reason of bad faith, gross negligence, or breach of a fiduciary obligation to the Trust. 
(7)  The Retiree Health Care Board may authorize the purchase of insurance for the Trust and for the Trustees and Trust Administrator to cover liability or losses occurring for any reason, including, but not limited to, an act or omission (errors or omissions) of a fiduciary, including the Trustees and Trust Administrator. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.965 - Sec. 15.TRUST LIABILITIES. 
(1)  The City shall not be liable for payment to the Trust of any amount other than those required pursuant to this Trust. The City, Plan participant/beneficiary, Trust Administrator or Trustee shall not be liable for any debts, liabilities or obligations of the Trust except as provided herein. Neither the City nor any Plan participant/beneficiary shall have any right to the return of any money properly paid into the Trust, except as otherwise specifically provided in the Trust. 
(2)  Neither the Retiree Health Care Board, Trust Administrator or its Trustees shall be responsible for the validity of any Insurance Agreement issued in connection with the Trust or for the failure on the part of the Insurer to make payments provided by such Insurance Agreement, or for the action of any person which may delay payment or render an Insurance Agreement null and void or unenforceable in whole or in part. Notwithstanding the establishment of the Trust or anything contained in this agreement, the Trustees and Trust Administrator shall not be empowered to interpret the rights and obligation of the City in any Collective Bargaining Agreements. 
(3)  No part of the Trust or any benefits payable by the Trustees shall be subject to alienation, sale, transfer, assignment, pledge, or encumbrance by any person. No Plan participant or beneficiary shall be entitled to receive any part of the Contributions made by the City or payments required to be made by the Trust, in lieu of such benefits provided under the Plan as determined by the Trustees in accordance with the Trust. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.966 - Sec. 16.REPORTS. 
(1)  The Retiree Health Care Board, or its respective designees, shall establish a uniform system for the timely transmission of required reports and shall complete and provide any reports as may be required by the Code, applicable federal, state or local law. 
(2)  The Trustees, in accordance with the requirements of law, may direct an impartial firm of independent certified public accountants to act as agent of the Trustees to examine the records and reports as may be necessary to determine the monies due on behalf of this Trust and to make a written report to the Trustees, 
(3)  The Trustees shall maintain, or cause to be maintained, proper books of accounts and records of and for the administration of the Trust, including the minutes of all meetings, make them available for inspection during reasonable business hours. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.967 - Sec. 17.INTERPRETATION AND LAW; CONSTRUCTION. 
(1)  The Trust is established and shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Michigan and applicable federal laws and regulations. 
(2)  The Trust shall constitute a governmental trust pursuant to Section 115 of the Code, as amended and shall be construed, enforced and administered and the validity thereof determined in accordance with the Code and the laws of the State of Michigan, If any provision of the Trust is held to violate the Code or to be illegal or invalid for any other reason, that provision shall be deemed to be null and void, but the invalidation of that provision shall not otherwise affect the Trust. 
(3)  Neither the establishment of the Trust, nor any modification thereof, nor the creation of any fund or account, nor the payment of any benefits, shall be construed as giving to any person covered under the Plan, or any other person, any legal or equitable right or claim to any benefits or assets against the City, its elected or appointed officials or employees, the Retiree Health Care Board or any individual Retiree Health Care Board member, except as may otherwise be provided in this Trust. 
(4)  The headings and subheadings in this Trust are inserted for convenience of reference only and are not to be considered in the construction of any provision of the Trust. 
(5)  Words herein in the masculine gender shall be construed to include the feminine gender where appropriate, and words used herein in the singular or plural shall be construed as being in the plural or singular where appropriate. 
(6)  In resolving any conflict among provisions of this Trust or any uncertainty as to the meaning or intention of any provision of this Trust, the interpretation that causes both the Trust to be exempt from tax and the Trust to comply with all applicable requirements of the Code shall prevail over any different interpretation. 
    This Trust shall be binding upon all Plan participants and beneficiaries, or their applicable heirs, executors, administrators, successors, and assigns. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.968 - Sec. 18.NOTICE. 
    Notice given to all interested parties shall, unless otherwise specified in this Trust, be sufficient if in writing and delivered or sent by prepaid first class mail. Except as otherwise noted, the distribution or delivery of any statements or documents required under the Trust shall be sufficient if delivered in person or prepaid first class mail. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.969 - Sec. 19.AMENDMENTS AND TERMINATION. 
(1)  The City, in its sole and absolute discretion, may amend the Retiree Health Care Trust in accordance with the provisions of Section 115 of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended, or as otherwise required pursuant to the provisions of applicable state and federal law and regulations. 
(2)  The Retiree Health Care Trust, though irrevocable, may be terminated by the City, but only in the following limited circumstances: 
(a)  At the option of the City, the Retiree Health Care Trust's assets may be distributed, in full, to satisfy the purpose of the Trust; 
(b)  If the Retiree Health Care Trust no longer has any assets; or 
(c)  Upon the City's satisfaction of its retiree health care liabilities. 
(3)  Upon termination of the Retiree Health Care Trust, the remaining assets shall be distributed to the City. 
(4)  In no event will the Retiree Health Care Trust assets revert to any entity that is not a state, a political subdivision of the state, or an entity whose income is excluded from gross income under Code Section 115. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.970 - Sec. 20.THIRD PARTY RELIANCE. 
    Third parties may rely on the representations of the Retiree Health Care Board relating to any authority granted under the Retiree Health Care Trust. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.971 - Sec. 21.SEVERABILITY. 
    Should any section, paragraph, or clause of this Chapter be determined to be invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalid portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent portion of this Ordinance, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.972 - Sec. 22.SAVINGS CLAUSE. 
    All proceedings pending and all rights and liabilities existing, acquired or incurred at the time this Ordinance takes effect are saved and may be consummated according to the law in force when they are commenced. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
12.973 - Sec. 23.EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    This Ordinance shall take immediate effect upon its approval by the City Commission. 
(ord. eff. May 1, 2017) 
14.000 - PLANNING COMMISSION ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct. 2, 2017[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted effective Oct. 2, 2017, repealed code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. eff. Jan., 1978. 

14.001 - Sec. 1. 
AUTHORITY. 
    This ordinance is adopted pursuant to the authority granted the City Commission under the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. , and the Michigan Zoning Enabling Act, Public Act 110 of 2006, MCL 125.3101, et seq. , to establish a Planning Commission with the powers, duties and limitations provided by those Acts and subject to the terms and conditions of this ordinance and any future amendments to this ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.002 - Sec. 2. 
PURPOSE. 
    The purpose of this ordinance is to provide that the Mount Clemens City Commission hereby amends and confirms the establishment, under the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. , of the Mount Clemens Planning Commission, formerly established under the Municipal Planning Act, Public Act 285 of 1931, MCL 125.31, et seq. , to establish the appointments, terms, and membership of the Planning Commission; to identify the officers and the minimum number of meetings per year of the Planning Commission, and to prescribe the authority, powers and duties of the Planning Commission. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.003 - Sec. 3. ESTABLISHMENT. 
    There shall be a Mount Clemens Planning Commission pursuant to Public Act 33 of 2008, as amended, being the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, MCL 125.3801 et seq. , hereinafter referred to as the " Planning Commission ", with the powers and duties as therein set forth and as hereinafter provided. This ordinance shall be officially known and described as the "Mount Clemens Planning Commission Ordinance." Members of the Planning Commission as of the effective date of this ordinance shall, continue to serve for the remainder of their existing terms so long as they continue to meet all of the eligibility requirements for planning commission membership set forth within the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.004 - Sec. 4. 
MEMBERSHIP. 
A.  The Planning Commission shall consist of 7 members appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the majority of the City Commission elected and serving. To be qualified to be a member and remain a member of the Planning Commission, the individual shall be a qualified elector of the City of Mount Clemens, except that one member may be an individual who is not a qualified elector of the City. 
B.  The membership of the Planning Commission shall be representative of important segments of the community, such as economic, governmental, educational, and social development of the City, in accordance with the major interests as they exist in the City, such as natural resources, recreation, education, public health, government, transportation, residential uses, industry, and commerce. The membership may also be representative of the entire geography of the City to the extent practicable. 
C.  Members shall be appointed for three-year terms. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.005 - Sec. 5. 
OFFICERS. 
A.  The Planning Commission shall elect a chairperson, and a secretary from its members, and may create and fill other offices as it considers advisable. The term of each office shall be one year, with opportunity for re-election as specified in the Planning Commission Bylaws. 
B.  The Planning Commission may also appoint advisory committees, whose members are not members of the Planning Commission. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.006 - Sec. 6. 
REMOVAL FROM OFFICE. 
    The City Commission may remove a member of the Planning Commission for misfeasance, malfeasance, or nonfeasance in office upon written charges and after a public hearing. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.007 - Sec. 7. 
MEMBERSHIP; VACANCIES. 
    The City Commission shall fill any vacancy in the membership of the Planning Commission for the unexpired terms in the same manner as the initial appointment and shall do so within 60 days. A Planning Commission member shall hold office until his or her successor is appointed. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.008 - Sec. 8. 
MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION. 
    The Planning Commission members may be compensated for their services and expenses as provided by City Commission Resolution. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.009 - Sec. 9. 
MEETINGS. 
A.  The Planning Commission shall hold at least four regular meetings each year, and shall by resolution determine the time and place of such meetings. 
B.  Unless otherwise provided in the Planning Commission's Bylaws, a special meeting of the Planning Commission may be called by the chairperson or by two other members, upon written request to the secretary. Unless the Bylaws otherwise provide, the secretary or planner shall send written notice of a special meeting to Planning Commission members at least 48 hours prior to the meeting. 
C.  The business that the Planning Commission may perform shall be conducted at a public meeting held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, Public Act 267 of 1976, MCL 15.261, et seq. 
D.  The Planning Commission shall keep a public record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations. A writing prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained by a Planning Commission in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with the Freedom of Information Act, Public Act 442 of 1976, MCL 15.231, et seq . 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.010 - Sec. 10. 
POWERS AND DUTIES. 
    The Planning Commission shall have the powers and duties as set forth in Public Act 33 of 2008, as amended being the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. , and the Michigan Zoning Enabling Act, Public Act 110 of 2006, MCL 125.3101, et seq. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.011 - Sec. 11. 
BYLAWS. 
    The Planning Commission shall adopt Bylaws for the transaction of business. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.012 - Sec. 12. 
ANNUAL REPORT. 
    The Planning Commission shall make an annual written report to the City Commission concerning its operations and the status of the planning activities, including recommendations regarding actions by the City Commission related to planning and development. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.013 - Sec. 13. 
MASTER PLAN. 
A.  Under the authority of the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. , and other applicable planning statutes, the Planning Commission shall make a Master Plan as a guide for development within the City's planning jurisdiction. 
B.  Final authority to approve a Master Plan or any amendments thereto shall rest with the Planning Commission, unless the City Commission passes a resolution asserting the right to approve or reject the Master Plan. 
C.  Unless rescinded by the City, any plan adopted or amended under the Municipal Planning Act, Public Act 285 of 1931, need not be readopted under the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.014 - Sec. 14. 
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS PROGRAM. 
    The Planning Commission shall annually prepare a capital improvements program of public structures and improvements, showing those structures and improvements in general order of their priority and financial feasibility, for the following 6 year period, in accordance with the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. , unless the planning commission is exempted from this requirement by charter or otherwise. If the planning commission is exempted, the legislative body either shall prepare and adopt a capital improvements program, separate from or as a part of the annual budget, or shall delegate the preparation of the capital improvements program to the chief elected official or a nonelected administrative official, subject to final approval by the legislative body. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.015 - Sec. 15. 
SUBDIVISION AND LAND RECOMMENDATIONS. 
A.  The Planning Commission may recommend to the City Commission provisions of an ordinance or rules governing the subdivision of land. Before recommending such an ordinance or rule, the Planning Commission shall hold a public hearing on the proposed ordinance or rule. The Planning Commission shall give notice of the time and place of the public hearing not less than 15 days before the hearing by publication in a newspaper of general circulation within the City, or any other method permitted by law. 
B.  The Planning Commission shall review and make recommendation on a proposed plat before action thereon by the City Commission under the Land Division Act, Public Act 288 of 1967, MCL 560.101, et seq. Before making its recommendation, the Planning Commission shall hold a public hearing on the proposed plat. A plat submitted to the Planning Commission shall contain the name and address of the proprietor or other person to whom notice of hearing shall be sent. Not less than 15 days before the date of the hearing, notice of the date, time and place of the hearing shall be sent to that person at that address by mail and shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the City, or by any other method permitted by law. Similar notice shall be mailed to the owners of land immediately adjoining the proposed platted land. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.016 - Sec. 16. 
APPROVAL, RATIFICATION AND RECONFIRMATION. 
    All official actions taken by all City Plan Commissioners of Mount Clemens, preceding the Planning Commission established by this ordinance, are hereby approved, ratified and reconfirmed. Any project, review or process taking place at the effective date of this ordinance, shall continue with the Commission created by this ordinance, subject to the requirements of this ordinance, and shall be deemed a continuation of any previous City Plan Commission of the City of Mount Clemens. This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its adoption and publication. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.017 - Sec. 17. 
REPEALER. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this ordinance are repealed only to the extent necessary to give this ordinance full force and effect. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.018 - Sec. 18. 
SEVERABILITY. 
    Should any section, subsection, clause or phrase of this ordinance be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, the validity of the ordinance as a whole, or in part, shall not be affected other than the part invalidated. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.019 - Sec. 19. 
SAVINGS. 
    All proceedings pending and all rights and liabilities existing, acquired or incurred at the time this ordinance takes effect are saved and may be consummated according to the law in force when they were commenced. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.020 - Sec. 20. 
EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    The provisions of this ordinance are ordered to take effect following publication in the manner prescribed by the Charter of the City of Mount Clemens and state law. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 2, 2017) 
14.050 - ARETHUSA DEVELOPMENT PLAN CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 
An ordinance to amend Title 6 Buildings Chapter 7 Arethusa Development Plan as amended to revise the Chapter Designation to Chapter 9 and to revise the numbering system for sections of the Ordinance from Sections 6-701 etc. to Sections 6-901 etc. 
THE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS ORDAINS: 

14.051 - Sec. 1. 
PLAN AMENDED. 
    That Title 6 Buildings, Chapter 7, "Arethusa Development Plan" , be amended to read as follows: 
Title 6 Buildings Chapter 9 Arethusa Development Plan 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.052 - Sec. 2. 
SHORT TITLE. 
    This Ordinance shall be known and cited as "The Arethusa Development Plan" for the City of Mount Clemens, Michigan. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.053 - Sec. 3. 
PREAMBLE AND PURPOSES. 
A.  AUTHORITY. Whereas, the Rehabilitation of Blighted Areas Act, Act 344, P.A. of 1945, as amended, authorized cities to adopt plans for the rehabilitation of blighted areas and to carry out such rehabilitation; and 
B.  BOUNDARIES IDENTIFIED. Whereas, it is desirable and in the public interest that the City of Mount Clemens undertake and carry out the rehabilitation project identified as the West Side Downtown Redevelopment Project, encompassing the area bounded as follows, in the City of Mount Clemens, Macomb County, Michigan: Beginning at the point of intersection of the west right-of-way line of South Gratiot Avenue and the south right-of-way line of Cass Avenue, proceed south along the west right-of-way line of South Gratiot Avenue for approximately 475 feet to the southeast corner of lot 10, Assessor's Plat No. 31; then proceed west for approximately 208 feet to the southwest corner of lot 10, Assessor's Plat No. 31; then proceed northerly along the east right-of-way line of South Walnut for approximately 430 feet to the northwest corner of lot 2B, Assessor's Plat No. 31; then proceed easterly along the south right-of-way line of Cass Avenue for approximately 230 feet to the point of beginning; including the following lots of Assessor's Plat No. 31: Lots 1A, 1B, 2A, 2B, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10; and 
C.  NECESSITY DETERMINED. Whereas, the Community Development Department of the City of Mount Clemens has made and caused to be made detailed studies of the location, physical condition of structures, land use, environmental influences, and social, cultural, and economic conditions of the project area; and has determined that the area is a blighted area characterized by obsolescence, physical deterioration of structures therein, and similar characteristics which endanger the health, safety, morals, or general welfare of the municipality; and which may include buildings or improvements not in themselves obsolescent, and real property improved or unimproved, the acquisition of which is deemed necessary for rehabilitation of the area; and that the area in its existing condition is detrimental to the health, safety, and welfare of the inhabitants and users thereof, and of the community at large, because of deteriorating and blighting influences upon adjoining and nearby areas and property, congestion, building overcrowding on the land, inadequate building setbacks, physical and structural deterioration; and the members of the City Commission have been fully apprised by the Community Development Department, and are aware of these facts and conditions; and 
D.  DEVELOPMENT PLAN SUBMITTED. Whereas, there has been prepared and referred to the Mount Clemens City Commission for review and approval a development plan for the project area, dated January 4, 1977, and consisting of 12 pages and one exhibit; supported by supplementary material, data, and recommendations not a part of the development plan; and 
E.  MASTER PLAN AS GUIDE. Whereas, a General Development Plan for the City of Mount Clemens has been prepared, and is recognized and used as a master plan guide for the general development of the City as a whole; and 
F.  REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS; PLANNING COMMISSION. Whereas, the City Planning Commission of Mount Clemens, which is the duly designated and acting official planning body of the City, has submitted to the City Commission its report and recommendations respecting the development plan for the development area; and has certified that the development plan conforms to the General Development Plan for the locality as a whole; and the City Commission has duly considered the report, recommendations, and certification of the City Planning Commission; and 
G.  PRESCRIBED LAND USE; CHANGES. Whereas, the Development Plan for the development area prescribes certain land uses for the development area; and may require, among other things, changes in zoning, the vacating and removal of streets, alleys, and other public rights-of-way, the establishment of new street patterns, the location and relocation of sewer and water mains and other public facilities, and other public actions; and 
H.  CITIZENS' DISTRICT COUNCIL. Whereas, a Citizens' District Council, constituting not less than twelve (12) nor more than twenty-five (25) members, has been selected by the City Commission in a manner that insures maximum possible representation of the residents of the area and of other persons with a demonstrable and substantial interest in the area, with a majority of the Citizens' District Council composed of citizens living in the development area; and 
I.  CHARACTER OF LAND DESIGNATED. Whereas, the Development Plan hereby adopted designates the location and extent of streets and other public facilities within the development area; and designates the location, character, and extent of the categories of public and private land uses proposed for and within the development area; and also includes a feasible method for the relocation of families and individuals who will be displaced from the area to decent, safe, and sanitary dwelling accommodations; and 
J.  IMPROVEMENTS; COST; CONTEMPLATED. Whereas, the Development Plan designates the location, extent, character, and estimated cost of the improvements contemplated for the area; and 
K.  SURVEYS AND STATISTICS. Whereas, the Development Plan includes estimates of the number of persons residing in the development area, and the number of families and individuals to be displaced, a survey of their income and racial composition; and a statistical description of the housing supply in the community; and 
L.  PUBLIC HEARING. Whereas, the City Commission has held a public hearing on the Development Plan pursuant to Section 4, paragraph (f) of Act 344, P.A. of 1945, as amended; and 
M.  RELOCATION OF INDIVIDUALS. Whereas, the Community Development Department has prepared and submitted a program for the relocation of individuals, families, and businesses that may be displaced as a result of carrying out the Development Plan; and 
N.  COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT; STUDIES. Whereas, there have also been presented to the City Commission information and data respecting the relocation program prepared by the Community Development Department as a result of studies, surveys, and inspections in the development area; and the assembling and analysis of the data and information obtained from such studies, surveys, and inspections; and 
O.  CITY COMMISSION REVIEWS PROPOSALS. Whereas, members of the City Commission have general knowledge of the conditions prevailing in the development area, and of the availability of proper housing in the general area for the relocation of individuals and families that may be displaced from the development area; and in the light of such knowledge of local housing conditions have carefully considered and reviewed such proposals for relocation. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.054 - Sec. 4. 
DEVELOPMENT AREA. 
    It is ordained: 
A.  OBSOLESCENCE DETERMINED. That it is hereby found and determined that the development area is a deteriorating, blighted, and obsolescent area, and qualifies as a Rehabilitation Project under Act 344, P.A. of 1945, as amended. 
B.  PLAN APPROVED. That the Development Plan for the development area having been duly reviewed and considered, is hereby approved, and the City Clerk be and is hereby directed to file said copy of the Development Plan with the minutes of this meeting. 
C.  PROPOSED ACTIONS NECESSARY. That it is hereby found and determined that the objectives of the Development Plan cannot be achieved without the actions proposed by the Development Plan. 
D.  PLAN CONFORMS TO MASTER PLAN. That it is hereby found and determined that the Development Plan for the development area conforms to the General Development Plan of the City of Mount Clemens. 
E.  PROJECT TO PROMOTE PUBLIC WELFARE. That it is hereby found and determined that, in addition to the elimination of blight and deterioration from the development area, the undertaking of the Development Project in such area will further promote the public welfare and the proper development of the community by making land in such area available for disposition for uses in accordance with the Development Plan. 
F.  CONSISTENT WITH COMMUNITY NEEDS. That it is hereby found and determined that the Development Plan for the development area will afford maximum opportunity consistent with the sound needs of the community as a whole for the redevelopment of the development area by private enterprise. 
G.  RELOCATION; FEASIBILITY. That it is hereby found and determined that the program for the proper relocation of individuals and families displaced in carrying out the project to decent, safe, and sanitary dwellings, in conformance with acceptable standards, is feasible and can be reasonably and timely effected to permit the proper prosecution and completion of the project; and that such dwellings available or to be made available to such displaced individuals and families are at least equal in number to the number of displaced individuals and families, and are not generally less desirable with regard to public utilities and public and commercial facilities than the dwellings of the displaced individuals and families in the development area; and that such dwellings are or will be available at rents or prices within the financial means of the displaced individuals and families, and are reasonably accessible to their places of employment. 
H.  CHANGES NECESSARY FOR IMPLEMENTATION. That, in order to implement and facilitate the effectuation of the Development Plan hereby approved, it is found and determined that certain official actions must be taken by this body with reference, among other things, to changes in zoning, the relocation and extension of water and sewer mains, and other public facilities. 
I.  MASTER PLAN ADOPTED. That the 1970 General Development Plan, supplemented by the 1974 West Side Downtown Development Plan, are hereby adopted by the City Commission as the Master Plan for purposes of the Rehabilitation of Blighted Areas Act. 
J.  DISTRICT COUNCIL DESIGNATED. That the Citizens' District Council and the district area referred to in Section 4, paragraph (c) of said Act, have been designated subsequent to a public hearing held by the City Commission, pursuant to said Section. 
K.  DEVIATIONS FROM PLAN PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS. That no permit shall be issued for work or work done in the development area which is not in accordance with the Development Plan, provided, however, that the City Commission shall provide by ordinance that the Zoning Board of Appeals shall have the power, on appeal filed with it by the owner of real property in the area, to approve a minor deviation from the plan in any case in which said Board finds, upon the evidence presented to it, that the application of the plan results in unnecessary hardship or practical difficulties, and that a minor deviation from the Development Plan is required by considerations of justice and equity. 
L.  ADMINISTRATION; COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT. That the City Commission hereby designates the Community Development Department to be responsible for the administration of the project. 
M.  FINANCING. That, in addition to Act 344, P.A. of 1945, as amended this project is also undertaken pursuant to the Shopping Area Redevelopment Act, Act 120, P.A. of 1961; and the powers and methods of financing provided for therein shall be deemed additional powers and methods of financing to the City of Mount Clemens in carrying out the subject project. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.055 - Sec. 5. 
BOUNDARY DESCRIPTION OF DEVELOPMENT AREA. 
    Beginning at the point of intersection of the west right-of-way line of South Gratiot Avenue and the south right-of-way line of Cass Avenue, proceed south along the west right-of-way line of South Gratiot Avenue for approximately 475 feet to the southeast corner of lot 10, Assessor's Plat No. 31; then proceed west for approximately 208 feet to the southwest corner of lot 10, Assessor's Plat No. 31; then proceed northerly along the east right-of-way line of South Walnut for approximately 430 feet to the northwest corner of lot 2B, Assessor's Plat No. 31; then proceed easterly along the south right-of-way line of Cass Avenue for approximately 230 feet to the point of beginning; including the following lots of Assessor's Plat No. 31: Lots 1A, 1B, 2A, 2B, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.056 - Sec. 6. 
PROJECT ACTIVITIES PROPOSED. 
    All real property in the development area will be acquired by the City. (See "Property Acquisition" below). All of the buildings to be acquired by the City will be cleared, either by the City before disposition of the property or by redevelopers after acquiring redevelopment sites from the City and before redevelopment takes place. 
    All property to be acquired by the City will be disposed of by the City, except property which the City retains for off-street parking, streets, walkways, utilities, and other public purposes. Before disposition of land for redevelopment, the City shall reserve land along Cass and Gratiot Avenues to increase the rights-of-way thereof and for other rights-of-way depicted by the Development Plan Map. 
    Land acquired by parties for redevelopment shall be redeveloped in accordance with the land use restrictions and building requirements of the Redevelopment Plan, and shall be subject to such other conditions and requirements as are incorporated into disposition agreements entered into between the City and redevelopers. 
    Other activities will include: 
A.  Advice, consultation, and relocation grants to individuals and families in locating suitable and appropriate rehousing; 
B.  Assisting businesses in finding suitable relocation sites; 
C.  Establishment of a Citizens' District Council, which shall include representation of residents and businesses in the development area; consultation with the Citizens' District Council with particular reference to rehousing and relocation; furnishing timely information, and other activities set forth in the Rehabilitation of Blighted Areas Act. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.057 - Sec. 7. 
PROPERTY ACQUISITION. 
    All property in the development area will be acquired for the purpose of redeveloping the area, which is characterized by: obsolete and deteriorated structures; improper division and arrangement of lots; inadequate rights-of-way of adjoining streets; detrimental mixture of residential and non-residential uses in buildings; other blighting characteristics; and which includes buildings, not in themselves obsolescent, the acquisition of which is necessary for the redevelopment of the area. 
    The City shall acquire fee simple title in real property by purchase, gift, exchange, condemnation, or otherwise, and shall apply such real property thereafter to the express purposes of this plan. The purposes contemplated by this plan are hereby declared to be public purposes within the meaning of the Constitution, State laws, and the City Charter. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.058 - Sec. 8. 
HOUSING CONDITIONS IN PROJECT AREA. 
    The project area comprises that portion of Census block 101 (Census tract 2044) in which most, if not all, of the block's housing units existed in 1970. The 1970 U.S. Census of Housing and Population reported the following characteristics in block 101: 
total population 67  percent of total population  Negro  3% percent under eighteen years  of age  2% percent sixty-two years and  over 27%  
    The 1970 Census reported the following housing characteristics in this block: 
Housing units lacking some  or all plumbing facilities 26 Other housing units 28 Total housing units 54 Renter occupied units 46 Average number of rooms/ unit 1.9 Average contract rent/month $94.00 One persons households 31  
    The Census classifies rooms in hotels and similar places as housing units only when they are occupied by permanent residents. A substantial number of rooms in the project area were therefore not covered by the Housing Census. Nevertheless, the above Census data indicates that about half of the counted housing units had inadequate plumbing, a key index to housing quality. 
    Counting all accommodations, there are now about 84 housing units in the project area, of which 59 are rooming units and 25 are dwelling units. A dwelling unit is defined as a housing unit with its own kitchen and bathroom. 
    The 84 housing units are in 3 buildings: 
John R. Murphy Hotel Parcel CD-2A 55 12 - 14 S. Gratiot Parcel CD-3  4 40 - 42 S. Gratiot 25  Total 84  
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.059 - Sec. 9. 
RELOCATION. 
    The relocation caseload is estimated at 6 families (2 or more persons), 68 individuals, and 13 businesses. (This caseload excludes 6 prison parolees to be relocated by the State.) 
    Characteristics of residents are as follows: 
Persons in 
Household Number of 
Households Total 
Persons 1 62 62 2  4  8 3  1  3 4  1  4 _____   Total 68 77  
    The typical current rents range from $100 to $150 per month. Eleven households are headed by females, 3 by blacks, 1 by a Mexican-American, and 10 by persons 65 years of age and over. The typical household monthly income is between $300 and $500. The majority of the households have been residents for less than 1 year, indicating a high turnover rate. Before relocation, all resident household and businesses will be individually interviewed to ascertain relocation needs. The Community Development Department is in administrative charge of relocation, including provision of information concerning private and public housing available to displaced families and individuals, and advice and assistance in their relocation. 
    Relocation payments and assistance to households and businesses will be provided and replacement dwellings will be made available to displaced persons in accordance with "relocation payments and assistance and real property acquisition under the Uniform Relocation Assistance and Real Property Acquisition Policies Act of 1970," Title 24, Part 42 of the Code of Federal Regulations, February 20, 1975, as such regulations may be amended from time to time. Those regulations shall be maintained available for reference and inspection at the office of the Community Development Director. 
    Relocation preferences by displaced households are expected to almost entirely constitute rental housing. Housing resources for the relocation of households in the project area include 255 units of low-rent, public housing of which 147 units are for the elderly, and 108 units are for families. Additional housing resources include twenty units of existing rental housing planned to be available for Section 8 housing assistance payments. 
    There are 3,094 rental housing units in standard condition in Mount Clemens of which approximately 4% or 120 are currently vacant. This housing inventory is expected to be adequate to accommodate relocatees not otherwise accommodated in public housing. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan. 1978) 
14.060 - Sec. 10. 
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS. 
    The City shall furnish and pay for the widening and/or improvements in the roadways of Cass and Gratiot Avenues, and the new east-west street. 
    All other public improvements in the project area will be paid for by the redeveloper(s). The location, extent, character, and estimated cost of the improvements will be established as part of the redeveloper(s) Preliminary Design Plans, and are contemplated to include: 
A.  Replatting; 
B.  Construction of water and sewer service lines and taps; 
C.  Construction and reconstruction of walkways, curb cuts, and driveways in the public rights-of-way; 
D.  Street tree planting; 
E.  Street Lighting; 
F.  Installation of public utility (electric, gas, and telephone) service lines and appurtenances not otherwise borne by public utility companies. All electric and telephone service lines shall be installed underground. Public utility companies shall be required to bear the cost of relocation, installation, and removal of public utility lines and appurtenances to the extent allowed by law. 
    The City's cost of public improvements is estimated at between $100,000 and $150,000. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.061 - Sec. 11. 
USES PERMITTED. 
    The following uses are permitted: 
A.  Retail stores, including food stores, eating and drinking places, department stores, general merchandise stores, variety stores, apparel and accessory stores, furniture stores, home furnishing stores, appliance stores, drug stores, proprietary stores, liquor stores, jewelry stores, book and stationery stores, sporting goods and bicycle stores, florists, tobacco stores, news dealers, gift, novelty, and souvenir stores, music stores, cameras and photographic supply stores, paint stores, hardware stores, art galleries, and similar, generally recognized retail establishments. 
B.  Selected services, including movie theaters, barber and beauty stops, shoe repair stores, laundry and dry cleaning shops, and similar generally recognized service establishments. 
C.  Office uses, including administrative, governmental, or professional offices, clinics, real estate offices, accounting, insurance, stock brokers, engineering, design professions, and similar offices uses. 
D.  Telephone exchanges, television and radio studios, data processing centers, banks and financial institutions, health clubs, motor hotels, parking lots and parking structures, churches, libraries, and museums. 
E.  Multiple housing subject to the following requirements: No dwelling unit shall have more than two bedrooms. Each dwelling unit shall have at least four distinctly separate rooms composed of a living room, kitchen, bathroom and bedroom. A dining area may be included in the living room or kitchen. The minimum floor area of each dwelling unit, measured to the interior surface of the unit's perimeter walls, shall be not less than 450 square feet for a one (1) bedroom unit and 585 square feet for a two (2) bedroom unit. 
    No building or part thereof originally designed for nonresidential use shall thereafter be converted to or used or occupied for residential purposes (including temporary or transient purposes) without the approval of the City Commission. 
    No building or part thereof originally designed for residential use shall thereafter be converted to or used or occupied for non-residential purposes without the approval of the City Commission. 
    The following uses are prohibited: funeral homes, mortuaries, hospitals, veterinary hospitals, manufacturing, automobile service stations, outdoor storage of materials or goods, drive-in restaurants, storage and warehouse buildings, auto wash, open-lot sales or rentals of merchandise. 
    The requirements of the Zoning Ordinance for Zoning Compliance Permits and Certificates of Occupancy shall be applicable to all buildings in the project area, and notwithstanding the issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy for a building, no portion of a building shall be occupied or reoccupied by a non-residential user except upon issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy for that user and that portion of a building. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.062 - Sec. 12. 
PARKING REQUIREMENTS. 
    For each residential dwelling there shall be provided off-street parking on the premises and/or within three hundred (300) feet thereof in amount of at least one (1) off-street parking space per bedroom. 
    Off-street parking for all other uses shall be provided on the premises and/or within three hundred (300) feet thereof. Off-street parking shall be provided at the rate of fifty percent (50%) of the requirements specified in the Mount Clemens Zoning Ordinance, 15.322, Sec. 32.2. 
    In lieu of providing the required parking, the developer and the City may agree that the developer either lease public parking or pay a capital charge to the City's parking system for expansion of parking in the nearby environs of the premises thereby to be served. 
    Parking shall be prohibited on all public streets in and contiguous to the project area. Facilities and space for off-street loading and unloading of trucks and other vehicles shall be furnished on the premises. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.063 - Sec. 13. 
BUILDING REQUIREMENTS. 
    Maximum building height: one hundred and fifty (150) feet. 
    Minimum building setbacks: 
fifty (50) feet from Cass Avenue existing center line; 
fifty (50) feet from Gratiot Avenue existing center line; 
thirty (30) feet from South Walnut Street existing center line. 
    At least twenty percent (20%) of the site shall be landscaped open space. 
    All buildings shall be of fireproof construction as specified by the BOCA Building Code. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
4.064 - Sec. 14. 
SIGN REGULATIONS. 
    No sign shall be located or project into a public right-of-way except where permanently attached to or part of an approved marquee. 
    There shall be no flashing, intermittent, or red or green illumination on any sign. 
    Only signs announcing information pertaining to the premises upon which they are located shall be permitted. There shall be no general advertising or billboard signs. 
    Signs visible from the exterior of buildings shall only furnish the following information: 
A.  Name of building. 
B.  Address of building. 
C.  Name of tenants. 
D.  Parking lot traffic control information. 
E.  Identification of activities on the premises, such as title of movie or name of entertainer. 
    No free-standing sign shall be allowed which announces other than A, B, or D above, or the one principal tenant of a building. No free-standing sign other than type D. above, shall have a height greater than four (4) feet above ground grade. 
    No sign or advertising material shall be placed in a window which is visible from the outside, other than on the grade level. 
    The total surface display area of all signs on or along the facade of a building shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet plus one percent (l%) of the facade's area. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.065 - Sec. 15. 
NON-DISCRIMINATION. 
    No person shall on the ground of race, color, national origin, creed or religion, or sex be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination in: employment; use; occupancy; ownership, rental, lease or other tenure; availability of facilities and services. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary above, nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit any one from maintaining or constructing separate living facilities or rest room facilities for the different sexes. Furthermore, selectivity on the basis of sex is not prohibited when institutional or custodial services can properly be performed only by a member of the same sex as the recipients of the services. The above requirements shall be: incorporated into all contracts by the redeveloper(s) for construction in the development area and shall be applicable to subcontracts thereof; shall be incorporated into all instruments for the sale, lease, rent or other disposition of real property in the development area including improvements thereon. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.066 - Sec. 16. 
DURATION OF LIMITATIONS AND CONTROLS. 
A.  The limitations and controls of this plan shall be binding upon all purchasers of project land, their heirs, and assignees, and shall run with the project land for a period of twenty (20) years from the date of this plan's adoption by the City Commission, provided however that the City Commission may at any time amend this plan, after public hearing, as so petitioned by the owners of two-thirds (2/3) or more of the privately owned land area of the project area. 
B.  On and after the date this plan has been approved by the City Commission, no permit shall be issued for work or work done in the area which is not in accordance with this plan; provided, however, that the Zoning Board of Appeals of the City of Mount Clemens shall have the power on appeal filed with it by the owner of real property in the area to approve a minor deviation from the plan. Such appeal shall be granted in any case which such Board finds upon the evidence presented to it that the application of the plan results in an unnecessary hardship or practical difficulties, and that a minor deviation is required by considerations of justice and equity, pursuant to Section 10 of Act 344, P.A. of 1945 as amended. 
C.  The provisions and requirements of this plan do not waive or supercede any Ordinance of the City of Mount Clemens, such as, but not limited to, Building Code, Housing Code, and Zoning Ordinance; except that where a provision or requirement of this plan is more restrictive than that of another City Ordinance, the plan's restriction shall control. 
D.  If, previous to the lease, sale, or exchange of any real property in the development area, the City Commission desires to modify the Development Plan, it shall hold a public hearing thereon pursuant to Section 9 of Act 344, P.A. of 1945 as amended. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.067 - Sec. 17. 
LAND DISPOSITION. 
    All land acquired by the City, except that land necessary for streets, utilities, or other public purposes, shall be disposed of by sale, or lease for redevelopment. Land disposition shall be awarded by the City Commission after a public hearing on the basis of overall benefits that will accrue to the City, taking into account: 
A.  Land disposition proceeds. 
B.  Qualifications of the redeveloper(s) to successfully and expeditiously carry out its (their) agreement with the City. 
C.  Property tax revenues, employment, housing, economic development, and environmental impact. 
D.  The quality of design, construction, and operation. 
    Redevelopers shall be required to furnish preliminary design plans before their selection. This preliminary proposal shall be sufficiently complete to convey a realistic picture of the intent, concept, and objectives of the redevelopment in terms of architectural design, site layout, traffic access and circulation, pedestrian circulation, open space, land and building uses, time table for redevelopment, and conformance with the requirements of this Development Plan, local codes and ordinances. 
    The disposition agreement will incorporate the redeveloper's preliminary design plans as approved by the City. The redeveloper will be offered the choice, before execution of the disposition agreement, either to adhere to the preliminary design plan or to furnish to the City for its review and approval an advanced version of the preliminary design plan for incorporation into the disposition contract. 
    After the disposition agreement is executed, but before title is conveyed and building permits are issued for construction, final contract drawings of proposed construction will be reviewed by the City to determine conformance with the previously approved preliminary design plan. Overall general conformance of the final contract drawings with the approved preliminary design plan shall be considered a condition for approval of building permits and for conformance with the disposition agreement; failure to so conform shall be considered a default of the agreement. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.068 - Sec. 18. 
DEVELOPMENT PLAN MAP. 
    The accompanying Development Plan Map, which is part of this Development Plan, generally designates the following: 
A.  The location and extent of streets within the development area. 
B.  The location and extent of land proposed for redevelopment in accordance with this Plan. 
C.  The Development Plan Map also constitutes the plan of the general features of development of the district within which the development area lies and of other districts adjacent to the development area. The general features of development of other districts adjacent to the development area are also set forth in the 1970 General Development Plan and the 1974 West Side Downtown Development Plan. 
    The designation by the Development Plan Map of the location and extent of streets, rights-of-way, parking, and other public facilities both within and outside of the development area, are generalized. After final engineering, these may be modified in location and extent, subject to approval of the City Commission, without constituting a change of this Development Plan. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan. 1978) 
14.069 - Sec. 19. 
EXECUTION OF DEVELOPMENT PLAN. 
    The City of Mount Clemens, a Municipal Corporation, is the governmental entity responsible for carrying out the Development Plan. The City Commission is the governmental body representing the City. The Community Development Department is in administrative charge of carrying out the Plan, under the direction of the City Commission. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.070 - Sec. 20. 
SEPARABILITY. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this Ordinance is for any reason held invalid by any Court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.071 - Sec. 21. 
REPEAL CLAUSE. 
    All existing Ordinances of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Mount Clemens shall remain in full force and effect except as herein amended. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
14.072 - Sec. 22. 
EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    The within Ordinance shall become effective ten (10) days after its adoption. 
(Code effective October, 1958; amended January, 1978) 
14.200 - MACOMB PLACE MALL CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. March 27, 1980 
An ordinance to implement the provisions of Act 120 of the Public Acts of 1961, establishing the Macomb Place Mall and providing for the regulation and use of the mall area. 
THE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS ORDAINS: 

14.201 - Sec. 1. 
TITLE. 
    This ordinance shall be known as the Macomb Place Mall Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. March 27, 1980) 
14.202 - Sec. 2. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    As used in this chapter, the term "mall" shall mean the Macomb Place Mall, as established in Section 4. 
(ord. eff. March 27, 1980) 
14.203 - Sec. 3. 
FINDINGS OF FACT. 
    The City of Mount Clemens has since 1960, been carrying out the redevelopment and revitalization of its Central Business District in accordance with the general features of the 1958 General Development Plan, the 1970 General Development Plan and the 1974 West Side Downtown Plan all prepared and adopted by the City Planning Commission pursuant to Act 285, P.A. 1931. The 1979 Mount Clemens Urban Design Phase I has been approved by the City Planning Commission as a particular project to carry out general goals and objectives of the aforementioned plans. Said Mount Clemens Urban Design Phase I, supported by detailed plans and specifications, proposes the construction of a pedestrian mall on Macomb Street and surrounding areas. Taking into account all of these reports and its own observations, the City Commission finds that: 
1)  The Macomb Street area between South Walnut Street and Pine Street; Cherry Street from New Street south through Macomb Street; and the alley lying between Walnut Street and Cherry Street from Macomb Street to New Street is a principal commercial area in the Central Business District and has significant problems of deterioration and obsolescence; 
2)  That such deterioration, if permitted to continue, will adversely affect the tax structure, health, law abiding conduct, morals and general welfare of this community and its citizens; and that it is a reasonable and proper exercise of its police powers of this city to take measures designed to correct this trend, by maintaining and improving such Central Business District so that it may retain its position as a mercantile and service center for Macomb County, and as the core of business, professional, social, religious and cultural life for this community; 
3)  The construction of the Macomb Place Mall will significantly improve the physical environment and provide strong incentives for the rehabilitation and redevelopment of private properties, in accordance with the city's powers under Act 120, P.A. 1961, and under Chapter 2 of the City Charter. 
(ord. eff. March 27, 1980; amend. eff. May 15, 1986) 
14.204 - Sec. 4. 
ESTABLISHMENT OF MALL. 
    The following streets and alley in the City of Mount Clemens are hereby declared and established as the Macomb Place Mall: 
Macomb Street between South Walnut and Pine Streets. 
Cherry Street from Macomb Street north to New Street. 
Cherry Street from Macomb Street south to a point 90 feet from Macomb Street. 
Alley Lying east of Cherry Street and west of Walnut Street from Macomb Street north to New Street. 
For purposes of street addresses, Macomb Street shall be identified as Macomb Place and Cherry Street shall continue to be identified as Cherry Street. 
(ord. eff. March 27, 1980; amend. eff. May 15, 1986) 
14.205 - Sec. 5. 
CONTROLLING EFFECT OF CHAPTER. 
    To the extent, but only to the extent, that this chapter, as to the mall area, may be inconsistent with other ordinances of this city, including the Traffic and Building Codes, among others, this chapter shall be deemed to control. 
(ord. eff. March 27, 1980) 
14.206 - Sec. 6. 
COMPLIANCE. 
    All persons shall comply with the provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations established by the City Commission regarding the use of the mall area, including appurtenances and facilities. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 27, 1980) 
14.207 - Sec. 7. 
MAINTENANCE OF IMPROVEMENTS. 
    The Department of Public Works is hereby authorized and directed to maintain the mall and its appurtenances and facilities. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 27, 1980) 
14.208 - Sec. 8. 
APPROVALS REQUIRED. 
(a)  Any of the following are prohibited without official approval by the City Commission: 
(1)  Any sign, building appurtenance, merchandise, display, decoration, furniture, fixtures, or pole placed in the mall right-of-way, except as provided in (b) below. 
(2)  Any sign projecting into the right-of-way more than 12?. 
(3)  Any marquee, awning, or other building appurtenance or decoration projecting into the mall right-of-way. 
(4)  Any loudspeaker or other amplification of sound in or into the mall right-of-way. 
(b)  The city may install kiosks or other places specifically designated for the posting of paper temporary signs, which shall be subject to regulations approved by the City Commission. 
(c)  Any of the following are prohibited without official written permission by the City Manager: 
(1)  Any vending of goods or services or solicitations of funds. 
(2)  Any parade, rally, demonstration, meeting, concert, or similar prearranged gathering. In making his determination, the City Manager shall be guided by considerations of: 
Public Safety; 
Interference with legitimate use of land and buildings in the mall and environs; 
Traffic and parking; 
Damage to mall appointments and landscaping; 
Freedom of speech and assembly. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 27, 1980) 
14.209 - Sec. 9. 
VEHICLE RESTRICTIONS. 
(a)  Commercial vehicles are prohibited in the mall. 
(b)  The use and/or operation of scooters, roller skates, rollerblades or skate boards in the mall is prohibited. 
(c)  The Traffic engineer is hereby authorized and directed to install such signs and other devices in the mall as may be necessary, and to promulgate rules and regulations regarding the use thereof by all self-propelled vehicles. Such regulations may be more restrictive but not less restrictive than the regulations of this chapter. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 27, 1980; ord. eff. Aug. 13, 1992; ord. eff. Feb. 26, 2016) 
14.210 - Sec. 10. 
SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL. 
    The occupant of any premises, or the owner of any unoccupied premises in the mall is required to keep the mall area adjoining the premises cleared, so far as is practicable and reasonable, from snow and ice to facilitate pedestrian use. The area to be cleared shall be 5 feet from the property. The snow or ice shall be deposited in windrows between 5 and 9 feet from and parallel to the property line, and shall not obstruct storm catch basins or fire hydrants; the windrows shall be not greater than 2 feet in height. Whenever any snow or ice has fallen or accumulated, it shall be cleared within 12 hours after it has fallen or accumulated. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 27, 1980) 
14.211 - Sec. 11. 
SEVERABILITY. 
    If any section, sub-section, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this ordinance is, for any reason, held invalid or unconstitutional by any Court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of the within ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 27, 1980) 
14.212 - Sec. 12. 
RESERVED. 
Editor's note- Former section 14.212, regarding effective date and notice, was repealed by an ordinance effective August 13, 1992. This section has been reserved for future use at the discretion of the editor. 
14.300 - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983; amend. Aug. 18, 1990; amend. Nov. 12, 1992; amend. eff. July 31, 2014 
An ordinance to establish a Downtown Development Authority in the City of Mount Clemens pursuant to Act 197, Public Acts of Michigan, 1975; to provide for establishment of a Board of Directors for the Authority; to define the boundaries of the Downtown District constituting the Downtown Development Authority; and to provide for all other matters necessary and related thereto. 
THE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS ORDAINS: 

14.301 - Sec. 1. 
TITLE OF ORDINANCE. 
    This ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "Downtown Development Authority Ordinance." 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983) 
14.302 - Sec. 2. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    The terms used in this ordinance shall have the same meaning as given to them in Act 197 or as hereinafter in this section provided unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary. As used in this ordinance: 
    "Authority" means the Downtown Development Authority of the City of Mount Clemens created by this ordinance. 
    "Act 197" means Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1975, as now in effect or hereafter amended. 
    "Board" or "Board of Directors" means the Board of Directors of the Authority, the governing body of the Authority. 
    "Chief Executive Officer" means the Mayor of the City. 
    "City" means the City of Mount Clemens, Michigan. 
    "Commission" or "City Commission" means the City Commission of the City. 
    "Downtown District" means the downtown district designated by this ordinance as now existing or hereafter amended. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983) 
14.303 - Sec. 3. 
DETERMINATION OF NECESSITY. 
    The City Commission of the City hereby determines that it is necessary for the best interests of the City to halt property value deterioration and increase property tax valuation where possible in the business district of the City, to eliminate the causes of that deterioration and to promote economic growth by establishing a downtown development authority pursuant to Act 197. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983) 
14.304 - Sec. 4. 
CREATION OF AUTHORITY. 
    There is hereby created pursuant to Act 197 a Downtown Development Authority for the City. The Authority shall be a public body corporate and shall be known and exercise its powers under the title of "Downtown Development Authority of the City of Mount Clemens." The Authority may adopt a seal, may sue and be sued in any court of this State and shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purpose of its incorporation as provided by this ordinance and Act 197. The enumeration of a power in this ordinance or in Act 197 shall not be construed as a limitation upon the general powers of the Authority. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983) 
14.305 - Sec. 5. 
DESCRIPTION OF DOWNTOWN DISTRICT. 
    The Downtown District in which the Authority shall exercise its powers as provided by Act 197 shall consist of the described territory in the City, subject to such changes as may hereinafter be made pursuant to this ordinance and Act 197, as set forth in Exhibit A, attached hereto and made a part hereof. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983; amend. eff. July 31, 2014) 
14.306 - Sec. 6. 
BOARD OF DIRECTORS. 
    The Authority shall be under supervision and control of a Board of Directors consisting of the Chief Executive Officer of the City and ten (10) members as provided by Act 197. The members shall be appointed by the Chief Executive Officer subject to approval by the Commission and shall hold office for the terms provided in Act 197. All members shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed. 
    The Authority may employ and fix the compensation of a director, subject to the approval of the City Commission, and a treasurer and secretary. The director shall furnish bond in the amount of $100.00, and the treasurer shall furnish bond in such amounts as prescribed by the Board. The bonds shall be in such form as may be approved by the Board, including coverage in the form of a blanket policy carried by the Authority or the City. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983; amend. July 28, 1983) 
14.307 - Sec. 7. 
POWERS OF THE AUTHORITY. 
    Except as specifically otherwise provided in this ordinance, the Authority shall have all powers provided by law subject to the limitations imposed by law and herein. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983) 
14.308 - Sec. 8. 
FISCAL YEAR; ADOPTION OF BUDGET. 
(a)  The fiscal year of the Authority shall begin on July 1 of each year and end on June 30 of each year, or such other fiscal year as may hereafter be adopted by the City. 
(b)  The Board shall annually prepare a budget and shall submit it to the Commission on the same date that the proposed budget for the City is required by the City Charter to be submitted to the Commission. The Board shall not finally adopt a budget for any fiscal year until the budget has been approved by the Commission. The Board may, however, temporarily adopt a budget in connection with the operation of any improvements which have been financed by revenue bonds where required to do so by the ordinance authorizing the revenue bonds. 
(c)  The Authority shall submit financial reports to the Commission at the same time and on the same basis as departments of the City are required to submit reports. The Authority shall be audited annually by the same independent auditors auditing the City, and copies of the audit report shall be filed with the Commission. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983) 
14.309 - Sec. 9. 
SECTION HEADINGS; SEVERABILITY; REPEALER. 
    Section headings are provided for convenience only and are not intended to be part of this ordinance. If any portion of this ordinance shall be held to be unlawful, the remaining portions shall remain in full force and effect. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983) 
14.310 - Sec. 10. 
PUBLICATION, RECORDING AND FILING. 
    This ordinance shall be published once after its adoption in full in the Macomb Daily, a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Mount Clemens; and the City Clerk shall file a certified copy of the ordinance with the Michigan Secretary of State promptly after its adoption. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 9, 1983) 
14.400 - TAX INCREMENT FINANCING PLAN CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985 
An ordinance to adopt and approve a development plan and a tax increment financing plan for Downtown Development Area pursuant to the provisions of Act 197, Public Acts of Michigan of 1975, and to provide for all matters related thereto 
THE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS ORDAINS: 

14.401 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    The terms used in this ordinance shall have the following meaning unless the context clearly required otherwise: 
    "Base Year Assessment Roll" means the base year assessment roll prepared by the City Assessor in accordance with Section 4 of this ordinance. 
    "Captured Assessed Value" means the amount in any one year by which the current assessed value as finally equalized of all taxable property in the Development Area exceeds the initial Assessed Value. 
    "Development Area" shall mean the area legally described in the Development Plan. 
    "Development Plan" means the "Tax Increment and Development Plan Mount Clemens Downtown Development Area" dated December, 1985, as amended and transmitted to the City Commission by the Downtown Development Authority for public hearing, as modified by action of the City Commission and confirmed by this ordinance, copies of which are on file in the office of the City Clerk. 
    "Downtown Development Authority" means the City of Mount Clemens Downtown Development Authority. 
    "Initial Assessed Value" means the most recent assessed value as finally equalized of all the taxable property within the boundaries of the Development Area at the time of adoption of this ordinance.
