    "Project Fund" means the Downtown Development Authority Project Fund Established pursuant to Section 6 of this ordinance. 
    "Taxing Jurisdiction" shall mean each unit of government levying an ad valorem property tax on property in the Development Area. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.402 - Sec. 2. 
APPROVAL AND ADOPTION OF DEVELOPMENT PLAN. 
    The Development Plan as amended by the City Commission is hereby approved and adopted. The duration of the plan shall be 20 years from the date of issuance of the last series of bonds issued pursuant to the Development Plan, except as it may be extended by subsequent amendment of the plan and this ordinance. A copy of the plan and all amendments thereto shall be maintained on file in the City Clerk's office and cross-indexed to this ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.403 - Sec. 3. 
BOUNDARIES OF DEVELOPMENT AREA. 
    The boundaries of the Development Area as set forth in the Development Plan are hereby adopted and confirmed. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.404 - Sec. 4. 
PREPARATION OF BASE YEAR ASSESSMENT ROLL. 
(a)  Within 60 days of the effective date of this ordinance, the City Assessor shall prepare the initial Base Year Assessment Roll. The initial Base Year Assessment Roll shall list each Taxing Jurisdiction in which the Development Area is located, the initial Assessed Value of the Development Area on the effective date of this ordinance and the amount of tax revenue derived by each Taxing Jurisdiction from ad valorem taxes on the property in the Development Area. 
(b)  The Assessor shall transmit copies of the initial Base Year Assessment Roll to the City Treasurer, County Treasurer, Downtown Development Authority and each Taxing Jurisdiction, together with a notice that the assessment roll has been prepared in accordance with this ordinance and the tax increment financing plan in the Development Plan approved by this ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.405 - Sec. 5. 
PREPARATION OF ANNUAL BASE YEAR ASSESSMENT ROLL. 
    Each year within 15 days following the final equalization of property in the Development Area, the Assessor shall prepare an updated Base Year Assessment Roll. The updated Base year Assessment Roll shall show the information required in the initial Base Year Assessment Roll and, and addition, the Captured Assessed Value for that year. Copies of the annual Base Year Assessment Roll shall be transmitted by the Assessor to the same persons as the initial Base Year Assessment Roll together with a notice that it has been prepared in accordance with this ordinance and the Development Plan. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.406 - Sec. 6. 
ESTABLISHMENT OF PROJECT FUND; APPROVAL OF DEPOSITARY. 
    The Treasurer of the Downtown Development Authority shall establish a separate fund which shall be kept in a depositary bank account or accounts in a bank or banks approved by the Director of Finance of the City, to be designated the Downtown Development Authority Project. All moneys received by the Downtown Development Authority pursuant to the Development Plan shall be deposited in the Project Fund. All moneys in that fund and earnings thereon shall be used only in accordance with the Development Plan and this ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.407 - Sec. 7. 
PAYMENT OF TAX INCREMENTS TO DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY. 
    The City and County Treasurer shall, as ad valorem taxes are collected on the property in the Development Area, pay that proportion of the taxes, except for penalties and collection fees, that the Captured Assessed Value bears to the initial Assessed Value to the Treasurer of the Downtown Development Authority for deposit in the Project Fund. The payments shall be made on the date or dates on which the City and County Treasurers are required to remit taxes to each of the taxing jurisdictions. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.408 - Sec. 8. 
USE OF MONEYS IN THE PROJECT FUND. 
    The money credited to the Project Fund and on hand therein from time to time shall annually be used in the following manner and following order of priority: 
First, to pay into the debt retirement fund, or funds, for all outstanding debts established pursuant to this Plan an amount equal to the interest and principal coming due prior to the next collection of taxes. 
Second, to reimburse the City for funds advanced to make preliminary plans and improvements necessary in the Development Area in accordance with this Plan. 
Third, to pay the administrative and operating costs of the Downtown Development Authority and City for the Development Area, including planning and promotion, to the extent provided in the annual budget of the Tax Increment Finance Authority. 
Fourth, to establish a reserve account for payment of one year's principal and interest on debts encountered pursuant to this Plan. 
Fifth, to pay, to the extent determined desirable by the Downtown Development Authority and approved by the City, the cost of improvements as set forth in the Development Plan to the extent those costs are not financed from the proceeds of bonds. 
Sixth, to establish a sinking fund or a set-aside account to be used to retire the debt incurred pursuant to this Plan at the earliest possible date. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.409 - Sec. 9. 
ANNUAL REPORT. 
    Within 90 days after the end of each fiscal year, the Downtown Development Authority shall submit to the City Commission, with copies to each Taxing Jurisdiction, a report on the status of the Project Fund. The report shall include the amount and source of revenue in the account, the amount and purpose of expenditures from the account, the initial Assessed Value of the Development Area, the Captured Assessed Value of the Development Area, the tax increments received and the amount of any surplus from the prior year, and any additional information requested by the City Commission or deemed appropriate by the Downtown Development Authority. The Secretary of the Downtown Development Authority shall cause a copy of the report to be published once in full in a newspaper of general circulation in the City. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
14.410 - Sec. 10. 
REFUND OF SURPLUS TAX INCREMENTS. 
    Any surplus money in the Project Fund at the end of the year, as shown by the annual report of the Downtown Development Authority, shall be paid by the Authority of the City or County Treasurer, as the case may be, and rebated by them to the appropriate Taxing Jurisdiction. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 28, 1985) 
Introduction and First Reading: December 16, 1985 
Second Reading and Adoption: December 18, 1985 
Effective Date: December 28, 1985 
    The "Tax Increment and Development Plan Mount Clemens Downtown Development Area" was amended by action of the Mount Clemens City Commission on August 6, 1990. To be effective: August 18, 1990. 
    The "Tax Increment and Development Plan Mount Clemens Downtown Development Area" was further amended by action of the Mount Clemens City Commission on November 2, 1992. To be effective: November 12, 1992." 
    The "Tax Increment and Development Plan Mount Clemens Downtown Development Area" was amended by action of the Mount Clemens City Commission on June 21, 1999. To be effective: June 30, 1999. 
16.100 - INSPECTION UPON SALE OR TRANSFER OF ANY DWELLING CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Nov. 1, 1990 repealed eff. Dec. 26, 2002 
16.200 - REGISTRATION AND INSPECTION OF RENTAL DWELLINGS AND RENTAL UNITS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Oct. 1, 1990; ord. eff. Oct. 1, 1990; amend. eff. Apr. 25, 1991; ord. eff. Jan. 15, 2009; ord. eff. Apr. 25, 1991 

16.201 - Sec. 1. 
STATEMENT OF PURPOSE. 
A.  The City of Mount Clemens recognizes the importance to the general health, safety and welfare of all of its citizens, including its citizens who occupy residential rental structures and units. Therefore, the City has a compelling interest to maintain safe and sanitary conditions in all rental dwellings and rental units throughout the city. This ordinance is designed to promote the continued maintenance of quality and safe residential rental structures and units which enhances living conditions and property values for of all properties and reduces the causes of blight and other deleterious factors affecting neighborhoods. 
B.  It is the City's policy that all residential rental structures must be registered with the City and a valid and current rental certificate of compliance shall be in effect at all times a residential rental structure is being occupied by a tenant. It is further the policy of the City that rental certification only be available for those residential rental structures which meet and maintain the minimum standards set by the City. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.202 - Sec. 2. 
DEFINITIONS. 
A.  As used in this ordinance, the following terms shall have the following meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
1.  Building Official: The chief inspector of the City or authorized representative. 
2.  Certificate of Compliance: A Certificate issued by the Department of Community Development which certifies compliance with the provisions of the Codes and Ordinances of the City of Mount Clemens. 
3.  Lease: Any written or oral agreement that sets forth any and all conditions concerning the use and occupancy of rental dwellings or rental units. 
4.  Manager: Any person, partnership, firm or entity that actively operates or manages a residential rental property for the owner. 
5.  Notice of Violation: A notice issued to the owner or Responsible Local Agent stating that there has been a violation of a provision of this Ordinance or any other applicable code, ordinance, rule or regulation concerning said premises. 
6.  Occupants: Includes all tenants, lessees and persons residing within a rental dwelling or rental unit. 
7.  Owner: Any person, agent, firm, trust or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in a residential rental structure or unit. 
8.  Premises: Any lot or parcel of land containing a residential rental structure or a residential rental unit. 
9.  Residential Rental Structure: Any building that contains one or more residential rental units. 
10.  Rent: Any arrangement whereby one person pays a consideration to another, for the privilege of residing in a residential rental unit for any period of time, including let, lease and barter. 
11.  Rental Unit: Any apartment, room, rooming house, boarding house, dwelling house or portion thereof or any condominium unit for which a person or group of persons pays rent directly or indirectly to the owner thereof for the purpose of residing therein. This definition includes, but is not limited to, one and two family dwellings, apartment units, boarding houses, rooming houses, assisted living facilities, hotels, motels and flats (except owner-occupied single-family residential structures). A dwelling house sold on a "land contract" is considered a residential rental unit requiring registration and a rental Certificate of Compliance if the land contract is not recorded, a Property Transfer Affidavit has not been filed with the City Assessor, and a copy not provided to the Community Development Department as required under subsection 16.203 Sec. 3. 
12.  Responsible Local Agent: The Responsible Local Agent shall be a person or representative of a corporation, partnership, firm, joint venture, trust association, organization or other entity, having his or her place of residence in the County of Macomb or within a fifty (50) mile radius of the City of Mount Clemens, and shall be designated by the owner as responsible for operating such premises in compliance with all the provisions of the City of Mount Clemens Codes and Ordinances. The owner may act as the Responsible Local Agent provided he/she resides in the County of Macomb or within a fifty (50) mile radius of the City of Mount Clemens. All official notices of the City may be issued to the Responsible Local Agent, and any notice so issued shall be deemed to have been issued upon the owner of record. 
13.  Rooming House: Any dwelling occupied in such a manner that certain rooms, in excess of those used by the members of the immediate family and occupied as a home or family unit, are leased or rented to persons outside of the family, without any attempt to provide therein or therewith, cooking or kitchen accommodations for individuals leasing or renting rooms. In the case of single- and two-family dwellings, the number of such rooms leased or rented shall not exceed one unless such dwellings be made to comply in all respects with the provisions of this act relating to multiple dwellings. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.203 - Sec. 3. 
REGISTRATION REQUIRED. 
A.  Initial Registration . The owner of any residential rental structure or residential rental unit shall register each residential rental structure and all residential rental units contained within the residential rental structure with the City and shall designate a person, as defined in Section 16.202, as the Responsible Local Agent who shall be legally responsible for operating the registered residential rental structure dwelling or residential rental unit and shall also be responsible for providing access to such premises for making the inspections necessary to insure compliance with the terms of this Ordinance and all applicable Codes and Ordinances adopted by the City of Mount Clemens. A Certificate of Compliance shall not be issued if the registration provisions of this Ordinance are not complied with. 
B.  Land Contract . The seller of a dwelling house sold on a land contract, within 45 days of its execution, shall (1) complete and file a Property Transfer Affidavit with the City Assessing Department, and (2) provide a copy of the land contract or memorandum of land contract to the Community Development Department. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.204 - Sec. 4. 
REGISTRATION FORMS AND FEE. 
A.  Applications for registration shall be made in such form and in accordance with such instructions as may be provided by the Community Development Department and shall include at least the following information: 
1.  The name, address, driver's license number and telephone number of the applicant. 
2.  The names, addresses, driver's license numbers, telephone numbers and dates of birth of all owners of the residential rental dwelling structure. 
3.  The name, local address, driver's license number and telephone number and date of birth of the Responsible Local Agent. 
4.  The number of residential rental structures at each site, address of, and number of residential rental units in each residential rental structure, and the number of occupants in each residential rental unit. If the property is a single-family dwelling, the owner must also provide the legal name and telephone number of the tenant as shown on the lease agreement. 
5.  An authorization appointing a Responsible Local Agent signed by both the owner and the Responsible Local Agent. 
B.  An annual registration fee for each residential rental unit shall be paid at the time of registration. The City Commission shall, by resolution, set the registration fee, which shall include the initial inspection fee applicable to a Certificate of Compliance. The City Commission may, by resolution, set additional inspection fees for reinspections beyond the initial inspection or for a residential rental unit or residential rental structure not being made accessible at the time of a scheduled inspection. No post office boxes will be accepted as a legal address. A post office box, however, may be accepted as a mailing address for legal correspondence upon written request of the property owner and maintaining the legal street address on file with the city's Community Development Department. Upon registration the Community Development Department shall inform applicants of Certificate of Compliance requirements. The owner shall be responsible for notifying the City of any changes of addresses of either the owner or the Responsible Local Agent. 
C.  All fee(s) due hereunder shall constitute a debt due and owing to the City and are hereby made a lien on the premises. Whenever any such fee(s) shall be delinquent for six months, the City official in charge of collection thereof shall certify such delinquency to the City assessor and such fee(s) shall be entered upon the next tax roll as a charge against such premises, and shall be collected and the lien thereof enforced in the same manner as special assessments against such premises. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.205 - Sec. 5. 
REGISTRATION TERM AND RENEWAL. 
    Registration shall be made prior to the use or occupancy of any residential rental structure or residential rental unit. The term of the registration shall be valid as long as the owner remains unchanged or for one year, whichever occurs first. Any new owner shall register in accordance with Section 16.203 and apply to have the Certificate of Compliance for each residential rental structure and residential rental unit transferred into the new owner's name within ten (10) days of the date of transfer of ownership. A fee for each residential rental structure (which shall be established by resolution of the City Commission) shall be paid at the time of registering the transfer of ownership, which fee shall also include the transfer of the Certificate of Compliance, if any. A late fee shall also be established by resolution of the City Commission which shall be imposed for late annual registrations on a per unit basis. The late fee shall be in addition to the annual and/or ownership transfer registration fees applicable to each unit. Annual registrations shall be filed on or before November 30 of each year. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.206 - Sec. 6. 
TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any residential rental structure or residential rental unit who has received a notice of violation of any code or ordinance of the City (including notices that the number of residential rental units exceeds that permitted by the zoning ordinance) to transfer, convey, lease or sell (including by land contract) his/her/its ownership and/or interest in any way to another, unless such owner shall have first furnished to the grantee, lessee, vendee, or transferee a true copy of any notice of violation and shall have furnished to the Community Development Department a signed and notarized statement from the grantee, vendee, lessee, or transferee acknowledging the receipt of such notice of violation and acknowledging legal responsibility for the correction of the violation. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.207 - Sec. 7. 
CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE REQUIRED. 
A.  No person shall lease, rent or cause to be occupied a residential rental structure or residential rental unit unless there is a valid Certificate of Compliance issued by the Department of Community Development in the name of the Owner/Responsible Local Agent and issued for the specific residential rental structure and each residential rental unit. The certificate shall be produced upon request by the City. The certificate shall be issued after an inspection by the Department of Community Development which may include inspections by the building inspector, mechanical inspector, housing inspector, electrical inspector, plumbing inspector, code enforcement officer and fire department inspector (in instances where fire inspectors have jurisdiction) to determine that each residential rental structure and residential rental unit complies with the provisions of the Codes and Ordinances of the City of Mount Clemens. 
B.  Such inspections shall be commenced after the effective date of this ordinance and shall continue until all residential rental structures and all residential rental units in the City have been inspected. The inspection process will then be continued for all such residential rental structures and residential rental units on a periodic basis, as defined by this ordinance. 
C.  Once issued, a Certificate of Compliance will be valid for a maximum of two (2) years (provided that the residential rental structure and residential rental units remain in compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances), but will terminate on the date of the next subsequent inspection. The owner will be given thirty (30) days from the date of each such inspection to make necessary repairs and obtain a Certificate of Compliance for the residential rental structure or residential rental unit. 
D.  Revocation . The Director of Community Development may revoke a Certificate of Compliance for a violation of any code, ordinance, rule or regulation of the City of Mount Clemens. The Director of Community Development may also revoke a Certificate of Compliance for any residential rental structure dwelling or residential rental unit which has been the subject of three or more emergency response incidents, as the same is defined in the Public Safety or Fire Emergency Incident Cost Recovery Ordinance, within the preceding 365 days. A certificate revoked under this subparagraph shall be revoked for a minimum period of at least 90 days. 
E.  Between 60 and 30 days before the expiration date on the certification issued for a rental property, every owner shall apply to the Community Development Department for the scheduling of an inspection for the issuance of a new certification for that residential rental structure. If an owner fails to apply within this timeframe, the owner or Responsible Local Agent shall be sent a reminder notice regarding the need to schedule an inspection for the renewal of certification. 
F.  Issuance of a certification pursuant to this article shall not constitute a guarantee or warranty of the habitability or complete compliance of the building or structure to code requirements, and the occupant of any residential rental structure or residential rental unit shall not rely on any certificate as such a guaranty or warranty. The certification shall contain a notice to this effect. 
    The city shall not assume any liability to any person by reason of the inspections required by this article or issuance of a certification. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.208 - Sec. 8. 
INSPECTIONS. 
A.  Guidelines . The Department of Community Development shall prepare a list of inspection guidelines to be used in inspections relating to the enforcement of this ordinance. The inspection guidelines shall be based on the International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted by the City. The inspection guidelines shall not be construed to relieve the owner from compliance with any other requirements of codes adopted by the City, including but not limited to, housing, electrical, plumbing, mechanical, blight, property maintenance, fire codes and zoning requirements as necessary due to renovations requiring permits. 
B.  Fees . The fees for the periodic inspection of each residential rental unit shall be adopted by resolution of the City Commission and amended, as necessary, by resolution of the City Commission. 
C.  Intervals . The Community Development Department shall inspect the interior and exterior of residential rental units for the purpose of conduction of an initial inspection in the case of new rental certification, or on a periodic basis for the purpose of a renewal. The Community Development Department may also conduct an inspection under any of the following circumstances: 
1.  Upon receipt of a complaint from the occupant of a residential rental unit that the premises are in violation of this ordinance. 
2.  Upon receipt of a report or referral from the Sheriff's Office, Fire Department or other public agencies or departments that the premises are in violation of this ordinance. 
3.  If an exterior survey of the premises gives the enforcing officer probable cause to believe that the premises are in violation of this ordinance. 
4.  Upon receipt of information by the enforcing officer that a residential rental unit is not registered with the City or certified by the City as required by this ordinance. 
5.  Upon receipt of information by the enforcing officer that a residential rental unit lacks utilities, such as water, heat or electricity. 
D.  Violations . During the inspection, the enforcing officer shall note any violations of this ordinance or other sections of this Code and give notice of the violations to the owner and/or Responsible Local Agent. Such notice shall: 
1.  Be in writing. 
2.  Include a statement of the conditions that constitute violations. 
3.  State the date of the inspection, the address of the dwelling, and the date set for reinspection. 
4.  Specify a time limit for the performance of any act it requires. A reasonable time for correcting violations shall be determined by the enforcing officer in light of the nature of the violations and all relevant circumstances, but shall not exceed 30 days. Upon request of the person responsible for correcting violations, the enforcing officer may extend the time for correcting violations if the enforcing officer deems such action appropriate under all relevant circumstances, but not to exceed an additional 30 days. 
5.  Be served upon the owner or the occupant, as the case may require, and on the Responsible Local Agent and that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served if a copy thereof is (i) served personally, or (ii) sent by first class mail to the last known address. Notice given to the responsible local agent is deemed as notice given to the owner. Notice given to the owner is sent to the owner of record with the Assessing Department. 
E.  Harassment. Under this article, any tenant or other person who shall maliciously or vexatiously cause an inspection to be made for the purpose of harassing any individual, corporation or governmental agency when no violation is present or is de minimis shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than Five Hundred ($500.00) dollars or imprisonment for not more than nine (90) days, or both, pursuant to 11.005 Sec. 5. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.209 - Sec. 9. 
APPLICABILITY TO EXISTING RENTAL DWELLINGS AND RENTAL UNITS. 
A.  This ordinance applies to all residential rental structures and residential rental units within the City existing on the effective date of the ordinance. 
B.  Any residential rental structure which is a new construction or renovation which required a comprehensive inspection and which is issued a certificate of occupancy pursuant to an inspection after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived will also be issued a rental certificate of compliance simultaneous with the certificate of occupancy. Such units are still required to pay the initial registration fee. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.210 - Sec. 10. 
VIOLATIONS; PENALTY. 
    Any owner of a residential rental structure or residential rental unit who shall fail to register his/her residential rental structure and residential rental units or who shall fail to obtain a Certificate of Compliance for each of his/her residential rental structures and residential rental units shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any owner who fails to comply with any of the other requirements of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
    Upon conviction under this section, the owner shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. Each violation for each rental dwelling and rental unit shall constitute a separate offense. A penalty created by this ordinance shall not limit or derogate any other statutory or common law right or action. 
(amend. eff. May 16, 2019) 
16.900 - LAND DIVISION ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Dec. 15, 1988 

16.901 - Sec. 1. 
LAND DIVISION. 
    A parcel of land or platted lot may be divided into two (2) or more parcels or lots provided that the resulting parcels conform with the provisions of the Mount Clemens Code of Ordinances and the provisions of Act 288 of the Public Acts of the State of Michigan 1967, as amended, only after approval by the offices of the City Assessor, the City Treasurer, and the Community Development Director. It shall be unlawful to develop any parcel or lot not conforming with the minimum requirements of all applicable Ordinances except in conjunction with the immediately adjoining parcel (the combination of which must result in a conforming parcel), unless a variance is granted pursuant to the procedure set forth in Section 15.133(c) of the Mount Clemens Zoning Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 15, 1988) 
16.902 - Sec. 2. 
PROCEDURE FOR LAND DIVISION. 
    It shall be unlawful to divide any parcel or lot except in accordance with the following procedure: 
1.  The applicant shall be required to furnish: 
(A)  Evidence of ownership satisfactory to the City Assessor; 
(B)  A legal description and a plot plan indicating the present property boundaries and locating all structures within 60 feet of the subject parcel; 
(C)  A legal description and the boundary lines as proposed; 
(D)  A description of all existing and proposed public rights-of-way and easements; 
(E)  A duly executed written memorandum of conveyance (e.g. deed, land contract, lease, etc.) suitable for recording with the Macomb County Clerk, Register of Deeds, which the proprietor intends to utilize for conveyance of said parcels; 
(F)  Any other documentation deemed necessary by the City Assessor or the other reviewing departments. 
2.  The City Assessor in conjunction with the Community Development Director and City Treasurer shall determine whether the proposed division complies with the Mount Clemens Code of Ordinances and Act 288, Michigan Public Acts of 1967, as amended, and that the resulting parcels comply with the above stated Act and Ordinances. 
3.  A proposed division which will result in parcels or lots which contain less than the minimum requirements imposed by the above stated Act or Code of Ordinances may be permitted if the proprietor shall also file with the City Assessor a duly executed affidavit suitable for recording with the Macomb County Register of Deeds, signed by all persons having legal or equitable interest in said parcels or lots, attesting that said parcels or lots will not thereafter be developed or used separately, but only in conjunction with adjoining parcels which together satisfy the minimum requirements of the above stated Act and Code of Ordinances, unless a variance has been granted by the Board of Zoning Appeals. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 15, 1988) 
16.903 - Sec. 3. 
APPLICATION FEES. 
    The fee for the processing of land division requests shall be $200.00 for non-residential properties and $25.00 for residential properties. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 15, 1988) 
16.904 - Sec. 4. 
TAXES. 
    The City Treasurer shall not divide any parcel for tax purposes unless the applicant has complied with the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 15, 1988) 
16.905 - Sec. 5. 
PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this Ordinance is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof may be punished by a fine not exceeding Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment in the County Jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate violation. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 15, 1988) 
17.000 - SUBDIVISION CONTROL ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- For state law relative to authority of the City Planning Commission to make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the City, see C.L., 1948, sec. 125.36; Mich. 

17.010 - ARTICLE I TITLE, PURPOSE AND DEFINITIONS 

17.011 - Sec. 1.1. 
SHORT TITLE. 
    This Ordinance shall be known and cited as "The Subdivision Control Ordinance of the City of Mount Clemens, Michigan." 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.012 - Sec. 1.2. 
PURPOSE. 
    The purposes of this Ordinance are to provide for the orderly growth and harmonious development of the community; to secure adequate traffic circulation through coordinated street systems with relation to major thoroughfares, adjoining subdivisions and public facilities; to achieve individual property lots of maximum utility and livability; to secure adequate provisions for water supply, drainage and sanitary sewer facilities, and other health requirements; to secure adequate provisions for recreational areas, school sites, and other public facilities; and to provide logical procedures for the achievement of these purposes. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.013 - Sec. 1.3. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    In this Ordinance, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
A.  EASEMENT. A grant by the owner of the use of a strip of land by the public, a corporation, or persons, for specific uses and purposes, and shall be designated a "public" or "private" easement depending on the nature of the user. 
B.  LOT. A parcel or portion of land separated from other parcels or portions by description as in a subdivision or on a record survey map or by metes and bounds for purpose of sale, lease or separate use. 
C.  GENERAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN. A composite of the graphic and written proposals recommending the physical development of the community which shall have been duly adopted by the Planning Commission and City Commission (sometimes called the "master plan" ). 
D.  PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE. Any security which may be accepted by the City Commission in lieu of a requirement that a certain improvement be made prior to approval of a final plat, including performance bonds, escrow agreements and other similar collateral or surety agreements. 
E.  PLAT. A map of a subdivision. 
1.  SKETCH PLAN. A sketch map of a proposed subdivision of sufficient accuracy and scale to be used for the purpose of discussion and meeting the needs of sections 2.1 to 2.3, inclusive, of this Ordinance. 
2.  MASTER DEVELOPMENT PLAN. A preliminary map indicating the tentative layout of streets and location of schools, recreation areas and other community facilities, for the entirety of a large landholding of which a portion is to be submitted as a preliminary plat. A map meeting the needs of section 2.4 of this Ordinance. 
3.  PRELIMINARY PLAT. A preliminary map indicating the proposed layout of the subdivision in sufficient detail to provide adequate basis for renew by the Planning Commission and meeting the requirements of section 2.5 of this Ordinance. 
4.  FINAL PLAT. A map of all or part of a subdivision prepared and its accuracy certified by a registered engineer or land surveyor in accordance with requirements of Act No. 172, Public Acts of 1929, as amended, otherwise known as the "Plat Act" , and suitable for recording by the County Register of Deeds. 
State Law reference- For state law relative to the making, approving, filing, recording altering and vacating of plats, see C.L., 1948, secs. 560.1 et seq.; Mich. Stat. Anno., secs. 26.431 et seq. 
F.  STREET. Any street, avenue, boulevard, road, lane, parkway, viaduct, alley or other way which is an existing state, county or municipal roadway, or a street or way shown in a plat heretofore approved pursuant to law or approved by official action, or a street or way on a plat duly filed and recorded in the office of the County Register of Deeds, including the land between the street lines whether improved or unimproved, and which may comprise pavements, shoulders, gutters, sidewalks, parking areas, lawn areas and other areas within the street lines. 
1.  MAJOR THOROUGHFARES. Arterial streets of considerable continuity which carry a large volume of both private and commercial vehicles. 
2.  COLLECTOR STREETS. Streets carrying traffic from minor streets to major streets, including principal entrance streets of a residential development. 
3.  MINOR STREETS. Streets which are used primarily for access to abutting residential properties. 
4.  MARGINAL ACCESS STREETS. Minor streets which are parallel and adjacent to major thoroughfares and highways and which provide access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
5.  CUL-DE-SACS. Short streets having one end permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
6.  ALLEYS. Minor ways which are used primarily to provide vehicular access to the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
G.  SUBDIVIDER. Any individual, firm, association, syndicate, co-partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity commencing proceedings under this Ordinance to affect a subdivision of land, either as principal or agent. 
H.  SUBDIVISION. The partitioning or division of a tract of land into five or more lots, tracts or parcels of land; or, if a new street is involved, any division of a parcel of land; or, the division into more than two parts of any lot or piece of land, the boundaries of which have been fixed in a recorded plat; provided that a partitioning or division of land into tracts or parcels of land of ten acres or more and not involving a new street shall not be deemed a subdivision. 
State Law reference- For similar state law, see C.L., 1948, sec. 560.2; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 26.432. 
I.  SUBDIVISION COMMITTEE. A committee of at least three Planning Commission members appointed by the Chairman of the Planning Commission for the purpose of giving detailed consideration to subdivision proposals in the pre-application and preliminary plat stages in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance, and such other duties relating to land subdivisions as may be conferred on this committee by the Planning Commission. 
J.  MAJOR THOROUGHFARE PLAN. The part of the general development plan which sets forth the location, alignment and dimensions of existing and proposed major thoroughfares. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.020 - ARTICLE 2 PRELIMINARY PLAT PROCEDURES 

17.021 - Sec. 2.1. 
PRE-APPLICATION STAGE, PURPOSE. 
    The purpose of the pre-application stage is to afford the subdivider the opportunity to obtain the advice and assistance of the Planning Commission and to discuss the proposed development informally with members of the Subdivision Committee prior to the expense of preliminary plat preparation. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.022 - Sec. 2.2. 
SUBDIVISION COMMITTEE; FUNCTIONS. 
    A Subdivision Committee composed of at least three members of the Planning Commission is delegated to represent the Planning Commission in pre-application negotiations with the subdivider and to perform such other functions as may be assigned by the chairman of the Planning Commission. 
    The committee or any of its members, shall discuss such proposals with the subdivider, review sketch plans and other data, inspect sites and make such other investigations as necessary, and shall furnish information to the subdivider regarding plat procedures and requirements. It shall determine whether a Master Development Plan shall be required prior to consideration of a preliminary plat in compliance with section 2.4. It shall present its recommendations regarding a proposal to the Planning Commission at its next regular meeting designating in its recommendations the owners of adjoining unplatted lands which are considered to be interested parties to the review of the proposed subdivision. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.023 - Sec. 2.3. 
INFORMATION TO SUBDIVIDER AUTHORIZED. 
    The information which may be furnished the subdivider by the committee includes the following: 
A.  Procedural steps, design standards, preliminary plat requirements, zoning requirements and public health requirements. 
B.  Any known unusual or difficult problems pertinent to the site, such as adjacent land use, drainage, soil percolation, water supply, public utilities and streets. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.024 - Sec. 2.4. 
MASTER DEVELOPMENT PLAN. 
A.  REQUIREMENT. When the tract proposed for any subdivision constitutes a part of a larger landholding of the subdivider, whose intention it is to subdivide the remaining part or parts of the larger tract at some future date, a Master Development Plan shall be prepared and submitted by the subdivider and tentatively approved by the Planning Commission prior to preparation and submission of the Preliminary Plat of the section proposed for initial development. 
B.  PREPARATION. The Master Development Plan shall be prepared to a scale and accuracy commensurate with the purpose of setting forth the subdivider's intentions regarding the: 
1.  General street pattern with particular attention to collector streets and future neighborhood circulation. 
2.  Location of schools and parks or recreational areas. 
3.  Sanitary sewage, storm water disposal and water supply. 
4.  Shopping centers, multi-family residential or other proposed land uses. 
C.  SUBMISSION. Three copies of the Master Development Plan shall be filed with the secretary of the Planning Commission at least ten days prior to a regular Planning Commission meeting. The secretary shall check the submission, assign it a case number and place the case on the meeting agenda. 
D.  REVIEW. The Planning Commission may assign the plan to its Subdivision Committee for review and recommendations. It shall immediately contact the superintendent of the appropriate school district for his information and recommendations as to general school needs in the projected development. The owners of adjoining unplatted land who are considered to be interested parties to the review of the proposed development shall be notified of the date, time and place of the meeting at which the case is to be heard at least five days prior to said meeting. 
E.  APPROVAL. The Planning Commission shall consider the plan not later than the next regular meeting following its presentation and reach a determination of recommended revision or tentative approval. Tentative approval of a Master Development Plan may be subject to modification from time to time as progressive sections are submitted as Preliminary Plats. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.025 - Sec. 2.5. 
PRELIMINARY PLATS; PREPARATION, CONTENTS, CONDITIONS. 
A.  FORM. The information hereinafter required as part of the Preliminary Plat may be shown graphically or by note thereon, and the plat may be composed of several sheets showing various elements of the required data. 
B.  DESIGNER. The Preliminary Plat shall be designed and drawn by a planner holding full membership or fellowship in the American Society of Landscape Architects, or by a registered engineer or land surveyor; or by such other planner whose qualifications are deemed adequate by the Planning Commission. 
C.  REQUIRED INFORMATION. The Preliminary Plat shall show or be accompanied by the following information: 
1.  DESCRIPTION. 
a.  Proposed name of subdivision and location by section. 
b.  Name and address of subdivider. 
c.  Name and address of designer. 
d.  Graphic scale, north point, and date of preparation. 
2.  EXISTING CONDITIONS. 
a.  Topography by contours. U.S.G.S. Survey datum to be used. 
i.  5-foot intervals where slope is greater than 10 percent. 
ii.  2-foot intervals where slope is ten percent or less. 
b.  Location of streams, lakes and swamps with direction of flow and elevations. Investigation of any past history of flooding should be made by the subdivider since this element will be closely checked in plat review. 
c.  Location, width and names of all platted streets, railroads, utility rights-of-way, public areas, permanent buildings or structures, and municipal corporation lines within or adjacent to the tract. 
d.  In case of re-subdivision, a copy of existing plat. 
e.  Existing sewers, water mains, drains, culverts or other underground facilities within the tract or within right-of-way of boundary streets, with pipe sizes, grades and invert elevations from the public records. Location of these facilities in adjoining tracts or subdivisions if proposed for use or extension. 
f.  Acreage of tract to nearest tenth. 
g.  Names of owners or tract designations of adjoining unplatted tracts. 
3.  PROPOSED CONDITIONS. 
a.  Plan for development of land proposed for platting. The scale of the plat shall be 100 feet to the inch or larger and it shall show the following: 
i.  Layout of streets, alleys and public crosswalks, if any, with widths noted; street names or designation by alphabetical lettering; preliminary grades and cross section. 
ii.  Layout of all lots including building setback lines and typical lot dimensions; scaled dimensions of all corner lots and lots on curvilinear sections of street; utility easements with width and use on all lots; total number of lots. 
iii.  Designation of all land to be reserved for public use. 
iv.  Preliminary plan and profile of sanitary sewers with grade, pipe sizes and points of discharge. Where a public sanitary sewer main is not reasonably accessible, but where the plans for the sanitary sewer system of the district in which the subdivision is located have been prepared by the City Engineer and officially approved by the City Commission (information available at office of City engineer), the subdivider shall install sewers in conformity with such plans, although a connection with an existing main may not be immediately practicable. In such cases, and until such connection is made with the sewer system of the district, the subdivider shall provide for the disposal of sanitary sewage by a method approved by the City engineer and the County Board of Health. 
v.  Preliminary Plan of water supply systems with pipe sizes and location of hydrants. 
vi.  Preliminary Plan of storm sewer system with grade, pipe sizes and location and invert elevation of outlet; approval of persons or agency controlling outlet; approval of the County Drain Commissioner if county drains are involved. 
vii.  Any other data pertinent to a specific site which may be necessary to review by the Planning Commission and so designated by the Subdivision Committee in the preapplication recommendation. 
viii.  Draft of proposed protective covenants to be imposed. 
(a) Where the dividing line between municipalities or other areas of political and legislative jurisdiction occurs within the tract proposed for subdivision, the street and lot pattern shall be so arranged as to place such dividing line at the centerline of a street or on a lot line. Insofar as possible the platting of streets on such dividing lines shall be avoided. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.026 - Sec. 2.6. 
PRELIMINARY PLATS; SUBMISSION, REVIEW, APPROVAL. 
A.  SUBMISSION. 
1.  Five copies of the application for subdivision approval, comprising completed application forms to be provided by the City, Preliminary Plat and supporting data, shall be filed with the secretary of the Planning Commission at least ten days prior to the regular Planning Commission meeting at which the subdivider expects it to be presented. The secretary shall check the submission for completeness, assign it a case number and place the case on the meeting agenda. 
2.  The owners of adjoining unplatted land who are considered to be interested parties to the review of the proposed subdivision shall be notified, by the secretary, of the date, time and place of the meeting at which the case is to be heard, at least five days prior to said meeting. 
3.  Upon presentation of the application to the Planning Commission by the subdivider or his representative, its receipt shall be entered in the meeting minutes and one copy of the complete application retained in Planning Commission files. In no case shall the Planning Commission receive for review a Preliminary Plat which is a part of a larger landholding of the subdivider, which larger tract is intended for future residential development, until a Master Development Plan has been submitted, reviewed and tentatively approved in accordance with section 2.4 of this Ordinance. 
B.  REVIEW. The Planning Commission may assign the case to its Subdivision Committee for review and recommendations. It shall immediately forward one copy of the application and supporting data to the superintendent of the appropriate school district, and one to the City Engineer. 
C.  APPROVAL. 
1.  PLANNING COMMISSION. The Planning Commission shall consider the application not later than the next regular monthly meeting following its presentation, at which time the various reviewing bodies shall make known by letter or in person their recommendations. 
a.  Whenever the Planning Commission is satisfied that all conditions have been satisfactorily met, it shall give preliminary approval to the application; the chairman shall make a notation to that effect thereon, and forward it to the City Clerk with recommendations for preliminary approval by the City Commission. 
b.  If the Planning Commission's approval is tentative and subject to certain conditions, no recommendation shall be sent to the City Commission until said conditions have been satisfied by the subdivider. The revised application shall be reentered on the Planning Commission meeting agenda for ten days in advance and again presented for review, whereupon it may receive preliminary approval as hereinabove prescribed. 
c.  If the Planning Commission rejects the plat, it shall record the reasons therefor in the meeting minutes. An excerpt of the pertinent portions of the meeting minutes shall be sent to the subdivider. 
State Law reference- For composition, duties & authority of the City Planning Commission see 14.001, sec. 1. et seq. 
2.  CITY COMMISSION. The City Commission shall neither receive nor review preliminary plats until it has received the recommendations of the Planning Commission. Following receipt of such application and recommendations, it shall consider the case at its first regular meeting thereafter. If the City Commission rejects a plat, it shall record the reasons therefor in the meeting minutes. An excerpt of the pertinent portions of the meeting minutes shall be sent to the Planning Commission and to the subdivider. 
3.  SIGNIFICANCE OF APPROVAL. Preliminary approval by the City Commission shall confer upon the subdivider the following conditional rights for a period of one year from the date of approval: 
a.  The general terms and conditions under which preliminary approval was granted will not be changed. 
b.  Preliminary approval does not guarantee final acceptance of streets for dedication. 
c.  Preliminary approval does not guarantee a continuation of zoning requirements for the tract or its environs. 
d.  The subdivider may submit on or before the expiration date the whole or any part of said plat for final approval. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.030 - ARTICLE 3 DESIGN PRINCIPLES AND STANDARDS 

17.031 - Sec. 3.1. 
GENERAL REQUIREMENTS. 
A.  Every subdivision shall conform to the requirements and purposes of the General Development Plan, or any parts thereof, as adopted by the Planning Commission and the City Commission; the Zoning Ordinance and other Ordinances of the City; and to the Public Acts of the State. 
B.  Whenever a tract to be subdivided embraces any part of a street designated on the major thoroughfare plan, as a part of the General Development Plan, such part shall be platted in the location and width indicated on such Plan. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.032 - Sec. 3.2. 
STREET LOCATION AND ARRANGEMENT. 
A.  Street layout shall provide for the continuation of existing major or collector streets in surrounding areas, or conform to a plan of the neighborhood approved and adopted by the Planning Commission. 
B.  Minor streets shall be so arranged as to discourage their use by through traffic. 
C.  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed major thoroughfare, the Planning Commission may require marginal access streets or reverse frontage with an approved screen planting contained in a private non-access easement having a minimum width of 20 feet along the rear and/or side property line; or, such other treatment as may be desirable for protection of residential properties and reduction of traffic hazards. 
D.  Where a subdivision abuts or contains a railroad right-of-way or limited access thoroughfare right-of-way, the Planning Commission may recommend the location of a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the abutting land, as for park purposes in residential districts or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances should also be determined with due regard to approach grades, drainage and future grade separations. 
E.  Certain proposed streets, as indicated by the Planning Commission, shall be extended to the boundary line of the tract to provide for satisfactory future circulation within the neighborhood. In general, these extensions should not be more than 1300 feet apart. The purpose of this provision is to intercept streets approaching the tracts at right angles, and to avoid permanent dead-ends. 
F.  Proposed streets shall be arranged in relation to the existing topography so as to produce usable lots and streets of reasonable gradient. 
G.  Except where justified by extreme topographic or other conditions, alleys will not be approved in those parts of the proposed subdivision located in single- or two-family residential districts. 
H.  Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall be avoided. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.033 - Sec. 3.3. 
STREET DESIGN. 
A.  MINIMUM STREET AND ALLEY WIDTHS. 
1.  Major thoroughfares shall have a width not less than that indicated on the major thoroughfare plan. 
2.  Collector and minor streets shall have a width of not less than 60 feet. 
3.  Cul-de-sac streets shall have a width of not less than 50 feet and terminate in a circular right-of-way with a minimum diameter of 100 feet having an improved traffic turning circle of not less than 80 feet in diameter. The Planning Commission may approve an equally and convenient form of space instead of the required turning circle. 
4.  Alleys shall have a width of not less than 20 feet. 
5.  Half-streets are prohibited except where essential to the reasonable development of the tract in conformity to the provisions hereof. Whenever a half-street is adjacent to the tract to be subdivided, the other half shall be platted within the tract. 
B.  STREET GRADES. 
1.  MAXIMUM GRADES. 
a.  Major thoroughfares, not greater than six percent. 
b.  Minor streets, not greater than seven percent. 
2.  MINIMUM GRADES. 
a.  Concrete streets and gutters - 0.40 percent. 
b.  All other types of street and gutter surfacing - 0.50 percent. 
C.  VERTICAL CURVES. 
1.  MAJOR THOROUGHFARES. Minimum sight distance, 600 feet, measured between points five feet above centerline of streets. 
2.  MINOR STREETS. Minimum sight distance, 300 feet, measured as in 1 above. 
D.  HORIZONTAL ALIGNMENT. 
1.  When street lines deflect from each other more than 10° in alignment, the centerlines shall be connected by a curve with a minimum radius of: 
a.  Collector streets - 300 feet. 
b.  Minor streets - 150 feet. 
These minimum radii may be varied, however, where the topography requires other treatment of streets to secure the best overall design. 
2.  Between reverse curbs there shall be a minimum tangent distance of 100 feet. 
3.  Intersections - Streets intersecting a major street shall do so at as near 90° angle as possible. 
4.  Minor streets intersecting a collector street or major thoroughfare shall do so with a tangent section of centerline not less than 50 feet in length measured from the right-of-way line of the collector street. This requirement may be waived, however, where the curve of the minor street has a radius greater than 400 feet with the center of the curve located on the right-of-way line of the collector street. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.034 - Sec. 3.4. 
BLOCKS; LENGTH REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS. 
A.  MAXIMUM LENGTH OF BLOCKS. 1300 feet, measured between intersections of centerline. Exceptions: 
1.  Country home subdivisions, having lots of one-half acre or larger, may exceed this maximum by not more than 500 feet. 
2.  Extreme topographic conditions. 
B.  MAXIMUM LENGTH OF CUL-DE-SAC STREETS. 600 feet, measured form the intersection of right-of-way lines to extreme depth of turning circle along centerline of cul-de-sac. 
EXCEPTION: Extreme topographic conditions. An exception will not be made for properties with restrictive boundary dimensions, wherein provision should be made for extension of street pattern to adjoining unplatted lands. 
C.  CROSSWALKS. Where necessary to obtain satisfactory pedestrian circulation in a subdivision where blocks exceed 1000 feet in length, the Planning Commission may require a crosswalk or pedestrian-way eight feet wide to be dedicated entirely through the block. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.035 - Sec. 3.5. 
LOT PLANNING. 
A.  In any residential subdivision, the minimum lot width, depth and area shall be appropriate for the location and type of land use contemplated and shall generally have a width at the building set-back line of not less than 60 feet nor an area of less than 6000 square feet. 
B.  The depth-to-width ratio of the usable area of a lot shall not be greater than three to one. 
C.  Building setback lines shall conform to the minimum requirements of the Zoning Ordinance, but in no case shall they be less than 25 feet from any minor street lines; except in case there is no frontage on the side street, wherein a lesser setback line may be permitted in accordance with the Zoning Ordinance. 
D.  Side lot lines generally shall be at right angles or radial to street lines except where other treatment may be justified in the opinion of the Planning Commission. 
E.  Every lot shall abut on a public street providing satisfactory access to an existing public street. 
F.  Lots extending through the block and having frontage on two streets shall be prohibited, except that this shall not be constructed to contradict any portion of section 3.2. 
G.  Except where alleys are provided for the purpose, an easement shall be provided along rear or side lot lines as necessary for utility lines, not less than twelve feet in total width, being six feet from each lot. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.040 - ARTICLE 4 STREET AND UTILITY IMPROVEMENT REQUIREMENTS 

17.041 - Sec. 4.1. 
PURPOSE. 
    It is the purpose of this Article to establish and define specific major policies concerning the responsibilities of the subdivider in the detailed planning, construction and financing of public facilities and to establish procedures for determining compliance to requirements. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.042 - Sec. 4.2. 
SUBDIVIDER; PLANS, PREPARATION; RESPONSIBILITY. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider of every proposed subdivision to have prepared by a registered engineer a complete set of construction plans, including profiles, cross-sections, specifications and supporting data, for the hereinafter required public facilities. Such construction plans shall be based on preliminary plans which have been approved with the preliminary plat and shall be prepared in conjunction with the final plat. Such construction plans shall be prepared in accordance with requirements of the public improvement standards approved by the City Engineer and adopted by the City Commission. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.043 - Sec. 4.3. 
PLANS, SUBMISSION, PROCEDURE. 
A.  FILING. Three copies of engineering plans and specifications shall be filed with the City Clerk simultaneously with the filing of the final plat. 
B.  REVIEW. The City Clerk shall check the submission for completeness, and, if complete, shall record receipt of engineering plans and final plat and date thereof, and immediately distribute the documents to the City Engineer and the Planning Commission for review. The Planning Commission shall review the complete submission and report its recommendations to the Clerk. The engineer shall review the engineering plans in detail for compliance to standards, prepare an estimate of cost of construction of the required improvements, and submit his recommendations to the Clerk. If either recommendation is for rejection, it shall be in writing with reasons therefor. 
C.  APPROVAL. Approval of engineering plans shall be simultaneous with that of the final plat as set forth in section 5.2 of this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.044 - Sec. 4.4. 
STREETS AND ALLEYS; IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED. 
A.  STREETS AND ALLEYS. The subdivider shall provide streets and alleys completed according to plans, profiles, cross-sections and specifications prepared by or for him and approved by the City Engineer, as required in sections 4.2 and 4.3, prior to the start of any construction. 
1.  PAVEMENT WIDTHS. The classification of streets shall be in accord with the major thoroughfare plan and conform to the following widths: 
a.  MINOR STREETS. 27 feet measured from back to back of curbs. 
b.  COLLECTOR STREETS. 37 feet measured from back to back of curbs. 
c.  MAJOR STREETS. The width to which each individual major street shall be improved shall be determined by the Commission acting on the recommendations of the City engineer. Close agreement on standards should be reached with the Macomb County Road Commission and with the Michigan State Highway Department for streets wholly or partially under their jurisdiction. These standards should include width of pavement, sidewalk policy, and type of storm drainage facilities. 
d.  ALLEY. 16 feet wide. 
2.  STREET GRADING. All streets and alleys shall be graded to the full width of the right-of-way as shown on plans and profiles approved by the City Engineer and in accordance with adopted local standards. 
3.  PAVEMENT SPECIFICATIONS. All streets and alleys shall be constructed in accordance with cross-sections and detailed specifications for same in accordance with adopted local standards. 
B.  CURB AND GUTTER. Permanent concrete curb (integral if pavement is concrete) or separate curb and gutter (for asphalt paving) shall be installed on all streets in accordance with the adopted local standards. 
C.  SIDEWALKS. Sidewalks shall normally be required on both sides of streets for the safety of pedestrians and children at play, and shall be constructed to a width, line and grade as determined by the City engineer and in accordance with adopted local standards. Where for a considerable distance, one side abuts on a railroad, park, golf course, cemetery, or other type of use not requiring a walk and where continuity is not essential, the Planning Commission may recommend that the requirement of a walk on that side be waived. The Planning Commission shall likewise recommend the requirement for sidewalks along streets from which access to abutting property is eliminated by a non-access easement as referred to in section 3.2. 
D.  CROSSWALKS. Where recommended by the Planning Commission, crosswalks through blocks shall be constructed to a line and grade as determined by the City Engineer and in accordance with adopted local standards. Such a crosswalk shall be surfaced to its entire width and fenced on both sides with 4-foot high permanent materials. Street lights shall be located at each end for protection. 
E.  STREET TREES. Street trees of a variety and size set forth in the standards adopted by the City shall be planted at intervals of 40 to 50 feet between curb and sidewalk or, at the option of the subdivider, on the lots and parallel to and within ten feet of the sidewalk. Trees shall be planted in accordance with specifications established by the City Commission and their livelihood guaranteed by the developer for a period of one year. 
F.  STREET NAME SIGNS. Signs shall be placed at all street intersections, and installation shall be in place by the time the street pavement is ready for use. Specifications for construction, location and placement of signs shall be in accordance with the adopted local standards. 
G.  STORM DRAINAGE. Proper and adequate provision shall be made for the disposal of storm water. This shall apply equally to the grading of private properties and to public streets-the responsibility for proper lot drainage belongs with the developer-if it is not properly handled prior to sale of property, later correction is difficult, expensive and a headache to the public authorities. Existing water courses shall be maintained and dedicated as drainage courses. The type, extent, location and capacity of drainage facilities shall be determined by the City Engineer. All properties shall be served by underground storm sewer systems discharging into approved outlets and constructed in accordance with adopted local standards. 
H.  SANITARY SEWERS. The subdivider shall provide a complete sanitary sewer system discharging into an approved outlet. Construction shall be done in accordance with specifications conforming to adopted local standards and to plans and profiles approved by the City Engineer. 
I.  WATER SUPPLY. Water mains property connected with the public water supply system shall be constructed in such a manner as to adequately serve all lots for both domestic use and fire protection. Sizes of mains, location and types of valves and hydrants shall be in accordance with adopted local standards. 
J.  GREENBELTS. Where recommended by the Planning Commission as a protection for residential properties, greenbelts or landscape screen plantings shall be constructed along public street and railroad rights-of-way. Construction to approved specifications and maintenance and guaranty for the period of one year shall be at the expense of the subdivider. Such greenbelts shall be constructed on private easements and maintained by private property owners. Where not required along public rights-of-way, such greenbelts may be constructed only with Planning Commission approval. 
K.  MONUMENTS. Permanent metal monuments shall be installed in compliance with and as specified by Section 10 of Act No. 172, Public Acts of 1929, as amended. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- See C.L., 1948, sec. 560.10; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 26.440. 
17.045 - Sec. 4.5. 
COMPLETION OF IMPROVEMENTS; CASH DEPOSIT, PERFORMANCE BOND; ALTERNATIVES. 
    In lieu of the actual installation of required improvements of public facilities, the subdivider may elect to provide a financial guarantee of performance in one or a combination of the following arrangements: 
A.  PERFORMANCE OR SURETY BOND. 
1.  AMOUNT OF BOND. The amount determined by the City Commission. The Bonding Company shall be authorized to do business in the State. 
2.  LENGTH OF TERM. A period to be specified by the City Commission, but such a period shall not exceed twelve months; provided, however, that under extraordinary circumstances or conditions this period may be extended by the City Commission for not more than twelve months. 
B.  CASH DEPOSIT, CERTIFIED CHECK OR NEGOTIABLE BONDS. Deposit shall be made with the City Treasurer or a responsible escrow agent or trust company, subject to the approval of the City Commission, or money or negotiable bonds in the same amount of the kind approved by law for securing deposits of public funds in banks. If a cash deposit is made, the agreement shall provide that progress payments shall be made to the contractor or the subdivider out of the deposit as work progresses. 
C.  SPECIAL ASSESSMENT. In cases where all properties abutting on a public right-of-way are not under the control of the subdivider, the subdivider may petition the City Commission to provide the necessary improvements and to assess the cost thereof against the abutting property in accordance with local requirements regarding special assessments; provided, however, that the subdivider shall be responsible for any differences between the cost of the improvements and the amount that can be legally assessed by the City against the property to be subdivided and shall furnish the necessary waivers to permit the assessment of the entire cost of the improvements. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.046 - Sec. 4.6. 
IMPROVEMENTS, INSTALLATION; INSPECTION, FEES. 
    The agreement to install required public improvements shall also provide for checking or improvement plans and inspection of all improvements by the City Engineer and reimbursement of the City for the cost of checking and inspection at the rate of two percent of the cost of improvements as estimated by the City Engineer. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.047 - Sec. 4.7. 
PROGRESSIVE INSTALLATIONS; REDUCTION OF BONDS, DEPOSITS, AUTHORIZED. 
    Whenever any portion of any improvement has been fully completed to the satisfaction of the City Engineer, he shall recommend, and the City Commission authorize, the reduction in bonds or a partial withdrawal of funds equal to the estimated cost of such completed portion. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.048 - Sec. 4.8. 
FAILURE TO COMPLETE IMPROVEMENTS; PENALTY. 
    In the event the subdivider shall in any case fail to complete such work within such period as required by the conditions of the guarantee, the City Commission shall have such work completed. To reimburse the City for the cost and expense thereof, the City may appropriate the deposit of cash money or negotiable bonds which the subdivider may have deposited in lieu of a surety bond, or may take such steps as may be necessary to require performance by the Bonding Company. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.050 - ARTICLE 5 FINAL PLAT PROCEDURES 

17.051 - Sec. 5.1. 
FINAL PLAT; PREPARATION; REGULATIONS, COMPLIANCE REQUIRED. 
    The preparation of the fInal plat shall comply with the requirements and suggestions set forth in the Plat Manual of Instructions Relative to Making and Filing of Township, Village and City Plats, issued by the Auditor General's office in 1948, which publication, with all subsequent amendments, is hereby made apart of this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.052 - Sec. 5.2. 
FINAL PLATS; SUBMISSION, FILING, REVIEW, APPROVAL. 
A.  FILING OF PLAT. 
1.  The subdivider shall file five copies of the final plat together with three copies of engineering plans and specifications, prepared in accordance with Article 4 of this Ordinance, with the City Clerk. 
2.  Simultaneous with the filing of final plats, the subdivider shall deposit with the Clerk the sum of $60.00 for expenses of inspection of lands, meetings and such fees required to be paid in Act No. 172, Public Acts of 1929, as amended. 
3.  The Clerk shall record receipt and the date thereof, and shall immediately check the submission for completeness. If incomplete, the Clerk shall so inform the subdivider in order that the date of filing may be revised. 
B.  REVIEW. 
1.  If complete, the Clerk shall transmit one copy to each of the following reviewing offices: 
a.  Planning Commission to determine whether plans conform satisfactorily to approved preliminary plans. 
b.  City Engineer to determine that metes and bounds of the plat are accurate and the traverse closed, for detailed review of engineering plans and specifications; for preparation of a cost estimate for installation of required improvements, and for recommendations as to the type and amount of performance guarantee to be required. 
c.  City Assessor to determine whether there are liens for special assessments existing against the land. 
d.  City Treasurer to determine whether there are existing and unpaid taxes against the land. 
2.  The City Clerk shall assemble recommendations of the reviewing offices and present the plat at the next meeting of the City Commission with recommendations of the reviewing offices. 
C.  APPROVAL. 
1.  The City Commission shall review the recommendations of the reviewing offices and approve or reject the plat within 30 days of its filing with the City Clerk. 
2.  If the Commission rejects the plat for any reason whatsoever, it shall notify the subdivider in writing with the reasons for rejection. 
3.  If the Commission finds approval subject to completion of required improvements or deposit of performance guarantee, one copy of excerpts of pertinent portions of the meeting minutes shall be sent to the Planning Commission. 
4.  When evidence of completion of required improvements has been received by the Clerk from the City engineer, or evidence of deposit of performance guarantee has been received by the Clerk from the City treasurer, he shall transcribe a certificate of approval of the City Commission on the plat and deliver it to the Clerk of the County Plat Board. 
5.  No construction of improvements shall be commenced by the subdivider until he has received notice of the conditional approval of the City Commission. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
17.053 - Sec. 5.3. 
VIOLATIONS, PENALTIES. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this Ordinance shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 and the costs of prosecution or, in default of the payment thereof, by imprisonment for a term not to exceed 90 days, or both. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. The imposition of any sentence shall not exempt the offender from compliance with the requirements of this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
17.054 - Sec. 5.4. 
SUBDIVISION PLAT PROCEDURE. 
    (Preliminary to Provisions of the Plat Act) 

17.055 - Sec. 5.5. 
FINAL PLAT PROCEDURE. 
    Note: Parenthetical numbers refer to applicable Sections of "Plat Act", P.A., 172, as amended. 

17.100 - RECREATIONAL EQUIPMENT CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Oct. 4, 1967; further amend. Jan., 1978; ord. eff. May 27, 2010; ord eff. Nov. 17, 2016 

17.101 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITION. 
    As used in this Ordinance, recreational equipment is defined as and shall include the following: 
A.  A "travel trailer" is a vehicular structure built on a chassis and propelled by another vehicle to which it may be attached; designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses. 
B.  A "pickup camper" is a structure designed primarily to be mounted on a pickup or truck chassis and with sufficient equipment to render it suitable for use as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses. 
C.  A "motorized home" is a portable dwelling designed and constructed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle. 
D.  A "folding tent trailer" is a canvas folding structure mounted on wheels and designed for travel and vacation uses. 
E.  "Boats" and "boat trailers" shall include boats, jet skis, floats, and rafts, plus the normal equipment to transport the same on the highway. 
F.  "Snowmobile" shall include all snowmobiles, trailers and normal equipment to transport the same on the highway. 
    Front yard means the yard on the same lot with a building between the front line of the building and the front lot line and extending to the other side lot line. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Oct. 4, 1967; further amend. Jan., 1978; ord. eff. May 27, 2010; ord. eff. Nov. 17, 2016) 
17.102 - Sec. 2. 
PERMITTED PARKING AND USE. 
    Any person may park or store recreational equipment as defined subject to the following conditions: 
A.  Recreational equipment parked or stored shall not have fixed connections to electricity, water, gas, or sanitary sewer facilities, and at no time shall this equipment be used for living or housekeeping purposes, except as otherwise provided herein. 
B.  If the recreational equipment is parked or stored outside of a garage it shall be parked or stored in the rear open space or behind the front yard of the house or building line and set back from the side and rear lot line a distance of at least three (3) feet. In no case shall any recreational equipment be parked in the front yard. 
C.  All recreational equipment must be operational, kept in good repair and carry a current year's license and registration. 
D.  The parking or storage of an unoccupied mobile home, being a movable or portable dwelling, constructed to be towed on its own chassis and connected to utilities and designed without a permanent foundation for year-around living is specifically prohibited. 
E.  Recreational equipment may not be stored on vacant lots or another resident's property unless the outdoor storage use has been approved by the planning commission. No property shall have more than two recreational vehicles on their property at any time. 
F.  Outdoor storage of recreational equipment as outlined above shall be permitted from April 1 through October 31. Outdoor storage between November 1 and March 31 shall only be allowed in the rear yard on an improved surface as approved by the Building Official. Provided, however, in the event storage in the rear yard is not possible because of size or topography, recreational equipment not exceeding thirty-six (36) feet in length may be stored in the side yard, but not closer than three (3) feet from the side lot line and screened from the adjacent property by a solid fence or landscaping six (6) feet in height. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Oct. 4, 1967; further amend. Jan., 1978; ord. eff. May 27, 2010; ord. eff. Nov. 17, 2016) 
17.103 - Sec. 3. 
PROHIBITED PARKING AND USE EXCLUDING ONE, MULTIPLE FAMILY AND RURAL RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS. 
A.  No person shall park or cause to be parked any mobile home or recreational equipment overnight on any street, alley, highway, or other public place. 
B.  No mobile home or recreational equipment shall be used or occupied by any person unless there is a clear, unoccupied space of at least ten (10) feet on all sides thereof. 
C.  No mobile home or recreational equipment shall at any time be parked between the established setback line and the curb line on any lot. 
D.  No person shall park or permit the parking of any occupied mobile home or recreational equipment or use or occupy or permit the use or occupancy of any mobile home or recreational equipment on any site, lot, field, or tract of land not specifically licensed as a mobile home or recreational equipment park, in accordance with the provisions of this Code, except only as provided in this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Oct. 4, 1967; further amend. Jan., 1978; ord. eff. May 27, 2010; ord. eff. Nov. 17, 2016) 
17.104 - Sec. 4. 
RESERVED.
