    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any common gambling house or gaming room, or to permit on any premises owned, occupied or controlled by him, any apparatus or device used for gaming or gambling, or to use such apparatus or device or to assist any other person to use same for gaming or gambling purposes. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any policy or pool slips, tickets, checks, or any paper which is marked additionally with any kind of notation indicating any form of gambling, and the possession of such writing or device shall constitute, prima facie, evidence of intention to use same for gambling. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.007 - Sec. 7. 
LARCENY; PROHIBITION. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the offense of larceny by stealing the property of another of the value of $100.00 or less. The word "property" , for the purpose of this section, shall include any money, goods or chattels, or any bank note, promissory note, due bill, bill of exchange or other bill, draft, order, or certificate, or any book of accounts for or concerning money or goods due or to become due or to be delivered, or any deed or writing containing a conveyance of land or any other valuable contract in force or any receipt, release or defeasance, or any writ process of public record. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.008 - Sec. 8. 
PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC PROPERTY. 
A.  PURPOSE. Failure to preserve public property is detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the community and creates a perception in the community that the laws protecting public property can be disregarded with impunity. This perception fosters a sense of disrespect of the law that is detrimental to the property values of the community, is inconsistent with the City's property maintenance goals and aesthetic standards, leads to blight, and contributes to a deterioration in the quality of life of the community. 
B.  DEFINITIONS. Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of the terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
1.  DEFACE means to cover, mark, inscribe, write on, paint, color, chalk, stamp, post or sticker, or otherwise mar, disfigure or draw whatsoever, whether permanent or temporary, on any public property of any kind or nature, without the express consent of the owner or party in charge of the property. 
2.  PUBLIC ART means original works of art in any medium for temporary or permanent placement on public property, with the express consent of the owner or party in charge of the property. 
3.  PUBLIC PROPERTY means any publicly owned property within the City of Mount Clemens, and includes by way of example only and without limitation, any public school building, city, state or county building, bridge, park, sidewalk, street, crosswalk, curb, lamp post, fence, retaining wall, fire hydrant, tree, bush, flag pole, utility pole, traffic signal pole, traffic controller cabinet, electrical service cabinet, electrical transformer cabinet, telephone cabinet, fountain, pedestrian barricade, guardrail, telephone booth, public display kiosk, gazebo, bench or bus shelter, as well as any public art thereon or made a part thereof. 
C.  PROHIBITED ACTS. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully destroy, remove, damage, alter, tamper with or in any manner deface or to interfere with or hinder the use of, any public building or public property, whether rendering the same inoperable or not, without the consent of the owner or party in charge of the property. 
D.  PENALTY. Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00, or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Apr. 30, 2009) 
20.009 - Sec. 9. 
FIREARMS, AIR GUNS; PROHIBITIONS. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm or other instrument producing a like effect and noise within the city, except in the lawful defense of his person or property or as otherwise permitted by law. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to the Police Department pistol range. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt within the city. 
C.  It shall be unlawful for any person, except Police Officers or any person duly licensed by law, to carry any loaded firearm within the city. 
D.  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any air gun within the city except on an indoor target range; provided, that this provision shall not apply whenever air guns using only B.B. shot are used on premises with the consent of the owner or occupant of such premises. 
E.  It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of premises within the city to permit the use of any air gun using B.B. shot upon his premises by any other person, unless such use is personally supervised by some person 17 years of age or older. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.010 - Sec. 10. 
DANGEROUS WEAPONS; POSSESSION PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS. 
A.  No person shall possess any machine gun, sawed off shotgun, or any instrument or weapon of the kind commonly known as a blackjack, sling shot, sand club, sandbag, switch-blade knife, or metal knuckles, nor any instrument, attachment or appliance for causing the firing of any firearm to be silent or intended to lessen or muffle the noise of the firing of any firearms, except as is otherwise permitted by law. 
B.  No person shall possess, with intent to use unlawfully against another, any imitation pistol, dagger, dirk, razor, stiletto, knife or other dangerous weapon. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.011 - Sec. 11. 
CONTRACEPTIVES; SALE, ETC.; PROHIBITIONS. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a duly registered pharmacist, to sell, offer for sale, or display or expose for sale, or give away, by means of vending machines or otherwise, any contraceptive device or prophylactic rubber goods, or any sex-inciting device, contrivance or substance; provided, that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to wholesale druggists, jobbers or manufacturers who sell to retail drug stores. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise the sale of any of the above described articles in any form or manner. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.012 - Sec. 12. 
PUBLIC PLACES; LOITERING; PROHIBITION. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter on or in any street, sidewalk, office, business establishment, or public place. For the purpose of this section, "loitering" is defined as the act of standing or idling on, in or about any street, sidewalk, office, business establishment, or public place so as to hinder, impede or tend to hinder or impede the passage of pedestrians or vehicles. Violation of this section shall be a misdemeanor punishable as set forth in Code Section 11.005. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. 9-2-88) 
20.013 - Sec. 13. 
REFRIGERATORS; ABANDONING; REMOVAL OF DOORS OR LOCKS; PENALTY. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling, or in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded ice box, refrigerator, trunk, or any other container of any kind which has an airtight door or lock which may not be released for opening from the inside of said ice box, refrigerator, trunk or other container, without first removing the locks or doors therefrom. 
B.  Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or imprisoned for a term not to exceed 90 days, or both. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.014 - Sec. 14. 
PUBLIC PLACES; SPITTING PROHIBITED, PENALTY. 
A.  No person shall spit upon any public sidewalk, or upon the floor or interior of any public conveyance, or upon the floor or walls of any theatre, hall, assembly room, church, school or public building. 
B.  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $10.00. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.015 - Sec. 15. 
MOTORS, MECHANICAL DEVICES; SERIAL NUMBERS, REMOVAL; PROHIBITION. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to conceal or misrepresent the identity of any motor, household appliance or mechanical device by removing or defacing the manufacturer's serial or motor number, or by altering or replacing any part of such motor, appliance or device, bearing the serial or motor number, with a new or replaced part upon which the proper serial or motor number has not been stamped or placed. 
B.  Possession by any dealer, distributor, wholesaler, or other person engaged in the business of buying and selling, of any motor, household appliance or mechanical device upon which the manufacturer's serial or motor number has been removed, defaced or altered or the part bearing such number replaced by one on which the proper number does not appear, shall constitute, prima facie, evidence that such person has violated the provisions of this section. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.016 - Sec. 16. 
SUNDAY SALES PROHIBITED, EXCEPTION. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of buying, selling or exchanging new, used or secondhand motor vehicles, or offering to buy, sell or exchange or participate in the negotiation thereof, or attempt to buy, sell or exchange any motor vehicle or interest therein or of any written instrument pertaining thereto, on the first day of the week, commonly called Sunday. Any person violating any provision of this subsection shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or imprisonment for a term not to exceed 90 days, or both. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person, whether owner, proprietor, agent or employee, to conduct or engage in the business of selling, renting, leasing or exchanging, furniture, televisions, radios or household appliances, or to keep open any store, office or other place for the purpose of selling, renting, leasing or exchanging thereof, on the first day of the week, commonly called Sunday. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to works of necessity or charity. 
C.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any person who conscientiously believes that the seventh day of the week should be observed as the Sabbath and who actually refrains from secular business or labor on that day. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.017 - Sec. 17. 
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES; PROHIBITION. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverage in a container which is open, uncapped or which has a broken seal, or to consume any alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverage while upon the public highways of the city. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverage in a container which is open, uncapped, or which has a broken seal or to consume any alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverage in any public place or in any place of amusement not licensed to sell alcoholic liquors or alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises, except as provided in paragraphs C., D. and E., below. 
C.  Consumption of alcoholic liquor and alcoholic beverages may be permitted in the area known as Clinton River Park, described below (which does not include the waters of the Clinton River but does include the municipal docks), at such times and at such community events as the City Commission shall establish. During the times which the consumption of alcoholic liquors and alcoholic beverages is permitted, the administration shall install appropriate signs around the perimeter of Clinton River Park in order to apprise the public that alcohol consumption must be confined to that area. Clinton River Park is described as: 
A parcel of land bounded on the northeast by the southwesterly edge of the sidewalk and bridge on the southwesterly side of Dickinson Avenue; on the northwest by the southeasterly edge of the sidewalk on the southeasterly side of Northbound Gratiot Avenue; on the southwest by the northeasterly edge of the sidewalk and bridge on the northeasterly side of Crocker Boulevard; and on the southeast by a line running in a northeasterly direction from the end of the northeasterly wing wall of the Crocker Boulevard Bridge to the northwesterly corner of the Municipal Building, then along the northwesterly face of the Municipal Building to the northwesterly edge of the Municipal Building Parking Lot, then along the northwesterly edge of the Municipal Building Parking Lot and the northwesterly edge of a sidewalk running from said Parking Lot to the southwesterly edge of the sidewalk on the southwesterly side of Dickinson Avenue. 
D.  Consumption of alcoholic liquor and alcoholic beverages may be permitted by the Recreation Director at the Community Center (300 N. Groesbeck) and the Wilson Park gymnasium (58 S. Wilson) pursuant to the Rules and Regulations governing the use of those facilities which have been approved by the City Commission. There shall be no sale of alcoholic liquor and/or alcoholic beverages permitted at either location. There shall be no admission charges or ticket sales for admission to an event at which alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverages are served. The serving of alcoholic liquor and alcoholic beverages shall be the responsibility of the lessee of the facility with no involvement by the City, its agents or employees. 
E.  Sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages may be permitted in the area known as the adult softball complex on the south side of Lafayette at Memorial Field at events which are: 
1.  approved by the City Commission; and 
2.  properly licensed by the State of Michigan Liquor Control Commission. 
The City Commission shall establish the dates and times when such sales are permitted. Liability insurance in an amount acceptable to the City Manager shall be provided listing the City of Mount Clemens as an additional insured. The sponsor of the event shall adhere to all other rules applicable to the use of Memorial Field. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Nov. 29, 1990; eff. Mar. 30, 1995; further amend. eff. May 28, 1998) 
20.018 - Sec. 18. 
CONSUMPTION ON PREMISES; DANCING, RESTRICTION. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.019 - Sec. 19. 
STATE LAW, MISDEMEANORS. 
    Every act prohibited by state law as a misdemeanor, is hereby prohibited within the City. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.020 - Sec. 20. 
CARNIVALS, AMUSEMENTS; PROHIBITION, PENALTY. 
A.  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate amusements commonly known as carnivals, street fairs or street shows, and every such amusement and every component part thereof are hereby prohibited without the prior approval of the City Commission. No person shall participate in, attend or sell or purchase tickets for any such amusement, except in accordance with the conditions imposed by the City Commission. As part of its approval process, the City Commission may impose requirements on the applicant in such areas as security, insurance coverage, fire protection and others which the City Commission deems necessary for the protection of the general health, safety and welfare of the public. 
B.  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or imprisonment for a term not to exceed 90 days, or both. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 4, 1984; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.021 - Sec. 21. 
MAYOR'S EMERGENCY POWER. 
A.  The Mayor is hereby declared to be a conservator of the peace, pursuant to section 46 of the Charter, and in addition to the power given to him in emergencies, declared by the Commission, he shall have the following powers and may promulgate the following rules and regulations: 
1.  During times of great public crisis, disaster, rioting, civil disorders, catastrophe, or similar public emergency with the City of Mount Clemens, or reasonable apprehension of immediate danger thereof, when public safety is or threatened to be imperiled, upon his own volition the Mayor may proclaim a state of emergency and designate the area involved. Following such proclamation or declaration which may be written or oral, the Mayor may promulgate such reasonable orders, rules and regulations as he deems necessary to protect life and property, or to bring the emergency situation within the affected area under control. Without limiting the scope of the same, said orders, rules and regulations, the Mayor may provide for the control of traffic, including public and private transportation, within the area or any section thereof; designation of specific zones within the area; or in the total area in which occupancy and use of buildings and ingress and egress of persons and vehicles may be prohibited or regulated; control of places of amusement and assembly, and of persons on public streets and thoroughfares; establishment of a curfew; control of the sale, transportation and use of alcoholic beverages and liquors; control of the possession, sale, carrying and use of firearms and other dangerous weapons and ammunition, and control of the storage, use and transportation of explosives or inflammable materials or liquids deemed to be dangerous to public safety. Such orders, rules and regulations shall be effective from the date, and in the manner prescribed in such orders, rules and regulations, and shall be made public as provided therein. Such orders, rules and regulations may be amended, modified or rescinded in like manner from time to time by the Mayor, during the pendency of the emergency, but shall cease to be in effect upon declaration by the Mayor that the emergency no longer exists. 
B.  It is hereby declared to be the legislative intent to invest the Mayor with sufficiently broad power of action in the exercise of the police power of the City, and as conservator of the peace to provide adequate control over persons and conditions during such periods of impending or actual public crisis, riot, civil disorders, catastrophe, or disaster. The provisions of this Ordinance shall be broadly construed to effectuate this purpose. 
C.  The violation of any such orders, rules and regulations made in conformity with this Ordinance shall be punishable as a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days, or both. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Sept. 20, 1967; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.022 - Sec. 22. 
INSPECTION VIOLATION NOTICE; PROCEDURE. 
    Any Inspector, or duly authorized employee of the City of Mount Clemens, shall serve a notice of violation upon the occupant, and owner according to the city tax rolls, of any building or structure in violation of the provisions of any City Code, or in violation of a detail statement or a plan approved thereof, or in violation of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of the said City Code; and such violation notice shall direct the forthwith discontinuance of the illegal action or condition and the abatement of the violation. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Oct. 20, 1969; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.023 - Sec. 23. 
VIOLATION NOTICE; FORM. 
    Every violation notice served pursuant to this section shall contain the following information: 
A.  The name of the owner. 
B.  The name of the occupant. 
C.  The street address or legal description of the property. 
D.  The type of building. 
E.  The name of the Inspector or said duly authorized employee. 
F.  The date of inspection. 
G.  The date the violation notice was issued. 
H.  A list of the defects to be corrected or abated. 
I.  The specific sections of the City Codes alleged to be violated. 
J.  A reasonable time within which such corrections are to be made or abated. 
K.  The official telephone number and address of the Inspector or said duly authorized employee. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Oct. 20, 1969; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.024 - Sec. 24. 
VIOLATION SUMMONS; FORM; PROCEDURE. 
A.  Whenever any person served with a violation notice in the foregoing section fails or neglects to correct or abate the conditions described therein within the time allotted by said City Inspector or said duly authorized employee, the said City Inspector or said duly authorized employee shall prepare in duplicate a written summons to appear in the Mount Clemens District Court, containing the name and address of such person, the offense charged, the section number of the code for the offense charged, and the time and place when and where such person shall appear in court, and shall serve personally a copy of such summons upon such person, provided, that if such person so demands, he shall be taken forthwith before the District Judge in lieu of being given such summons. 
B.  The time specified in said summons to appear must be within a reasonable time after such person is served with said summons, unless the person shall demand an earlier hearing. 
C.  Appearance must be made by such person in person and not by mail or any other means, except that legal counsel may appear on behalf of such person as in any other misdemeanor violation and enter a plea on behalf of such person. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Oct. 20, 1969; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.025 - Sec. 25. 
NON-APPEARANCE. 
    In the event the person receiving said summons in the foregoing section fails to appear in District Court as required therein, such Inspector or said duly authorized employee issuing said summons, shall forthwith apply to the City Attorney for recommendation or order by said City Attorney for issuance of a warrant for the arrest of such person. 
(code eff. Oct. 1958; amend. Oct., 20, 1969; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.026 - Sec. 26. 
ISSUANCE OF WARRANT; DIRECT PROCEDURE. 
    Nothing contained herein shall prevent any such Inspector or said duly authorized employee from applying to the City Attorney for recommendation or order for issuance of a warrant without first having served a violation notice and summons upon any person, pursuant to the above provisions. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Oct. 20, 1969; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.027 - Sec. 27. 
NOTICE OF INSPECTOR; CITY CODE; REQUIREMENTS. 
    Nothing contained herein shall be construed as amending or changing any existing notice requirement in any other section of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Mount Clemens, or contained in any National Code of Ordinances adopted by said City. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Oct. 20, 1969; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.028 - Sec. 28. 
SUMMONS; SANITATION DIVISION. 
    Nothing contained herein shall be construed as preventing the Supervisor of Sanitation or employee duly authorized by him from issuing a violation summons as hereinbefore provided without the prerequisite of a violation notice for violations of Title 7, "Health and Safety" , of the Code of Ordinances. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Oct. 20, 1969; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.029 - Sec. 29. 
TRESPASS; PROHIBITION. 
(1)  Any person who shall wilfully enter upon the lands or premises of another without lawful authority, after having been forbidden so to do by the owner or occupant, agent, or servant of the owner or occupant, or any person being upon the land or premises of another, upon being notified to depart therefrom by the owner or occupant, the agent or servant of either, who without lawful authority neglects or refuses to depart therefrom, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2)  Any person violating this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by imprisonment in the County Jail for not more than 90 days or by a fine of not more than $500.00, or both, in the discretion of the Court. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. eff. Apr. 17, 1980; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.030 - VEHICLE CODE; UNIFORM CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Aug. 13, 1981; amend. eff. Feb. 19, 2008; amend. eff. Nov. 15, 2012 
An ordinance to adopt by reference the Uniform Traffic Code for Michigan Cities, Townships, and Villages. 
THE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS ORDAINS: 

20.031 - Sec. 1. 
UNIFORM TRAFFIC CODE ADOPTED. 
    The Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages promulgated by the Director of State Police as the same exists on January 1, 2005 is hereby adopted by reference as in this Ordinance modified. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 13, 1981; amend. eff. Feb. 19, 2008) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt UTC, MCL 257.951 et seq. 
20.032 - Sec. 2. 
REFERENCES IN CODE. 
    References in the Uniform Traffic Code for Michigan Cities, Townships, and Villages to "governmental unit" shall mean the City of Mount Clemens. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 13, 1981; amend. eff. Feb. 19, 2008) 
20.033 - Sec. 2. 
MICHIGAN VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED. 
    The Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.), and all future amendments and revisions to the Michigan Vehicle Code when they are effective in this state are incorporated by reference. MCL 257.625(1)(c) of the Motor Vehicle Code is specifically adopted by reference, pursuant to Public Act 7 of 2012. All references in said Michigan Vehicle Code to "local authorities" shall mean the City of Mount Clemens. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 13, 1981; Code 1980 § 20.038; amend. eff. Feb. 19, 2008; amend. eff. Nov. 15, 2012) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 117.3(k). 
20.034 - Sec. 3. 
PENALTIES. 
    The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code adopted by reference are hereby adopted as the penalties for violations of the corresponding provisions of this Ordinance, provided, however, that the City of Mount Clemens may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than 93 days, except that a violation of MCL 257.625(1)(c) is punishable by one or more of the following: 
(i)  Community service for not more than 360 hours. 
(ii)  Imprisonment for not more than 180 days. 
(iii)  A fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $700.00. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 13, 1981; Code 1980 § 20.039; amend. eff. Feb. 19, 2008; amend. eff. Nov. 15, 2012) 
20.035 - Sec. 4. 
MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY ACT ADOPTED. 
    The Motor Carrier Safety Act, Public Act No. 181 of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.), and all future amendments and revisions to the Motor Carrier Safety Act, are incorporated and hereby adopted by reference, as if set out fully in this chapter. 
(Amend. eff. Feb. 19, 2008) 
20.036 - Sec. 5. 
PENALTIES. 
    The penalties provided by the Motor Carrier Safety Act adopted by reference are hereby adopted as the penalties for violations of the corresponding provisions of this Ordinance, provided, however, that the City of Mount Clemens may not enforce any provision of the Motor Carrier Safety Act for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than 93 days. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 30, 1983; amend. eff. Jan. 1, 1992; amend. eff. Sept. 19, 1992; further amend eff. May 11, 1995; amend. eff. June 29, 1995; amend. eff. Oct, 31, 1996; amend. eff. Aug. 28, 1997; Rpld. eff. May 13, 2004; amend. eff. Feb. 19, 2008) 
20.037 - TRAFFIC CODE; UNIFORM CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. May 13, 2004; repealed eff. June 26, 2008 
20.040 - SPEED RESTRICTIONS ON THE CLINTON RIVER CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. July 28, 1994; repealed eff. Feb. 19, 2008 
20.050 - TRAFFIC CODE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend, Jan., 1978

20.056 - Sec. 6. 
PROPERTY BELONGING TO MOUNT CLEMENS COMMUNITY SCHOOL DISTRICT; PROHIBITION. 
    Every act prohibited under Title 3 of the said Code of Ordinances pertaining to the operation, parking without fees, and the speed of motor vehicles is hereby prohibited upon the property of the Board of Education of the Mount Clemens Community School District and subject to any and all penalties contained within said Code of Ordinances. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Apr. 6, 1966; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.060 - MARIJUANA ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. May 14, 1987 

20.061 - Sec. 1. 
POSSESSION AND USE OF MARIJUANA, PROHIBITION. 
    No person shall knowingly or intentionally possess or use the controlled substance known as marijuana unless the substance was obtained directly from, or pursuant to, a valid prescription or order of a practitioner while acting in the course of the practitioner's professional practice. 
(ord. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.062 - Sec. 2. 
DEFINITIONS. 
(a)  The term "marijuana" means all parts of the plant canabis sativa L., growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of the plant; and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the plant or its seeds or resin. It does not include the mature stalks of the plant, fiber produced from the stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the mature stalks, except the resin extracted therefrom, fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination. 
(b)  The term "practitioner" means: 
(1)  A prescriber or pharmacist, a scientific investigator as defined by rule of the administrator, or other person licensed, registered, or otherwise permitted to distribute, dispense, conduct research with respect to, or administer a controlled substance in the course of professional practice or research in this state. 
(2)  A pharmacy, hospital, or other institution or place of professional practice licensed, registered, or otherwise permitted to distribute, prescribe, dispense, conduct research with respect to, or administer a controlled substance in the course of professional practice or research in this state. 
(ord. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.063 - Sec. 3. 
PENALTY. 
    The violation of Section 20.061 of this Ordinance is a misdemeanor and upon conviction is punishable by a fine of up to $500.00 or imprisonment for a term not to exceed 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. 
(ord. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.064 
PROHIBITION OF MARIHUANA ESTABLISHMENTS ORDINANCE. 
20.065 - Sec. 1. 
SHORT TITLE. 
    This ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the City of Mount Clemens Prohibition of Marihuana Establishments Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 17, 2018) 
20.066 - Sec. 2. 
[PROHIBITION OF MARIHUANA ESTABLISHMENTS.] 
    Pursuant to the Michigan Regulation and Taxation of Marihuana Act, Section 6.1, the City of Mount Clemens elects to prohibit marihuana establishments within its boundaries. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 17, 2018) 
20.067 - Sec. 3. 
EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    This ordinance requires that it be immediately effective as is necessary for the preservation of public peace, health or safety, pursuant to Mount Clemens City Charter Section 10.134. 
20.068 - Sec. 4. 
SEVERABILITY. 
    If any subsection, clause, phrase, or portion of this Ordinance is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent portion of this Ordinance and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 17, 2018) 
20.069 - Sec. 5. 
REPEAL. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this Ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 17, 2018) 
20.070 - PROSTITUTION ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990; further amend. eff. May 29, 2003 

20.071 - Sec. 1. 
PROSTITUTION, DEFINITION. 
(a)  PROSTITUTION: Any act of knowingly accepting, receiving, levying or appropriating any payment, money, valuable thing or other form of consideration, in exchange for lewdness, moral perversion, or sexual activity. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990; further amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
20.072 - Sec. 2. 
GENERAL PROHIBITIONS. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, male or female, within the city to knowingly commit, engage in or offer to engage in a lewd act, an act of prostitution, or moral perversion, with another male or female, in exchange for accepting, receiving, levying or appropriating any payment, money, valuable thing or other form of consideration. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to secure or offer another for the purpose of committing a lewd act or an act of prostitution, assignation or moral perversion. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to be in or near any place frequented by the public or any public place for the purpose of inducing, enticing, or procuring another to commit a lewd act or an act of prostitution or moral perversion. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to knowingly transport or cause to be transported, any person to any place, by any means of conveyance, through or across the city, with the intent or purpose of inducing or enticing, another to commit a lewd act or an act of prostitution or moral perversion. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to direct or offer any person to any place of building for the purpose of committing any lewd act or act of prostitution or moral perversion. 
(f)  This section does not apply to law enforcement officers in the lawful performance of their duties as law enforcement officers. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990; further amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
20.073 - Sec. 3. 
ACCOSTING AND SOLICITING. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city, male or female, to accost, solicit, or invite another in any public place or in or from any building or vehicle by word, gesture or any other means, to commit the act of prostitution or to do any other lewd, immoral or perverse act. 
(b)  This section does not apply to law enforcement officers in the lawful performance of their duties as law enforcement officers. 
(amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions MCL 750.448. 
20.074 - Sec. 4. 
PATRONIZING OR KEEPING HOUSES OF ILL FAME. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, male or female, within the city to patronize, frequent, be found in or be an inmate of a house of ill fame or assignation or place for the practice of prostitution, lewdness or moral perversion. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to knowingly receive, admit, or offer to or agree to receive or admit any person into any place, structure house or building for the purpose of performing a lewd act or an act of prostitution or moral perversion or to knowingly permit any person to remain in any place, structure, house, or building for any such purpose. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to keep, maintain or operate, or aid and abet another in keeping, maintaining, or operating, a house of ill-fame, building or residence for the purpose of engaging in acts of prostitution. 
(amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCLA 750.449; MCLA 750.449a; MCLA 750.452. 
20.075 - Sec. 5. 
AIDERS AND ABETTORS. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, male or female, who shall aid, assist, or abet another to commit, or offer to another, any act prohibited by this Ordinance. 
(amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
20.076 - Sec. 6. 
PENALTY. 
    Violation of this Ordinance is a misdemeanor and upon conviction is punishable by a term of imprisonment of not more than 93 days, or a fine not to exceed $500.00, or both. 
(amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
20.080 - NUISANCE ABATEMENT ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990 

20.081 - Sec. 1. 
DECLARED NUISANCES. 
    Any building, vehicle boat, aircraft or place used for the purpose of lewdness or prostitution or gambling, or used by, or for the use of prostitutes or other disorderly persons, or used for the unlawful manufacture, storing, possessing, transporting, sale, keeping for sale, giving away, bartering, furnishing or otherwise disposing of any narcotic and/or hypnotic drug as defined by law or of any vinous, malt, brewed, fermented, spirituous or intoxicating liquors or any mixed liquors or beverages, any part of which is intoxicating, is hereby declared a nuisance and the furniture, fixtures and contents of any such building, motor vehicle, boat, aircraft, or place and all such intoxicating liquors therein are also declared a nuisance, and all such narcotic and/or hypnotic drugs and nuisances shall be enjoined and abated as hereinafter provided, and as provided in the Michigan Court Rules. Any person, or his servant, agent or employee who shall own, lease, conduct, or maintain any building, motor vehicle, boat, aircraft or place used for any of the purposes or by any of the persons above set forth or where any of the acts above enumerated are conducted, permitted or carried on, is guilty of maintaining a nuisance. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990) 
20.082 - Sec. 2. 
ACTION TO ABATE; PARTIES. 
    The City attorney of Mount Clemens, Michigan or the Macomb County prosecuting attorney (hereinafter "prosecuting attorney"), or any citizen of the City may maintain an action for equitable relief in the name of the City in the Macomb County Circuit Court (hereinafter "Court") to abate said nuisance and to perpetually enjoin any person, his servant, agent, or employee, who shall own, lease, conduct or maintain such building, motor vehicle, boat, aircraft or place, from permitting or suffering such building, motor vehicle, boat, or aircraft or place owned, leased, conducted or maintained by him to be used for any of the purposes or by any of the persons set forth in Section 1 of this Ordinance or for any of the acts enumerated in said section. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990) 
20.083 - Sec. 3. 
OWNER DEFINED; AUTHORITY OF COURT; CLOSING OF PREMISES; VEHICLES; DEFENDANTS. 
A.  An owner of the premises within the meaning of this Ordinance is deemed to be the grantee or vendee of the last recorded deed or contract which describes the premises, or any part thereof upon which any nuisance exists as heretofore defined, and the naming of such person a party defendant gives the Court authority to abate the nuisance by closing the premises and such defendant is subject to the order and judgment of the Court. 
B.  An owner of a motor vehicle, boat or aircraft within the meaning of this Ordinance is deemed to be the person in whose name the motor vehicle, boat or aircraft, is titled, and any chattel mortgagee, secured party or assignee thereof and other lien holder whose lien has been filed in the office of the register of deeds prior to the commencement of suit, and the plaintiff shall join such mortgagee, secured party, assignee or lien holder as a party defendant. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990) 
20.084 - Sec. 4. 
ADMISSIBLE EVIDENCE; UNNECESSARY PROOF; JUDGMENT AND ORDER. 
    In any action brought under this Ordinance, evidence of the general reputation of the building, motor vehicle, boat, aircraft or place is admissible for the purpose of proving the existence of the nuisance. 
A.  Proof of knowledge of the existence of the nuisance on the part of the defendants or any of them, is not required. 
B.  It is not necessary for the Court to find that the property involved was being used as and for a nuisance at the time of the hearing, or for the plaintiff to prove that the nuisance was continuing at the time of the filing of the complaint, if the complaint is filed within thirty (30) days after any act, any violation, or the existence of a condition herein defined as a nuisance presented itself. On finding that the material allegations of the complaint are true, the Court shall render judgment and enter an order of abatement as hereinafter provided. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990) 
20.085 - Sec. 5. 
CONTEMPT; PUNISHMENT; PROCEDURE; BAIL. 
    If any order or injunction granted under the provisions of this Ordinance is violated, the Court may summarily try and punish the offender for contempt, and the person so offending shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment in the Macomb County Jail for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the Court. Such violations shall be charged by a motion supported by affidavit, and the court, if satisfied of the sufficiency thereof, shall immediately issue a bench warrant for the arrest of such offender to bring him before such Court to answer for such misconduct. The Court may, in its discretion, permit such person arrested to give bail and fix the amount thereof pending hearing of the matters charged in such motion. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990) 
20.086 - Sec. 6. 
ORDER OF ABATEMENT; CLOSING OF BUILDING; REMOVAL OF CONTENTS, SALE, CONTEMPT; ORDER OF ABATEMENT. 
    If the existence of the nuisance is established in an action as provided in this Ordinance, an order of abatement shall be entered as part of the judgment in the case, which order shall direct the removal from the building or place of all furniture, fixtures and contents therein and shall direct the sale thereof and the effectual closing of the building or place against its use for any purpose, and so keeping it closed for a period for one (1) year, unless sooner released as provided in this Ordinance. 
    Disposition of the contents may be by public or private proceedings and may be made by way of one or more contracts. Sale or other disposition may be as a unit or in parcels and at anytime and place and on any terms, but every aspect of the disposition including the method, manner, time, place and terms must be commercially reasonable. Reasonable notification of the time and place of any public sale or reasonable notification of the time after which any private sale or other intended disposition is to be made shall be provided by the City, City attorney or prosecuting attorney (relying on information as is reasonably available to the City, City attorney or prosecuting attorney) to the owners, as defined in Section 3 of this Ordinance, unless the owner(s) have signed a statement renouncing or modifying the owner(s)' right to notification of sale. Owners without knowledge or notice of the unlawful use of the thing(s) identified as nuisances under this Ordinance may buy at any public sale. If the thing(s) being sold are of a type customarily sold in a recognized market or are of a type which customarily have widely distributed standard price quotations, owners without knowledge or notice of the unlawful use of the thing(s) may buy at a private sale. 
A.  MOTOR VEHICLES, BOATS AND AIRCRAFT. Any motor vehicle, boat, or aircraft found by the Court to be a nuisance within the meaning of this Ordinance, is subject to the same order of abatement and judgment as any furniture, fixtures and contents as herein provided and subject to the same terms regarding sale as set forth in this Section. 
B.  SALE OF PERSONALITY, COSTS, LIENS, BALANCE TO TREASURER. Upon the sale of any furniture, fixtures, contents, motor vehicle, boat or aircraft as provided in this section, the officer executing the order of the Court shall, after deducting the expenses of keeping such property and costs of such sale, (including, but not limited to, the reasonable expenses of taking, holding, preparing for sale, selling and the like, reasonable attorneys' fees, and costs incurred by the City) pay all liens according to their priorities which may be established by intervention or otherwise at the hearing or in other proceedings brought for that purpose as being bona fide and as having been created without the lienor having any knowledge or notice that such property was being used or was to be used for the maintenance of a nuisance as herein defined, and shall pay the balance to the City treasurer to be credited to the general fund of the City. 
C.  USE OF CLOSED BUILDING; CONTEMPT. If any person uses a building or place so directed to be closed, with knowledge that such building or place is closed by order of the Court, he shall be punished as for contempt, as provided in Section 5 of this Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990) 
20.087 - Sec. 7. 
LOSS OF PROPERTY EXEMPTIONS; LIABILITY OF OFFICERS. 
    Any person found guilty of maintaining a nuisance under the provisions of this Ordinance shall forfeit the benefit of all property exemptions, so far as the satisfaction of the order or judgment of the Court requires the same, and the taking and disposing of any property of the defendant or defendants by virtue of such order or judgment by any officer directed to execute the same is not a trespass nor shall such officers be liable either civilly or criminally therefor, if a property return of such order or judgment and accounting for such property is made to the court within ten (10) days after the order or judgment is executed. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990) 
20.088 - Sec. 8. 
DELIVERY OF PREMISES, TO OWNER; BOND, ABATEMENT, LIABILITY OF SURETIES; AGREEMENT TO DISCONTINUE ACTION TO ABATE FOR MOTOR VEHICLES, BOATS OR AIRCRAFT. 
A.  If the owner of such building or place pays all costs of the proceedings, and files a bond with sureties approved by the circuit judge in the penal sum of not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $50,000.00 conditioned that he/she will immediately abate the nuisance and prevent the same from being established or kept therein within a period of one (1) year from the date of the judgment, the court may order such premises to be delivered to the owner and if the bond is given and costs therein are paid before order of abatement, the action shall be thereby discontinued as to that building only. 
B.  LIABILITY OF SURETIES. If it appears to the Court that the conditions of the bond have been violated, the principal and sureties thereon are liable for the full penalty of the bond in an action brought in the name of the City; or upon motion in the action in which the bond was given. 
C.  AGREEMENT TO DISCONTINUE ABATEMENT ACTION AGAINST A MOTOR VEHICLE, BOAT OR AIRCRAFT . 
1.  If the owner who is the focus of an action to abate a nuisance under this Ordinance relating to a motor vehicle, boat or aircraft makes an offer of payment as a settlement or compromise and for the payment of costs and related expenses of keeping the property (including but not limited to, reasonable costs of any needed towing, transportation and/or storage of a motor vehicle, boat or aircraft, as well as any attorney's fees associated with the preparation and/or commencement of a nuisance abatement action) the city, after approval of the city commission, may accept such payment from said owner, and the city, through the city attorney or the prosecuting attorney, shall then discontinue any nuisance abatement action and render said motor vehicle, boat or aircraft available to said owner. 
2.  The city commission may, by resolution, authorize the Mount Clemens Chief of Police or his designee to negotiate and to accept payment from such owner as a settlement or compromise and for the payment of costs and related expenses of keeping the property (including but not limited to, reasonable costs of any needed towing, transportation and/or storage of a motor vehicle, boat or aircraft, as well as any attorneys' fees associated with the preparation and/or commencement of a nuisance abatement action) and the city commission may, also by resolution, authorize the Mount Clemens Chief of Police or his designee to, upon receipt of the owner's payment, turn over of the property to the owner and render said motor vehicle, boat or aircraft available to said owner. Upon settlement or compromise of the claim, the chief of police or his designee shall immediately forward to the commission a report of the settlement, including all such information as the city commission may, by resolution, direct. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 1990; ord. eff. Aug. 29, 1991) 
20.090 - EMERGENCY SERVICES COMPENSATION ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. June 29, 1995; amend. eff. Nov. 29, 2001 

20.091 - Sec. 1. 
PURPOSE. 
    This Ordinance shall be known as and may be recited as "The Emergency Services Compensation Ordinance." 
    The City of Mount Clemens finds that a significant number of motor vehicle and watercraft arrests involving accidents occurring in the City of Mount Clemens or City of Mount Clemens waters involving drivers/operators operating a motor vehicle or watercraft while under the influence of intoxicating liquor and/or a controlled substance. In addition, the City of Mount Clemens finds that motor vehicle and watercraft accidents involving drivers who are operating a motor vehicle or watercraft while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage and/or a controlled substance present a greater likelihood of personal injury and/or property damage. As a result, a significantly greater operational/financial burden is suffered by the City of Mount Clemens Police Department, Department of Public Works and Fire Departments and it is necessary to recover these increased emergency response costs. 
(ord. eff. June 29, 1995; further amend. eff. Nov. 29, 2001) 
20.092 - Sec. 2. 
DEFINITIONS. 
A.  "Emergency Response" shall mean: 
1.  Providing, sending and/or utilizing Department of Public Works, Police, Fire, and/or Rescue Personnel of the City of Mount Clemens, or by a private individual or corporation operating at the request or direction of the City, to an accident involving a motor vehicle or watercraft where one or more of the driver/operators were found to be operating the motor vehicle or watercraft while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or controlled substance or the combined influence of alcohol or a controlled substance; or 
2.  Stopping and arrest by a police officer of a motor vehicle driver or watercraft operator who was operating the motor vehicle or watercraft while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or controlled substance or the combined influence of alcohol or a controlled substance. 
B.  "Expense of Emergency Response" shall mean all direct and reasonable costs incurred in making an emergency response as set forth in A.1. and 2. aforereferenced, including, but not necessarily limited to, the costs of providing Police, Fire, Rescue and emergency medical services at the scene of the incident, which costs shall include the salary, wages and fringe benefits of the City of Mount Clemens personnel responding to the incident. The expense of an emergency response as set forth shall include the expense of conducting and analyzing preliminary chemical breath analysis tests and chemical tests of blood, urine and/or breath to determine the amount or presence of alcohol or controlled substances in the blood and the costs of processing or analyzing other physical evidence. 
(ord. eff. June 29, 1995; further amend. eff. Nov. 29, 2001) 
20.093 - Sec. 3. 
LIABILITY FOR EXPENSES. 
A.  Any person who operates a motor vehicle or watercraft while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, a controlled substance, or any combination thereof, in a manor so as to cause an emergency response as herein defined shall be responsible and/or liable for the expenses of that emergency response. 
B.  For purposes of this section, it shall be presumed that a person was operating a motor vehicle or watercraft under the influence of an intoxicating liquor when his or her physical or mental abilities are impaired to a degree that he or she no longer has the ability to operate a motor vehicle or watercraft with the caution characteristic of a sober person of ordinary prudence. Further, it shall be presumed that a person is under the influence of an intoxicating liquor if chemical analysis of that driver's blood, urine, or breath indicates that the amount of alcohol in the driver's blood was 0.07 percent or in excess of 0.07 percent. Any amount of a controlled substance determined by a urine, blood or other recognized and accepted test shall satisfy the "under the influence" requirement. 
(ord. eff. June 29, 1995; further amend. eff. Nov. 29, 2001) 
20.094 - Sec. 4. 
ADMINISTRATION AND PAYMENT OF EXPENSES. 
A.  A detailed invoice for payment of emergency, and/or other service expenses shall be promptly prepared and delivered by first class mail or personal service to person(s) deemed liable pursuant to this Ordinance. 
B.  A person who is liable for the payment shall make payment in full to the City of Mount Clemens Treasurer within ten days of receipt of the detailed invoice. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 2001) 
20.095 - Sec. 5. 
FAILURE TO PAY EXPENSES WITHIN TEN (10) DAYS. 
A.  A person who is liable for payment of expenses for emergency services, other services or both and who fails to make payment in full to the City of Mount Clemens Treasurer within ten days of receipt of a detailed invoice, shall be considered to have committed a civil infraction under the terms of the Michigan Vehicle Code being PA 300 of 1949, as amended. 
B.  Failure to make payment within ten days of receipt of invoice shall cause notification to be provided to the appropriate District Court together with a request that the invoice be given consideration at the time of determining sentence on the operating under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or controlled substance violation. 
C.  In addition, or as an alternative method of collection, the City of Mount Clemens may commence a civil action against an individual who is liable for payment of expenses for emergency, and other services when that individual fails to make payment in full to the City of Mount Clemens Treasurer within the period aforedescribed. 
D.  All proceeds realized by the City of Mount Clemens under this Ordinance shall be paid to the general fund for the purpose of reimbursement for the funds expended during the emergency response. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 2001) 
20.096 - Sec. 6. 
CIVIL LIABILITY. 
    The infraction encompassed by this Ordinance shall be construed to be civil in nature and shall not be construed to conflict, contravene, enlarge or reduce any criminal liability or other civil responsibility which may be imposed by a Judge under Michigan law for the identical offense. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 2001) 
20.097 - Sec. 7. 
REPEAL CLAUSE. 
    All Ordinances or parts of Ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 2001) 
20.098 - Sec. 8. 
SEVERABILITY. 
    If any portion of this Ordinance is for any reason declared invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate distinct and independent provisions and such declaration shall not affect the validity of the remainder, it being the intent of the City of Mount Clemens that the validity of this Ordinance be severable. 
(ord. eff. Nov. 29, 2001) 
20.100 - TOBACCO AND VAPOR PRODUCTS ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. July 1, 1999; further amend. eff. July 11, 2002; repealed eff. Sept. 12, 2018; ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018 

20.101 - Sec. 1. 
SHORT TITLE AND PURPOSE. 
    This Ordinance shall be known and cited as the City of Mount Clemens Tobacco and Vapor Products Ordinance. The purpose of the ordinance is to protect the public health, safety and general welfare of property and persons in the City by prohibiting persons under Eighteen (18) years of age from possessing tobacco products and vapor products, and prohibiting the sale of tobacco products and vaping products to persons under the age of Eighteen (18) years of age. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018) 
20.102 - Sec. 2. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    "Alternative Nicotine Product" shall mean a noncombustible product containing nicotine that is intended for human consumption, whether chewed, absorbed, dissolved, or ingested by any other means. 
    "Minor" shall mean an individual who is less than Eighteen (18) years of age. 
    "Person who sells Vapor Products at Retail" shall mean a person whose ordinary course of business consists, in whole or in part, of the retail sale of vapor products. 
    "Person who sells Tobacco Products at Retail" shall mean a person whose ordinary course of business consists, in whole or in part, of the retail sale of tobacco products subject to state sales tax. 
    "Possess a Tobacco Product or Vapor Product" shall mean either actual physical control of the tobacco product or vapor product without necessarily owning that product, or the right to control the product even though it is in a different room or place than where the person is physically located. 
    "Public Place" shall mean a public street, sidewalk, or park or any area open to the general public in a publicly owned or operated building or premises, or in a public place of business. 
    "Tobacco Product" shall mean a product that contains tobacco and is intended for human consumption, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, non-cigarette smoking tobacco, or smokeless tobacco, as those terms are defined in section 2 of the tobacco products tax act, 1993 PA 327, MCL 205.422, and cigars. 
    "Vapor Product" shall mean all noncombustible products that employ a heating element, power source, electronic circuit, or other electronic, chemical, or mechanical means, regardless of shape or size, that can be used to produce vapor from nicotine or an alternate hazardous substance in a solution or other form. Vapor product includes an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, or similar product or device and a vapor cartridge or other container of nicotine or other hazardous substance in a solution or other form that is intended to be used with or in an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, or similar product or device. Vapor product does not include a product regulated as a drug or device by the United States Food and Drug Administration. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018) 
20.103 - Sec. 3. 
PURCHASE, CONSUMPTION OR POSSESSION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS BY MINORS. 
A.  PROHIBITED. A minor shall not do any of the following: 
1.  Purchase or attempt to purchase a tobacco product, vapor product or alternative nicotine product. 
2.  Possess or attempt to possess a tobacco product, vapor product or alternative nicotine product. 
3.  Use a tobacco product, vapor product or alternative nicotine product. 
4.  Use a tobacco product, vapor product or alternative nicotine product in a public place. 
5.  Present or offer to an individual a purported proof of age that is false, fraudulent, or not actually his or her own proof of age for the purpose of purchasing, attempting to purchase, possessing, or attempting to possess a tobacco product, vapor product or alternative nicotine product. 
B.  EXEMPTIONS. This section does not apply to a minor participating in any of the following: 
1.  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives a tobacco product or vapor product under the direction of the minor's employer and with the prior approval of the local prosecutor's office as part of an employer-sponsored internal enforcement action. 
2.  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives tobacco or vapor product under the direction of the state police or a local police agency as part of an enforcement action. 
3.  The handling or transportation of a tobacco product or vapor product by a minor under the terms of that minor's employment. This subsection shall not be construed to exempt from liability minors in possession of tobacco products or personal use or consumption at any time. 
C.  PENALTY. An individual who violates this Section is responsible for a civil infraction punishable by a fine of not more than $50.00 for the first violation. For a second or subsequent violation, an individual is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00, or by imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018) 
20.104 - Sec. 4. 
FURNISHING TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO MINORS. 
A.  PROHIBITED. A person shall not sell, offer to sell, give, or furnish a tobacco product, vapor product or alternative nicotine product to a person who is less than 18 years of age, including, but not limited to, through a vending machine. 
B.  VERIFICATION REQUIRED. Before selling, offering for sale, giving, or furnishing a tobacco product, vapor product or alternative nicotine product to an individual, a person shall verify that the individual is at least 18 years of age by examining a government issued photographic identification that establishes that the individual is at least 18 years of age, unless the seller has some other conclusive basis for determining the buyer is over the age of Eighteen (18) years. In the event the seller does not request and examine identification from the purchaser, the seller shall be deemed to have not had "a conclusive basis" under this section, if the purchaser is in fact a minor. Identification shall be by means of an officially issued card accepted as proof of age in the State of Michigan. 
C.  AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE. It is an affirmative defense that the defendant had enforced at the time of arrest and continues to have enforced a written policy to prevent the sale of tobacco products including vapor products, to a person under Eighteen (18) years of age and that the defendant enforce and continues to enforce the policy. If a defendant proposes to offer evidence of the affirmative defense, it shall file and serve a notice of such defense in writing, with the court serving a notice on the city attorney not less than fourteen (14) days prior to the date scheduled for trial. If the city attorney proposes to offer testimony to rebut the affirmative defense, the city attorney shall file notice of rebuttal, in writing, with the court and serve a copy of the notice on the defendant not less than seven (7) days prior to the trial date, setting forth name and address of each rebuttal witness. 
D.  SALE OF NON-PACKAGED CIGARETTES PROHIBITED. No person or entity who sells tobacco products at retail, shall sell cigarettes in packages of less than twenty cigarettes or otherwise not packaged with a Food and Drug Administration approval warning. Any violation is a misdemeanor under this Ordinance. 
E.  PENALTY. A person who violates this Section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $50.00 for the first violation. For a second or subsequent violation, a person is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00, or by imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018) 
20.105 - Sec. 5. 
PROHIBITION OF VAPOR PRODUCT OR ALTERNATIVE SMOKE PRODUCT IN SMOKE FREE PLACES. 
A.  It shall be a violation of the Ordinance to use a vapor product or alternative smoke product in any place within the City of Mount Clemens where smoking of tobacco products is prohibited by law. 
B.  No person, employer, or entity shall knowingly permit the use of vapor products or alternative smoke products in an area under the legal or de facto control of that Person, Employer, or Nonprofit Entity and in which smoking is prohibited by law. 
C.  PENALTY. A person who violates this Section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $50.00 for the first violation. For a second or subsequent violation, a person is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00, or by imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018) 
20.106 - Sec. 6. 
SEVERABILITY. 
    If any article, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this ordinance is held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of remaining portions of the ordinance, it being the intent of the City that this ordinance shall be fully severable. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018) 
20.107 - Sec. 7. 
REPEAL. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this Ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018) 
20.108 - Sec. 8. 
    This ordinance shall become immediately effective upon publication. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 12, 2018) 
20.110 - MEDICAL MARIHUANA FACILITIES CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Dec. 27, 2018 

20.111 - Sec. 1. 
SHORT TITLE. 
    This Ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the City of Mount Clemens Medical Marihuana Facilities Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 27, 2018) 
20.112 - Sec. 2. 
LEGISLATIVE INTENT. 
    The purpose of this article is to exercise the police regulatory, and licensing powers of the City of Mount Clemens by licensing and regulating grower facilities, provisioning centers, safety compliance facilities, processor facilities, and secure transporter facilities to the extent permissible under the Michigan Marihuana Facilities Licensing Act (PA 281 of 2016) and to protect the public health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the City of Mount Clemens. 
    The city finds that the activities described in article III are significantly connected to the public health, safety, security and welfare of its citizens and it is therefore necessary to regulate and enforce safety, security, fire, policing, health and sanitation practices related to such activities and also to provide a method to defray administrative costs incurred by such regulation and enforcement. The city finds that it is necessary to protect the residential neighborhoods by limiting the location and the concentration of the types of medical marihuana facilities to specified areas within the city. 
    It is not the intent of article III to diminish, reduce, or restrict the rights of a qualified patient or primary caregiver otherwise authorized by the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 27, 2018) 
20.113 - Sec. 3. 
DEFINITIONS, INTER- 
PRETATION AND CONFLICTS. 
    For the purposes of chapter: 
(a)  All activities related to marihuana, including those related to a grower facility, provisioning center, secure transporter facility, processor facility, or a safety compliance facility shall be in compliance with the rules of the medical marihuana licensing board, the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs or any successor agency, the rules and regulations of the City of Mount Clemens, the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act and the Medical Marihuana Facilities Licensing Act. 
(b)  Any use which purports to have engaged in the cultivation or processing of marihuana into an usable form, or the distribution of marihuana, or the testing of marihuana either prior to or after enactment of chapter, but without obtaining the required licensing set forth in chapter, shall be deemed to be an illegally established use and therefore not entitled to legal nonconforming status under the provisions of chapter, Code of Ordinances, the City Zoning Ordinances or state law. 
(c)  As of the effective date of this article, marihuana is classified as a schedule 1 controlled substance under federal law, which makes it unlawful to manufacture, distribute, cultivate, produce, possess dispense or transport marihuana. Nothing in this article is intended to grant immunity from any criminal prosecution under federal law. 
(d)  By accepting a permit issued pursuant to chapter, the permit holder waives and releases the city, its officers, elected officials and employees from any liability for injuries, damages or liabilities of any kind that result from any arrest or prosecution of medical marihuana facility owners, operators, employees, clients or customers for a violation of state or federal laws, rules or regulations. 
(e)  By accepting a permit issued pursuant to the chapter, all permit holders agree to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the city, its officers, elected officials, employees and insurers, against all liability, claims or demands arising on account of bodily injury, sickness, disease, death, property loss or damage or any other loss of any kind, including, but not limited to, any claim of diminution of property value by a property owner whose property is located in proximity to a permitted operating facility, arising out of a, claimed of have arisen out of, or in any manner connected with the operation of a medical marihuana facility or use of a product cultivated, processed, distributed or sold that is subject to the permit, or any claim based on an alleged injury to business or property by reason of a claimed violation of the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), 18 U.S.C. §1964(c). 
(f)  By accepting a permit issued pursuant to chapter, a permit holder agrees to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the city, its officers, elected officials, employees and insurers, against all liability, claims, penalties, or demands arising on account of any alleged violation of the federal Controlled Substances Act, 21 U.S.C. §801 et seq. or Article 7 of the Michigan Public Health Code, MCL 333.7101 et seq. 
(g)  The following terms shall have the definitions given: 
    Application means an application for a permit under this article and include all supplemental documentation attached or required to be attached thereto; the person filing the application shall be known as the "applicant." 
    Chapter means this chapter of the Mount Clemens City Code of Ordinances. 
    City means the City of Mount Clemens, Michigan. 
    Church means an entire building set apart for purposes of public worship, which is tax exempt under state law, and in which religious services are held, and the entire building structure of which is kept for that use and not put to any other use inconsistent with that use. 
    Commission means the City Commission of Mount Clemens, Michigan. 
    Cultivation or cultivate means (1) all phases of growth of marihuana from seed to harvest, and drying, trimming, and curing; or (2) preparing, packaging or repackaging, labeling or relabeling of any form of marihuana. 
    Department means the Michigan State Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs. 
    Grower means a licensee that is a commercial entity located in this state that cultivates dries, trims, or cures and packages marihuana for sale to a processor or provisioning center. 
    License means a current and valid license for a commercial medical marihuana facility issued by the State of Michigan. 
    Licensee means a person holding a state operating license under the MMFLA. 
    Location means the particular building or buildings within a permitted property on which the permit holder will be authorized to conduct the medical marihuana facility(s) activities pursuant to the permit. 
    Marihuana means that termed as defined in section 7106 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.7106. 
    Marihuana board means the medical marihuana licensing board created pursuant to Part 3 of the MMFLA. 
    Medical marihuana facility(ies) means any facility, establishment and/or center that is required to be licensed under chapter including a grower, processor, safety compliance facility, and secure transporter. 
    MMFLA means the Medical Marihuana Facilities Licensing Act, MCL 333.2701, et seq. as amended from time to time. 
    MMMA means the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act, MCL 333.26421 et seq. as amended from time to time. 
    MTA means the Marihuana Tracking Act, MCL 333.27901 et seq. as amended from time to time. 
    Ordinance means the ordinance adopting this chapter. 
    Permit means the formal document of approval issued by the city under this chapter, which shall grant to a permit holder the ability to obtain a license(s) for a commercial medical marihuana facility(s), only for and limited to, a specific location. 
    Permit application refers to the requirements and procedures set forth in sections 22-96 and 22-97 [this chapter]. 
    Permit holder means the person that holds a current and valid permit issued under this article. 
    Permitted property means the real property comprised of a lot, parcel or other designated unit of real property (ie; property address) upon which the location is situated. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, limited partnership, limited liability partnership, limited liability limited partnership, trust, or other legal entity. 
    Processor or processor facility means a commercial entity that purchases marihuana from a grower and that extracts resin from the marihuana or creates a marihuana-infused product for sale and transfer in packaged form to a provisioning center. 
    Provisioning center means a commercial entity that purchases marihuana from a grower or processor and sells, supplies, or provides marihuana to registered qualifying patients, directly or through the patients' registered primary caregivers. Provisioning center includes any commercial property where marihuana is sold at retail to registered qualifying patients or registered primary caregivers. A noncommercial location used by a primary caregiver to assist a qualifying patient connected to the caregiver through the department's marihuana registration process in accordance with the MMMA is not a provisioning center for the purposes of this article. 
    Safety compliance facility means a commercial entity that receives marihuana from a medical marihuana facility or registered primary caregiver, tests it for contaminants and for tetrahydrocannabinol and other cannabinoids, returns the test results, and may return the marihuana to the medical marihuana facility. 
    Secure transporter means a commercial entity that stores marihuana, marihuana infused products and transports marihuana and marihuana infused product between medical marihuana facilities for a fee. 
    Stakeholder means, with respect to a trust, the beneficiaries, with respect to a limited liability company, the managers or members, with respect to a corporation, whether profit or non-profit, the officers, directors, or shareholders, and with respect to a partnership or limited liability partnership, the partners, both general and limited. 
    State means the State of Michigan. 
(h)  Any term defined by the MMMA or the Medical Marihuana Facilities Licensing Act and not defined in chapter shall have the definition given in the MMMA or the Medical Marihuana Facilities Act. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 27, 2018) 
20.114 - Sec. 4. 
LOCATIONS AND PERMITS AUTHORIZED. 
(1)  The city shall limit the number of permits and locations upon which medical marihuana facilities are hereby authorized under this article to the following: 
_____ 
Type of Facility Number Authorized a. Grower Facility:  Class A - 500 plants:    1  Class B - 1,000 plants:    1  Class C - 1,500 plants:    1 location, uncapped licenses b. Processor:    2 c. Provisioning Center:    2 d. Safety Compliance Facilities:    2 e. Secure Transporters:    2  
  
_____
    The city commission may review and amend these numbers by resolution as it determines to be advisable and in the best interest of the city. 
(2)  A grow facility, provisioning center and a processor may co-locate at the same Location. 
(3)  A grower that has been issued a class C license and has applied to stack license(s) at a location shall apply for and obtain a separate permit from the city for each license stacked at a location. 
(4)  This article does not apply to, regulate or prohibit any protected patient or caregiver conduct pursuant to MMMA. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 27, 2018) 
20.115 - Sec. 5. 
Permit Required. 
A.  No person shall own or operate a medical marihuana facility within the city without first applying for and receiving a permit from the city clerk's office and must also obtain a license from the State of Michigan. 
B.  A medical marihuana facility shall operate pursuant to the requirements of chapter and shall comply at all times with the MMMA, MMFLA, MTA and the general rules of the department, as they may be amended from time to time. 
C.  The city shall assess an annual non-refundable permit fee and or renewal fee of $5,000.00. The annual non-refundable fee shall be due and payable with the application for a permit and upon the application for a renewal of any such permit under chapter. Applicant shall also pay any certificate of zoning fees, certificate of occupancy fees and inspection fees to defray the costs incurred by the city for inspection, administration and enforcement of the local regulations regarding the medical marihuana facilities. 
D.  A medical marihuana facility must be registered with the building department as part of its certificate of compliance as to be inspected by the zoning, building, electrical, mechanical and plumbing inspectors and the fire department and Macomb County Sheriff's Office for compliance with applicable local and state laws and codes. The medical marihuana facility must pass annual safety inspections for compliance with the requirement of chapter. 
E.  A permit and a renewal permit shall not confer any vested rights or reasonable expectation of subsequent renewal on the applicant or permit holder and shall remain valid only for one year. A permit issued under chapter is conditioned on the approval of the applicant by the state pursuant to the MMFLA. 
F.  All applicants for a permit or renewal must be current on taxes and any other financial obligation to the city. 
G.  Each year, any pending applications for renewal or amendment of existing permits shall be reviewed and granted or denied before application for new permits are considered. 
H.  It is the sole and exclusive responsibility of each permit holder or person applying to be a permit holder at all times during the application period and during its operation to immediately provide the city with all material changes in any information submitted on an application and any other changes that may materially affect any license or its permit. 
I.  No permit issued under chapter may be assigned or transferred to any person unless the assignee or transferee has submitted an application and all required fees under chapter and has been granted a permit by the city and approved by the state. No permit issued under chapter is transferrable to any other location. 
J.  The permit issued under chapter, as well as the license shall be prominently displayed at the location in a place where it can be easily viewed by the public, law enforcement, city officials and or agents and marihuana board authorized agents. Failure to maintain or display a current permit and license shall be a violation of chapter. 
K.  Acceptance by the permit holder of a permit constitutes consent by the permit holder and its owners, officers, managers, agent and employees for any state, federal or local law enforcement to conduct random and unannounced inspections of the facility without a search warrant, and all articles of property in that facility at any time.
