The Parking Violations Bureau is authorized to collect any penalties due hereunder in any appropriate manner, including but not limited to, the use of a third party or agency. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 30, 1982; amend. March 29, 1984; further amend. eff. July 30, 1987; further amend. eff. Oct. 29, 1987; further amend. eff. Dec. 31, 1987; further amend. eff. July 26, 2001; further amend. eff. March 14, 2002(1); further amend. eff. March 26, 2009; further amend eff. July 15, 2011) 
20.212 - Sec. 12. 
PENALTY. 
A.  Any person who violates any provision of Section 20.209, Sec. 9, shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
B.  Except as herein otherwise provided, any person who violates any provision of this Ordinance shall be guilty of a civil infraction. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 30, 1982; amend. eff. May 14, 1987; further amend. eff. July 26, 2001; further amend. eff. March 26, 2009; further amend. eff. July 15, 2011) 
20.213 - Sec. 13. 
PARKING VIOLATIONS BUREAU. 
    In conformity with Section 8395 of Public Act No. 236 of 1961 (MCL 600.8395), there is hereby created a Mount Clemens Parking Violations Bureau, established to accept pleas in parking violation cases, and to collect and retain parking fines pursuant to the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 30, 1982; further amend. eff. July 26, 2001; further amend. eff. March 26, 2009; further amend. eff. July 15, 2011) 
20.214 - Sec. 14. 
TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS BUREAU. 
    In conformity with Section 8391 of Public Act No. 236 of 1961 (MCL 600.8391), the City of Mount Clemens, as a district control unit of the 41-B District Court, hereby approves the establishment of a Traffic Violations Bureau within the district court, under the direction and supervision of the chief judge of the district. The bureau shall make a monthly accounting of fines and costs collected to the City Finance Director. 
(amend. eff. July 15, 2011) 
20.215 - Sec. 15. 
IMPOUNDING AND IMMOBILIZATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES. 
A.  A member of the sheriff's office may impound or immobilize by use of a wheel-lock device or otherwise a vehicle parked in the city in all instances where: 
(1)  The owner has failed to answer six (6) or more parking violation notices or citations; and 
(2)  The owner has been given at least three days' notice sent to the owner at the address according to the vehicle registration, notifying said owner that he has failed to answer six or more outstanding parking violation notices or citations. 
B.  An owner may recover an impounded or immobilized vehicle upon: 
(1)  Payment of all outstanding parking violations and citations. Said payment to be made at the offices of the City Traffic Violations Bureau during regular business hours, 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. daily, except weekends and holidays; and 
(2)  Payment of towing and storage fees to the towing agent. 
C.  Nothing in this section shall prevent the enforcement and collection of fines and other penalties for failure to answer parking violation notices or citations. 
(Amend. eff. Sept. 13, 2013) 
20.216 - Sec. 16. 
RESERVED. 
    An ordinance effective March 26, 2009, repealed section 20.215, regarding handicapped parking; prohibitions; as derived from an ordinance eff. Sept. 30, 1982 and further amend. eff. July 26, 2001. This section has been reserved at the discretion of the editor. 
(amend. eff. July 15, 2011) 
20.217 - Sec. 17. 
CITY MANAGER; PARKING DUTIES. 
    The City Manager shall, at his/her discretion, mark off and designate sufficient parking spaces in parking-metered zone areas for physically handicapped persons. 
(ord. eff. Sept. 30, 1982; further amend. eff. July 26, 2001; further amend. eff. March 26, 2009; amend. eff. July 15, 2011) 
20.218 - Sec. 18. 
CONNECTION WITH MICHIGAN VEHICLE CODE. 
    All of the provisions herein relating to parking meter regulations and their enforcement shall be read in conjunction with the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.). If any clause, paragraph, or section of this Ordinance is in conflict with the provisions of the Michigan Vehicle Code, then the provisions of this Ordinance shall apply. 
(ord. eff. September 6, 1999; further amend. eff. July 26, 2001; further amend. eff. March 26, 2009; further amend. eff. July 15, 2011) 
20.219 - Sec. 19. 
REMOVING PARKED OR STANDING VEHICLES FROM PRIVATE PARKING AREAS. 
A.  No owner or operator of any vehicle shall park or leave said vehicle unattended on any private parking lot, space, way, or alley without the express or implied consent, authorization, or ratification of the owner, holder, occupant, lessee, agent or trustee of such property. 
B.  It shall be the duty of the parking enforcement officer or police officers to issue a notice of violation of subsection a. in the same manner as provided for the issuance of violations under Section 20.211, "Parking Meters." 
C.  Whenever an owner or operator of any vehicle shall park or leave said vehicle unattended on any private lot, space, way or alley without the express or implied consent, authorization or ratification of the owner, holder, occupant, lessee, agent or trustee of such property, the said owner, holder, occupant, lessee, agent or trustee of such property may sign a criminal complaint therefor and, upon a warrant being issued pursuant to said complaint, the said vehicle may be impounded by the City or its duly authorized agent. No such impounded vehicle shall be returned to the operator or owner thereof unless said operator or owner first pays the expenses of impounding and storing such vehicle which expense shall in no way affect the imposition of any civil infraction fine for violation of this section. 
D.  Anything to the contrary notwithstanding contained in this section, no vehicle shall be removed or ticketed or impounded as herein provided, unless such private parking lot, space, way or alley is legally and plainly designated as such by appropriate sign or placard and registered with the City. 
E.  In any proceeding for violation of the provisions of this Ordinance, the registration plate displayed on the motor vehicle shall be prima facie evidence that the owner of such motor vehicle, is the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the place where such violation occurred. 
F.  Any person who violates any provision of this Ordinance shall be guilty of a civil infraction, and the Mount Clemens Parking Violations Bureau is hereby vested with the jurisdiction of enforcement under Section 20.213. 
(ord. eff. Apr. 12, 1984; further amend. eff. July 26, 2001; further amend. eff. March 26, 2009; further amend eff. July 15, 2011) 
20.250 - LICENSING CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 

20.251 - Sec. 1. 
BUSINESS LICENSES REQUIRED. 
    No person shall, directly or indirectly, operate, conduct, maintain or manage any business or premises for which any license or permit if required by any provision of this Ordinance or code without first procuring a license or permit from the City in the manner prescribed in this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
Cross reference- For City authority to license, regulate and control businesses and occupations, see Char., sec. 11 (12). 
20.252 - Sec. 2. 
SAME; STATE LICENSE, NOT EXEMPTION. 
    The fact that a license or permit has been granted to any person by the State to engage in the operation, conduct, maintenance or management of any business or premises shall not exempt such person from the necessity of obtaining a license or permit from the City, if such license is required by this Ordinance or Code. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.253 - Sec. 3. 
APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; OATH, CONTENTS. 
    Each person required to procure a license from the City shall make application for said license to the City Clerk in the form and manner prescribed by him, and shall state, under oath, such facts as may be required for, or applicable to, the granting of such license, including the following: 
A.  The full names, business addresses and residence addresses of all owners, proprietors, officers, managers and local employees of applicant's business; and, if the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of each officer. 
B.  The place or places in the city where it is proposed to maintain applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business be conducted. 
C.  The nature, character and quality of the goods, wares, merchandise or services to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the City. 
D.  The nature and kind of business which applicant proposes to conduct, and the manner of operating same. 
E.  A list of all assumed, trade or firm names under which applicant intends to do business. 
F.  The nature and character of advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers. 
G.  Whether the applicant or any person conducting or managing applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any Municipal Ordinance, and, if so, full particulars in connection therewith. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.254 - Sec. 4. 
EXPIRATION DATE, EXCEPTION. 
    The license year shall terminate on the first day of June at 12:00 midnight next after the issuance of such license; provided, however, that whenever the provisions of this Ordinance or Code permit the issuance of licenses for periods of less than one year, the expiration date shall be indicated on the face of the license. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. no. 1018 eff. May 20, 1960; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.255 - Sec. 5. 
STATE LICENSE LAWS; COMPLIANCE PREREQUISITE TO ISSUANCE OF CITY LICENSE. 
    No license or permit required by this Ordinance or Code shall be issued to any person who is required to have a license or permit from the State, until such person shall submit evidence of such state license or permit and proof that all fees appertaining thereto have been paid. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.256 - Sec. 6. 
COMPLIANCE WITH CODE REQUIRED. 
    No license shall be granted to any applicant therefor until such applicant has complied with all of the provisions of this Ordinance and Code pertaining to the business for which application for the license is made, nor shall any license be granted whenever the approval of any Officer of the City is required prior to the issuance thereof until such approval is made. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.257 - Sec. 7. 
PAYMENT OF FEES. 
    No license shall be issued until the fees as set forth in this Ordinance or Code shall have been paid by the applicant. All annual license fees are due and payable on June 1 of each year. If not paid prior to June 30th, the license fee shall be double. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by Ord. 1018, eff. May 25, 1960; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.258 - Sec. 8. 
PERSONS IN DEFAULT TO CITY; LICENSE, ISSUANCE PROHIBITED. 
    No license shall be issued to any person who is in default to the City on any accrued obligation due and owing to said City. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by Ord. 1019, eff. June 30, 1960; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.259 - Sec. 9. 
EXEMPTION FROM PAYMENT OF FEE. 
    No license fee shall be required from any person exempt from payment of the fee by State or Federal Law. Such persons shall comply with all other provisions of this Ordinance and Code. The City Clerk shall, in all such cases, issue to such persons licenses which are clearly marked as to said exemption and the reason therefor. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.260 - Sec. 10. 
REFUSAL TO ISSUE LICENSE; REVOCATION, CAUSES. 
    Licenses requested under this Ordinance and Code may be refused by the City Manager, and licenses issued may be revoked by the City Manager at any time, for any of the following causes: 
A.  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
B.  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the operation of the business; 
C.  Conducting a business in an unlawful manner or in such manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, morals, safety or welfare of the public; 
D.  The failure or inability of the applicant to meet and satisfy the requirements and provisions of this Ordinance and Code. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.261 - Sec. 11. 
SUSPENSION, REVOCATION; NOTICE REQUIRED, SERVICE. 
    Written notice of suspension or revocation of license, stating the cause thereof, shall be delivered to the licensee personally or mailed to his address stated in the application for license. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.262 - Sec. 12. 
SAME; HEARING, DEMAND; REVIEW, COMMISSION POWERS. 
    Any person whose license is revoked or suspended, or any person whose request for a license is refused, shall have the right to a hearing before the City Commission, provided that a written request therefor is filed with the City Clerk within ten days following the delivery or mailing of notice of revocation or suspension or within ten days following such refusal. 
    The City Commission may reverse any refusal to issue a license or any revocation of a license, and the City Commission may grant or reinstate any license. No person shall operate any business during any time when his license or permit therefor has been suspended, revoked or cancelled. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.263 - Sec. 13. 
RENEWAL OF LICENSE, CONSIDERED SAME AS ORIGINAL APPLICATION. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Ordinance or Code, an application for renewal of a license shall be considered in the same manner as an original application. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.264 - Sec. 14. 
CARRYING LICENSE; DISPLAY; REQUIREMENTS. 
    No licensee shall fail to carry any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance or Code upon his person at all times when engaged in the operation, conduct or maintenance of any business for which the license was granted; except that whenever such business is operated, conducted or maintained at a fixed place or establishment, said license shall be displayed at all times in some conspicuous location in his place of business. The licensee shall produce the license for examination when applying for a renewal thereof or when requested to do so by any Police Officer or by any person representing the issuing authority. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.265 - Sec. 15. 
DISPLAY OF LICENSE REQUIRED ON DEVICE OR VEHICLE. 
    No licensee shall fail to display conspicuously on each vehicle or mechanical device or machine required to be licensed by this Ordinance or Code such tags or stickers as are furnished by the City Clerk and required by this Ordinance or Code. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.266 - Sec. 16. 
EXPIRED OR DUPLICATE LICENSE; DISPLAY PROHIBITED. 
    No person shall display any expired, suspended or revoked license, or any license for which a duplicate has been issued. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.267 - Sec. 17. 
LICENSES NON-TRANSFERABLE. 
    No license or permit issued under the provisions of this Ordinance or Code shall be transferrable. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.268 - Sec. 18. 
BUSINESS PREMISES; NIGHT LIGHT REQUIRED. 
    Every office or business establishment, located on the ground or first floor of any building, shall keep a night light burning during the hours such premises are closed until they are again re-opened. Said light shall be of sufficient wattage to illuminate the interior of such premises in order that a clear view of the interior may be obtained from outside such premises. The provisions of this section shall not apply to factories or unoccupied premises. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.269 - Sec. 19. 
WEIGHING OR MEASURING DEVICES; APPROVAL REQUIRED. 
    No licensee shall use any weighing or measuring device in the conduct of his business, or have such device in his possession, unless such device shall have been approved by the City Sealer of Weights and Measures. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
Cross reference- For other provisions of this Code relative to weights and measures, see 12.301, Sec. 1 et seq., supra. 
20.270 - Sec. 20. 
ACTUAL WEIGHTS AND MEASURES TO EQUAL PURPORTED QUANTITIES. 
    No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any article or commodity unless the weight or measure of the same shall be actually equal to the weight of measure purported. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.271 - Sec. 21. 
DEFECTIVE, DETERIORATED, ETC., MERCHANDISE; REQUIREMENTS AND PROHIBITIONS. 
    No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any defective, faulty, incomplete or deteriorated articles of merchandise, unless the goods are so represented to prospective customers. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.272 - Sec. 22. 
POOL AND BILLIARD ESTABLISHMENTS; LICENSE REQUIRED. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.273 - Sec. 23. 
SAME; CLOSING HOURS. 
    All pool or billiard establishments shall close at 1:00 a.m. and not reopen until 8:00 a.m. on Mondays, Tuesday, Wednesdays and Thursdays, and shall close at 2:00 a.m. and not reopen until 8:00 a.m. on Fridays and Saturdays, and shall not open on Sundays until 12 noon and shall close Sundays at 2:00 a.m. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. June 1, 1966; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.274 - Sec. 24. 
POOL AND BILLIARD ESTABLISHMENTS; MINORS; AGE, RESTRICTION. 
A.  No child under the age of 15 years shall be permitted, caused or suffered to be present in, frequent, or remain in or on, said pool or billiard premises after the hour of 10:00 p.m. on Sundays, Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays, or 10:30 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays, unless such child is accompanied by his parent or guardian or some adult person delegated by his parent or guardian to accompany such child, or is upon an errand or duty under the direction of his parent or guardian, or unless the employment of such child requires that he be upon such premises during the nighttime after such specified hours. 
B.  (Repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Dec. 20, 1971; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.275 - Sec. 25. 
POOL & BILLIARD ESTABLISHMENT; OBSTRUCTIONS TO PUBLIC VIEW PROHIBITED. 
    No owner or operator of any pool or billiard establishment shall permit on the premises any obstruction of the public view by the use of drawn shades or blinds or screens, either permanent or movable. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.276 - Sec. 26. 
BOWLING ALLEYS, LICENSE REQUIRED. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.277 - Sec. 27. 
BOWLING ALLEYS; CLOSING HOURS. 
    No licensee shall permit bowling on Sunday, except during the hours designated for sale of alcoholic beverages under the rules and regulations of the Michigan Liquor Control Commission. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.278 - Sec. 28. 
THEATRES; LICENSE REQUIRED. 
    No person shall conduct, maintain or operate any theatre without first obtaining a license and paying the license fee as required by this Ordinance. No such license shall be granted except upon approval of the Police Chief, the Fire Chief and the Health Officer. The word "theatre" , as used herein, shall include any structure or parcel of land used primarily for entertainment on the stage or screen. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.279 - Sec. 29. 
THEATRES; SUNDAYS, CLOSING HOURS. 
    No theatre shall be open to the public between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 12:45 a.m. on Sundays. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.280 - Sec. 30. 
THEATRES; MINORS, RESTRICTIONS. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to permit any minor under the age of twelve years to enter into or gain admission to any theatre after 7:30 p.m., unless such minor is accompanied by such parent or guardian or another adult person designated by the parent or guardian of the minor. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the parent, guardian or an adult person designated by such parent for guardian, to accompany or take any minor under the age of twelve years into any theatre after 7:30 p.m., or to procure a ticket for or otherwise assist such minor to gain admission into any theatre after 7:30 p.m. 
C.  It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager, operator, agent or employee of any theatre to permit any minor under the age of twelve years to enter into or gain admission to such theatre after 7:30 p.m., unless such minor is accompanied by his parent or guardian or an adult person authorized to accompany such minor. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.281 - Sec. 31. 
THEATRES; LOTTERIES, ETC., PROHIBITED. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager, operator, agent or employee of any theatre to maintain, operate, carry on or permit in such theatre any lottery, game of chance, game of skill, bank night, screeno, luck-o-grams or any other game of a similar nature or to engage in any similar device or plan. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.282 - Sec. 32. 
PROVISIONS COMPLEMENTARY AND SUPPLEMENTAL. 
    The general provisions of this Ordinance, together with other relevant provisions of any other Ordinance, or the provisions hereafter authorized or required by state law, and any and all thereof relative to licenses, permits, businesses, premises or anything connected therewith, shall each be construed to be complementary and supplemental to each other so far as relevant; and shall, where not otherwise provided or inconsistent herewith, constitute a part of the regulations and conditions applicable generally to any particular license or permit in the same manner as though such provisions were fully written into each separate Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.283 - Sec. 33. 
REQUIRED LICENSES; BONDS, FEES; SCHEDULE. 
    The fees and bonds for the businesses, activities or things requiring licenses under this Ordinance or Code, unless otherwise specifically set forth in this Ordinance or Code, shall be established by resolution of the City Commission, which shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
1.  Adult Bookstores, Video Rental Store, Drug Paraphernalia Store, Adult Motion Picture Theatres; Adult Mini Picture Theatres, or Cabarets 
2.  Arcades 
3.  Auctioneers 
4.  Business Registration Fee 
5.  Circuses, Menageries and Carnivals 
6.  Closing-Out Sales and/or Fire Sales 
7.  Coin-Operated Amusement Devices 
8.  Coin-Operated Music Devices 
9.  Dog and Cat Licenses 
10.  Fireworks Vendor 
11.  (Reserved) 
12.  Massage Parlors 
13.  Myomassologist 
14.  Pawnbrokers 
15.  (Reserved) 
16.  Taxicabs 
17.  Trailer Coaches 
18.  Transient Merchants (includes Itinerant Merchants and Itinerant Vendors) 
18a.  Trade Center Merchants 
19.  Vending Machines 
20.  Motor buses 
(ord. eff. Aug. 27, 1987; amend. eff. Mar. 29, 1990; further amend. eff. Aug. 18, 1990; further amend. eff. Mar. 12, 1992; further amend. eff. Apr. 30, 1992; further amend. eff. May 14, 1992; further amend. eff. Feb. 17, 1994; further amend eff. Apr. 27, 1995; further amend. eff. Aug. 31, 1995) 
20.284 - Sec. 34. 
BUSINESS REGISTRATION FEE. 
    All persons, firms or corporations conducting business activities within the City of Mount Clemens not otherwise covered by a specific substantive licensing provision are hereby required to register said business activities with the City Clerk on forms to be provided to the registrants. The fee for such registration is set forth in Code Section 20.283(4). Such registrations shall expire at 12:00 midnight on June 1 after the date of registration. This registration is required so that the City can keep adequate records of the types and locations of business activities, which records can be used by the various Departments of the City, including the Fire, Police, and Public Works Departments, to ensure that adequate services can be supplied. Such registrations shall also serve to provide the various City Departments with the names and addresses of contact persons in cases of emergency. Failure to comply with the provisions of this Ordinance is declared to be a misdemeanor punishable as set forth in Code Section 11.005. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 27, 1987; amend. May 1, 2014) 
20.285 - Sec. 35. 
FEES FOR CITY SERVICES. 
    Fees for services listed below which are performed by personnel of the City shall be established by resolution of the City Commission, which activities include, but are not limited to the following: 
1.  Processing Gun Registrations 
2.  Processing Concealed Weapons Permits 
3.  Fingerprinting 
4.  Processing Liquor Licenses 
(ord. eff. Aug. 11, 1988; amend. eff. Aug. 31, 1995) 
20.300 - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. May 29, 2008; ord. eff. May 29, 2008 

20.301 - [Sec. 1.] 
LICENSE REQUIRED. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, attempt to sell, engage in or attempt to engage in any business or other activity as a transient merchant without a license obtained in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance. Transient merchant shall be defined in this Ordinance as a peddler, solicitor, vendor, distributor, trade center merchant or other person or company engaged in similar types of sales activities. Said license shall be prominently displayed upon the transient merchant as required by the City. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.302 - [Sec. 2.] 
LICENSE APPLICATION. 
    Persons desiring a license or registration as provided for in this chapter shall file an application and other documents as prescribed by the City Clerk. The City Clerk shall be responsible for the collection of all applications, issuance of licenses and enforcement of regulations relating to this Ordinance. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.303 - [Sec. 3.] 
FEE. 
    Prior to the issuance of a license or registration pursuant to the provisions of this Ordinance, a fee shall be paid as specified by resolution of the City Commission. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.304 - [Sec. 4.] 
PROHIBITED. 
    The following shall be prohibited within the City Limits: 
A)  No person, whether licensed or not, shall stop or remain in any one location on any street, alley, or public place within the City for longer than is necessary to make a sale to a customer wishing to engage in a transaction. 
B)  No person, whether licensed or not, shall conduct business from a fixed stand located in any street, alley, or public place. 
C)  No person shall operate or maintain any stand, store or place of business on or near to any street, lane, highway, sidewalk or public place in such a manner that the customers or traders with such person occupy or congregate within the limits of the street, lane, highway, sidewalk or public place. 
D)  No person shall be permitted to use the streets, alleys, lanes or public places of the City for the service of customers or for the transaction of business or to operate in any manner that would require the customer, when transacting said business, to stand within the limits of the streets, highways, alleys or public places. This provision shall not apply to licensed street vendors operating in accordance with an approved Special Event. 
E)  No person, whether licensed or not, shall remain, barter, sell, offer or expose for sale any goods, wares or merchandise on the sidewalk or adjacent to any property. This provision shall not apply to approved sidewalk sales and firework vendors licensed under Ordinance 20.640 (Fireworks). 
F)  No person shall engage in the business of being a transient merchant on any street, alley or public place after having been requested to desist by any City Official or the Macomb County Sheriff. 
G)  No person, whether licensed or not shall call at any dwelling or residence prior to 10:00 a.m. or later than 7:00 p.m. on any day of the week, unless an appointment is made with the owner of the dwelling place or residence. 
H)  No person, whether licensed or not shall call at any dwelling, residence or place of business where a sign is displayed stating "no peddlers", "no solicitors", "no salesmen", "no trespassing", or words of similar meaning or import. Additionally, no person, whether licensed or not, shall call on any dwelling or residence that has requested to be placed on a "No Soliciting" list. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.305 - [Sec. 5.] 
PROHIBITED PRACTICES. 
    No transient merchant shall, while in any public place, shout or cry out his or her goods or merchandise, nor blow any horns, ring any bell, broadcast or play any sound or use any similar device to attract the attention of the public. Ice cream trucks engaged in the delivery of ice cream within a neighborhood shall be permitted to play music in a manner customary to the industry. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.306 - [Sec. 6.] 
EXEMPTIONS. 
    The following shall be exempt from the licensing requirements of this chapter, but shall be subject to the other provisions hereof and shall register with the City Clerk: 
A.  Any person under eighteen (18) years of age, when engaged in the business of being a transient merchant on foot in the neighborhood of his or her residence under the direct supervision of any school or recognized charitable or religious organization; 
B.  Any person exempt from the licensing requirements of this chapter by virtue of state or federal law; 
C.  Any person who is the duly authorized representative or agent of any church, charitable or labor organization, educational or fraternal organization or of any political group seeking funds or membership or contacting members or electors; 
D.  Any person engaging in business solely at a City operated market, provided that all transactions are conducted solely within the confines of that market and that the rules and regulations of the market are observed. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.307 - [Sec. 7.] 
SPECIAL EVENT LICENSE. 
(ord. eff. May 29, 2008; repeal eff. May 1, 2014) 
20.308 - [Sec. 8.] 
TRADE CENTER MERCHANT LICENSES. 
    Applicants for Trade Center Merchant licenses under this Ordinance shall file an application, on a form prescribed by the City Clerk and signed by the applicant if an individual, by a partner if a partnership, by an authorized agent if a corporation and by a member if a limited liability company, with the Trade Center stating the following: 
A.  The name of the person having management or supervision of the applicant's business and his or her permanent address. 
B.  Documentation verifying that the Trade Center Merchant has a tenancy/space rental agreement with the Trade Center. 
C.  The location of the Trade Center within which the business will be conducted. 
D.  A statement of the types of goods and or services which the applicant will sell. 
E.  Such other reasonable information as to identify the person having management or supervision of the applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the City Clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this Ordinance in the protection of the public interest. 
    The Trade Center shall be responsible for the processing of all license applications and shall forward any and all amounts received for licensure to the City Clerk upon receipt. 
    The provisions of the City Code Sections 20.301-20.307 shall not apply to Trade Center Merchants. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.309 - [Sec. 9.] 
INSURANCE. 
    All vehicles and equipment of a licensee shall be insured in accordance with the provisions set forth by the Purchasing Department. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.310 - [Sec. 10.] 
REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF LICENSE. 
    Any license under this article may be revoked upon notice of either fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application or by violation of any provision of this article or other Mount Clemens City ordinance or any law of the state relating to the business for which the license was issued or the qualifications of the licensee as required under this article. 
    If a license is denied or if a license, which has been issued is revoked, the applicant shall be entitled to a hearing before the City Commission upon written request through the office of the City Clerk made within ten days of such denial or revocation. Upon receipt of such request, the clerk shall place the appeal upon the City Commission agenda for the next available meeting time. At that time a public hearing will be held on the matter and the applicant may appear and present such evidence as he deems appropriate in support of his request for relief from the denial or revocation. The Commission may also receive evidence from any City Department or resident of the community that is relevant to the denial or revocation. Within 30 days of the public hearing, the Commission shall render its decision and give written notice to the applicant. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.311 - [Sec. 11.] 
PENALTY. 
    Any transient merchant, upon conviction of violation of the within Ordinance, shall be fined not more than $500.00 and/or 90 days in jail, or both. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. eff. May 29, 2008) 
20.320 - SECONDHAND DEALERS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend, Jan., 1978 repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987 
20.340 - PAWNBROKERS MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 

20.341 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITION. 
    In this Ordinance, "pawnbroker" means any person who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal property or other valuable thing, other than securities or printed evidence of indebtedness, or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable thing on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated price. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan. 1978) 
20.342 - Sec. 2. 
LICENSE REQUIRED; PENALTY. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of pawnbroker within the City without first having procured a license therefor. 
B.  Any person who violates this provision shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.343 - Sec. 3. 
APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; BOND REQUIRED. 
    Application for a license shall be made to the City Clerk in the form and manner prescribed by him. No such license shall be granted except upon the approval of the Police Chief and the Fire Chief. 
    Before any such license is issued, the applicant therefor shall furnish a corporate surety bond in the penal sum of $3,000.00, with sufficient surety to be approved by the City Commission, which bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful observance of all laws of the state and provisions of this Ordinance and Code during the license term. Any person aggrieved by the action of any such licensee shall have a right of action on the bond for the recovery of damages or to enforce any lawful right. Such bond shall remain in full force and effect for a period of 90 days after the expiration or cancellation of any such license or after the termination of any action upon such bond. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
Cross reference- For general licensing provisions, see 20.250 sec. 1 et seq.; these provisions are supplemental and complementary to the provisions of this Ordinance, see 20.282 sec. 32. 
State Law reference- For similar state law, see C.L., 1948, secs. 446.202, 446.204; Mich. Stat. Anno., secs. 19.582, 19.584. 
20.344 - Sec. 4. 
LICENSES, RENEWALS; TERM, FEES. 
A.  FEES. Before any license shall be issued, the applicant shall pay to the City Treasurer a license fee in the sum specified in Section 20.283(14). 
B.  TERM. All licenses granted under the provisions of this Ordinance shall expire on the first day of June at 12:00 midnight after the date of issuance thereof. 
C.  RENEWALS. Applications for renewal of license shall be made to the City Clerk in the same manner as the filing of the original application. If any licensee does not renew such license before the first day of July of any year, the fee for such license shall be twice the sum specified in Section 20.283(14), and no renewal license shall be issued until such fee has been paid to the City Treasurer. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.345 - Sec. 5. 
RECORD OF PROPERTY REQUIRED; CONTENTS, INSPECTION. 
    Each license shall keep a book in which shall be written, in ink, in the English language, at the time he shall receive any article of personal property or other valuable thing by way of pledge or pawn, a description of such article, the sum loaned thereon, the rate of interest payable thereon, and the name, residence and general description of the person from whom, and the day and hour when, such property was received. Such book and the licensed premises may be inspected at any time by any police officer. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.346 - Sec. 6. 
RECORD OF PROPERTY; STATEMENT TO POLICE, REQUIRED. 
    Each license shall make daily, except Sunday, a sworn statement of his transactions, describing the goods or pledge received, and setting forth the name, residence and description of the person from whom the goods or pledge were received, to the Chief of Police. 
20.347 - Sec. 7. 
DEALING IN SECONDHAND PROPERTY, RESTRICTION. 
    No pawnbroker shall purchase any secondhand furniture, metals, clothing or other articles or thing, or sell, dispose of or keep for sale any such secondhand articles or thing, except they have been pawned to him, and are or have been sold at public auction to the highest bidder, as hereinafter provided. Any articles sold to such pawnbroker, upon the understanding that such article is to be purchased from such pawnbroker by the seller thereof, or by any person acting for such seller, shall be deemed to be pawned within the meaning of this section. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- For similar state law, see C.L., 1948, sec. 416.207; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 19.587. 
20.348 - Sec. 8. 
PAWNED ARTICLES; MEMORANDUM, CONTENTS. 
    Each licensee shall, at the time of such loan, deliver to the person pawning or pledging any goods, article or thing, a memorandum or note signed by him, containing the substance of the entry required to be made by him in his book in Section 5, and no charge shall be made or received by such licensee for any such entry, memorandum or note. The memoranda or notes shall be consecutively numbered and upon the back thereof, in the English language, shall be printed: "If interest or charges in excess of 3 percent per month are asked or received, this loan is void and of no effect; and the borrower cannot be made to pay back the money loaned or any interest, or any charges or part thereof, and the pawnbroker in such instance loses all right to the possession of the goods, article or thing pawned, and shall surrender the same to the borrower or pawner upon due demand therefor." 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- For similar state law, see C.L., 1948, sec. 446.208; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 19.588. 
20.349 - Sec. 9. 
INTEREST ON LOANS; REGULATIONS. 
    Any licensee may lawfully charge upon any loan a rate of interest not to exceed 3 percent per month; provided, however, that any licensee may charge a minimum of 50 cents for any loan made by him. Interest on any loan shall not be payable in advance and shall be computed on unpaid monthly balances, only, without compounding of interest. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to charge to any person obtaining a loan a rate of interest in excess of the amount prescribed herein, or to make any charge whatsoever which is not authorized by the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- For limitation of interest charges, see C.L., 1948, sec. 446.209; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 19.589. 
20.350 - Sec. 10. 
PAWNED PROPERTY; DESTRUCTION, DEFACING, ETC.; PROHIBITION. 
    It shall be unlawful for any license to deface, scratch, obliterate, melt, separate or break into parts any particle or thing received by him in pawn or otherwise, or in any manner do, cause or suffer to be done by others, anything which shall destroy or tend to destroy the identity of such article or render the identification thereof more difficult. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- For similar state law, see C.L., 1948, sec. 446.213; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 19.593. 
20.351 - Sec. 11. 
SUNDAYS; BUSINESS TRANSACTIONS PROHIBITED. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to transact any business or keep his premises open to the public on any Sunday. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.352 - Sec. 12. 
SALES OF PAWNED PROPERTY; REGULATIONS. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell any pawn or pledge until the same shall have remained six months in his possession. All such sales shall be a public auction to the highest bidder. The licensee shall hold such sales in his regularly established place of business. 
B.  Notice of sale of any pawn or pledge shall be published for at least six days previous thereto in a newspaper in general circulation in the City. The notice shall specify the time and place at which such sale is to take place and by whom it is to be conducted, and shall contain the same description of the articles or goods to be sold as was given in the memorandum or note delivered to the pawner as required by section 8. 
C.  Prior to the sale, the pawner may, by payment to the licensee of the debt and interest thereon, together with the cost of advertising the sale if the same has been advertised, regain title and right of possession to the property pawned or pledged. 
D.  The surplus money, if any, arising from such sale, after deducting the amount of the loan, the interest then due on the same, and the expense of advertising, shall be paid over by the licensee to the person who pawned or pledged the article or thing sold by auction. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.353 - Sec. 13. 
PURCHASES, PLEDGES, ETC.; RESTRICTIONS. 
    It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to receive any pledge, pawn, article or thing whatever from: 
A.  Any minor under 18 years of age; 
B.  Any person who is drunk or intoxicated; 
C.  Any person known or suspected by the licensee to be a thief or a receiver of stolen property; 
D.  Any person known by the licensee to be of unsound mind. 
    Whenever any city official or police officer shall serve written notice to any pawnbroker that the receipt of pledges, etc. from certain persons is prohibited, it shall be unlawful for the licensee to receive such pledges, etc. from such persons. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- For similar state law, see C.L., 1948, sec. 446.214; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 19.594. 
20.354 - Sec. 14. 
STATE LAW; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED. 
    All provisions of state law relative to pawnbrokers shall be complied with. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- For state law, see C.L., 1948, secs. 446.201 et seq.; Mich. Stat. Anno., secs. 19.581 et seq. 
20.360 - PEDDLERS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct. 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987 
20.380 - JUNK PEDDLERS AND DEALERS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987 
20.400 - AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- For State law relative to auctions and auctioneers generally, see C.L., 1948, sec. 440.21; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 19.261; see also C.L., 1948, sec. 446.35 et seq.; Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 19.560 et seq. 

20.401 - Sec. 1. 
AUCTIONEERS; LICENSE REQUIRED. 
    No person shall engage in the business of auctioneer or sell or cry off at auction any real estate, goods, wares or merchandise of any description within the City until he shall first procure a license so to do from the City Clerk. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
Cross reference- For general licensing provisions, see 20.201, sec. 1 et seq.; these provisions are supplemental and complementary to the provisions of this Ordinance, see 20.282, sec. 32. 
20.402 - Sec. 2. 
APPLICATION FOR LICENSE. 
    No license shall be granted to any person under eighteen years of age or to any person not of good reputation and moral character. Each applicant shall file with the City Clerk his application therefor, and to such application three residents of the City shall certify to the good reputation and moral character of the applicant. Before issuing a license the Clerk may require such further information as he deems necessary to determine the reputation and character of the applicant. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.403 - Sec. 3. 
LICENSE FEE. 
    Before any license is issued, the applicant shall pay to the City Treasurer a license fee in the sum as specified in Section 20.283(3) and shall execute a bond in the penal sum of $2,000.00 with two or more sufficient sureties to be approved by the Clerk, conditioned upon the faithful compliance by the applicant with the provisions of the Charter and this Code and the payment of all penalties which may be recovered against him for the violation thereof and upon the faithful accounting to the consignor or owner of the goods entrusted to and moneys received by him and for the protection of any person purchasing goods who shall sustain any damaged by unlawful or fraudulent sale of said auctioneer. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.404 - Sec. 4. 
SALE RESTRICTIONS. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, dispose of, advertise for sale, or offer for sale at public auction any property of any kind unless he complies with the following conditions: 
A.  Such sale shall be conducted by an auctioneer, duly licensed as herein provided. 
B.  Such property shall have been on the tax rolls of the City for a period of one year prior to such sale, or comprise the stock of goods of a merchant who has regularly done business in the City for one year continuously prior to such sale. 
C.  All taxes, plus penalties, which have become a lien under any law or provision of this Code, shall have first been paid. 
D.  In the event such sale is a closing-out sale, the statutes and provisions of this Code regulating such sales shall be complied with. 
E.  No property of any kind shall be added to the goods, wares or stock at any closing-out sale after the inventory is filed, nor shall any property be added within 60 days prior to the commencement of such sale in anticipation thereof. 
F.  No property which has been struck off to the highest bidder during the course of such sale shall again be offered for sale during such auction. 
G.  No sale of platinum, gold, silver, plated ware, precious or semi-precious stones, watches or other jewelry shall be permitted unless it is a closing-out auction and application therefor has been on file with the City Clerk for a period of 60 days prior to the first day of such sale, and every such article sold shall have securely attached to it a tag or label upon which shall be plainly written or printed in English a true and correct statement of the kind and quality of the metal of which such article is made or with which it is plated, and the true name or names, weight, quality and color of any precious or semiprecious stone or stones, together with the name of the manufacturer of such article. 
H.  A sales book shall be kept, signed by the purchaser, showing each sale of any article at the time of purchase, opposite a description of the article, and if no purchaser comes forward to sign such book, then the next highest bidder shall have the right to sign such sales book and to demand and receive such article at the amount of his last highest bid. 
I.  No auction shall be conducted or continued in the City after 6:00 p.m. of any day. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.405 - Sec. 5. 
PROHIBITED PRACTICES. 
    The following acts, omissions and practices are prohibited: 
A.  The use of deceit, fraud or misrepresentation in the sale or offering for sale of any article. 
B.  The substitution of any article in place of an article bid upon at auction. 
C.  The use of false bidders, cappers or puffers. 
D.  The use of bells, buzzers, bally-hoo or any variety of mechanical or excessive vocal sound to attract attention in connection with sales at auction. 
E.  The use of any false or misleading advertising matter, relative to the kind or quality of the goods or to the past history or present status thereof. 
F.  The substitution of an unlicensed person in place of a licensed auctioneer. 
G.  The failure to exhibit an auctioneers license to any police officer upon demand at the place where an auction is conducted. 
H.  The receipt for sale by auction or the sale by auction of any licensed auctioneer of any goods, wares or merchandise from any minor, knowing him to be such. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.406 - Sec. 6. 
ACCOUNTS REQUIRED. 
    Each auctioneer shall keep an accurate record of all goods and chattels sold by him, together with the name and address of the person from whom such goods and chattels were received, which record shall be open to inspection by any police officer or the City Clerk at all reasonable times. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.407 - Sec. 7. 
SWORN STATEMENT REQUIRED, CONTENTS. 
    At least five full days before commencing any sale by auction, except as specified in Section 10, the owner of the property sought to be sold shall file a sworn application with the City Clerk which shall state the following: 
A.  Whether the auction sought to be conducted is a closing-out auction. 
B.  If it is a closing-out auction, that the application is made in good faith for the purpose of retiring from business and that all statutes and the provisions of this Code governing closing-out sales have been complied with. 
C.  That the stock of goods, or other property, sought to be sold, is a bona fide part of applicant's stock or has been on the tax rolls of the City for one year. 
D.  A complete description of the property sought to be sold, in duplicate, including, if it is personal property, a completely itemized inventory with identifying numbers, or other means of readily determining the identity of each and every article. 
E.  The place where the auction is to be conducted. 
F.  The name of the auctioneer who is to conduct the sale. 
G.  The name of the owner of the property for the preceding year. 
H.  The length of time the applicant has been in business in the City and the address of such business. 
I.  That all taxes on such property have been paid. 
J.  That no property other than that listed shall be sold or offered for sale on the premises where the auction is being conducted during such auction sale. 
K.  That all of the property listed is actually on the premises where the auction is to be conducted. 
    It shall be unlawful for the auctioneer to conduct the auction at any place other than that stated in the application, and it shall be unlawful for either the auctioneer or owner to do, either themselves or through their agents or servants, any act or thing contrary to the statements made in the application, and any false statement therein, or any act done contrary to such statements, shall be deemed a violation of this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.408 - Sec. 8. 
SALE INSPECTION. 
    The City Clerk shall appoint an inspector for every auction sale conducted in this City, except such as are exempt by the provisions of this Ordinance, who shall be at all times on the premises while such sale is in progress. He shall be given a copy of the inventory by the City Clerk and shall, as each article is sold, check such item off the inventory. If any article is offered for sale which does not appear on the inventory, the inspector is authorized to forbid the sale of such article, and if the auctioneer refuses to comply with such request the inspector may forthwith stop the sale until the auctioneer furnishes satisfactory proof that such article was included in the inventory. The owner or auctioneer shall pay or cause to be paid to the City Treasurer the sum of $10.00, in advance, for each day such auction is to continue, for the services of said inspector, but such payment may be made on the day of the sale prior to the commencement of the sale. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.409 - Sec. 9. 
NEW GOODS. 
    Whenever any auction sale is one of used or secondhand goods, no new goods, wares, merchandise or personal property shall be offered or included at such sale. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.410 - Sec. 10. 
HOUSEHOLD GOODS. 
    The provisions of subsections B, C, D, E, F, and G of Sec. 4. and Sec. 7. shall not apply to auction sales of secondhand household furniture and household goods. The words "secondhand household furniture and household goods", in this Ordinance, means household furniture and household goods which have actually been used for housekeeping purposes. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.411 - Sec. 11. 
SALES AUTHORIZED BY COURT. 
    The provisions of this Ordinance shall not apply to any sale conducted by any sheriff, constable or other public or court officer, or any person acting under the license, direction or authority of any court. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.412 - Sec. 12. 
SALES IN THE REGULAR COURSE OF BUSINESS. 
    The provisions of subsections B, D, E, and I of Section 4, Sections 7, 8 and Section 9 shall not apply to auction sales which are conducted on a regular basis at a single location in the regular course of a business. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 18, 1982) 
20.450 - GASOLINE FILLING STATION CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987 
20.500 - RESTAURANTS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- For general licensing provisions, see 20.251, sec. 1 et seq.; these provisions are supplemental and complementary to the provisions of this Ordinance, see 20.282, sec. 32. 

20.501 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    In this Ordinance: 
A.  RESTAURANT includes coffee shops, cafeterias, short order cafes, luncheonettes, taverns, sandwich stands, soda fountains, coffee houses (so called), any place where beverages commonly known as "soft drinks" are sold, and all other eating or drinking establishments and kitchens or other places in which food or drink is prepared for sale but is consumed elsewhere. 
B.  ITINERANT RESTAURANT means one operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition, lecture, amusement, or other entertainment. 
C.  EMPLOYEE means any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving, or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils, or who is employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served. 
D.  UTENSILS include any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils, containers or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during storage, preparation, or serving. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.502 - Sec. 2. 
LICENSE REQUIRED. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.503 - Sec. 3. 
APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, FEE, TERM. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.504 - Sec. 4. 
FIRE AND HEALTH INSPECTION REQUIRED. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.505 - Sec. 5. 
SANITARY REQUIREMENTS. 
    All restaurants shall comply with the following sanitary requirements: 
A.  FLOORS. The floors of all rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be of such construction as to be easily cleaned, shall be smooth, and shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
B.  WALLS AND CEILINGS. Walls and ceilings of all rooms shall be kept clean and in good repair. All walls and ceilings of any room in which food or drink is stored or prepared shall be finished in light color. The walls of all rooms in which food or drink is prepared or utensils are washed shall have a smooth, washable surface up to the level reached by splash or spray. 
C.  DOORS AND WINDOWS. When flies are prevalent, all openings into the outer air shall be effectively screened and doors shall be self-closing, unless other effective means are provided to prevent the entrance of flies. 
D.  LIGHTING. All rooms in which food or drink is stored or prepared or in which utensils are washed shall be well lighted. 
E.  VENTILATION. All rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be well ventilated. 
F.  TOILET FACILITIES. Each restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its employees, conforming with the laws and regulations of the State. In restaurants hereafter constructed, toilet rooms shall not open directly into any room in which food, drink or utensils are handled or stored. The doors of all toilet rooms shall be self-closing. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair and well lighted and ventilated. Hand-washing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees. In case privies or earth closets are permitted and used, they shall be separate from the restaurant building, and shall be of a sanitary type constructed and operated in conformity with the standards of the State Board of Health. 
G.  WATER SUPPLY. Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in which food is prepared or utensils are washed, and the water supply shall be adequate and of a safe, sanitary quality. 
H.  LAVATORY FACILITIES. Adequate and convenient hand-washing facilities shall be provided, including hot and cold running water, soap and sanitary towels. The use of a common towel is prohibited. No employee shall resume work after using the toilet room without first washing his hands. 
I.  CONSTRUCTION OF UTENSILS AND EQUIPMENT. All multi-use utensils and all show and display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerating equipment, sinks, and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation of a restaurant shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair. Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be used; provided, that solder containing lead may be used for jointing. 
J.  CLEANING AND BACTERICIDAL TREATMENT OF UTENSILS AND EQUIPMENT. All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods and sinks, shall be kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects and other contaminating material. All cloths used by waiters, chefs and other employees shall be clean. Single-service containers shall be used only once. 
All multi-use eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each usage. All multi-use utensils used in the preparation or serving of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose. 
No article, polish or other substance containing any cyanide preparation or other poisonous substance shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of utensils. 
K.  STORAGE AND HANDLING OF UTENSILS AND EQUIPMENT. After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies, dust and other contamination, and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination as far as practicable. Single-service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers, shall be stored therein in a clean, dry place until used, and shall be handled in a sanitary manner. 
L.  DISPOSAL OF WASTES. All wastes shall be properly disposed of, and all garbage and trash shall be kept in suitable receptacles, in such manner as not to constitute a nuisance. 
M.  REFRIGERATION. All readily perishable food and drink shall be kept at or below 50° F., except when being prepared or served. Waste water from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of. 
N.  WHOLESOMENESS OF FOOD AND DRINK. All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome, free from spoilage, and so prepared as to be safe for human consumption. All milk, fluid milk products, ice cream and frozen deserts served shall be from approved sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual original containers in which they were received from the distributor, or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device; provided, that this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be served from the original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service. All oysters, clams and mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked shall be kept until used in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking plant. 
O.  STORAGE, DISPLAY AND SERVING OF FOOD AND DRINK. All food and drink shall be so stored, displayed and served as to be protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage, and other contamination. No animal or fowl shall be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared or stored. All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches and rodents shall be used. 
P.  CLEANLINESS OF EMPLOYEES. All employees shall wear clean outer garments and shall keep their hands clean at all times while engaged in handling, food, drink, utensils or equipment. Employees shall not expectorate or use tobacco in any form in rooms in which food is prepared. 
Q.  LINENS, LOCKERS, PREMISES, ETC. The premises of all restaurants shall be kept clean and free of litter or rubbish. None of the operations connected with a restaurant shall be conducted in any room used as living or sleeping quarters. Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employees' clothing, and shall be kept clean. Soiled linens, coats and aprons shall be kept in containers provided for such purpose. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.506 - Sec. 6. 
UNWHOLESOME FOOD OR DRINK; EXAMINATION, CONDEMNATION. 
    Samples of food, drink and other substances may be taken and examined by the Health Officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. The Health Officer may condemn and forbid the sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink which is unwholesome or adulterated. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.507 - Sec. 7. 
INSPECTION OF RESTAURANTS. 
    At least once every six months, the Health Officer shall inspect every restaurant located in the City. The person operating the restaurant shall, upon request of the Health Officer, permit access to all parts of the establishment and shall permit copying any or all records of food purchased. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.508 - Sec. 8. 
FOOD HANDLERS PERMIT REQUIRED. 
    No person who is affected with, or is a carrier of, any infectious disease in a communicable form shall be employed in handling food or food utensils in any restaurant or itinerant restaurant. No person shall employ any person to handle food or food utensils in any restaurant unless such employee shall first procure a food handlers permit from the Health Officer and file same with his employer before entering upon his duties. The Health Officer shall not issue such permit to any person unless the permittee has been examined by a duly licensed physician who shall report his findings on the form and in the manner prescribed by the Health Officer. No permit shall be valid for more than one year; no permit shall be renewed without submitting to another medical examination as aforesaid. 
    Such permit shall be revoked by the Health Officer at any time that the holder thereof could not qualify for a new permit if requested so to do. Refusal to submit to another medical examination, if requested by the Health Officer for good cause, shall constitute adequate reason to revoke any permit. 
(code. eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- For State law relative to physical examinations for employees, see C.L., 1948; Sec. 750.470; Mich. Stat. Anno., Sec. 28.738. 
20.509 - Sec. 9. 
DUTY TO REPORT TO HEALTH OFFICER. 
    In the event any owner or operator of a restaurant has any reason to believe that any employee has contacted an infectious, contagious or communicable disease, it shall be his duty to exclude such employee from the licensed premises and immediately notify the Health Officer of this fact. In the event any employee has reason to believe he has contacted an infectious, contagious or communicable disease, or in the event such employee suffers a cough or skin eruption or other suspicious symptom which persist for more than fourteen days, it shall be his duty to immediately notify his employer and the Health Officer. 
    The Health Officer shall immediately exclude such employee from the premises until an investigation is made and shall, in addition, take such other action as he may deem necessary for the protection of the health and welfare of the public. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.510 - Sec. 10. 
SUSPENSION OF LICENSE; REINSTATEMENT, REVOCATION. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.511 - Sec. 11. 
PENALTY. 
    Any person violating any provision of this Ordinance shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, or imprisoned for a term of not more than 90 days, or both. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.525 - RESTAURANTS; DRIVE-IN CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 

20.526 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITION. 
    A drive in restaurant, within the meaning of this Ordinance, shall be deemed to be any restaurant where meals, sandwiches, ice cream, or other food is served directly to or is permitted to be consumed by patrons in automobiles, motorcycles or other vehicles parked on the premises. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.527 - Sec. 2. 
LICENSE REQUIRED. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.528 - Sec. 3. 
LICENSE APPLICATION, RENEWAL, AND REVOCATION. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978; repealed eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.529 - Sec. 4. 
APPLICATION OF FOOD ORDINANCE. 
    All provisions of the Food Ordinance of the City of Mount Clemens shall govern drive-in restaurants so far as applicable. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.530 - Sec. 5. 
PARKING ACCOMMODATIONS. 
    All drive-in restaurants shall have an adequate parking area to accommodate the patrons of such restaurants. Such parking area shall be surfaced with blacktop or other appropriate dustless surfacing not less than two (2) inches in depth. Such parking area shall have one or more entrances and exits suitably designed as such from the adjoining street or streets. Such parking area shall be enclosed by a suitable fence on the side and rear; provided, that the City Commission may for a good cause shown waive this requirement if the adjoining property on the side and rear is zoned for business or industrial use. Exits and entrances shall be from the street only unless, for good cause shown, permission is otherwise granted by the City Commission. The plan for enclosing the parking area shall be submitted to the City Manager, and approved by him, before a drive-in restaurant can be operated or maintained. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.531 - Sec. 6. 
WASTE CONTAINERS. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner, operator or manager of a drive-in restaurant to keep the premises whereon said restaurant is located, together with the parking area and that portion of any public street or streets adjoining said drive-in restaurant, free from all rubbish, waste products and debris, including napkins, straws, paper cups and plates, and other waste materials, at all times. Each drive-in restaurant shall be provided with a sufficient number of suitable containers to hold such waste material until the same is removed from the premises. Such containers shall be of metal construction or other approved material with self-closing, reach-in type cover. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.532 - Sec. 7. 
RUBBISH REMOVAL. 
    In addition to the other penalties provided in this Ordinance, the proprietor of any drive-in restaurant may be charged with the cost of cleaning up or removing debris found on the premises and on the public highway or highways adjacent to said premises. The City Manager, the Health Officer, the Chief Inspector, or any other Enforcement Officer, shall have the right, if he sees debris on the premises occupied by the drive-in restaurant and the highways adjacent thereto, to cause the same to be cleaned up and removed from the premises and shall certify the cost of said cleaning up and removal to the City Manager. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.533 - Sec. 8. 
LOUD SPEAKERS; PROHIBITION. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any drive-in restaurant to operate, or permit to be operated, any loud speakers or make or permit to be made, any other loud noise or permit any show or exhibit on the premises occupied by said drive-in restaurant; provided, however, the owner or operator of such restaurant may use public address system solely for the purpose of giving instructions to employees on the premises, but the instructions so given shall not be loud enough to cause disturbance to persons not on the premises of such drive-in restaurant. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.534 - Sec. 9. 
HORN BLOWING; LOUD NOISES; PROHIBITION. 
    It shall be unlawful for any patron of a drive-in restaurant while parking on or adjacent to the premises of such restaurant to race the motor of any car, to suddenly start or stop any car, or to make or cause to be made, any other loud or unseemly noise. It shall also be unlawful for any patron of a drive-in restaurant, or any other person parked on the premises of such restaurant, to blow or cause to be blown any automobile horn or motorcycle horn at any time while so parked. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.535 - Sec. 10. 
UNLAWFUL ACTS OF CONDUCT; ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES; LOITERING, CRUISING VEHICLES, PROHIBITION. 
    It shall be unlawful for any patron or other person on the premises of a drive-in restaurant, whether in or out of an automobile, to consume any beer, wine or other alcoholic beverages, or to have in his possession any open bottle, can or other receptacle containing beer, wine or other alcoholic beverage. It shall be unlawful for any number of persons to congregate for any time whatsoever at any location on the premises of a drive-in restaurant other than in the restaurant building, or in a legally parked motor vehicle. Any persons so congregating shall be deemed guilty of loitering. No person shall drive a motor vehicle onto the premises of a drive-in restaurant then from said premises without parking such motor vehicle and seeking service, unless there is no unoccupied parking space available on said premises. It shall be the duty of the licensee to post on the premises in a conspicuous location, one or more signs bearing the following legend: 
CRUISING AND GATHERING OUTSIDE OF VEHICLE UNLAWFUL 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.536 - Sec. 11. 
PENALTY. 
    Any person violating any provision of this Ordinance shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, or imprisoned for a term of not more than 90 days, or both. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.537 - Sec. 12. 
EMERGENCY ORDINANCE. 
    This Ordinance is declared to be an emergency Ordinance for the preservation of the public peace, health and safety, and shall take effect immediately upon its passage. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.538 - Sec. 13. 
SEPARABILITY. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this Ordinance is for any reason held invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 29, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.550 - AMUSEMENT AND ENTERTAINMENT; PLACES OF CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978 

20.551 - Sec. 1. 
FORMS OF ENTERTAINMENT, LICENSE REQUIRED. 
    No person, persons, firm, company, companies or partnerships shall exhibit or maintain in the City of Mount Clemens, any circus, carnivals, menagerie, game or operate any adult bookstore, adult video rental store, adult motion picture theatre, or store which markets for sale any drug paraphernalia, or any amusement park or concession, or exhibit any natural or artificial curiosity, operate a massage parlor, operate or advertise any business which offers as its principal activity the provision of nude human models or artists or photographers, or give a show of any kind either free or for which pay is demanded or received, without a license from the City of Mount Clemens. Said license shall be issued by the City Clerk upon the approval of the City Commission, and for every license granted shall pay the license fee as specified in Section 20.283 of the Mount Clemens Code of Ordinances. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.552 - Sec. 2. 
BOND REQUIRED. 
    Before any license shall be granted, there shall be deposited by the applicant for such license with the City Clerk, a cash bond, in the amount of One Thousand ($l,000.00) Dollars, conditioned that no damage will be done to the streets, sewers, trees, or adjoining property and that no dirt, paper, litter other debris will be permitted to remain upon the streets or upon any private property by such licensee. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.553 - Sec. 3. 
PUBLIC LIABILITY AND WORKMANS COMPENSATION INSURANCE REQUIRED. 
    The City Clerk shall require every licensee to carry Public Liability and Workmans Compensation Insurance upon all property being used by the applicant in the conduct of his or its business, copies of said policies to be filed with the City Clerk at the time of issuance of said license, and to be in the sum of $200,000.00 for damages resulting to one person and $500,000.00 for damages resulting from one casualty, and $50,000.00 property damage insurance resulting from any one occurrence. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.554 - Sec. 4. 
PETITION OF APPROVAL; REQUIREMENTS. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter, none of the above activities listed in Section 25.551, shall hereafter be established or licensed within the City, unless a petition of approval shall be filed with the Police Department signed by fifty-one per cent (51%) of the people living, owning, and/or doing business within a radius of five hundred (500) feet of the premises upon which the amusement or activity is to be established, and applicant shall have complied with this Chapter, the official Zoning Ordinance, and other applicable Ordinances of the City of Mount Clemens, including an inspection of the proposed premises, by the Building Department, the Health Department, the Fire Department and the State Fire Marshal. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.555 - Sec. 5. 
PROHIBITION IN PROXIMITY TO CHURCH, SCHOOL BUILDING, OR PUBLIC BUILDING. 
    Any new application for a license under this Chapter, or any request to transfer location of an existing license, shall be denied in the event the contemplated location is within one thousand (1,000) feet of a church, school building or a public building. Such distance between the church, school building or public building and the contemplated location shall be measured along the centerline of the street or streets of address, between 2 fixed points on the centerline determined by projecting straight lines, at right angles to the centerline, from that part of the church, school building or public building nearest to the contemplated location and from that part of the contemplated location nearest to the church, school building or public building. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.556 - Sec. 6. 
APPROVAL BY POLICE DEPARTMENT. 
    No applicant for a license under this Chapter shall be granted same until an investigation has been made by the Police Department and complete criminal record check as to whether or not any offense involving gambling, narcotics, any offense involving moral turpitude or the violation of any criminal statute of the State of Michigan has been committed by the applicant within the past 2 years and the further recommendation by the Chief of Police, that the applicant is of a sufficient moral character as to warrant the granting of such license. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.557 - Sec. 7. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter, the following definitions are incorporated herein: 
A.  ADULT BOOKSTORE.
