An establishment having as a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, books, magazines, and other periodicals, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "Specified Sexual Activities" or "Specified Anatomical Areas" (as defined below) or an establishment with a segment or section devoted to the sale or display of such material. 
B.  ADULT MOTION PICTURE THEATER. An enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "Specified Sexual Activities" or "Specified Anatomical Areas" (as defined below) for observation by patrons therein. 
C.  ADULT MINI MOTION PICTURE THEATER. An enclosed building with a capacity for less than 50 persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "Specified Sexual Activities" or "Specified Anatomical Areas" (as defined below) for observation by patrons therein. 
D.  CABARET. A cabaret which features topless dancers, go-go dancers, exotic dancers, strippers, male or female impersonators, or similar entertainers. 
For the purpose of this section, "Specified Sexual Activities" is defined as: 
1.  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
2.  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; 
3.  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breast. 
And "Specified Anatomical Areas" is defined as: 
1.  Less than completely and opaquely covered; (i) human genitals, pubic region, (ii) buttock, and (iii) female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; and 
2.  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
E.  ADULT VIDEO RENTAL STORE. An establishment having as a portion of its stock-in-trade for sale or any establishment with a segment or section devoted to the rental or display of adult video cassettes which depict, describe or in any way relate to "Specified Sexual Activities" or "Specified Anatomical Areas" (as defined above). 
F.  DRUG PARAPHERNALIA STORE. An establishment having as a portion of its stock-in-trade, for sale or rent some or all of those items defined and enumerated in the City of Mount Clemens Drug Paraphernalia Ordinance, Code Sections 35.280 et seq., but specifically Code Section 35.282. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.558 - Sec. 8. 
CONDUCT OF LICENSEE. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee, his agent or employee to knowingly permit or display in any manner, any advertising in connection with his business, depicting, describing or relating to "Specified Sexual Activities" or "Specified Anatomical Areas" which is visible from a public street or highway, or permit any disorderly conduct or the use of any immoral, profane or indecent language upon his premises. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.559 - Sec. 9. 
LICENSE FEE. 
    Before any license shall be issued for the operation of an adult bookstore, adult motion picture theatre, adult mini motion picture theatre, cabaret, adult video rental store or drug paraphernalia store, as defined in Section 25.557 of this Ordinance, the applicant shall pay to the City Treasurer a license fee in the sum specified in Section 20.283(1). 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.560 - Sec. 10. 
PENALTY. 
    Any person violating any provision of this Ordinance shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, or imprisoned for a term of not more than 90 days, or both. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.561 - Sec. 11. 
CONFLICTING PROVISIONS REPEALED. 
    Any Ordinance or part of any Ordinance in conflict herewith, is hereby repealed. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.562 - Sec. 12. 
VALIDITY. 
    Should any section, clause or provision of this Chapter be declared by the Court to be invalid, the same shall not affect the validity of the Chapter as a whole or any part thereof, other than the part so declared. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.563 - Sec. 13. 
DECLARATION OF EFFECT. 
    This Ordinance is hereby declared to be an emergency Ordinance which is deemed to be immediately necessary for the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the City of Mount Clemens, and to prevent the creation of nuisances and hazards to the public welfare and is hereby ordered to take immediate effect. 
(code eff Oct., 1958; amend. May 22, 1973; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.570 - VENDING MACHINES, DISTRIBUTORS AND OWNERS ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted effective Dec. 16, 1982, added secs. 20.570-20.577 to this Code, with sec. 20.570 entitled "Definitions" and containing two secs. designated 20.572. In order to conform the ordinance to the style established in the Code, the editor has designated the main heading sec. 20.570, with secs. 20.571 through 20.578 following. 

20.571 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    In this Ordinance: 
A.  DISTRIBUTOR means any person who places coin-operated vending machines in any place or establishment, excluding an "owner" as herein defined, for operation. 
B.  OWNER means any person who owns, operates or conducts any place or establishment in which any coin-operated vending machine may be operated. 
C.  VENDING MACHINE means any mechanical device which upon insertion of a coin returns the value in merchandise of the sum thus inserted. 
D.  PREMISES means any structure or place wherein any service or merchandise is offered for sale to the public, or where any vending machine is furnished for anticipated gain or profit by the owner or operator. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982) 
20.572 - Sec. 2. 
LICENSE REQUIRED. 
    No person, owner, distributor, society, club, firm, or corporation shall distribute, operate, maintain, or cause to be maintained any coin-operated vending machine as herein defined, without having first obtained a license therefor for the premises wherein the said device is to be located; and in addition thereto, no such device shall be operated or maintained on the premises without having first obtained a license for each device. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982) 
20.573 - Sec. 3. 
PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING LICENSE; REQUIREMENTS, FEES AND TERM. 
A.  Application for a license shall be made to the City Clerk, in the form and manner required by the Clerk and in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance and Code, which application shall include at least the following information: 
1.  The name and address of the owner, operator, or distributor. 
2.  The location of the premises where such vending machines will be located. 
3.  The number, type, and serial number of each such device; provided, if the serial number is not available at the time of application, it shall be submitted prior to placing the device into operation after issuance of a license. 
B.  If, after the issuance of any license, the licensee desires to operate other machines in addition to the number stated in the application for a license he shall make a new application to the City Clerk in the same form and manner as the original application for a license. 
C.  Before any license shall be issued under the provisions of this Section, the applicant shall pay to the City Treasurer a license fee in the sum specified in Section 20.283(19). 
D.  All licenses granted under the provisions of this Ordinance shall expire on the first day of June at 12:00 midnight after the date of issuance thereof. 
E.  After filing of the application with the required fee, copies thereof shall be promptly forwarded by the City Clerk to the Chief of Police and the Building Inspector, who shall then cause an investigation to be made for the purpose of determining if the application and the proposed operation of the vending machines are in compliance with the City of Mount Clemens Zoning Ordinance and this Ordinance and whether the premises complies with the Building, Fire, Safety, and Zoning Codes of the City of Mount Clemens. Upon completion of such investigation, the Chief of Police and the Building Inspector shall file with the City Clerk a recommendation for approval or disapproval. In the event that disapproval is recommended, such recommendation shall set forth the reasons therefor. 
F.  Upon receipt of the recommendation of the Chief of Police and the Building Inspector, if approval is recommended, the City Clerk shall issue a license within fifteen (15) days. If disapproval is recommended by either the Chief of Police or Building Inspector, the City Clerk shall within fifteen (15) days cause the application to heard by the licensing board to be appointed by the City Commission for action by the board in granting approval or disapproval of the license. If the licensing board shall disapprove the issuance of a license, it shall state the reasons therefor. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982; amend. July 1, 1983; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.574 - Sec. 4. 
REVOCATION OF LICENSE. 
A.  Any license hereunder may be revoked by the licensing board upon violation of any provision of this Ordinance or term, or condition of the license issued hereunder. 
B.  Notice of proposed revocation of license shall be given in writing by the licensing board or the Chief of Police as its agent to the licensee, who may within a period of ten (10) days after receipt of said notice demand a public hearing on such revocation before the licensing board. At any such hearing, the licensee may appear in person or by an attorney and offer any evidence it may have why such license should not be revoked. Upon conclusion of all such evidence, the licensing board shall render its decision on the revocation in writing within fourteen (14) days thereafter. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982) 
20.575 - Sec. 5. 
POLICE INSPECTION REQUIRED. 
    It shall be the duty of police officers to make inspections of all vending machines and if any unlawful practices are observed in connection therewith, they shall report the same to the Chief of Police for such action as he may deem proper and the Chief of Police may recommend the immediate revocation of such license. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982) 
20.576 - Sec. 6. 
IDENTIFICATION MARKS REQUIRED. 
    Each coin-operated vending machine shall have affixed thereto in a conspicuous position a suitable and permanent identification stamp, mark, or plate bearing the name and address of the distributor thereof. The City Clerk shall furnish a list containing the names and addresses of all licensees hereunder to the Chief of Police to facilitate the inspections required by Section 5. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982) 
20.577 - Sec. 7. 
OBSCENE, INDECENT; PROHIBITION. 
    No vending machine device shall display, expose, produce, or emit any printed matter, advertisement, writing or other matter that is obscene, indecent, pornographic, or contrary to good morals. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982) 
20.578 - Sec. 8. 
PENALTY. 
    Any person, society, club, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this Ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof may be fined a sum not exceeding $500.00 or imprisoned for a term not exceeding 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. For purposes of this Section, each day a person, society, club, firm, or corporation is not in compliance with this Ordinance shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(ord. eff. Dec. 16, 1982; amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
Introduction and First Reading: November 15, 1982 
Second Reading and Adoption: December 6, 1982 
Effective Date: December 16, 1982 
20.580 - AMUSEMENT MACHINES CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 further amend. eff. Dec. 16, 1982[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Article 2 of an ordinance adopted Dec. 6, 1982, effective Dec. 6, 1982, repealed all references to vending machines contained in secs. 20.580-20.590. 
Cross reference- For city authority to regulate amusements, see Char. sec. 11(L). 
State Law reference- See also C.L., 1948, sec. 117.4j(4); Mich. Stat. Anno. sec. 5.2082. 

20.581 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    In this Ordinance: 
A.  COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICE means any electric, electronic or mechanical device for the purpose of amusement which may be operated or set in motion by the insertion of a coin or for which a financial charge is made by the owner or operator even though such device is not coin-operated. Samples of such devices by way of illustration, and not by way of limitation, are pinball machine, skeeball machine, motion picture machine or electrically operated game, pool table, shuffleboard, bagatelle, pitch and hold, pin game, puck game, marble game, space invaders, laffleboard, Pac-Man, tabletop game and any and all similar devices. 
B.  COIN-OPERATED MUSIC DEVICE means a piano, phonograph, jukebox or any similar machine or contrivance which emits recitations, songs, speeches, or music upon the insertion of a coin. 
C.  DISTRIBUTOR means any person who places coin-operated amusement or music devices in any place or establishment, excluding an "owner" as herein defined, for operation. 
D.  OWNER means any person who owns, operates or conducts any place or establishment in which any coin-operated amusement or music device may be operated. 
E.  PREMISES means any structure or place wherein any service or merchandise is offered for sale to the public, or where any amusement or service is furnished for anticipated gain or profit by the owner or operator. 
F.  ARCADE means any premises on which more than three (3) coin-operated amusement devices are operated; except if such premises shall possess a Class C liquor license pursuant to the Michigan Liquor Control Act, being section 436.1 et seq. of the Michigan Compiled Laws, such premises shall not be an "ARCADE" for purposes of this Ordinance unless more than five (5) coin-operated amusement devices are operated. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Jan. 14, 1982; further amend. eff. Oct. 13, 1983) 
20.582 - Sec. 2. 
LICENSE REQUIRED. 
A.  No person, owner, distributor, society, club, firm or corporation shall distribute, operate, maintain or cause to be maintained any coin-operated amusement device or coin-operated music device, as herein defined, without having first obtained a license therefor, for the premises wherein the device is to be located; and in addition thereto, no such device shall be operated or maintained on the premises without having first obtained a license for each such device. 
B.  No person shall operate an arcade, as defined herein, without first having obtained an arcade license in addition to a license for each coin-operated amusement device, as required by subsection A, supra, and without first complying with all of the requirements of this chapter. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Jan. 14, 1982) 
20.583 - Sec. 3. 
PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING LICENSE; REQUIREMENTS, FEES AND TERMS. 
A.  Application for a license shall be made to the City Clerk in the form and manner required by him, and in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance and code; and the application shall state, among other things: 
1.  The name and address of the owner, operator or distributor. 
2.  The location of the premises where such amusement devices will be located. 
3.  The number, type and serial number of each such device; provided, if the serial number is not available at the time of application, it shall be submitted prior to placing the device into operation after issuance of a license. 
B.  If, after the issuance of any license, the licensee desires to operate other machines in addition to the number stated in the application for a license, he shall make a new application to the City Clerk in the same form and manner as the original application for a license. 
C.  The application for a distributor's license shall be accompanied by the fingerprints of the applicant; and, in the event the applicant is a corporation, the application shall be accompanied by the fingerprints of the officers thereof and the names of the stockholders thereof. 
D.  Before any license shall be issued under the provisions of this Section, the applicant shall pay to the City Treasurer a license fee in the sum specified in Section 20.283(7) for coin-operated amusement devices, Section 20.283(8) for coin-operated music devices, and Section 20.283(2) for arcades. 
E.  All licenses granted under the provisions of this Ordinance shall expire on the first day of June at 12:00 midnight after the date of issuance thereof. 
F.  After filing of the application with the required fee, copies thereof shall be promptly forwarded by the City Clerk to the Chief of Police and the Building Inspector who shall then cause an investigation to be made for the purpose of determining if the application and the proposed operation of the amusement devices are in compliance with the City of Mount Clemens Zoning Ordinance, [2] and this Ordinance and the following matters: 
1.  Whether the distributor, owner or operator is of good moral character. 
2.  Whether the distributor, owner or operator has been convicted of any criminal offense involving moral turpitude. 
3.  Whether the premises complies with the Building, Fire, Safety and Zoning Codes of the City of Mount Clemens and in the case of an arcade, whether it complies with Section 4 of this Chapter. 
Upon completion of such investigation, the Chief of Police and the Building Inspector shall file with the City Clerk a recommendation for approval or disapproval. In the event that disapproval is recommended, such recommendation shall set forth the reason(s) therefor. 
G.  Upon receipt of the recommendation of the Chief of Police and the Building Inspector, if approval is recommended, the City Clerk shall issue a license within fifteen (15) days. If disapproval is recommended by either the Chief of Police or Building Inspector, the City Clerk shall within fifteen (15) days cause the application to be heard by the licensing board to be appointed by the City Commission for action by the board in granting approval or disapproval of the license. If the licensing board shall disapprove the issue of a license, it shall state the reasons therefor. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Nov. 27, 1980; further amend eff. Jan. 14, 1982; further amend. eff. Jan. 20, 1983; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
Cross reference- For general licensing provisions see secs. 20.251 et seq.; these provisions are supplemental and complementary to the provisions of this Ordinance, see sec. 20.282, supra. 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The cite to specific section to be supplied later. 

20.584 - Sec. 4. 
AMUSEMENT DEVICES; OPERATION, MINORS; AGE RESTRICTIONS; PROOF OF AGE; ARCADE REQUIREMENTS. 
A.  No person under the age of 16 years shall be permitted, caused or suffered to be present in, frequent, or remain on or in any arcade, as defined herein, unless such child is accompanied by his parent or guardian or is on an errand or duty under the direction of his parent or guardian, or unless the employment of such child requires that he be upon such premises. 
B.  No licensee shall permit or condone the violation of the above subsection. 
C.  Any person allowed to remain in an establishment licensed under this chapter, who is not with a parent or guardian, shall possess proof of age. No licensee shall allow a person to remain on the premises who does not have proof of age as required herein. 
D.  No person shall operate an arcade unless lighting of at least 80 candlepower is provided measuring 30 inches off the floor. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Jan. 14, 1982) 
20.585 - Sec. 5. 
REVOCATION OF LICENSE. 
A.  Any license issued hereunder may be revoked by the licensing board upon violation of any provision of this Ordinance or term or condition of the license issued hereunder. 
B.  Notice of proposed revocation of license shall be given in writing by the licensing board or the Chief of Police as its agent to the licensee who may, within a period of ten (10) days after receipt of said notice, demand a public hearing on such revocation before the licensing board. At any such hearing, the licensee may appear in person or by an attorney and offer any evidence it may have why such license should not be revoked. Upon conclusion of all such evidence, the licensing board shall render its decision on the revocation in writing within fourteen (14) days thereafter. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Jan. 14, 1982) 
20.586 - Sec. 6. 
POLICE INSPECTION REQUIRED. 
    It shall be the duty of police officers to make inspections of all coin-operated amusement and music devices; and if any unlawful practices are observed in connection therewith, they shall report the same to the Chief of Police for such action as he may deem proper and the Chief of Police may recommend the immediate revocation of such license. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Jan. 14, 1982) 
20.587 - Sec. 7. 
IDENTIFICATION MARKS REQUIRED. 
    Each coin-operated amusement and music device shall have affixed thereto, in a conspicuous position, a suitable and permanent identification stamp, mark or plate bearing the name and address of the distributor thereof. The City Clerk shall furnish a list containing the names and addresses of all licensees hereunder to the Chief of Police to facilitate inspections as required by Section 6. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Jan. 14, 1982) 
20.588 - Sec. 8. 
LIMITING NUMBER OF DEVICES. 
    The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to limit the number of coin-operated amusement or music devices in any one establishment or place of business. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978, further amend. eff. Jan. 14, 1982) 
20.589 - Sec. 9. 
OBSCENE, INDECENT; PROHIBITION. 
    No device shall display, expose, produce or emit any motion picture, printed matter, advertisement, writing, song, recitation, speech, music or other matter that is obscene, indecent, pornographic or contrary to good morals. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Jan. 14, 1982) 
20.590 - Sec. 10. 
PENALTY. 
    Any person, society, club, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this Ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof may be fined a sum not exceeding $500.00 or imprisoned for a term not exceeding 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. For purposes of this Section, each day a person, society, club, firm, or corporation is not in compliance with this Ordinance shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(ord. eff. Jan. 14, 1982; amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
20.590 - AMUSEMENT DEVICE LICENSING BOARD ord. eff. Feb. 26, 1982 

20.591 - Sec. 1. 
CREATION OF AMUSEMENT DEVICE LICENSING BOARD; TERM; REMOVAL; CHAIRPERSON. 
    The Amusement Device Licensing Board shall consist of five (5) members who shall be appointed by the City Commission and have the duties, responsibilities and powers that are provided for in this Article. The members shall serve for a term of three (3) years, except for members first appointed, two (2) of which shall serve three (3) years, two (2) of which shall serve two (2) years, and one (1) who will serve for one (1) year. The members shall be subject to removal by the City Commission at any time. The members of the Board shall elect a chairperson who shall preside at all meetings and a secretary who shall duly record all minutes at all meetings. 
(ord. eff. Feb. 26, 1982; amend. Apr. 15, 1982) 
20.592 - Sec. 2. 
MEETINGS; PROCEDURE; RECORDS; AND PUBLIC NOTICE. 
    Meetings of the Amusement Device Licensing Board shall be held at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as the Board may determine. The Board shall adopt rules of procedure and shall keep records of petitions and revocations and the actions thereon, which shall be a public record. The Board's business shall be conducted at a public meeting, and public notice thereof shall be given. 
(ord. eff. Feb. 26, 1982) 
20.593 - Sec. 3. 
POWERS OF THE AMUSEMENT DEVICE LICENSING BOARD. 
    The Amusement Device Licensing Board shall have the power to approve, disapprove, or revoke any license required by Sections 20.581 through 20.590 of the City of Mount Clemens Code of Ordinances and to implement its decisions hereby duly authorized. 
(ord. eff. Feb. 26, 1982) 
20.594 - Sec. 4. 
LICENSES, DENIAL, REVOCATION, CAUSES ENUMERATED; NOTICE. 
1.  A license may be denied of any applicant, and any license may be revoked by the Amusement Device Licensing Board, for any of the following causes: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the license application. 
(b)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement while engaging in conduct regulated by the City of Mount Clemens Amusement Device Ordinance. 
(c)  Any violation of the City of Mount Clemens Amusement Device Ordinances Sections 20.581 through 20.590. 
(d)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
2.  Where the Amusement Device Licensing Board shall deny or revoke any license, a notice specifying the cause of such denial or revocation shall be given the applicant or licensee at the address supplied in the license application, with written reasons therefor. 
(ord. eff. Feb. 26, 1982) 
Introduction and First Reading: Jan. 4, 1982 
Second Reading and Adoption: Feb. 16, 1982 
Effective Date: Feb. 26, 1982 
20.600 - MINORS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 29, 2003 

20.610 
CURFEW. 
    The Mount Clemens City Curfew Ordinance has been amended to lower the age of the curfew to 16 years old, in conformity with Michigan Statute, MCLA 722.752. The former Mount Clemens Curfew Ordinance set the age at 18 years old. A new "Aiding and Abetting," provision has been included in this proposed ordinance, and the penalty provision has also been updated to conform to state law. 
(ord. eff. May 29, 2003) 
20.611 - Sec. 1. 
CURFEW. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of 16 years old to loiter, idle, congregate, or be upon the public streets or in any public place between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6 a.m. on Sundays, Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, or between 10:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Fridays and Saturdays, unless such minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian, or an adult person delegated by the minor's parent or guardian to accompany such minor, or is upon an errand or duty under the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, or unless the employment of such minor requires that the minor be upon the public streets or in public places during the nighttime after the above-specified hours. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Sept. 29, 1988; further amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
20.612 - Sec. 2. 
AIDING AND ABETTING. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person over the age of 16 years old, including a parent, guardian or other person having the care an custody of any minor under the age of 16 years old, to aid, abet, assist, permit, allow or encourage such minor to violate the provisions of this Curfew Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
20.613 - Sec. 3. 
PENALTY. 
    Violation of this section shall be a misdemeanor punishable by 93 days in jail or a $500.00 fine, or both. 
(amend. eff. May 29, 2003) 
Introduction and First Reading: May 5, 2003 
Second Reading and Adoption: May 19, 2003 
Effective Date: May 29, 2003 
20.620 
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES. 
20.621 - Sec. 1. 
AGE; MISREPRESENTATION PROHIBITED. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to falsely represent himself to be of the age of 21 years or older when purchasing, offering to purchase, or attempting to purchase or procure beer, wine or any other alcoholic beverage, or to give any false information regarding age to any law enforcement officer or to any person selling beer, wine or any other alcoholic beverage for the purpose of securing a sale thereof to himself. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Feb. 14, 1980) 
20.622 - Sec. 2. 
PROCURING FOR MINORS; PROHIBITION. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any false representation in order to procure the sale or furnishing of beer, wine or any other alcoholic beverage to any person under the age of 21 years. 
B.  It shall be unlawful to give or to loan to any minor a birth certificate or other document evidencing age or identity for the purpose of assisting any minor to obtain beer, wine or any other alcoholic beverage. The possession and use of such document by any minor to obtain beer, wine or any other alcoholic beverage shall be prima facie evidence that such document was furnished to such minor for the purpose of assisting in the purchase or procurement of such alcoholic beverage. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Feb. 14, 1980) 
20.623 - Sec. 3. 
POSSESSION, TRANSPORTATION; PROHIBITION, EXCEPTION. 
    That it shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to purchase or knowingly possess or transport any beer, wine or other alcoholic beverage, or knowingly possess, transport, or have under his control in any motor vehicle any beer, wine or other alcoholic beverage unless said person is employed by a licensee under license issued by the Michigan Liquor Control Commission and is possessing, transporting or having such beer, wine or other alcoholic beverage in his motor vehicle under his control during regular working hours and in the course of his employment. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Feb. 14, 1980) 
20.624 - Sec. 4. 
PENALTY. 
A.  Any person violating any provision of Number 20.623, Sec. 3, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed 90 days, or by both. 
B.  Any minor, subject to the jurisdiction of the Juvenile Division of the Probate Court, who violates any provision of this Ordinance, shall be dealt with in the manner prescribed by the laws of the State. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan. 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.630 
PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY. 
20.631 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITION. 
    That, for the purposes of enforcing and construing the within Ordinance, the following definitions shall apply: 
A.  PARENTAL NEGLECT. Parental neglect is hereby defined as an act or acts of commission or omission by the parent of a minor which results in the minor being a repeat offender of the statutes of the State of Michigan and/or the Code of Ordinances of the City of Mount Clemens and/or the Juvenile Code of the State of Michigan, and shall include only those acts of commission or omission wherein the parent failed to exercise reasonable parental control over the minor; 
B.  PARENT. A parent is herein defined as the mother or father or both, or a legal guardian, and, in the case of a legal guardian, only a legal guardian of the person of said minor and who has the care, custody and control of said minor; 
C.  MINOR. A minor, for the purposes of this Ordinance, is defined as a person under the age of seventeen (17) years at the time of the allegation of the commission of the latest offense which makes him a repeat offender; 
D.  CRIMINAL ACTS. Criminal acts is herein defined as those acts which are in violation of the statutes of the State of Michigan and/or the Code of Ordinances of the City of Mount Clemens and/or the Juvenile Code of the State of Michigan, but only in those instances where such statutes and/or Ordinances and/or Juvenile Code provisions contain penalty provisions; 
E.  REPEAT OFFENDER. A repeat offender is defined as a minor who has been adjudicated as having committed two or more criminal acts, exclusive of moving traffic violations, or who has been adjudicated as having committed four moving traffic violations. In the case of moving traffic violations, the four violations shall have occurred within a 12-month period. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; ord. adopted Apr. 19, 1971; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.632 - Sec. 2. 
UNLAWFUL ACTS. 
    Upon the effective date of this Ordinance, it shall be unlawful for a parent to commit parental neglect according to the definitions of the within Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; ord. adopted Apr. 19, 1971; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.633 - Sec. 3. 
NOTICE AND MANNER OF NOTICE. 
    Whenever a minor shall be apprehended or arrested or detained for the alleged commission of a criminal act within the City of Mount Clemens, County of Macomb, State of Michigan, the parent of such minor, as defined herein, shall be forthwith notified by the Mount Clemens Police Department, either personally or by telephonic communication or by first-class mail, advising the parent of such apprehension, arrest or detention, and the reason therefor, and the parents' responsibility under this Ordinance. In the event that the minor is apprehended, arrested, or detained by another law enforcement department for an alleged criminal act committed within the City of Mount Clemens, then, and in that event, the Mount Clemens Police Department shall notify said parent, as above set forth, as soon as practicable after receiving notice itself. The date, time and the place to where notice is given, and the place from where the notice is given, shall be kept as a matter of record by the Mount Clemens Police Department; provided, however, that no notice of conviction of said minor shall be required. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; ord. adopted Apr. 19, 1971; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.634 - Sec. 4. 
NUMBER OF NOTICES. 
    No prosecution shall be commenced under this Ordinance until the parent notified has received at least two notices of the apprehension, arrest or detention of a minor. No notice of convictions shall be required. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; ord. adopted Apr. 19, 1971; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.635 - Sec. 5. 
REPEAL. 
    All Ordinances and parts of Ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; ord. adopted Apr. 19, 1971; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.636 - Sec. 6. 
VALIDITY. 
    If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of the within Ordinance is, for any reason, held to be unconstitutional, such adjudication, shall not affect the validity of the remaining sections, sentences, clauses and phrases of the within Ordinance, or the Ordinance as an entirety, it being the legislative intent that this Ordinance shall stand, notwithstanding the adjudicated invalidity of such section, sentence, clause or phrase. 
(code. eff. Oct., 1958; ord. adopted Apr. 19, 1971; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.637 - Sec. 7. 
PENALTY. 
    Any parent found guilty under this Ordinance shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00, or may be sentenced to a term of not more than 90 days in jail, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; ord. adopted Apr. 19, 1971; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.640 - FIREWORKS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. July 2, 2012; amend. eff. July 1, 2013 

20.640 - FIREWORKS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. no. 20.640 is hereby amended and shall read as follows: 
The Michigan Fireworks Safety Act, Act 256 of 2011, effective January 1, 2012, legalized the sale of consumer fireworks in Michigan, and delegated to local communities limited control over the use and discharge of fireworks. The following ordinance is adopted to repeal the existing fireworks ordinance that conflicted with the Act and to amend the ordinance to comply with the same and regulations promulgated thereto governing fireworks. 
20.641 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    As used in this ordinance, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  "Act 256" means the Michigan Fireworks Safety Act, Act 256 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 2011, being MCL 28.451, et. seq., as it may be amended from time to time. 
(2)  "Consumer fireworks" means that term as defined in Act 256. 
(3)  "Firework" or "fireworks" means that term as defined in Act 256. 
(4)  "Minor" means an individual who is less than 18 years of age. 
(5)  "Retailer" means that term as defined in Act 256. 
(6)  "Wholesaler" means that term as defined in Act 256. 
(7)  "Sky Lantern" means an unmanned, airborne floating device, which requires a candle or open flame which serves as a heat source to cause it to be propelled and lifted into the air. Sky lanterns include but are not limited to sky candles, fire balloons and airborne lanterns. 
(ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1992; amend. eff. July 2, 2012; amend. eff. July 1, 2013; amend. eff. Oct. 1, 2015; amend. eff. March 18, 2019) 
20.642 - Sec. 2. 
COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE ORDINANCES AND CODES. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this ordinance, a retailer or wholesaler of fireworks located within the City must comply with the requirements of the City Zoning Ordinance, as well as all building codes and regulations, and nothing in this ordinance or in Act 256 shall preclude the enforcement of ordinances prohibiting offensive conduct that is secondary or incidental to the use, discharge or ignition of fireworks, regardless of the day. 
(ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1992; further amend. eff. Feb. 17, 1994; amend. eff. July 2, 2012; amend. eff. July 1, 2013; amend. eff. March 18, 2019) 
20.643 - Sec. 3.1. 
USE OF CONSUMER FIREWORKS PROHIBITED. 
(A)  Except as provided in this Section, a person shall not ignite, discharge or use consumer fireworks in the City at any time. 
(B)  A person may ignite, discharge, or use consumer fireworks on the following days, during the following hours: 
1.  Between 11:00 a.m. on December 31 st and 1:00 a.m. on the day immediately following January 1 st . 
2.  Between 11:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on the Saturday immediately preceding Memorial Day. 
3.  Between 11:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on the Sunday immediately preceding Memorial Day. 
4.  Between 11:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on June 29 th , June 30 th , July 1 st , July 2 nd , July 3 rd , and July 4 th . 
5.  Between 11:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on July 5 th , if that date is a Friday or Saturday. 
6.  Between 11:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on the Saturday immediately preceding Labor Day. 
7.  Between 11:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on the Sunday immediately preceding Labor Day. 
(C)  A person shall not ignite, discharge or use consumer fireworks on public property, school property, church property, or the property of another person without that organization's or person's express permission to use those fireworks on those premises. 
(D)  Sky Lanterns shall not be ignited, launched, released, discharged or used within the City. 
(ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1992; amend. eff. July 2, 2012; amend. eff. July 1, 2013; amend. eff. Oct. 1, 2015; amend. eff. March 18, 2019) 
20.643 - Sec. 3.2. 
FIREWORKS SAFETY. 
    A minor shall not possess consumer fireworks, and no person shall recklessly endanger the life, health, safety or well being of any person by ignition, discharge, or use of consumer fireworks. 
(ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1992; amend. eff. July 2, 2012; amend. eff. July 1, 2013; amend. eff. March 18, 2019) 
20.644 - Sec. 4. 
VIOLATIONS, FINES AND PENALTIES. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this ordinance shall be deemed to have committed a civil infraction and may be ordered to pay a civil fine of not more than One Thousand ($1,000.00) dollars, plus costs. Of that fine, $500.00 must be remitted to the Macomb County Sheriff's Office. 
(ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1992; amend. eff. July 2, 2012; amend. eff. July 1, 2013; amend. eff. March 18, 2019) 
20.645 - Sec. 5. 
LICENSES; ISSUANCE AND REVOCATION. 
(ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1992; further amend. eff. Feb. 17, 1994; repealed eff. July 2, 2012) 
20.646 - Sec. 6. 
SERVICE OF PROCESS. 
(ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1992; repealed eff. July 2, 2012) 
20.647 - Sec. 7. 
LICENSE DISPLAY AND FEES. 
(ord. no. 20.640 eff. June 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1992; further amend. eff. Feb. 17, 1994; repealed eff. July 2, 2012)

ENFORCEMENT; DUTIES OF POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS.

REVOCATION OF LICENSE.

20.650 - CLOSING-OUT SALES CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend, Jan., 1978 

20.651 - Sec. 1. 
LICENSE REQUIRED. 
    No person shall advertise, represent or hold out that any sale of goods, wares or merchandise is an insurance, bankruptcy, mortgage, insolvent, assignee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's, trustee's, removal or closing-out sale, or a sale of goods, wares and merchandise damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, unless he shall have first procured a license. Such license shall be valid only for a sale of the goods, wares and merchandise inventoried and described in the application for such license, in the manner and at the time and place mentioned and set forth in such application. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
State Law reference- For state law, see C.L., 1948, secs. 442.201 et seq.; Mich. Stat. Anno., secs. 19.391 et seq. 
20.652 - Sec. 2. 
APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, CONTENTS. 
    Application for a license shall be made to the City Clerk in the form and manner prescribed by him, and shall include, among other things: 
A.  A sworn inventory containing a complete and accurate enumeration of the stock of goods, wares or merchandise to be sold at any sale for which a license is hereby required, together with the wholesale price thereof and the date of the acquisition of such merchandise. The inventory shall be signed by the applicant or by a resident agent and, by affidavit at the foot thereof, the affiant shall swear and affirm that the information therein contained is full and true and known by him so to be. 
B.  A statement of whether the personal property taxes have been paid to date on such goods, wares or merchandise proposed to be sold, and, if not, the amount of such taxes as are then due and unpaid. 
C.  A statement showing the ownership of the goods, wares or merchandise proposed to be sold, the ownership and the address of the premises where the sale is to be held, the name of the person or agent who is to conduct such sale, and the hours during which such sale is to be held. 
D.  A statement signed by the owner of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold and the owner of the premises where the sale is to be held, to the effect that they will freely and voluntarily permit any person so designated by the City Manager to inspect such merchandise or premises at any time during the sale for the purpose of determining whether the provisions of this Ordinance are complied with. 
E.  If such sale is to be conducted as a fire sale, there shall be included with such application a statement signed by the Fire Chief to the effect that the building where the goods, wares or merchandise were stored was actually damaged by fire and specifying the date thereof. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.653 - Sec. 3. 
APPLICATIONS; RECORDS REQUIRED, EVIDENCE. 
    The City Clerk shall endorse upon each application the date of its filing and shall preserve the same as a record in his office. He shall prepare an abstract of the facts set forth in the application in a book kept for that purpose. Such abstract and application shall be prima facie evidence of all statements therein contained. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.654 - Sec. 4. 
LICENSES; FEES, TERM. 
A.  FEES. Before any license shall be issued, the applicant shall pay to the City Treasurer, at the time the application for a license is filed, a license fee in the sum specified in Section 20.283(6), based on the length of time during which the sale is to be held. 
B.  TERM. No license shall be issued for a term less than 30 days nor more than 90 days, nor shall any person be granted more than one license during any twelve-month period. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987) 
Cross reference- For general licensing provisions, see secs. 20.251 et seq.; these provisions are supplemental and complementary to the provisions of this Ordinance, see sec. 20.282, supra. 
20.655 - Sec. 5. 
STATE LAW; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED. 
    All provisions of state law relative to such sales shall be complied with. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.670 - PRECIOUS METAL AND GEM DEALERS ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012 

20.671 - Sec. 1. 
PURPOSE. 
    In order to protect public health, safety and welfare and to advance the legitimate rational regulation of businesses, the City is desirous of licensing and regulating precious metal and gem dealers in order to promote and protect public health and welfare, reduce and or eliminate the acceptance and resale of stolen or unauthorized property, and reduce crime through such regulation. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
ARTICLE I - DEFINITIONS, TRANS- ACTIONS, RECORDING 

20.672 - Sec. 2. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    Definitions utilized under this ordinance shall be the same definitions as provided in the Precious Metal and Gem Dealer Act MCL 445.482 as amended. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.673 - Sec. 3. 
REGISTRATION AND 
TRANSACTION FEE. 
    A registration fee and renewal fee shall be assessed from each licensee in a manner and amount as set from time to time by resolution of the City Commission. A transaction fee per transaction shall be payable in an amount as set from time to time by the Macomb County Sheriff's Office. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.674 - Sec. 4. 
RECORDS OF TRANSACTIONS. 
(1)  A dealer shall maintain a permanent record of each transaction, on record of transaction forms provided for in Act 95 of 1981. Such record shall be legibly written or otherwise printed in ink in the English language. Each record of transaction form shall be filled out in quadruplicate by the dealer or agent or employee of the dealer. One copy of the form shall go to the Macomb County Sheriff's Office pursuant to State law; one (1) copy shall go to the customer; and one (1) copy shall be retained by the dealer pursuant to State law. 
(2)  At the time a dealer receives or purchases a precious item, the dealer or the agent or employee of the dealer shall insure that the following information is recorded accurately on a record of transaction form: 
(a)  The dealer certificate of registration number. 
(b)  A general description of the precious item or precious items received or purchased, including the type of metal or precious gem. In the case of watches, the description shall contain the name of the maker and the number of both the works and the case. In the case of jewelry, all letters and marks inscribed on the jewelry shall be included in the description. 
(c)  The date of the transaction. 
(d)  The name of the person conducting the transaction. 
(e)  The name, date of birth, driver's license number or State of Michigan personal identification card number, and street and house number of the customer, together with a legible imprint of the right thumb of the customer, or if that is not possible, of the left thumb or a finger of the customer. However, the thumbprint or fingerprint shall only be required on the record of transaction form retained by the dealer. The thumbprint or fingerprint shall be made available to a police agency during the course of a police investigation involving a precious item or items described on the record of transaction. After a period of 1 year from the date of the record of transaction, if a police investigation concerning a precious item or items described on the record of transaction has not occurred, the dealer and any police agency or sheriff's department holding a copy of the record of transaction shall destroy, and not keep a permanent record of, the record of transaction. A dealer who goes out of business or changes his or her business address to another local jurisdiction either within or out of this state shall transmit the records of all transactions made by the dealer within 1 year before his or her closing or moving, to the local police agency. 
(f)  The price paid by the dealer for the precious item or precious items. 
(g)  The form of payment to the customer; check, money order, bank draft, or cash. If the payment is by check, money order, or bank draft, the dealer shall indicate the number of the check, money order, or bank draft. 
(h)  The customer's signature. 
(3)  The record of each transaction shall be numbered consecutively, commencing with the number 1 and the current calendar year (example, 01-2012). 
(4)  The record of transaction forms of a dealer and each precious item received shall be open to an inspection by the county prosecuting attorney, the Macomb County Sheriff's office, the police agency or sheriff's office of the local unit in which the customer resides, and the Michigan State Police, at all times during the ordinary business hours of the dealer. As a condition of doing business, a dealer is considered to have given consent to the inspection prescribed by this subsection. The record of transaction forms of a dealer shall not be open to inspection by the general public. 
(5)  The items shall be photographed and any serial number or other markings provided, as well as any other information as required pursuant to the electronic transaction reporting processes utilized by the City. 
(6)  The form of the record of transaction shall be provided in a format as required by the Macomb County Sheriff's office. Any costs incurred to utilize the format required shall be borne by the dealer. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.675 - Sec. 5. 
RETENTION OF TRANSACTION AND TRANSMITTAL TO SHERIFF'S OFFICE. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided by State Law, each record of a transaction shall be retained by the dealer for not less than one (1) year after the transaction to which the record pertains. 
(2)  Within 48 hours after receiving or purchasing a precious item, the dealer shall send a copy of the record of transaction form to the Macomb County Sheriff's office and, if the record of transaction form indicates that the customer resides outside the jurisdiction of the City of Mount Clemens, the dealer shall send a copy of the record of transaction form to the police agency of the city, village, or township in which the customer resides as set forth on the record of transaction, or, if that city, village, or township does not have a police agency, to the police agency or sheriff's department of the county in which the customer resides as set forth on the record of transaction. 
(a)  Every licensee, owner and employee, shall keep a record of all persons and/or entities with whom business has transacted and all property coming into their possession. Reports must be electronically transmitted to the Macomb County Sheriff's office. Within forty-eight (48) hours of receipt by purchase, or otherwise of a precious item, a report must be transmitted by means of electronic transmission through a modem, or similar device in a format that the data is capable of direct electronic entry into the Macomb County Sheriff's office computerized system, or its designee for identifying property coming into the possession of a licensor. A transaction report by electronic transmission under this sub section shall not be reported on paper forms, unless the Macomb County Sheriff's office so requires. All dealers must have the equipment installed in their place of business no later than November 1, 2012. Information must be reported electronically beginning November 1, 2012. If the volume of transactions does not exceed ten (10) for a ninety (90) day period transactions taking place at that business may not be reported electronically, but shall be reported on paper forms approved by the Macomb County Sheriff's office. 
(b)  A fee as adopted and subject to change periodically by the Macomb County Sheriff's office shall be assessed per transaction. The vendor will assess the property registration fee for each transaction, the licensee reports either through batch file upload, or directly using the vendor's business interface or on the vendor's automated reported service that involves transactions subject to the provision of this chapter. 
(c)  Transaction is defined as a single buy, which may involve one or more items and does not include contract extension, or claims. The per transaction registration fee is not a per item fee, included in the transaction. It is within the sole discretion of the secondhand dealer whether to recover the fee from their customers for registering a transaction. 
(d)  The licensee will be invoiced on a monthly basis. The Macomb County Sheriff office's vendor automated reporting service isolates and generates a list of the billable transactions that will be used for deriving invoiced amounts. The above fees are assessed for the use of the standard vendor's automated recording service Any custom programming completed for the secondhand dealer will be negotiated on a contract basis and may result in additional licensing arrangements between the vendor and the licensor. Failure to timely pay as invoiced is a violation of this ordinance. 
(3)  The record of transaction forms received by a police agency or sheriff's department shall not be open to inspection by the general public. Each police agency or sheriff's department holding record of transaction forms shall be responsible for insuring the confidentiality of the record of transaction forms and insuring that the record of transaction forms are used only for the purpose for which they were received. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
ARTICLE II - CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION 

20.676 - Sec. 6. 
CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION. 
    No person shall carry on the business of a precious metal or gem dealer in the City without first having a "Certificate of Registration" issued from the City Clerk authorizing such person or entity to carry on such business subject to the provisions of this article. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.677 - Sec. 7. 
APPLICATION; PREREQUISITES. 
    A dealer shall apply to the City for a certificate of registration, and pay a fee in a manner and amount as set from time to time by resolution of the City Commission to cover the cost of processing and issuing the certificate of registration, by disclosing the following information: 
(a)  The name, address, and thumbprint of the applicant(s). 
(b)  The name and address under which the applicant does business. 
(c)  The name, address, and thumbprint of all agents or employees of the dealer. Within 24 hours after hiring a new employee, the dealer shall forward to the local police agency the name, address, and thumbprint of the new employee. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.678 - Sec. 8. 
CITY CLERK REVIEW. 
    The City Clerk shall review the application and determine whether the application complies with the provisions of this Ordinance and the "The Precious Metal and Gem Dealer Act" (Act 95 Of 1981). The Clerk shall complete the examination and issue a determination within thirty (30) days upon receipt of the application described herein. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.679 - Sec. 9. 
REVIEW BY COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT. 
    The Community Development Department shall within fifteen (15) days of the submittal of an application review the premises in order to determine whether the precious metal and gem dealer activities are compliant with the city building and zoning ordinances. Such determination shall be issued to the City Clerk. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.680 - Sec. 10. 
CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION, DURATION; RENEWAL; CHANGES. 
    Not less than 10 days before a dealer changes the name or address under which the dealer does business, the dealer shall notify the City Clerk in writing of the change. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.681 - Sec. 11. 
DISPLAY OF CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION. 
    Upon receipt of the certificate of registration, dealer shall post it in a conspicuous place in the dealer's place of business. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
ARTICLE III - REGULATIONS, BONDS, PENALTIES, REVOCATION 

20.682 - Sec. 12. 
PRECIOUS ITEM RETENTION; ALTERATION OR DEFACING UNLAWFUL. 
    A precious item received by a dealer shall be retained by the dealer for nine (9) calendar days after it was received, without any form of alteration other than that required for an accurate appraisal of its value. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.683 - Sec. 13. 
PRECIOUS ITEMS: ACCEPTANCE PROHIBITED AND UNLAWFUL. 
    A dealer or an agent or employee of a dealer shall not: 
(a)  Knowingly receive or purchase a precious item from any person who is less than 18 years of age or any person known by the dealer or agent or employee of the dealer to have been convicted of theft or receipt of stolen property within the preceding 5 years, whether the person is acting in his or her own behalf or as the agent of another. 
(b)  Knowingly receive or purchase a precious item from a person unless that person presents a valid driver's license or a valid state of Michigan personal identification card. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.684 - Sec. 14. 
VIOLATIONS; PENALTY. 
    Any violation of any provision of this ordinance shall be a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment of not more than ninety-three (93) days and/or a fine of Five Hundred ($500.00) Dollars, or both. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.685 - Sec. 15. 
LICENSE REVOCATION. 
    Any dealer, agent, or employee of a dealer who is convicted of any misdemeanor pursuant to this act, or under section 535 of the Michigan Penal Code, 1931, Public Act 328, MCL 750.535, or of the Precious Metal and Gem Dealer Act MCL 445.481, shall not be permitted to operate as a dealer for a period of one (1) year after conviction. A dealer, or an agent, or employee of a dealer who is convicted of a felony under MCL 445.481 et seq. Precious Metal and Gem Dealer Act, or under Section 535 of the Michigan Penal Code, 1931 Public Act 328, MCL 750.535, shall not be permitted to operate as a dealer for a period of five (5) years after conviction. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 30, 2012) 
20.700 - SHOPPING CARTS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978 

20.701 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    The following terms, whenever used or referred to in this Ordinance, shall have the following respective meanings, which definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this Ordinance unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
A.  PERSON shall mean and include any individual, firm, corporation or partnership. 
B.  CITY shall mean the City of Mount Clemens. 
C.  STORE shall mean and include any individual store, shop, chain-store or supermarket. 
D.  CART shall mean any rolling or nonrolling basket or container commonly used in so-called supermarkets or self-service stores. 
E.  PROPERTY shall mean and include any cart. 
F.  PREMISES shall mean and include all real estate in the name of the store owner, including the store building and any lot provided by the store owner for public parking. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.702 - Sec. 2. 
REMOVAL. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any cart, without permission of the owner, from any store premises. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.703 - Sec. 3. 
ABANDONMENT. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or suffer to be abandoned any cart removed from any store premises, upon any street, highway, alley, boulevard, public place, or private property not owned by the store owner within the City. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.704 - Sec. 4. 
LABELING. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to provide carts for patrons' use on the store premises unless such carts bear thereon a metallic tag designating the name of the owner. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.705 - Sec. 5. 
FAILURE TO RETRIEVE BY OWNER. 
    It shall be unlawful for any store to permit any person to remove a cart from the store premises unless the store retrieves such cart within one hour of closing on the day when removed. If any cart shall be found on any street, highway, alley, boulevard, public place, or private property not owned by the store owner within the City, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m., such finding will be presumptive evidence of violation of this section by the store. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.706 - Sec. 6. 
IMPOUNDMENT AND DISPOSAL. 
    Whenever any cart is found abandoned in any street, highway, alley, boulevard, public place or private property not owned by the store owner within the City, the cart shall be impounded by the police or other city representatives, who shall notify the owner thereof, who may reclaim the same by the payment of $5.00 for each cart. If the cart is not reclaimed within 30 days after such notice to said owner, such failure to reclaim shall be construed as a waiver of ownership of said cart by said owner and the City shall dispose of said cart accordingly. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.707 - Sec. 7. 
POSTING. 
    Any store using such carts, as defined in this Ordinance, shall post a copy of this Ordinance conspicuously upon the premises. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
20.708 - Sec. 8. 
PENALTY. 
    Any violation of this Ordinance shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or ninety (90) days in jail, or both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. adopted Apr. 20, 1964; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
20.750 - MASSAGE PARLORS CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Dec. 13, 1979; repealed April 12, 2001 
20.800 - LIQUOR LICENSE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. June 7, 2001 

20.810 - Sec. 1. 
SHORT TITLE. 
    This Ordinance may be known and cited as the "Mt. Clemens Liquor License Ordinance". 
(ord. eff. June 7, 2001) 
20.811 - Sec. 2. 
ENABLING AUTHORITY. 
    This Ordinance is adopted pursuant to and in accordance with, the provisions of Act 58, Public Acts of 1998, as amended, being MCLA 436.1101, et. seq. 
(ord. eff. June 7, 2001) 
20.812 - Sec. 3. 
APPLICATION FOR NEW LICENSE. 
A.  Application. Applications for license to sell beer and wine or spirits shall be made to the City Commission in writing, signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a partnership or corporation, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall contain the following statements and information: 
1.  The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; or, in the case of a co-partnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; in the case of a corporation, the objects for which organized, the names and addresses of the officers and directors of the corporation, whether the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominee, the name and address of such person. 
2.  The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and, if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization. 
3.  The character of business of the applicant, and in the case of a corporation, the object for which it was formed. 
4.  The length of time said applicant has been in business of that character, or, in the case of a corporation, the date when its charter was issued. 
5.  The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license. 
6.  A statement whether applicant has made application for a similar or other license on premises other than described in this application, and the disposition of such application. 
7.  A statement that applicant has never been convicted for a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in this Ordinance or the laws of the State of Michigan. 
8.  A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the State of Michigan or of the United States or any ordinances of the City in the conduct of its business. 
9.  The application shall be accompanied by building and plot plans showing the entire structure and premises and in particular the specific areas where the license is to be utilized. The plans shall demonstrate adequate off-street parking, lighting, refuse disposal facilities and where appropriate, adequate plans for screening, and noise control. 
10.  Applications and all information thereon shall be consistent with the rules and regulations of the Michigan Liquor Control Commission. 
B.  A license shall not be issued to: 
1.  A person whose liquor license, has been revoked for cause. 
2.  A person who, at the time of application or renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a first application. 
3.  A co-partnership, unless all of the members of such co-partnership shall qualify to obtain a license. 
4.  A corporation, if any officer, manage or director thereof, or a stock owner of stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason. 
5.  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless such manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the license. 
6.  A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance. 
7.  A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought or does not have a lease therefore for the full period for which the license is issued, or to a person, corporation or co-partnership that does not have sufficient financial assets to carry on or maintain the business. 
8.  Any law enforcing public official and no such official shall be interested in any way either directly or indirectly in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor. 
9.  For premises where there exists a violation of the applicable Building, Electrical or Mechanical Regulations or any other applicable City Ordinance. 
10.  For premises where it is determined by a majority of the City Commission that the premises do not or will not reasonably soon after commencement of operations have adequate off-street parking, lighting, refuse disposal facilities, screening, noise or nuisance control or where a nuisance does or will exist. 
11.  Where the City Commission determines, by majority vote, that the proposed location is inappropriate considering the desirability of establishing a location in developed, commercial areas, in preference to isolated, undeveloped areas; the attitude of adjacent residents and property owners; traffic safety; accessibility to the site from abutting roads; capability of abutting roads to accommodate the commercial activity; distance from public or private schools for minors; proximity of the inconsistent zoning classification; and accessibility from primary roads or state highways. 
C.  Terms and Conditions of License. Approval of a license shall be for a period of one (1) year subject to annual renewal by the City Commission upon continued compliance with the regulations of this Ordinance. Approval of a license shall be contingent upon the applicant satisfying the following conditions within the stated periods of time: 
1.  The issuance of a license shall be contingent upon the application for and receipt of site plan approval and other necessary approvals by the City within six (6) months of the action of the City Commission or the Michigan Liquor Control Commission approving such licensed, whichever last occurs. 
2.  Approval of a license shall further be contingent upon the commencement of the necessary remodeling or new construction for use of the license within six (6) months of the action of the City Commission or the Michigan Liquor Control Commission approving such license, whichever last occurs. 
3.  The remodeling or new construction shall be completed within time period not to exceed one (1) year from the date of the action of the City Commission or the Michigan Liquor Control Commission approving such license, whichever last occurs. 
4.  The applicant shall provide progress reports to the City Commission every three (3) months during the remodeling or new construction setting forth in detail the status of such remodeling or construction. 
5.  For cause shown, the City Commission may extend the time for remodeling or new construction. 
6.  The failure of an applicant to meet any of the above conditions shall be reason for the City Commission to deny the annual renewal of any license hereunder issued and the City Commission reserves the right to withdraw its approval and deny the license at the time of such review, or at the time of annual renewal. 
D.  Reservation of Authority. No such applicant for a liquor license has the right to the issuance of such license to him, her or it, and the City Commission reserves the right to exercise reasonable discretion in the grant or denial of same license. Additionally, no applicant for a liquor license has the right to have such application processed and the City Commission further reserves the right to take no action with respect to any application filed with the City Commission. The City Commission further reserves the right to maintain a list of all applicants and to review the same when, in its discretion, it determines that the issuance of an additional liquor license is in the best interests of the City at large and for the needs and convenience of its citizens. 
E.  License Hearing. The City Commission shall grant a public hearing upon the license application when, in its discretion, the City Commission determines that the issuance of an additional liquor license is in the best interests of the City Commission at large and for the needs and convenience of its citizens. Following such hearing the City Commission shall submit to the applicant a written statement of its findings and determination. The City Commission's determination shall be based upon satisfactory compliance with the restrictions set forth in Paragraph B.1 through 12 above. 
20.813 - Sec. 4. 
OBJECTIONS TO RENEWAL AND REQUEST FOR REVOCATION. 
A.  Procedure. Before filing an objection to renewal or request for revocation of a license with the Michigan Liquor Control Commission, the City Commission shall serve the license holder, by first class mail, mailed not less than ten days prior to hearing, a notice of a heating, which notice shall contain the following: 
1.  Notice of proposed action. 
2.  Reasons for the proposed action. 
3.  Date, time and place of hearing. 
4.  A statement that the licensee may present evidence and testimony and confront adverse witnesses. 
B.  Criteria For Nonrenewable or Revocation. The City Commission shall recommend nonrenewable or revocation of a license upon a determination by it that based upon a preponderance of the evidence presented at hearing, either of the following exist: 
1.  Violation of any of the restrictions on licenses set forth in paragraph 3.B.1. through 12. or paragraph 3.C.1. through 6. above; or, 
2.  Maintenance of a nuisance upon the premises. 
3.  Violation of any federal, state or local law, rule or regulation. 
(ord. eff. June 7, 2001) 
20.814 - Sec. 5. 
ENFORCEMENT. 
    This Ordinance shall be enforced by the Police Department Ordinance Enforcement Officers and any other persons or agencies who are so designated by the City Commission. 
(ord. eff. June 7, 2001) 
20.815 - Sec. 6. 
VIOLATION; PENALTY. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this Ordinance shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a penalty not to exceed Five Hundred ($500.00) Dollars and/or imprisonment in the Macomb County Jail for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(ord. eff. June 7, 2001) 
21.000 - CONSTRUCTION CODE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. Aug. 1, 1981; amended ord. eff. Sept. 25, 2006; amend. eff. Nov. 29, 2012 
An ordinance amendment to affirm an enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the City Mount Clemens located in Macomb County, and to designate regulated flood hazard areas under the provisions of the State Construction Code Act, Act No. 230 of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended. 
THE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS ORDAINS: 

21.011 - Sec. 1. 
AGENCY DESIGNATED. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the state construction code, in accordance with Section 8b(6) of Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, the Building Official of the City of Mount Clemens is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the City of Mount Clemens under Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, State of Michigan. The City of Mount Clemens assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of said Act through out the corporate limits of the community adopting this Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 1, 1981; amend. eff. Apr. 14, 1988; further amend. eff. March 16, 2000; further amend. eff. Sept 25, 2006) 
21.012 - Sec. 2. 
CODE APPENDIX ENFORCED. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the state construction code, in accordance with Section 8b(6) of Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, Appendix G of the Michigan Building Code shall be enforced by the enforcing agency within the City of Mount Clemens. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 1, 1981; repealed eff. Apr. 14, 1988; further amend. eff. Sept 25, 2006) 
21.013 - Sec. 3. 
DESIGNATION OF REGULATED FLOOD PRONE HAZARD AREAS. 
    The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Flood Insurance Study (FIS) Entitled Macomb County, Michigan (All Jurisdictions) and dated 12/4/12 and the Flood Insurance Rate Map(s) (FIRMS) panel number(s) of 26099C; 0332G and 0334G dated 9/29/06 and panel numbers of 26099C; 0351H and 0353H dated 12/4/12 are adopted by reference for the purposes of administration of the Michigan Construction Code, and declared to be a part of Section 1612.3 of the Michigan Building Code, and to provide the content of the "Flood Hazards" section of Table R301.2(1) of the Michigan Residential Code. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 1, 1981; ord. eff. Sept. 25, 2006; amend. eff. Nov. 29, 2012; amend. eff. Jan. 17, 2013) 
21.014 - Sec. 4. 
REPEALS. 
    Sections 21.016 through 21.026 are hereby repealed. All ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 1, 1981; further amend. eff. Sept 25, 2006) 
21.015 - Sec. 5. 
PUBLICATION. 
    This Ordinance is immediately necessary for the preservation of the public peace, health and safety and shall be effective upon the posting of copies thereof in conspicuous locations in three public places in the City and in accordance with the provisions of the Act governing same. 
(ord. eff. Aug. 1, 1981; amend. eff. May 14, 1987; further amend. eff. Sept 25, 2006) 
Adopted this 25th day of September, 2006 
This Ordinance duly adopted on September 25, 2006 at a special meeting of the Mount Clemens City Commission and will become effective immediately. 
CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, a Michigan Municipal Corporation 
By: 
      Barbara Dempsey, Mayor   By: 
      Lynne Kennedy, Clerk
