A.  The consumer shall assume all responsibility for the water service upon his premises from the curb stop, and for the service pipes, apparatus and plumbing used in connection therewith. 
B.  The consumer shall indemnify, save harmless and defend the City against all claims, demands, cost or expense for loss, damage or injury to persons or property in any manner, directly or indirectly, growing out of the transmission and use of water by the consumer from his service pipes or installation. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.113; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.114 - Sec. 4. 
RESERVED. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.115 - Sec. 5. 
ACCESS TO PREMISES. 
    Duly authorized representative(s) of the City of Mount Clemens may access the consumer's premises at all reasonable hours for the purposes of reading meters, inspections, making repairs, or installing or removing any or all City apparatus used for rendering service to the consumer. On request, the consumer shall furnish the representative(s) of the City of Mount Clemens any pertinent information regarding matters concerning water service to the consumer. The refusal to supply such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed a violation of this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug., 1996; Code 1980, § 25.115; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.116 - Sec. 6. 
BILLING PROCEDURE; LIEN ON PREMISES. 
A.  Water rates are to be charged and collected monthly or quarterly. Such rates shall be as established by resolution. 
B.  Failure of the consumer to receive any bill shall not relieve him of the liability for the charges incurred, and the consumer shall call at the office of the City for such bill if it has not been received. 
C.  If any bill is not paid on or before the due date, a penalty of five per cent shall be charged. If any bill is not paid within 20 days after the due date, service shall be discontinued. 
D.  The owner of the premises shall be jointly and severally liable with the occupant for any sum due for water consumed, unless an affidavit as set forth in paragraph H hereof is filed with the City. 
E.  The City shall have a lien on the premises for any unpaid amount due for water, unless an affidavit as set forth in paragraph H hereof is filed with the City. 
F.  The City may institute an action to recover any sums due and owing to the City in accordance with any of the provisions of this Ordinance. 
G.  Whenever service disconnection has been initiated by the Treasurer's Office because of the nonpayment of sums due for water, an additional fee in an amount to be established by resolution of the City Commission shall be paid. 
H.  When a tenant is responsible for payment of the water and/or sewer bill in a written lease, a landlord may file an affidavit verifying that the lease has been properly executed and is in effect, attaching a copy of the lease to the affidavit with the Treasurer's office. At the same time, a cash deposit as specified in the fee schedule, by resolution of the City Commission, shall be paid in full as security for payment of water and sewage disposal charges. Additionally, the landlord shall, within 20 days, provide notice of any cancellation, change in lease terms with respect to the water, or termination of the lease. Upon full compliance by the landlord with the foregoing, no lien shall accrue against the premises. The landlord shall be responsible upon expiration, termination or change of any lease terms for filing another proper affidavit with a copy of the lease. In the event the water bill remains unpaid for in excess of 30 days, all or any portion of the deposit may be applied toward any outstanding charges. The cash deposit or any depleted portion of it, so used, shall be restored in full within 30 days of any depletion, or a lien otherwise may be imposed, service not restored or shut off. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. by ord. adopted June 18, 1962; further amend. by ords. adopted July 3, 1968, May 3, 1971, Feb. 1, 1975, and Aug. 15, 1977; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 11, 1988; further amend. eff. Dec. 28, 1989; further amend. eff. Dec. 27, 1990; further amend. eff. Mar. 25, 1992; further amend. eff. June 16, 1994; further amend. eff. Aug. 28, 1994; further amend. eff. Aug. 31, 1995; further amend. eff. July 1, 1996; further amend. eff. June 11, 1998; further amend. eff. July 1, 1998; amend. eff. Aug. 17, 2002; Code 1980, § 25.116; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010; amend. eff. Apr. 1, 2019(1)) 
25.117 - Sec. 7. 
DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE. 
    The City is authorized to disconnect water service to the consumer, after reasonable notice, for violation of any of the rules or regulations of the City or the provisions of this Ordinance, or for nonpayment of all or part of a water bill, and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply system from cross connections or otherwise. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. ord. adopted June 8, 1962; further amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug., 1996; Code 1980, § 25.117; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.118 - Sec. 8. 
VACATING PREMISES; CHANGE OF OCCUPANCY; NOTICE REQUIRED. 
    When premises are to be vacated or there is a change of owner, occupant or agent, prompt notice shall be given to the City. The consumer may discontinue service by giving not less than 24 hours' notice to the City during its regular hours. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. ord. adopted June 18, 1962; further amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.118; Code 1980, § 25.119; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.119 - Sec. 9 
RESERVED. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.120 - Sec. 10. 
DISRUPTION OF SERVICE. 
    The City may shut off the water in a main for the purpose of making repairs or extensions, or for any other necessary purpose, at any time without notice to consumers. All persons having boilers or tanks within their premises, depending upon the pressure for the main to keep them filled, shall be notified by the City that the water will be shut off, unless the emergency is of such nature as to preclude the giving of notice. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.120; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.121 - Sec. 11. 
LAWN SPRINKLING; REGULATIONS. 
    The use of water for sprinkling lawns and gardens, and the hours for such use, shall be prescribed by the regulation adopted by the City. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.121; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.122 - Sec. 12. 
EMERGENCIES; USE OF WATER, CURTAILMENT. 
A.  The Superintendent of Water Purification and Pumping shall from time to time promulgate, subject to the approval of the City Manager, such regulations for the operation and use of the Water Distribution System, relative to the amount of pumpage of water, as shall be deemed expedient and necessary, and such regulations shall be and become part of this Ordinance and enforceable hereunder. 
B.  In the event of an emergency, whenever the amount of water pumpage from the Distribution System has reached such volume that unless restricted the public health, safety and general welfare of the people is likely to be endangered, the Superintendent of Water Purification and Pumping may promulgate and adopt such regulations without the approval of the City Manager. 
C.  The penalty prescribed in this Code shall apply to any violation of such regulations. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.122; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.123 - Sec. 13. 
FUNDS; MAINTENANCE, RECORDS. 
    All funds of the water system shall be kept separate from other funds of the City, and an accurate separate record shall be kept of all receipts and disbursements of the system. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.123; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.124 - Sec. 14. 
REGULATIONS AUTHORIZED. 
A.  The City shall from time to time promulgate, subject to the approval of the City Manager, such regulations for the operation and use of the water system as shall be deemed expedient and necessary to effectuate the provisions and provisions of this Ordinance, and such regulations shall be and become part of this Ordinance and enforceable hereunder. 
B.  In the event of an emergency, to protect the public health, safety and general welfare of the people, the City may promulgate and adopt such regulations without the approval of the City manager. 
C.  The penalty prescribed in this code shall apply to any violation of such regulations. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.124; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.130 - EQUIPMENT INSTALLATION 

25.131 - Sec. 1. 
PERMITS REQUIRED; APPLICATIONS, CONTENTS. 
    Permits shall be obtained from the City before any person shall install water service equipment. Permits shall not be issued to plumbers or contractors unless such persons have been licensed by the City. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to prohibit any person from performing any work on premises owned by him, provided a permit is procured and such work is performed in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance. Before extending service pipes, replacing or changing stop boxes or meter settings, or repairing and altering services, a permit shall be procured. In the event of an emergency when the City offices are closed, such work may be performed without a permit; provided, that the person doing such work shall notify the City on the next succeeding business day and pay the fees which would normally have been required for the issuance of the permit. 
    Applications for permits shall be made at the City offices in the form and manner prescribed. Complete information shall be furnished regarding the proposed installation or other work to be performed to insure adequacy of service. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.131; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.132 - Sec. 2. 
PROVISIONS; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED. 
    Whenever the Inspector finds any water service, curb box or plumbing job that is defective or irregular, the City may direct such work as will be required to correct the defect or irregularity. The permittee shall reimburse the City for any loss in revenue resulting from the water service being left on without permission or the failure to procure a permit. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.132; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.133 - Sec. 3. 
CITY INFORMATION; LIABILITY, EXEMPTION. 
    The City shall not be liable for any expense incurred by a permittee in locating mains, services, curb stops or corporation stops, arising out of information procured from City records. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.133); amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.134 - Sec. 4. 
SHUTTING OFF WATER; RESTRICTION. 
    No permittee shall turn water off or on at the corporation or stop cock to any service pipe, except to make repairs and test his work, after which he shall leave it off or on as he found it. No unauthorized person shall turn the water off or on at the corporation or stop cock. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.134; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.135 - Sec. 5. 
USE ON ONE CONNECTION, LIMITATION. 
A.  Unless permission is otherwise granted by the City, separate premises shall have separate service pipe installations, curb stops, curb boxes, and shall be separately metered. 
B.  In no event shall a consumer extend his service pipes or plumbing across any public way, or to an adjacent property in order to furnish service thereto, even though such adjacent property be owned by him. 
C.  Whenever water is to be supplied to several persons in apartments, offices or stores, all located in a single building and supplied through one service, the City shall contract with one person who shall be responsible for the payment of water bills. The apportionment of charges shall be determined by mutual agreement of such persons. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.135; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.136 - Sec. 6. 
LEAKS; REPAIR; NOTICE. 
    The consumer shall maintain all service pipes free from leaks at all times. Whenever a leak appears in a consumer's installation, which allows water to escape without registering upon the meter, the City shall give the consumer written notice thereof and the consumer shall immediately proceed to repair such service pipe. If such repairs have not been completed within 48 hours after notice has been given, the City may discontinue the service by shutting off the water at the curb stop or by excavating to and closing the corporation stop. The cost of excavating and shutting off such service shall be paid by the consumer or by the owner of the property before service is restored. If, in the judgment of the City, any leak on the consumer's installation is of such nature as to endanger public safety or constitute a nuisance or a source of waste, the City may shut off or discontinue such service without previous notice to the consumer; service shall not be restored until such leak is repaired. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.136; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.137 - Sec. 7. 
CROSS CONNECTIONS. 
A.  CONNECTIONS. A connection with a public water supply system shall comply with all state laws, local ordinances and state and local rules, including R 325.11401 to R 325.11407 of the Michigan Administrative Code. A cross connection shall not be made, or be permitted to remain, to a public water supply system. 
B.  INSPECTIONS. The City shall develop a program for the elimination and prevention of cross connections. As part of this program, the City shall cause inspections and reinspections to be made for cross connections to the public water supply. The frequency of inspections and reinspections shall be based on potential health hazards as determined by the City, or its designated agent, to the public water supply through possible cross connections. 
C.  PROTECTIVE DEVICES. A consumer shall obtain written approval by the City of any proposed backflow prevention corrective action or protective device before use or installation. The City may require the filing of a backflow device test report, on a periodic basis established by the City, for any backflow prevention devices used by a consumer. All testing and maintenance of consumer's backflow prevention devices shall be at the consumer's own expense and be performed by a person approved by the City. That individual testing the device shall certify the results of his or her testing. Such certification may be required to be part of the backflow prevention device test reports which may be required to be filed with the City, The City shall review backflow device test reports filed with the City but may refuse to review any backflow device test report until the review fee required by the City of Mount Clemens, if any, has been paid. Reports for which a required review fee, if any, has not been paid and which have not been reviewed will be treated for purposes of this Ordinance in the same manner as a failure to file a report. Failure to file a report required by the City may be deemed evidence of a cross connection. 
D.  CROSS CONNECTION PROGRAM FEES. The City of Mount Clemens may by resolution establish fees to be charged consumers that are reasonably related to the services provided the consumer by the City of Mount Clemens in the operation of the program for the elimination and prevention of cross connections. Any such fees may be added to, and for purposes of discontinuance of service, shall be considered part of a consumer's water bill. 
E.  PROTECTION OF POTABLE WATER AND WARNING REQUIREMENTS. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by a public water supply system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as "water unsafe for drinking." 
F.  PIPING IDENTIFICATION. When a secondary water source is used in addition to a public water supply system, exposed public water piping shall be identified by a blue color or tags and all other exposed piping shall be distinguished from the public water piping by a different contrasting color or tags and so maintained that the public water supply and secondary water supply pipes can be traced readily in their entirety. If such piping is so installed than it is impossible to trace it in its entirety, it will be necessary to protect the public water supply at the service connection in a manner acceptable to the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug., 1996; Code 1980, § 25.137; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.138 - Sec. 8. 
WATER SERVICE PIPE; REQUIREMENTS. 
A.  The water service pipe may be placed in the same trench with the building drain and building sewer, upon compliance with the following conditions: 
1.  The bottom of the water service pipe, at all points, shall be at least twelve inches above the top of the sewer line at its highest point and five feet deep. 
2.  The water service pipe shall be placed on a solid shelf excavated at one side of the common trench. 
3.  The number of joints in the service pipe shall be kept to a minimum. 
4.  The materials and joints of sewer and water service pipe shall be installed in such a manner and shall possess the necessary strength and durability to prevent the escape of solids, liquids and gases therefrom, under all known adverse conditions such as corrosion, strains due to temperature changes, settlement, vibrations, and superimposed loads. 
B.  When any premises is supplied through two or more interconnecting water service pipes, each pipe shall be equipped with a check valve near the meter outlets, so set that water can flow into the premises but no water can flow out. 
C.  The water service pipe to any building shall be of sufficient size to permit a continuous and ample flow of water on all floors at all times. It shall be so graded in size as to make for equal distribution of the water to the respective risers and branches in accordance with the need of the fixtures or flushing medium employed. Frictional losses in piping, meters, valves, fittings and faucets shall be considered and allowance made, according to maximum usage demand and average pressure, when piping size is estimated. 
The service line from the main to the premises shall be installed in accordance with City regulations. No service line shall have an inside diameter less than 3/4 inch. All service pipes of two inches or less in diameter shall be of AWWA specification type K copper tubing; those over two inches diameter may be of ductile iron. 
D.  Specifications of required copper service pipe dimensions shall be as follows: 
Outside diameter, inches 3/4? 
.875 1? 
1.125 11/2? 
1.625 2? 
2.125 Wall thickness, inches .065  .065  .072  .083 Weight per foot, pounds .641 .839 1.360 2.060  
The connection of the copper service pipe to the corporation stop shall be made by the use of an approved adapter fitting. The pipe shall be laid to provide for earth settlement and for contraction and expansion through arching or bending to form an expansion loop in the form of a half "S" bend, and shall contain at least six inches of excess material to provide for settlement and flexibility. Only three-part flared unions shall be used for connections in copper pipes and all other types of flared unions are prohibited. 
E.  All service pipes shall be placed at least 41/2 feet below the finished grade. 
F.  The service line shall be laid out to the main at right angles to the face of the building at the point where the service line enters the face of the building. Service lines to buildings without basements shall be laid from the main in front of the building, and at right angles to the face of the building. From this point the service line may be offset to pass the building in a line parallel to the side of the building, inside the property line and as close to the building as practicable. If such procedure does not enable the service line to approach the main at right angles, no plumber, contractor, or any other person shall proceed with such work unless he notifies the City and receives specifications for the completion of the work. 
G.  No drainage or plumbing system or part thereof shall be covered, backfilled or floored until it has been inspected, tested and approved as prescribed in this Ordinance. 
H.  If any building drainage or plumbing system or part thereof which is installed, altered or repaired, is covered before being inspected, tested and approved as prescribed in this Ordinance, it shall be uncovered for inspection after notice to the plumber, contractor, owner, or other person to uncover the work has been issued by the City. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; amend. eff. Aug. 17, 2002; Code 1980, § 25.138; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.139 - Sec. 9. 
CORPORATION STOPS; GATE VALVES; SERVICE CONNECTIONS. 
A.  Single or multiple corporation stops or pipe saddles will be used to supply services or private mains up to and including two inches in diameter. Gate valves will be used to supply services or private mains over two inches in diameter. Connection of services between 11/4? and 2? to the City main shall be through one inch corporation stops with branch connections making an angle of 45° to the service proper. 
B.  On 11/2? and 2? services, a saddle will be required; on 3? services, a 4-inch connection at the main and a 4-inch valve shall be required. Services four inches and over shall have the same size connection as the service. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.139; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.140 - Sec. 10. 
CURB STOPS. 
    An approved type round way, inverted core, Minneapolis pattern, tee head curb stop of good bronze material shall be installed on all 3/4-inch, 1-inch and 2-inch service lines at a point as near the curb line as practical and permissible. A case iron extension curb box of an approved pattern shall be placed over the curb stop so that it is readily accessible for turning on and off by City employees. The curb box shall be centered over the curb stop and shall be exposed flush with the finished grade level. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.140; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.141 - Sec. 11. 
CURB STOP KEYS; POSSESSION, USE; RESTRICTION. 
    Only plumbers and other persons authorized by the City shall be permitted to use curb stop keys. The loaning of such keys is prohibited. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.141; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.142 - Sec. 12. 
SERVICE CONTROL VALVES. 
    Valves of wheel, nonrising stem gate valves, stop cock or plug type may be used. They shall be of approved standard manufacture, and housed in approved type service or roadway valve boxes. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.142; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.143 - Sec. 13. 
TAPPING MAINS; EXTENSIONS OF MAINS; APPLICATIONS, FEES AND CHARGES. 
A.  TAPPING MAINS. All connections shall be made under the supervision of the City after proper application for service by consumers or their authorized agents. Such applications shall be made on standard forms, and shall contain the street name, house number, lot number, the name of the plumber or contractor, the names of the applicant and the owner, the size of the service pipe, and any other information which may be required by the City. The City shall be given at least 24 hours' notice in advance of the time connection is to be made. 
Whenever any person shall make application to the City for any connection, he shall exhibit all plumbing and excavation permits that may be required from any city, county or other authority having jurisdiction. 
Connections of 2 inches or less may be performed by City personnel upon application and payment of all applicable fees and charges. All connections may be performed by qualified outside contractors at the property owner's expense upon application and payment of all applicable fees and charges. 
B.  EXTENSION OF MAINS. If a City watermain is not readily accessible and must be extended, the person making application to the City for any connection must pay for any expenditures required to provide service to the building or development, including watermain extensions. In such cases, the person making application may perform all installations and connections provided that the person shall exhibit all plans, specifications and permits that may be required from any governmental authority having jurisdiction. In addition, any such installation or connection must be constructed in accordance with the engineering standards of the City. Once constructed in any public right-of-way or easement, any watermain extension which is accepted by the City shall become the property of the City for all purposes. 
C.  FEES AND CHARGES. Prior to connecting to the City of Mount Clemens water system, the following fees and charges shall be paid (more than one fee may be applicable): 
1.  Water System Benefit Fee: The City Commission shall establish by resolution the Water System Benefit Fee based upon size of the tap. This fee includes separate lines installed solely for fire suppression purposes, metered or not. 
2.  Tap Fee: For connections of 2 inches or less which are installed by the City, the applicant shall pay the actual costs of installation (including labor, materials, meter, equipment, and street repair) prior to receiving water service from the City. The City is authorized to take into account disparities in cost which arise from the location of water facilities on only one side of the street in determining a fair and equitable final cost to the applicant. 
3.  Miscellaneous Charges: The City Commission shall establish by resolution the fees to be charged for other items or services, related to connections to the system, including, but not limited to: 
(a)  Meter (assembly) and start up fee. 
(b)  Trench permit. 
(c)  Street opening permit. 
(d)  Water and meter fees for construction projects. 
(e)  Fire Hydrant use fee. 
(f)  Requests for water service turn-off or turn-on at the curb stop during non-business hours. 
D.  WAIVER OF FEES. The City Commission may, in its sole discretion, authorize a waiver of the fees and/or charges outlined in this Ordinance if the City Commission makes a finding that one of the following exemptions is applicable: 
(1)  The applicant is a General Powers School District, as defined by MCLA 380.11; or 
(2)  The applicant is performing a vital public service at the property; and the applicant will suffer a financial hardship if required to pay the required fees and/or charges; and the waiver of fees and/or charges will not nullify the purpose of the Ordinance. 
The applicant shall request such a waiver in writing, giving all reasons for the request and including any other documents or data which support the request. The City Commission, in its sole discretion, may waive some or all of the fees and/or charges and may prescribe other requirements as a condition to the applicant obtaining the waiver of fees and/or charges. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. ords. adopted Sept. 22, 1965 and May 27, 1977; amend. Jan., 1978; Mar. 3, 1995; further amend. March 13, 1997; amend. eff. Aug. 17, 2002; amend. eff. May 29, 2003; amend. eff. May 29, 2004; Code 1980, § 25.143; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010; amend. eff. Apr. 28, 2011) 
25.144 - Sec. 14. 
SERVICE PIPE, INSTALLATION PREREQUISITE. 
    The service trench shall not be backfilled until the tap has been completed and the City has approved the installation. Clean earth or sand shall be carefully tamped every two feet above the top of the service line. This material shall be carefully and solidly rammed with proper tools. The use of clay for such purpose is prohibited. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.144; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.145 - Sec. 15. 
COMPLETION OF WORK; INSPECTION REQUIRED. 
A.  The inspection and approval of water services, installed or repaired in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance, shall be by the City. 
B.  Upon completion of any new service pipe installation or repairs, it shall be the duty of the permittee to obtain City approval before covering same. The permit, showing work performed and including sketch and accurate measurements, shall be returned [to] the City within ten days after the work authorized by such permit has been completed. 
C.  When work is completed, the permittee shall leave the water shut off at the curb stop, roadway valve, or service control valve. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.145; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.146 - Sec. 16. 
CHANGES IN WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM. 
    Any connection to, extensions of, or changes in, the water distribution system for which the City participates in any degree in the cost thereof, shall be made only upon approval of the City Commission. Requests for determination of appropriate special assessment districts for extensions of the water distribution system shall be addressed to the City Commission which will thereupon consider same and advise the petitioners of its decision. If a special assessment district is to be initiated, the City Commission shall then stipulate the portion of the cost to be borne by the petitioners and the portion, if any, to be borne by the City. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 3, 1995; Code 1980, § 25.146; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.147 - Sec. 17. 
DISCONNECTIONS AND SEALING OF WATER LINES. 
A.  The complete disconnection from and sealing of any and all connections to City water lines is required prior to demolition or removal of any foundation members, basement walls, basement floors or support pads on or below ground level. 
B.  Disconnection and sealing of water lines are to be performed as directed by the City and only during the presence of a person designated by the City for that specific purpose. The City will publish (and periodically update by formal amendment) disconnection and sealing of water line requirements. Hereafter, said requirements will be referred to as the disconnection and sealing of water line requirements and shall be enforced as part of this ordinance, and copies therefore will be available from the City. 
C.  No person shall make connections from any City water main to any structure or equipment regulated by this code that has been disconnected or use of which has been ordered to be disconnected by the City until the City authorizes the reconnection and use of such connection. 
(ord. eff. Mar. 29, 2012) 
25.150 - METER INSTALLATION 

25.151 - Sec. 1. 
METERS REQUIRED. 
A.  All connections with the water mains shall be prepared for the use of water through meters. 
B.  A block of store buildings, a terrace building or an apartment house may have a single meter for all, or separate meters for each unit, depending upon the arrangement of the service lines. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.151; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.152 - Sec. 2. 
WATER METERS; SIZE, TYPE; DETERMINATION. 
    All meters which are to be used for the measuring of water consumed shall be furnished by the City upon payment of all costs associated with the installation. When requesting the installation of any such meter, the consumer shall furnish information as to the amount of his contemplated water demand and the City shall then determine the proper type and size of meter to be installed. Unless otherwise authorized by the City, the supply of water through each water service shall be recorded through one meter. Unless otherwise authorized by the City, meters with inlet and outlet openings up to two inches, inclusive, shall be of the disc type. Whenever meters with openings larger than two inches are required, the City shall determine the type to be used. When used on fire protection services, special type meters prescribed by the City shall be used. All water services 1 1/2 inches and larger shall be installed with full size meter by-pass, equipped with a valve and with meter control valves at the inlet and outlet of the meter. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.152; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.153 - Sec. 3. 
INTERFERENCE, REMOVAL; PROHIBITIONS. 
    No unauthorized person shall interfere or tamper with, damage, destroy, or remove a water meter from any service connection. Whenever a meter is removed by permission of the City, it shall be returned to the City immediately under penalty of having the water shut off or, in the case of a plumber, the license of such plumber may be revoked. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.153; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.154 - Sec. 4. 
PRIVATE FIRE LINES, SPRINKLER SYSTEMS; METERS REQUIRED. 
A.  All water used for private fire lines and sprinkler systems shall be metered. The applicant may purchase the meter or "detector check" from the City. Whenever a "detector check" is used, the City shall install the by-pass and small meter thereon, after the plumber, contractor, owner or other person sets the "detector check" . Such "detector checks" shall be permitted on fire lines supplying sprinkler systems or hose connections dependent on City pressure only to maintain a supply of water in such systems or connections, and in sprinkler systems dependent on a storage tank or fire pump for supply and pressure. 
B.  Water service installed to supply stand pipes and sprinkler systems for fire protection, only, will be subject to metering and other regulations. Complete specifications for the proposed work shall be submitted to the City before connection to the water distribution system shall be made. Unmetered fire protection services shall be installed in such a manner that all outlets subject to sealing will be exposed and easily accessible for the inspection of seals at any time. No connections for any other purpose to unmetered fire services shall be permitted. 
C.  The City Commission shall establish private fire line service charges by resolution based upon the size of the pipe tap on the main. Any such charges may be added to, and for purposes of discontinuance of service shall be considered part of a consumer's water bill. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; amend. eff. Aug. 17, 2002; Code 1980, § 25.154; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.155 - Sec. 5. 
WATER METERS; INSTALLATION, LOCATION; REGULATIONS. 
A.  Should more than one meter be placed on a single line, an agreement shall be signed by the owner, protecting the City in treating the property in its entirety, should enforcement of regulations require that the City shut off the water service. 
B.  Reserved. 
C.  Whenever it is necessary to make more than one trip to start up a meter, due to faulty workmanship, a charge in the amount established by resolution shall be made for each additional trip. 
D.  Meters and the valves thereof located in locked closets or compartments, coal bins, under buildings or porches, or any other place not readily accessible are prohibited. Meters may be set in toilet rooms of gasoline service stations, provided they are set in accessible, clean and sanitary locations, 24 inches or farther from any urinal. Meters may be set under show windows only when set within eight inches of a door at least 24? wide and 24? high and with couplings at least four inches above the floor with 18-inch clearance above the meter coupling to allow for meter reading. The meter shall be set opposite the center of the doorway. 
E.  All meters shall be set horizontally in dry, clean, sanitary locations, readily accessible, with valves on both sides, and in such places that small leaks and the spilling of water will do no damage. Rod shutoff in lieu of valves is prohibited. 
F.  The City shall start up all meters whenever the plumber, contractor, owner or other person has completed all preparatory work. "Detector checks" used on fire lines shall be obtained at the City's meter shop and shall be installed by the plumber, contractor, owner or other person. 
G.  With City approval, meters may be set below grade line in a brick or cement well, cellar or basement, under a kitchen sink, or on the first floor. A run, not to exceed 130 feet, will be allowed between the lot line nearest the street main and the meter. 
H.  In dwellings or buildings used for residence purposes only, the owner may use check valves on feed pipes entering range boilers; provided that a safety valve is used whenever a check valve is set. 
I.  Plugged tees, or other accessible outlets between the meter and the main, are prohibited. 
J.  The clearance distance from a wall or any other object to the center of a service pipe shall not be less than shown below: 
Meter Size Clearance 5/8 ?, 3/4?, 1?  5? 11/2? 12? 2? 14?  
Larger sizes shall be installed in accordance with blueprints furnished by the City. 
K.  All meter wells shall be of brick or concrete, built in accordance with drawings furnished by the City, with cover openings directly over meters. Devices designed for use in lieu of wells may be used if approved by the City. 
L.  All meter wells shall have meter well covers as shown on the blueprints of standards meter wells. The manhole shaft from cover to well shall not exceed two feet. Wells shall be provided with iron steps set on 15-inch centers. 
M.  Meter wells on public property shall conform to City specifications and construction shall be performed only in accordance with the conditions of the permit. The owner shall be liable for any damage caused by departure from the City specifications in the construction of meter wells on private property. 
N.  All meter pits on public or private property shall be constructed in locations free from hazards to pedestrian traffic. Pits or boxes located in or near doorways are prohibited. Whenever buildings are altered, such hazards shall be removed or the pits relocated. The City shall not be liable for any damages for injuries or loss from hazards maintained on private property. 
O.  With the consent of the City, 5/8 ?, 3/4? and 1? meters may be installed in meter boxes. Meter boxes on public property are prohibited. All meters 11/2? and larger may be set in wells built in accordance with the blueprints and specifications furnished by the City. 
P.  All meter wells shall be drained to a sewer if within 100 feet of a sewer, and shall have a trap next to the well. If not drained, a sump shall be provided for pumping out the well, and such well shall be pumped out whenever required by the City. 
Q.  No risers other than fire connections shall be permitted. Wells shall be used for no other purpose than the reception of water meters and valves. 
R.  By-passes and meter connections, the same size as the service lines, shall be required on all meters 11/2? and larger. By-passes on 1? meters and smaller are prohibited. 
S.  If a suitable and readily accessible location is provided in a dry basement sufficiently well heated to prevent freezing of the meter during the winter, the meter may be placed in the basement. 
T.  Tile meter housing with iron rim and cover for 5/8 ? and 3/4? meters may be installed if such installation is made in compliance with City plans and specifications. The City shall provide plans and specifications for meter boxes larger than two inches. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; amend. eff. Aug. 17, 2002; Code 1980, § 25.155; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.156 - Sec. 6. 
WATER METERS; PROTECTION REQUIRED. 
    All consumers shall take any and all precautions that may be required to prevent the pipes and meters from freezing in cold weather. The meter boxes shall be maintained free from water at all times. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.156; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.157 - Sec. 7. 
FAILURE TO REGISTER; WATER USAGE; AMOUNT; DETERMINATION. 
    The consumer shall accept as standard of measurement the meter installed by the City. Should the meter become defective or fail to register correctly, the quantity of water used shall be determined by the amount used during the corresponding period of the preceding three years, or by averaging the amount for the period immediately preceding and subsequent to such defective registration by the meter. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.157; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.158 - Sec. 8. 
WATER METERS; TESTS, INSPECTIONS. 
A.  The City, at its expense, may make periodic tests and inspections of its meters in order to maintain them at a high standard of accuracy. A test of the accuracy of any water meter register shall be made, free of charge, upon request of a consumer, provided that such meter has not been tested within 12 months previous to such request. Any meter registering device that registers a variance of not more than two percent shall be deemed accurate. 
B.  A consumer may request the City to flow test the meter serving his premises. The City shall require the consumer to deposit a sum in an amount to be established by resolution of the City Commission to cover the reasonable cost of the test. A written report giving the results of the test will be furnished to the consumer within ten days after completion of the test. Such deposit shall be returned to the consumer if the meter is found to register more than two percent fast. If the meter is found to be accurate, the deposit shall be retained by the City to cover the reasonable cost of the test. 
C.  Should any consumer be unsatisfied with the test made by the City, the consumer may request that the meter be tested by the manufacturer or a representative thereof. The City shall require the consumer to deposit a sum in an amount equal to the estimated cost of the test by the manufacturer. A written report giving the results of the test will be furnished to the consumer after completion of the test. Such deposit will be returned to the consumer if the meter is found to register more than two percent fast. If the meter is found to be accurate, the deposit shall be retained by the City to cover the reasonable cost of the test. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. June 11, 1998; Code 1980, § 25.158; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.159 - Sec. 9. 
METER REPAIRS. 
    The City shall maintain and repair its meters at its own expense; provided, however, that should any meter be damaged by freezing, hot water otherwise, due to negligence of the consumer, the cost of such repairs shall be charged to the consumer; 25.143 sec.13.C. 3.(a.). 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. ord. adopted June 18, 1962; further amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.159; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.160 - Sec. 10. 
METERS, SEALS; TAMPERING; PROHIBITIONS. 
    Whenever it is necessary to break any seal attached to a water meter or water service, the City shall be notified. No unauthorized person shall tamper with, change, damage or destroy any seal attached to a water meter or water service. Any meter that shows evidence of tampering shall be removed by the City for testing and repairs, and the cost of such test and repairs shall be charged to the consumer of property owner. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Code 1980, § 25.160; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.161. - Sec. 11. 
CONNECTION CHARGES; SEWERAGE-WATER SYSTEMS; PROPERTIES OUTSIDE City; REQUIREMENTS. 
A.  No application for tapping into the water system of the City to service property outside the corporate boundaries of the City shall be accepted unless the municipal corporation in which the applicant resides shall have entered into a contract with the City for such services, and unless the payment of such charges as are set forth in this Ordinance, or any amendment thereto, are paid by the applicant as required. 
B.  No application for any connection to the sewerage system of the City to service property outside the corporate boundaries of the City shall be accepted unless the municipal corporation in which the applicant resides shall have entered into a contract with the City for such services, and unless the payment of such charges as are set forth in this Ordinance, or any amendment thereto, are paid by the applicant as required. 
C.  All applicants for water services who are otherwise entitled thereto shall pay capital/connection charges before a permit shall be issued to make such connection. The City Commission shall establish by resolution the Water System Benefit Fee based upon the size of the tap. This fee includes separate lines installed solely for fire suppression purposes, metered or not. 
In addition to the Water System Benefit fee, applicants shall pay such other fees which may be applicable. The City Commission may prescribe such terms for payment of above fees for water services as, in its discretion, it shall deem proper. 
D.  All applicants for wastewater and/or drainage water disposal services who are otherwise entitled there to shall pay capital/connection charges based upon the sewer tap size before a permit shall be issued to make such connection. 
The City Commission shall establish by resolution the Wastewater and/or Drainage Water Disposal System Benefit fee based upon the size of the sewer tap. In addition to the Wastewater and/or Drainage Water Disposal System Benefit fee, applicants shall pay such fees which may be applicable. The City Commission may prescribe such terms for payment of the above fees for Wastewater and/or Drainage Water Disposal services as, in its discretion, it shall deem proper. 
E.  All capital/connection charges shall be segregated for the purpose of paying bonds issued for improvements to the City water and sewerage systems, for extensions of facilities for both water and sewerage in the City and such other territory as may be served, and for such other purposes as the City Commission may direct. 
F.  The City Commission may enter into contracts with adjoining municipalities to supply water and sewerage services to such municipalities and in such contracts shall specify the conditions under which such services may be rendered, the method of payment for connection charges, the reservations for water and sewer connections upon payment of such sums as the commission may direct, and the manner of adjustment of connection charges and other fees as may be required in rendering such services to other municipalities. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 27, 1987; further amend. eff. Aug. 11, 1988; amend. eff. Aug. 17, 2002; Code 1980, § 25.161; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.161A - Sec. 11A. 
SEPARATELY METERED OUTDOOR CONNECTIONS. 
    Notwithstanding anything in this Ordinance to the contrary, the following regulations shall apply to separately metered outdoor faucets and in-ground sprinkler systems which shall be allowed only on the following terms and conditions. 
1.  Separate meters for connection to outside faucets and sprinkler systems shall be permitted if the water: 
a.  Is not deposited into a sanitary sewer system by other than accidental absorption; and 
b.  Is used for: 
i.  Watering lawns; 
ii.  Water ornamental flower gardens and residential vegetable gardens for personal consumption by occupants of the premises; and 
c.  Is used solely upon and at the property where the separate meter is located; and 
d.  Is not used for any business or commercial purpose other than those set forth in subparagraph (b) above. 
2.  CONNECTIONS. 
a.  Reserved. 
b.  All plumbing and meter installation work shall be commenced only after appropriate permits have been obtained. 
c.  All plumbing and meter installations shall be performed in accordance with rules, regulations, and diagrams promulgated by the state which shall require the installation of a backflow preventer. 
d.  No connections will be permitted between the outdoor lines and those used to provide water to the interior of the structure, or between the outdoor lines and any other structure or residence. 
3.  COST. 
a.  All costs associated with the installation of the separate meter and related plumbing, including, but not limited to, meter cost, permit and inspection fees, and labor and material costs shall be paid by the property owner. 
b.  Meter cost (including outside reader) shall be the standard charge established by the City. 
4.  BILLING AND RATES. 
a.  Separate meters for outdoor use shall be read at the same time as the reading on the first meter but shall be billed separately. 
b.  Rates for water use applicable to the separate meters for outdoor use shall be those set forth in Code Section 25.116, except that the minimum charge per billing period shall only be applicable to such separate meters in billing periods during which there is actual water use through the meter. 
c.  All other penalties, interest, liens and remedies related to non-payment of charges set forth in this Ordinance for the building service meter shall apply equally to separate meter for outdoor use. In the event of non-payment, service to both meters shall be discontinued until payment is made. 
d.  In the event of tampering or misuse of the separate meter for outdoor use, the privilege shall be discontinued and all water service to the premises shall be turned off until the second meter is removed and all plumbing reconnected to a single meter, all at the expense of the property owner. In addition, no second meter shall be reinstalled at the same premises for a period of three (3) years from the date a second meter is removed pursuant to this subparagraph (d), except in instances where there has been a complete change of ownership and possession of the premises. 
(ord. eff. May 14, 1992; amend Apr. 15, 1993; Code 1980, § 25.161A; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.162 - Sec. 12. 
PENALTY. 
    Any person violating any provision of this Ordinance, any written order of the City guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987; further amend. eff. Aug., 1996; Code 1980, § 25.162; amend. eff. Feb. 11, 2010) 
25.200 - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION City OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code effective Oct., 1958; amended Jan., 1978 

25.201 - Sec. 1. 
TITLE. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Rpld. eff. May 27, 2004) 
25.202 - Sec. 2. 
PURPOSES. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Rpld. eff. May 27, 2004) 
25.203 - Sec. 3. 
DEFINITIONS. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Rpld. eff. May 27, 2004) 
25.204 - Sec. 4. 
COMPLIANCE WITH CHAPTER REQUIRED FOR OCCUPANCY. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; Rpld. eff. May 27, 2004) 
25.205 - Sec. 5. 
PERMITS AND FEES. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. Aug. 31, 1995; Rpld. eff. May 27, 2004) 
25.206 - Sec. 6. 
BOND REQUIREMENT. 
    A grading permit shall not be issued unless the permittee shall first post with the City Engineer a bond executed by the owner and a corporate surety with authority to do business in this state as a surety. 
    The bond shall be in a form approved by the City Attorney, payable to the City, and in the amount of the estimated total cost of all temporary or permanent soil erosion control measures. The total cost shall be estimated by the City Engineer. The bond shall include penalty provisions for failure to complete the work on schedule as specified on the grading permit. In lieu of a surety bond, the applicant may file with the City a cash bond or an instrument of credit approved by the City Attorney in the amount equal to that which would be required for the surety bond. 
    The bond and instrument of credit shall include, and every cash deposit shall be made on, the conditions that the permittee shall comply with all of the provisions of this Ordinance and all of the terms and conditions of the grading permit, and shall complete all of the work contemplated under the grading permit within the time limit specified in the grading permit or, if no time limit is specified, within 180 days after the date of the issuance of the grading permit. 
25.207 - Sec. 7. 
EXTENSION OF TIME. 
    If the permittee is unable to complete the work within the specified time, he may, at least ten (10) days prior to the expiration of the permit, present in writing to the City Engineer a request for an extension of time, setting forth the reasons for the requested extension. In the event such an extension is warranted, the City Engineer may grant additional time for the completion of the work, but no such extension shall release the owner or the surety on the bond or the person furnishing the instrument of credit or cash bond. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan. 1978) 
25.208 - Sec. 8. 
FAILURE TO COMPLETE WORK. 
    In the event of failure to complete the work or failure to comply with all the requirements, conditions, and terms of permit, the City Engineer may order such work as is necessary to eliminate any danger to persons or property and to leave the site in a safe condition and he may authorize completion of all necessary temporary or permanent soil erosion control measures. The permittee and the surety executing the bond or person issuing the instrument of credit or making the cash deposit shall continue to be firmly bound under a continuing obligation for the payment of all necessary costs and expenses that may be incurred or expended by the City in causing any and all such work to be done. In the case of a cash deposit, any unused portion thereof shall be refunded to the permittee. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.209 - Sec. 9. 
DENIAL OF PERMIT. 
    Grading permits shall not be issued where: 
A.  The proposed work would cause hazards to the public safety, health, and welfare; or 
B.  The work, as proposed by the applicant, will damage any public or private property, or interfere with any existing drainage course in such a manner as to cause damage to any adjacent property or result in the deposition of debris or sediment on any public way or into any waterway or create an unreasonable hazard to persons or property; or 
C.  The land area for which grading is proposed is subject to geological hazard to the extent that no reasonable amount of corrective work can eliminate or sufficiently reduce settlement, slope instability, or any other such hazard to persons or property; or 
D.  The land area for which the grading is proposed may lie within the flood plain of any stream or water-course (not specifically designated and delineated by the City as an area subject to flood hazard), unless a Hydrologic Report, prepared by a registered professional engineer, is submitted to certify that the proposed grading will have, in his opinion, no detrimental influence on the public welfare or upon the total development of the watershed. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.210 - Sec. 10. 
MODIFICATIONS OF APPROVED PLANS. 
    All modifications of the approved grading plans must be submitted and approved by the City Engineer. All necessary sustaining reports shall be submitted with any proposal to modify the approved grading plan. No grading work in connection with any proposed modification shall be permitted without the approval of the City Engineer. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.211 - Sec. 11. 
RESPONSIBILITY OF PERMITTEE. 
    During grading operations the permittee shall be responsible for: 
A.  The prevention of damage to adjacent property. No person shall grade on land so close to the property line as to endanger any adjoining public street, sidewalk, alley, or any public or private property without supporting and protecting such property from settling, cracking, or other damage which might result. 
B.  Carrying out the proposed work in accordance with the approved plans and in compliance with all the requirements of the permit and this Ordinance. 
C.  The prompt removal of all soil, miscellaneous debris, or other materials applied, dumped, or otherwise deposited on public streets, highways, sidewalks, or other public thoroughfares during transit to and from the construction, where such spillage constitutes a public nuisance or hazard. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.212 - Sec. 12. 
GENERAL REQUIREMENTS. 
A.  Any earth changes shall be conducted in such a manner which will effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and resulting sedimentation. 
B.  All persons engaged in earth changes shall design, implement, and maintain acceptable soil erosion and sedimentation control measures, in conformance with the Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Act of 1972 (Act 347, P.A. 1972), and all official rules of the Michigan Water Resources Commission promulgated pursuant thereto, which effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion. 
C.  All earth changes shall be designed, constructed, and completed in such a manner which shall limit the exposed area of any disturbed land for the shortest period of time. 
D.  Sediment caused by accelerated soil erosion shall be removed from runoff water before it leaves the site of the earth change. 
E.  Any temporary or permanent facility designed and constructed for the conveyance of water around, through, or from the earth change area shall be designed to limit the water flow to a non-erosive velocity. 
F.  Temporary soil erosion control facilities shall be removed and earth change areas graded and stabilized with permanent soil erosion control measures pursuant to approved standards and specifications as prescribed by the Michigan Water Resources Commission rules. 
G.  Permanent soil erosion control measures for all slopes, channels, ditches or any disturbed land area shall be completed within 15 calendar days after final grading or the final earth change has been completed. When it is not possible to permanently stabilize a disturbed area after an earth change has been completed or where significant earth change activity ceases, temporary soil erosion control measures shall be implemented within 30 calendar days. All temporary soil erosion control measures shall be maintained until permanent soil erosion control measures are implemented. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.213 - Sec. 13. 
MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS. 
    Persons carrying out soil erosion and sediment control measures under this Ordinance, and all subsequent owners of property concerning which such measures have been taken, shall maintain all permanent anti-erosion devices, retaining walls, structures, plantings, and other protective devices. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.214 - Sec. 14. 
MINIMUM DESIGN STANDARDS FOR EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL. 
    All grading plans and specifications including extension of previously approved plans, shall include provisions for erosion and sediment control in accordance with, but not limited to, the standards contained in the Standards for Soil Erosion and Sediment Control as published by the Macomb County Soils Conservation District and the Michigan Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Guidebook as published by the State of Michigan Department of Natural Resources, the contents of which are herein enacted and adopted and incorporated by reference and made a part of this Ordinance. Copies of said standards shall be available for inspection in the Office of the City Engineer. 
Variances and exceptions. 
A.  No permits shall be required for the following: 
1.  Grading or an excavation below finished grade for basements, footings, retaining walls, or other structures on plots zoned R1A or R1B of less than one acre and more than five hundred (500) feet from any lake, stream, or drainage course. 
2.  A sidewalk or driveway authorized by a valid permit under 30.000, Streets and Public Ways, or 30.100, Sidewalks, Mount Clemens Code of Ordinances. 
3.  Where the City Engineer certifies in writing that the planned work and the final structures or topographical changes will not result in, or contribute to, soil erosion, sedimentation of the waters of the state, will not interfere with any existing drainage course in such a manner as to cause damage to any adjacent property or result in the deposition of debris or sediment on any public way, will not abate any hazard to any persons or property, and will have no detrimental influence upon the public welfare or upon the total development of the watershed. 
4.  Although no permits are required under subsections A. 1., 2., and 3. of this section, the operations and constructions exempted from obtaining permits must comply with the rules and regulations concerning grading and erosion specified in this Ordinance. 
B.  Where it is alleged that there is error or misinterpretation in any order, requirements, decisions, grant, or refusal made by the City Engineer, the City Commission shall have the power to hear specific applications and may amend or change such order, requirement, decision, grant, or refusal so that it is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of the requirements. Said hearing shall be a public hearing called for the specific purpose of hearing applications under this Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Aug., 4, 1975; further amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.215 - Sec. 15. 
INSPECTION. 
    The requirements of this Ordinance shall be enforced by the City Engineer, who shall inspect the work and shall require adequate inspection of compaction by a Soil Engineer or by a Soil Testing Agency, approved by the City Engineer, unless he determines that such inspection requirements may be waived due to the non-hazardous nature of the grading. 
    Upon satisfactory execution of all approved grading plans and other requirements, the City Engineer shall issue a Certification of Completion. If the City Engineer finds any existing conditions not as stated in any application, grading permit, or approved plan, he may refuse to approve further work until approval of a revised grading plan which will conform to the existing conditions. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.216 - Sec. 16. 
ENFORCEMENT. 
A.  Notwithstanding the existence or pursuit of any other remedy, the City of Mount Clemens may maintain an action in its own name in any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or other process against any person to restrain or prevent violations of this Ordinance. 
B.  The City Engineer or his duly authorized agents may enter, at all reasonable times, in or upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions and practices which may be in violation of this Ordinance, or the rules of the Department of Natural Resources, Water Resources Commission, promulgated pursuant to Act 347, P.A. 1972. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.217 - Sec. 17. 
PENALTIES. 
    Any person, as defined by this Ordinance, who shall violate any of the provisions of this Ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00, or be incarcerated for a period not to exceed 90 days, or be both so fined and incarcerated. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable hereunder. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978; further amend. eff. May 14, 1987) 
25.218 - Sec. 18. 
SEVERABILITY. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this Ordinance is, for any reason, held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining provisions of the within Ordinance. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.219 - Sec. 19. 
EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    Pursuant to Section 96 of the Charter of the City of Mount Clemens, the within Ordinance is deemed and declared to be an Emergency Ordinance which is immediately necessary for the preservation of the public health, safety, and welfare, and is hereby given immediate effect. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
25.300 - GAS FRANCHISE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. July 17, 1985; amend. eff. May 28, 2015 
AN ORDINANCE, granting to CONSUMERS ENERGY COMPANY, its successors and assigns, the right, power and authority to lay, maintain and operate gas mains, pipes and services on, along, across and under the highways, streets, alleys, bridges, waterways, and other public places, and to do a local gas business in the CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MACOMB COUNTY, MICHIGAN, for a period of thirty years. 
THE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS ORDAINS: 

25.301 - Sec. 1. 
GRANT, TERM. 
    The CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MACOMB COUNTY, MICHIGAN, hereby grants to the Consumers Energy Company, a Michigan corporation, its successors and assigns, hereinafter called the "Grantee," the right, power and authority to lay, maintain and operate gas mains, pipes and services on, along, across and under the highways, streets, alleys, bridges, waterways, and other public places, and to do a local gas business in the CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MACOMB COUNTY, MICHIGAN, for a period of thirty years. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.302 - Sec. 2. 
CONSIDERATION. 
    In consideration of the rights, power and authority hereby granted, said Grantee shall faithfully perform all things required by the terms hereof. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.303 - Sec. 3. 
CONDITIONS. 
    No highway, street, alley, bridge, waterway or other public place used by said Grantee shall be obstructed longer than necessary during the work of construction or repair, and shall be restored to the same order and condition as when said work was commenced. All of Grantee's pipes and mains shall be so placed in the highways and other public places as not to unnecessarily interfere with the use thereof for highway purposes. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.304 - Sec. 4. 
HOLD HARMLESS. 
    Said Grantee shall at all times keep and save the City free and harmless from all loss, costs and expense to which it may be subject by reason of the negligent construction and maintenance of the structures and equipment hereby authorized. In case any action is commenced against the City on account of the permission herein given, said Grantee shall, upon notice, defend the City and save it free and harmless from all loss, cost and damage arising out of such negligent construction and maintenance. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.305 - Sec. 5. 
EXTENSIONS. 
    Said Grantee shall construct and extend its gas distribution system within said City and shall furnish gas to applicants residing therein in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.306 - Sec. 6. 
FRANCHISE NOT EXCLUSIVE. 
    The rights, power and authority herein granted, are not exclusive. Either manufactured or natural gas may be furnished hereunder. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.307 - Sec. 7. 
RATES. 
    Said Grantee shall be entitled to charge the inhabitants of said City for gas furnished therein, the rates as approved by the Michigan Public Service Commission, to which Commission or its successors authority and jurisdiction to fix and regulate gas rates and rules regulating such service in said City, are hereby granted for the term of this franchise. Such rates and rules shall be subject to review and change at any time upon petition therefore being made by either said City, acting by its City Commission, or by said Grantee. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.308 - Sec. 8. 
REVOCATION. 
    The franchise granted by this ordinance is subject to revocation upon sixty (60) days written notice by the party desiring such revocation. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.309 - Sec. 9. 
MICHIGAN PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION, JURISDICTION. 
    Said Grantee shall, as to all other conditions and elements of service not herein fixed, be and remain subject to the reasonable rules and regulations of the Michigan Public Service Commission or its successors, applicable to gas service in said City. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.310 - Sec. 10. 
REPEALER. 
    This ordinance, when accepted and published as herein provided, shall repeal and supersede the provisions of a gas ordinance adopted by the City Commission on June 17, 1985 entitled: 
AN ORDINANCE, granting to CONSUMERS POWER COMPANY, its successors and assigns, the right, power and authority to lay, maintain and operate gas mains, pipes and services on, along, across and under the highways, streets, alleys, bridges and other public places, and to do a local gas business in the CITY OF MT. CLEMENS, MACOMB COUNTY, MICHIGAN. 
and amendments, if any, to such ordinance whereby a gas franchise was granted to Consumers Energy Company. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.311 - Sec. 11. 
EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    This ordinance shall take effect upon the later of ten days after enactment or upon publication thereof; provided, however, it shall cease and be of no effect after thirty days from its adoption unless within said period the Grantee shall accept the same in writing filed with the City Clerk. Upon acceptance and publication hereof, this ordinance shall constitute a contract between said City and said Grantee. 
(ord. eff. May 28, 2015) 
25.400 - CATV FRANCHISE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN ord. eff. June 16, 1983; further amd. eff. March 28, 2002 
An ordinance to regulate the granting of cable television franchises and the operation of a cable television system for the City of Mount Clemens. 
THE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS ORDAINS: 

25.401 - Sec. 1. 
DEFINITIONS. 
A.  "Cable Television System" or CATV System" shall mean a system of antennas, cables, wires, lines, towers, waveguides, or other conductors, convertors, equipment or facilities, designated and constructed for the purposes of producing, receiving, transmitting, amplifying and distributing audio, video and other forms of electronic or electrical signals, located in the City. Said definition shall not include any such facility that serves or will serve only subscribers in one or more multiple-unit dwellings under common ownership, control or management, and does not use City rights-of-way. 
B.  "City" is the City of Mount Clemens in its present incorporated form or as it may be changed by annexation. 
C.  Commission" shall mean the City Commission of the City of Mount Clemens. 
D.  "Grantee" is the party or parties to which a franchise under this Ordinance is granted by the Commission and its or their lawful successors and assigns. 
E.  "Gross Revenues" will be any and all compensation in whatever form, exchange or otherwise, received by Grantee from subscribers for the provision of cable service over the Cable Television System in the City of Mount Clemens. This term does not include any sales, excise or other taxes or feels collected by Grantee on behalf of any state, city or other governmental unit, and shall be net of bad debt, refunds to subscribers, home shopping revenues and advertising revenues. 
F.  "Two-way communications" means the transmission of telecommunications signals from subscriber locations or other points throughout the system back to the system's control center as well as transmission of signals from the control center to subscriber locations. 
G.  "Customer Service Standards" or "Customer Service Obligations" means those obligations specified by the Federal Communications Commission that the City may impose upon the Grantee. Enforcement provisions for these standards shall be as further set forth within this Ordinance. The terms "Customer Service Standards" and "Customer Service Obligations" shall be interchangeable when used within this Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.402 - Sec. 2. 
GRANT OF AUTHORITY. 
    No person may construct, erect, operate and maintain, in, upon, along, across, above, over and under the streets, alleys, public ways and public places now laid out or dedicated and all extensions thereof, and in additions thereto in the City, poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other cable conductors and fixtures necessary for the maintenance and operation in the City of Mount Clemens of a cable communications system, to be used for the sale and distribution of cable services to the residents of the City without a franchise granted by the Commission. Said broadband cable services shall include, but not be limited to, the carriage of television and radio signals and any cablecasting programming and shall be nonexclusive. 
    The Grantee shall, at all times during the operation of a franchise, be subject to all lawful exercise of the police power as may be provided by the franchising authority. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.403 - Sec. 3. 
CUSTOMER SERVICE STANDARDS. 
    The City of Mount Clemens adopts by reference those Customer Service Standards promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission under that agency's obligations to regulate the delivery of cable television services, together with all definitions, specifications and regulations included in such Customer Service Standards, except where such standards are exceeded in favor of the City by the terms and conditions previously set forth within this ordinance or within agreements between the City and any Grantees hereunder, or within future Ordinance modifications or agreements as may occur. The City reserves the right to unilaterally modify the terms and conditions of franchise agreements or clarify any Customer Service Standards as may otherwise be allowed by law. 
(ord. eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.404 - Sec. 4. 
DURATION OF FRANCHISES; RENEWAL. 
A.  The duration of the rights, privileges and authorizations granted by the franchise shall be fifteen (15) years from the date the franchise is awarded. The franchise may be renewed by the City upon application of the Company pursuant to the procedure established in subsection B of this section and in accordance with the then applicable law. 
B.  Renewal procedures. 
(1)  At least thirty (30) months prior to the expiration of the franchise, the Grantee shall inform the City in writing of its intent to seek renewal of the franchise and thereupon file with the City a proposal for services. 
(2)  After giving public notice, the City shall proceed to determine whether the Grantee has satisfactorily performed its obligations under the franchise. To determine satisfactory performance, the City shall consider technical developments and performance of the system, programming, other services offered, cost of services, and any other particular requirements set in the Ordinance; also, the City shall consider the Grantee's proposal and it annual reports made to the City and the FCC; industry performance on a national basis shall also be considered. Provision shall be made for public comment. 
(3)  A four-month period shall be provided to determine the Grantee's eligibility for renewal. 
(4)  The City shall then prepare within two (2) months any amendments to this Ordinance that it believes necessary. 
(5)  If, based upon Grantee's performance during this franchise term, the Grantee's new proposal, and report thereon, and the public hearing, the Commission finds a renewal of the franchise with the Grantee within the public interest, the Commission may enter into a renewal of the franchise with the Grantee under such terms and conditions and for an additional term not to exceed fifteen (15) years. 
(6)  In the event the Grantee is determined by the City to have performed unsatisfactorily, the Grantee will not be eligible to receive an additional term and new applicants will be sought and evaluated and a franchise award will be made by the City to a new applicant. 
(7)  The grantee shall supply to the City with its notice of intention to seek renewal of the franchise and, pursuant to subparagraph (1) of this subsection, a certified statement declaring that it has complied with all Customer Service Standards as promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission and adopted by the City of Mount Clemens through resolution or otherwise. The certified statements shall declare that the grantee has complied with all of the aforesaid obligations, together with any and all other and additional Customer Service Standards as provided for within the Franchise Agreement. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.405 - Sec. 5. 
FRANCHISE TERRITORY. 
    A franchise is for the present territorial limits of the City of Mt. Clemens and for any area henceforth added thereto during the term of the franchise. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.406 - Sec. 6. 
SERVICE REQUIREMENTS, CONSTRUCTION TIMETABLE AND LINE EXTENSIONS. 
(A)  Construction schedules and time tables shall be set forth in the Franchise Agreement. 
(B)  Any delay beyond the terms of this timetable, unless specifically approved by the Commission, will be considered a violation of this Ordinance for which the provisions of either Section 22 or Section 23 shall apply, as determined by the Commission. 
(C)  With respect to requests for connection requiring a drop in excess of one hundred fifty (150) feet, the Grantee must extend and make available cable television service to such residents at a connection charge not to exceed the actual installation costs incurred by the Grantee for the distance exceeding one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.407 - Sec. 7. 
CONSTRUCTION AND TECHNICAL STANDARDS. 
(A)  COMPLIANCE WITH CONSTRUCTION AND TECHNICAL STANDARDS. The Grantee shall construct, install, operate and maintain its system in a manner consistent with all laws, ordinances, construction standards, governmental requirements, FCC technical standards, and detailed standards submitted by the Grantee as part of its application, which standards are incorporated by reference. In addition, the Grantee shall provide the City, upon request, with a written report of the results of the Grantee's annual proof of performance tests conducted pursuant to FCC standards and requirements. 
(B)  ADDITIONAL SPECIFICATIONS. In addition to the requirements set forth in Section 11, construction, installation and maintenance shall be performed in an orderly and workmanlike manner. All cables and wires shall be installed, where possible, parallel with electric and telephone lines. Multiple cable configurations shall be arranged in parallel and bundled with due respect for engineering considerations. Grantee shall at all times comply with: 
National Electrical Safety Code of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers; 
National Electrical Code of the National Fire Protection Association; 
Bell System Code of Pole Line Construction; 
Applicable FCC or other federal, state and local regulation; and
