The Charter and Ordinances of the City of Mount Clemens, including provisions regulating public utility franchises and specifically will abide by Sections 166 and 168 of said Charter. In any event, the system shall not endanger or interfere with the safety of persons or property in the franchise area or other areas where the Grantee may have equipment located. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.408 - Sec. 8. 
ASSIGNMENT, TRANSFER OR SALE. 
(A)  GENERAL. There shall be no assignment of Grantee's Franchise, in whole or in part, by Grantee without the prior express written approval of the City. As used in this ordinance, the terms "assigned" and "transferred" shall mean any transaction which involves a "transfer of ownership in a cable system" within the meaning of 47 U.S.C. 537(a), as implemented by 47 C.F.R. Section 76.502 (with the exception of those transactions exempted in 47 U.S.C. 537(c)(3), as implemented by 47 C.F.R. Section 76.502(f)(3)). 
(B)  120-DAY PETITION. At least one hundred twenty (120) days before such a proposed assignment of Grantee's Franchise is scheduled to become effective, Grantee shall submit a written petition. ("Petition for Consent") for the City's written consent for such a proposed assignment. At the time Grantee submits the Petition for Consent, Grantee (or Grantee's proposed assignee) shall also file with the City a substantially complete (as defined below) FCC Form 394 (or successor form). As used in this subsection, the term "substantially complete" means that the City has been supplied with all information required by the request that is necessary to make a determination on the transfer request. 
(C)  CONSENT NOT UNREASONABLY WITHHELD. The City shall not unreasonably withhold its consent to such an assignment. However, in evaluating the Petition for Consent, the City may undertake, at the sole expense of Grantee's proposed assignee, a technical inspection and audit of the system to determine whether the Cable System complies with all applicable technical codes, as well as complies with, and operates within, the construction and construction-related practices set forth in this ordinance. Furthermore, the Petition for Consent shall include such financial information as the City may require in order for the City to determine whether the potential assignee has the financial ability to assume the obligations of the Grantee. The City shall determine whether the potential assignee has the ability to assume the obligations of Grantee. 
(D)  TECHNICAL INSPECTION DEADLINES. Should the City undertake a technical inspection pursuant to Subparagraph C. of this section, the City shall conduct such inspection no sooner than fifteen (15) days after receiving the Petition for Consent, and the City shall receive the technical inspection and audit report at least thirty (30) days before the proposed Cable System assignment, transfer or sale is to occur. 
(E)  SUBMISSION OF SALE AGREEMENT OR SUMMARY OF OBLIGATIONS. At the time that Grantee submits its written petition, it shall also submit a copy of the completed sales agreement, or a functionally equivalent instrument, between Grantee and the proposed assignee, so that the City may discover the assumption of obligations by Grantee and the proposed assignee with respect to the Cable System. The City may request, and Grantee shall provide, additional relevant information, so long as neither the request nor the submission of such information would be expressly prohibited by law. 
(F)  AFFIDAVIT OF PROPOSED ASSIGNEE. Before an assignment is approved by the City, the proposed assignee shall execute an affidavit stating that it has read, understood and will abide by both applicable law and this ordinance. 
(G)  ASSUMPTION OF OBLIGATIONS BY NEW GRANTEE. In the event of any approved assignment, the new Grantee will assume all obligation and liabilities of the former Grantee. 
(H)  DISPOSITION OF PETITION FOR CONSENT. Consistent with both the Federal Cable Act and FCC implementing rules, the City shall have one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of a substantially complete filing of the FCC Form 394, together with all required exhibits, data and reports, to act upon Grantee's Petition for Consent. The City may either approve the Petition for Consent or, for cause, not approve the Petition for Consent. 
(I)  FAILURE TO ACT IN ONE HUNDRED TWENTY (120) DAYS. Consistent with both the Federal Cable Act and the FCC implementing rules, should the City fail to act upon Grantee's Petition for Consent within the one hundred twenty (120) day time-frame, Grantee's Petition for Consent shall be deemed granted unless the City and Grantee otherwise agree to an extension of time in order to review the data submitted on behalf of the Petition for Consent. 
(J)  RESUBMISSION OF PETITION. Should the City, for cause, not approve a Petition for Consent, then Grantee may immediately submit another Petition for Consent. In such a situation, then the one hundred twenty (120) day time-frame runs anew. In such a situation, the procedural and substantive provisions of both federal and state law must be met. 
(K)  EXCEPTION. This Section 25.407 [25.408] shall not apply to any sale, assignment or transfer to one or more purchasers, assignees or transferees controlled by, controlling or under common control with, Grantee, and Grantee shall be permitted to effect any such sale, assignment or transfer without obtaining the prior approval of the City. 
(L)  The consent on approval of the Commission to any transfer of the franchise shall not constitute a waiver or release of the rights of the City in and to the streets, and any transfer shall by its terms, be expressly subordinate to the terms and conditions of the franchise. 
(M)  In an absence of extraordinary circumstances, the City will not approve any transfer or assignment of the franchise prior to substantial completion of construction of proposed system. 
(N)  In no event shall a transfer of ownership or control be approved without the successor in interest becoming a signatory to the franchise agreement assuming all of Grantee's responsibilities. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. Jan 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.409 - Sec. 9. 
SUBSCRIBER SERVICE RATES. 
    The Grantee may establish rates for service from time to time thereafter by filing with the commission a schedule of rates thirty (30) days prior to their implementation. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.410 - Sec. 10. 
PAYMENT OF FRANCHISE FEE. 
(A)  For the reason that the streets to be used by the Grantee in the operation of its system within the boundaries of the City are valuable public properties acquired and maintained by the City at great expense to its taxpayers, and that the grant to the Grantee to utilize said streets is a valuable right without which the Grantee would be required to invest substantial capital in right-of-way costs and acquisitions, and because the City will incur costs in administering the franchise, and at the option of the Commission, the City may make available a portion of the franchise fee to further the development of public and community uses of cable TV, the Grantee shall pay to the City an amount equal to 5 percent (5%) of the Grantee's annual gross revenues. 
(B)  The franchise fee and any other costs or penalties assessed shall be paid quarterly to the City Treasurer. The Grantee shall file a complete and accurate verified statement of all gross revenue within the City during the period for which said quarterly payment is made, and said payment shall be made to the City not later than forty-five (45) days after the end of the applicable calendar quarter. 
(C)  The City shall have the right to inspect the Grantee's income records and the right to audit and to recompute any amounts determined to be payable under this Ordinance; provided, however, that such audit shall take place thirty-six (36) months following the close of each of the Grantee's fiscal years. Any additional amount due to the City as a result of the audit shall be paid within thirty (30) days following a written notice to the Grantee by the City, which notice shall include a copy of the audit report. 
(D)  In the event that any franchise payment or recomputed amount, cost or penalty is not made on or before the applicable dates heretofore specified, interest shall be charged daily from such date at the annual rate of either twelve percent (12%) or the current prime interest rate, whichever is greater. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.411 - Sec. 11. 
REQUIRED SERVICES AND FACILITIES. 
(A)  The cable television system shall have at least ninety (90) channels available for immediate use. 
(B)  Such system shall maintain a plant having the technical capacity for return, or "two-way" communications. 
(C)  The Grantee shall provide three (3) public, educational and governmental (PEG) access channels for the use of local government, and local educational authorities to provide PEG programming to the City's residents. PEG programming shall be carried in the basic service and the channel designation for PEG programming shall not be moved without at least thirty (30) days written notice to the City and all subscribers of such relocation. 
(D)  Grantee shall install as part of its Cable System, and shall operate through the Term, an Emergency Alert System ("EAS") (or the successor to that system) in accordance with all requirements imposed from time to time by the Federal Communications Commission, including, without limitation, the requirements that cable television systems transmit a visual EAS message on at least one channel (47 C.F.R. § 11.51(g)(3)) provide video interruption and an audio EAS message on all channels, with the audio message further stating which channel is carrying the visual message (47 C.F.R. § 11.51 (g)(2)). In establishing Grantee's EAS system pursuant to this Section, Grantee shall: 
(1)  Designate a channel (which may be the government channel) which will be used for emergency broadcasts of both audio and video; 
(2)  Inform subscribers of the designated emergency channel at least daily on at least one channel (which may be the government channel) of the multi-channel system; 
(3)  Maintain the ability to activate it remotely by security measures deemed mutually agreeable by the City and Grantee; 
(4)  Test the emergency override system not less than every three (3) months; 
(5)  Cooperate with the City on the use and operation of the emergency alert override system; and 
(6)  Develop a reasonable and practical plan (with the City's concurrence) in order to provide continuity of multi-channel service, and response to service calls in the event of a natural or man-made emergency. 
(E)  The Grantee may be required to interconnect its system with other broadband communications facilities. Such interconnection shall be made within the time limit established by the City. The interconnection shall, at the City's discretion, be accomplished according to the method and technical standards determined by the City and generally accepted in industry practices. "Broadband communications facility", as used herein, means any network of cable, optical, electrical or electronic equipment, including cable television systems, used for the purpose of transmitting telecommunication signals. 
(F)  The Grantee shall provide such additional services and facilities as are contained in its application, which is incorporated by reference herein. 
(G)  In furtherance of the general policy that the services provided by innovative and modern, Grantee will pursue a continuous policy of incorporating new technical developments into the system and will identify and respond to changing community interests and desires regarding video programming where economically and technically feasible. 
(H)  In addition to the foregoing, the Grantee shall comply with all Customer Service Standards as they apply to its services and facilities as promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.412 - Sec. 12. 
USE OF STREETS. 
    All transmission and distribution structures, lines and equipment erected by the Grantee within the City shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of the said streets. 
    In case of disturbance of any street or paved area, the Grantee shall, at its own cost and expense and in a manner approved by the City, replace and restore such street or paved area in as good a condition as before the work involving such disturbance was done. 
    If at any time during the period of the franchise the City shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade of any street, the Grantee, upon reasonable notice by the City, shall remove, relay and relocate its poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes and other fixtures at its own expense. 
    Before placing poles, pedestals or any other above ground and underground fixtures in City streets or rights-of-way, Grantee shall notify the City in advance of the proposed placement and will make reasonable efforts to work with the City to minimize the impact of such placement. 
    The Grantee shall, at the request of any person holding a moving permit issued by the City, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of buildings. The expense of such temporary removal or raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting the same, and the Grantee shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. The Grantee shall be given not less than forty-eight (48) hours' notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
    The Grantee shall have the authority to trim trees upon and overhanging streets of the City so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming into contact with the wires and cables of the Grantee. If, upon reasonable notice to the Grantee, the Grantee fails to trim such trees which are interfering with the wires and cables, such trimming may be performed by the City or under its supervision and direction at the expense of the Grantee. 
    In all sections of the City where the cables, wires, or other like facilities of public utilities are placed underground, the Grantee shall place its cables, wires or other like facilities underground. 
    At the expiration of the term for which the franchise is granted, or upon its termination and cancellation, as provided for herein, the City shall have the right to require the Grantee to remove at its own expense all portions of the cable television system within the City, except underground cables. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.413 - Sec. 13. 
INDEMNIFICATION AND INSURANCE. 
(A)  It shall be expressly understood and agreed by and between the City and any Grantee that the Grantee shall save the City and its agents and employees harmless from and against all claims, damages, losses and expenses, including attorney's fees sustained by the City on account of any suit, judgment, execution claim or demand whatsoever arising out of but not limited to copyright infringements and all other damages arising out of the installation, operation or maintenance of a cable system, whether or not any act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this ordinance and any franchise. 
(B)  The Grantee shall maintain and by its acceptance of the franchise specifically agrees that it will maintain throughout the term of the franchise, liability insurance insuring the City and the Grantee in the minimum amount of One Million Dollars ($1,000,000.00). 
(C)  The insurance policy obtained by the Grantee in compliance with this section must be approved by the City Attorney and such insurance policy, along with written evidence of payment of required premiums, shall be filed and maintained with the City Manager during the term of the franchise. The Grantee shall immediately advise the City Attorney of any litigation that may develop that would affect this insurance. 
(D)  Neither the provisions of this section nor any damages recovered by the City shall be construed to or limit the liability of the Grantee under any franchise for damages. 
(E)  All insurance policies maintained pursuant to a franchise shall provide that they are noncancellable without thirty (30) days prior written notice of cancellation to the City. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.414 - Sec. 14. 
LETTER OF CREDIT. 
(A)  Within ten (10) days after the effective date of a franchise agreement, the Grantee shall deposit with the City a letter of credit from a financial institution in the amount of $50,000.00. The form and content of such letter of credit shall be approved by the City Attorney. The letter of credit shall be used to insure the faithful performance by the Grantee of all provisions of the franchise; and compliance with all orders, permits and directions of any agency, commission, board, department, division or office of the City having jurisdiction over its acts or defaults under this franchise, and the payment by the Grantee of any claims, liens and taxes due the City which arise by reason of the construction, operation or maintenance of the system. 
(B)  The letter of credit shall be maintained at $50,000.00 during the entire term of this franchise, even if amounts have to be withdrawn pursuant to subdivision (A) or (C) of this section. 
(C)  If the Grantee fails to pay to the City any compensation within the time fixed herein; or fails, after ten (10) days' notice, to pay to the City any taxes due and unpaid; or fails to repay the City, within ten (10) days, any damages, costs or expenses which the City is compelled to pay by reason of any act or default of the Grantee in connection with this franchise; or fails after three (3) days' notice of such failure by the City, to comply with any provision of this franchise which the City reasonably determines can be remedied by demand on the letter of credit, the City may immediately request payment of the amount thereof, with interest and any penalties, from the letter of credit. Upon such request for payment, the City shall notify the Grantee of the amount and date. 
(D)  The rights reserved to the City with respect to the letter of credit are in addition to all other rights of the City, whether reserved by this franchise or authorized by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such letter of credit shall affect any other right the City may have. 
(E)  The letter of credit shall contain the following endorsement: 
"It is understood and agreed that this letter of credit may not be canceled nor the intention not to renew be stated until sixty (60) days after receipt by the City, by registered mail, of written notice of such intention to cancel or not to renew." 
(F)  In lieu of a letter of credit as set forth above in paragraphs (A) through (E), the Grantee shall be permitted to deposit in an interest-bearing account in a local financial institution the sum of $50,000.00 under the same terms and conditions applicable to a letter of credit. All interest earned on said deposit shall be payable to the Grantee. The City shall have the right to withdraw said funds or a portion thereof at any time for the same reasons applicable to draws on a letter of credit as set forth above. The Grantee shall not be permitted to withdraw said funds, except upon sixty (60) days written notice to the City of its intention to withdraw and approval of the Commission of alternative security. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.415 - Sec. 15. 
CONSTRUCTION BOND. 
(A)  Within thirty (30) days of an award of a franchise, the Grantee shall obtain and maintain at its cost and expense, and file with the City Manager, a corporate surety bond in a company authorized to do business in the State of Michigan, and found acceptable to the City Attorney, in an amount set forth in the franchise agreement to guarantee the timely construction and full activation of the CATV system. 
    The bond shall provide, but not be limited to, the following condition: There shall be recoverable by the City, jointly and severally from the principal and surety, any and all damages, loss or costs suffered by the City resulting from the failure of the Grantee to satisfactorily complete and fully activate the CATV system throughout the franchise area pursuant to the terms and conditions of this Ordinance. 
(B)  Any extension to the prescribed time limit must be authorized by the Commission. Such extension may be authorized only when the Commission finds that such extension is necessary and appropriate due to causes beyond the control of the Grantee. 
(C)  The construction bond may be terminated only after the Commission finds that the Grantee has satisfactorily completed initial construction and activation of the CATV system, pursuant to the terms and conditions of Section 5(A) of this Ordinance. 
(D)  The rights reserved to the City with respect to the construction bond are in addition to all other rights of the City, whether reserved by this Ordinance or authorized by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such construction bond shall affect any other rights the City may have. 
(E)  The construction bond shall contain the following endorsement: 
"It is understood and agreed that this bond may not be cancelled by the surety nor the intention not to renew be stated by the surety until sixty (60) days after receipt by the City, by registered mail, of written notice of such intent to cancel or not to renew." 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.416 - Sec. 16. 
SERVICE STANDARDS 
    The Grantee shall put, keep and maintain all parts of the system in good condition throughout the entire franchise period. 
    Upon termination of service to any subscriber, the Grantee shall promptly remove all its facilities and equipment from the premises of such subscriber. 
    The Grantee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions, insofar as possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum system use. 
    The Grantee shall not allow its cable or other operations to interfere with television reception of persons not served by the Grantee, nor shall the system interfere with, obstruct or hinder in any manner the operation of the various utilities serving the residents of the City. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.417 - Sec. 17. 
CONTINUITY OF SERVICE MANDATORY. 
(A)  It shall be the right of all subscribers to continue receiving service insofar as their financial and other obligations to the Grantee are honored. In the event that the Grantee elects to overbuild, rebuild, modify or sell the system, or the City gives notice of intent to terminate or fails to renew this franchise, the Grantee shall act so as to ensure that all subscribers receive continuous, uninterrupted service regardless of the circumstances. 
    In the event of a change of franchisee, or in the event a new operator acquires the system, the Grantee shall cooperate with the City, new franchisee or operator in maintaining continuity of service to all subscribers. During such period, the Grantee shall be entitled to the revenues for any period during which it operates the system and shall be entitled to reasonable costs for its services when it no longer operates the system. 
(B)  In the event the Grantee fails to operate the system for seven (7) consecutive days without prior approval of the City, or in violation of Customer Service Standards or without just cause, the City may, at its option, operate the system or designate an operator until such times as the Grantee restores service under conditions acceptable to the City or until a permanent operator is selected. If the City is required to fulfill this obligation for the Grantee, the Grantee shall reimburse the City for all reasonable costs or damages in excess of revenues from the system received by the City that are the result of the Grantee's failure to perform. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.418 - Sec. 18. 
COMPLAINT PROCEDURE. 
    The City Manager is specified by the City as having primary responsibility for the continuing administration of the franchise and implementation of complaint procedures. 
    The Grantee will maintain a local, toll-free or collect call telephone access line which will be available to its subscribers twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. Trained representatives of Grantee will be available to respond to subscriber telephone inquiries twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. 
    The Grantee will establish procedures for receiving, acting upon and resolving subscriber complaints to the satisfaction of the City Manager. The Grantee shall furnish a notice of such procedures to each subscriber at the time of initial subscription to the system and at least once annually. 
    In the event that a customer complaint is not resolved to the mutual satisfaction of the customer or the Grantee, either the customer or the Grantee may request that the matter be presented to the Commission for a hearing and resolution. 
    When there have been similar complaints made or when there exist other evidence, which, in the judgment of the Commission, casts doubt on the reliability or quality of cable service, the Commission shall have the right and authority to compel the Grantee to test, analyze, and report on the performance of the system. Such report shall be delivered to the Commission no later than fourteen (14) days after the Commission formally notifies the Grantee and shall include the following information: the nature of the complaints which precipitated the special tests; what system component was tested, the equipment used, and procedures employed in said testing; the results of such tests; and the method in which said complaints were resolved. 
    Said tests and analyses shall be supervised by a professional engineer not on the permanent staff of the company. The aforesaid engineer should sign all records of the special tests and forward to the Commission such records with a report interpreting the results of the tests and recommending actions to be taken by the City. 
    The foregoing Complaint Procedures shall be applicable to the Grantee's compliance with the Customer Service Standards. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.419 - Sec. 19. 
AVAILABILITY OF BOOKS AND RECORDS. 
    The Grantee shall fully cooperate in making available at reasonable times, and the City Manager shall have the right to inspect the books, records, maps, plans and other like materials of the Grantee applicable to the CATV system, at anytime during normal business hours; provided where volume and convenience necessitate, the Grantee may require inspection to take place on the Grantee's premises. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.420 - Sec. 20. 
MOUNT CLEMENS CABLE COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION AND CHIEF ADMINISTRATOR. 
(A)  CABLE COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION AND OFFICE OF CHIEF ADMINISTRATOR ESTABLISHED. The City of Mount Clemens establishes the Mount Clemens Cable Communications Commission and Office of the Chief Administrator for the Cable Communications Commission. 
(B)  CABLE COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION COMPOSITION. The Cable Communications Commission shall be composed of seven (7) members and shall consist of: 
(1)  Three (3) City of Mount Clemens residents appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the Mount Clemens City Commission. East Cable Communications Commission member shall serve a term of three (3) years. 
(2)  Any vacancy in the above positions shall be filled by the appointment system set forth above for the remaining term of the Cable Communications Commission member. An employee or person with ownership interest in a cable television franchise granted pursuant to this Ordinance shall be ineligible for membership on the Cable Communications Commission. 
(3)  The governing board of the Mount Clemens Community Schools shall appoint three (3) City of Mount Clemens residents as members to the Cable Communications Commission who shall serve upon such terms and conditions as the Mount Clemens Community Schools shall set. The Mount Clemens Community Schools shall notify in writing the Mount Clemens City Commission, City Clerk, Chief Administrator for the cable system and Chair of the Cable Communications Commission of any appointment, re-appointment, or removal of such Cable Communications Commission members. 
(4)  The governing board of the Mount Clemens Cable Communications Commission shall appoint one (1) City of Mount Clemens resident as a member to the Cable Communications Commission who shall serve upon such terms and conditions as the Mount Clemens Cable Communications Commission shall set. The Cable Communications Commission shall notify in writing the Mount Clemens City Commission, City Clerk, Chief Administrator for the cable system and Chair of the Commission of any appointment, re-appointment or removal of such Cable Communications Commission member. 
(C)  CABLE COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION FUNCTIONS. The Cable Communications Commission, in addition to any functions assigned to it elsewhere in this Ordinance, shall have the following functions: 
(1)  Advise the Mount Clemens City Commission on applications for franchise; 
(2)  Advise the Mount Clemens City Commission on matters which might constitute grounds for revocation of the franchise in accordance with this Ordinance; 
(3)  Resolve disagreements among franchisees, subscribers, and public and private users of the system; such decisions of the Cable Communications Commission shall be appealable to the Mount Clemens City Commission; 
(4)  Advise the Mount Clemens City Commission on the regulation of rates in accordance with this Ordinance; 
(5)  Coordinate the franchisee's consultant services for best use of public facilities and channels of the System; 
(6)  Determine general policy relating to the service provided subscribers and the operation and use of public channels, with a view to maximizing the diversity of programs and services to subscribers; the use of public channels shall be allocated on a first-come-first-served basis, subject to limitation on monopolization of system time, or prime time; except that the following shall have priority on the use of public channel time; one the public access channel, Mounts Clemens residents; on the governmental access channel, the Mount Clemens City Government; and on the educational access channel the Mount Clemens Public School System; 
(7)  Encourage use of public channels among the widest range of institutions, groups and individuals within the City. This endeavor shall be conducted with a view toward establishing different categories of uses, and the annual reports by the Cable Communications Commission to the Mount Clemens City Commission shall be by such categories as defined as follows: 
a)  Local educational uses, including library, public schools, Macomb County Community College and other institutions of higher learning; 
b)  Local programming under public control with guaranteed access for students and minority groups; 
c)  Public agency access (including fire, police, burglar alarms, and public announcements); 
d)  Off-the-air network and independent entertainment programs; 
e)  Off-the-air educational programs; 
f)  Availability of channel time for lease or pay TV; 
g)  Availability of channel time for lease of business uses, including telemetry of information; 
h)  Information retrieval and professional communication; 
(8)  Cooperate with other systems, and supervise interconnection of systems; 
(9)  Maintain and implement a budget for the purpose of operating and maintaining public access channel programs and services. The Cable Communications Commission shall be eligible to receive revenues from the City of Mount Clemens and Mount Clemens Public Schools, as fixed by these entities, for the purpose of maintaining and implementing such budgets; 
(10)  Audit all franchisee records required by this Ordinance and, at the Mount Clemens City Commission's discretion, require the preparation and filing of additional information; 
(11)  Make an annual report to the Mount Clemens City Commission, including an account of franchise fees received and distributed, the total number of hours of utilization of public channels, and hourly sub-totals for various programming categories, and a review of any plans submitted during the year by franchisees for development of new services; and 
(12)  Conduct evaluations of the system at least every three (3) years with the franchisee and, pursuant thereto, make recommendations to the Mount Clemens City Commission for amendments to this Ordinance or the franchise agreement; 
(13)  The Cable Communications Commission shall have the authority to enter into contracts for goods and services, hire and fire employees, and take such other actions within the scope of these Ordinances and the statutory laws governing such acts; 
(14)  The Cable Communications Commission shall have the authority to negotiate and contract for the providing of funds from sources including but not limited to, the City of Mount Clemens, Mount Clemens Public Schools, Mount Clemens Public Library, any franchise holders under these Ordinances and any other funding source. 
(D)  CHIEF ADMINISTRATOR. The Chief Administrator for the Cable Communications Commission shall be the Director of Public and School Libraries for the Mount Clemens Public Schools. The administrator shall be responsible for maintaining day-to-day supervision over the operations under the control of the Cable Communications Commission. The duties and functions of the Chief Administrator shall be those set forth by the Cable Communications Commission. 
(E)  EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR. The Cable Communications Commission shall have the authority to appoint an Executive Director to supervise the daily operation of cable television services provided or authorized by the Cable Communications Commission. 
(F)  CABLE COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION MEMBERS AND EMPLOYEES NOT EMPLOYEES OF CITY. The Cable Communications Commission Members, Chief Administrator, Executive Director and employees of the system shall not be deemed employees of the City of Mount Clemens. For all purposes hereunder, the City of Mount Clemens shall not exercise management or supervision over said system employees nor shall the City directly compensate any system employees for work performed for the system. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. Feb. 13, 1992; amend. eff. Nov. 26, 1992; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.421 - Sec. 21. 
OTHER PETITIONS AND APPLICATIONS. 
    Copies of all petitions, applications, communications and reports submitted by the Grantee to the Federal Communications Commission, Securities and Exchange Commission, or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction in respect to any matters affecting cable television operations authorized pursuant to the franchisee shall be provided simultaneously to the City. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.422 - Sec. 22. 
FISCAL REPORTS. 
    Within ninety (90) days after the end of Grantee's fiscal year, Grantee shall provide the City those records and reports which pertain specifically to Grantee's Cable System under a franchise agreement and the financial records of the revenues earned by Grantee from the operation of Grantee's Cable System within the City. Grantee shall also provide an annual report which indicates a summary of the previous year's activities, a list of officers and members of its board of directors. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.423 - Sec. 23. 
FORFEITURE AND TERMINATION. 
(A)  In addition to all other rights and powers retained by the City under this franchise or otherwise, the City reserves that right to forfeit and terminate the franchise and all rights and privileges of the Grantee hereunder in the event of a substantial breach of its terms and conditions. A substantial breach by the Grantee shall include but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Violation of any material provision of the franchise or any material rule, order, regulation or determination of the City made pursuant to the franchise; 
(2)  Attempt to dispose of any of the facilities or property of its CATV system to prevent the City from purchasing it; 
(3)  Attempt to evade any material provisions of the franchise or practices any fraud or deceit upon the City or its subscribers or customers; 
(4)  Failure to provide begin or complete the system construction or system extension as provided under the franchise; 
(5)  Failure to provide the type of services promised; 
(6)  Failure to restore service after one hundred sixty-eight (168) consecutive hours of interrupted service, except when approval of such interruption is obtained from the City; 
(7)  For material or repeated violation of any Customer Service Standard; 
(8)  Failure to comply with paragraphs A and B of Section 24 of this Ordinance, "Rights of Individuals." 
(B)  The foregoing shall not constitute a substantial breach if the violation occurs but it is without fault of the Grantee or occurs as a result of circumstances beyond its control. The Grantee shall not be excused by mere economic hardship nor by misfeasance or malfeasance of its directors, officers or employees. 
(C)  The City shall make a written demand that the Grantee comply with such provision, rule, order or determination under or pursuant to the franchise. If the violation by the Grantee continues for a period of thirty (30) days following such written demand without written proof that the corrective action has been taken or is being actively and expeditiously pursued, the City may place the issue of termination of the franchise before the Commission. The City shall cause to be served upon the Grantee, at least twenty (20) days prior to the date of such Commission meeting, a written notice of intent to request such termination and the time and place of the meeting. Public notice shall be given of the meeting and issue which the Commission is to consider. 
(D)  The Commission shall hear and consider the issue and shall hear any interested person, and shall determine whether or not any violation by the Grantee has occurred. 
(E)  If the Commission determines the violation by the Grantee was the fault of the Grantee and within its control, the Commission may, by resolution, declare that the franchise of the Grantee shall be forfeited and terminated unless there is compliance within such period as the commission may fix, such period not to be less than sixty (60) days. No opportunity for compliance need be granted for fraud or misrepresentation. 
(F)  The issue of forfeiture and termination shall automatically be placed upon the Commission agenda at the expiration of the time set by it for compliance. The Commission then may terminate the franchise forthwith upon finding that the Grantee has failed to achieve compliance or may further extend the period, in its discretion. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.424 - Sec. 24. 
PENALTIES. 
    For the violation of any of the following provisions of this franchise, penalties shall be chargeable to the letter of credit as follows: 
(A)  For failure to complete the system construction in accordance with Section 5, unless the Commission specifically approves the delay by motion or resolution, due to the occurrence of conditions beyond the Grantee's control, the Grantee shall pay One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) per day for each day, or part of a day, the deficiency continues with a Ten Thousand Dollar ($10,000.00) cap for such damages/penalties. 
(B)  For failure to provide data, documents, reports, or information the Grantee shall pay Fifty Dollars ($50.00) per day each violation occurs or continues. 
(C)  For failure to test, analyze and report on the performance of the system following a request pursuant to the franchise, the Grantee shall pay to the City Fifty Dollars ($50.00) per day for each day, or part thereof, that such noncompliance continues. 
(D)  Forty-five (45) days following adoption of a resolution of the Council determining a failure of the Grantee to comply with operational or maintenance standards, the Grantee shall pay to the City One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) per day for each day, or part thereof, that such noncompliance continues. 
(E)  For failure to comply with Customer Service Standards the Grantee shall pay Fifty Dollars ($50.00) for each violation that occurs being considered as an independent violation for which a penalty may be assessed. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Oct. 1, 1993; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.425 - Sec. 25. 
RIGHTS OF INDIVIDUALS. 
(A)  The Grantee may not deny service, deny access, or otherwise discriminate against subscribers, channel users, or general citizens on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin or sex. The Grantee shall comply at all times with all other applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations, and all executive and administrative orders relating to nondiscrimination which are hereby incorporated and made part of this Ordinance by reference. 
(B)  The Grantee shall not discriminate against any employee or applicant for employment because of race, religion, color, sex or national origin. 
(C)  No signals shall be transmitted from a subscriber terminal for purposes of monitoring individual viewing patterns or practices without the express written permission of the subscriber. The request for such permission shall be contained in a separate document with a prominent statement that the subscriber is authorizing the permission in full knowledge of its provision. The authorization shall be revocable at any time by the subscriber in writing without penalty of any kind whatsoever. Such authorization is required for each type or classification of two-way cable communications activity planned. The Grantee shall be entitled to conduct system-wide or individually addressed "sweeps" for the purpose of verifying system integrity, controlling return-path transmission, or billing for pay services. 
(D)  The Grantee, or any of its agents or employees, shall not, without the specific written authorization of the subscriber involved, sell or otherwise make available to any party: 
(1)  Lists of the names and addresses of such subscribers; or 
(2)  Any list which identifies the individual viewing habits of subscribers. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
24.426 - Sec. 26. 
PURCHASE OF CATV SYSTEM BY CITY. 
(A)  RIGHTS TO PURCHASE. In the event the Grantee forfeits and the City terminates this franchise pursuant to provisions of this Ordinance, or at the normal expiration of the franchise term, the City shall have the right, directly or as an intermediary, to purchase the CATV system. 
(B)  FRANCHISE VALUATION. The valuation shall be undertaken in the traditional fair market value concept involving the physical assets of the Grantee or its assignees. "Going concern value," as defined herein, may be included in the fair market value. The "going concern value" shall mean the benefits that attach to the business as a result of the Grantee's reputation among franchise subscribers or potential subscribers for dependability and quality of service, and other circumstances resulting in probable retention of old subscribers; except no value shall be assigned to either the franchise itself or any right, privilege or expectancy arising to the Grantee out of the right to transact business under the franchise, and particularly no value shall be allowed for any increase in value arising out of any expectation of CATV system revenues beyond the forfeiture and termination date or expiration date, whichever is sooner. 
(C)  RELOCATION. In the acceptance of this franchise, the Grantee expressly waives its rights, if any, to relocation costs that might otherwise be provided by law. 
(D)  DATE OF VALUATION. The date of valuation shall be no earlier than the day following the date of expiration or termination and no later than the date City makes a fair and reasonable offer for the system or the date of transfer of ownership, whichever occurs first. 
(E)  TRANSFER TO CITY. Upon exercise of this option and the payment of the above sum by the City and its service of official notice of such action shall immediately transfer to the City possession and title to all facilities, real and personal, of the CATV system, free from any and all liens and encumbrances not agreed to be assumed by the City in lieu of some portion of the purchase price set forth above; and the Grantee shall execute such warranty deeds or other instruments of conveyance to the City as shall be necessary for this purpose. 
(F)  ARBITRATION OF VALUE AND COSTS. 
(1)  In the event the City and Company cannot agree upon the value of the CATV system, either may give notice of a demand to the other for arbitration. 
(2)  Arbitration shall commence and proceed according to law except as follows: 
a)  The parties shall, within fifteen (15) days, appoint one arbitrator each who is experienced and knowledgeable in the valuation of business property. Arbitrators shall each agree upon the selection of a third arbitrator, similarly qualified, within fifteen (15) days. 
b)  Within thirty (30) days after appointment of all arbitrators and upon ten (10) days written notice to parties, the board of arbitrators shall commence a hearing on the issue of valuation. 
c)  The hearing shall be recorded and transcribed at the request of either party. All hearing proceedings, debate and deliberations shall be open to the public and at such times and places as contained in the notice or as thereafter publicly stated in the order to adjourn, except as otherwise authorized by the City Attorney. 
d)  At the close of the hearings and within thirty (30) days, the board shall prepare findings and decision agreed upon by a majority of the board which shall be filed with the City and served by mail upon the Grantee. Unless the parties extend by mutual agreement the time which the board has to make a decision, the proceedings shall become null and void and shall be started anew. 
e)  The decision of the board shall be final and binding upon the parties. 
f)  Either party may seek judicial relief in the following circumstances: 
i)  A party fails to select an arbitrator; 
ii)  The arbitrators fail to select a third arbitrator; 
iii)  One or more arbitrators is unqualified; 
iv)  Designated time limits have been exceeded; 
v)  The board has not proceeded expeditiously; and 
vi)  Based upon the record, the board abused its discretion. 
g)  In the event a court of competent jurisdiction determines the board has abused its discretion, it may order the arbitration procedure repeated and issue findings, orders and directions, with costs of suit to be awarded to the prevailing party. 
h)  Cost of arbitration shall be borne equally unless the board finds the offer of the City or the demand of the Grantee was unreasonable in which case, cost may be apportioned so that less or none of the costs may be borne by one party. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.427 - Sec. 27. 
ACCEPTANCE AND EFFECTIVE DATE OF FRANCHISE. 
(A)  No franchise granted pursuant to the provisions of this Ordinance shall become effective unless and until this Ordinance has become effective and, in addition, unless all things required in this section are done and completed, all of such things being declared to be conditions precedent to the effectiveness of any such franchise. In the event any of such things are not done and completed in the time and manner required, the Commission may declare the franchise null and void. 
(B)  Within thirty (30) days after the effective date of any franchise awarded pursuant to this ordinance, or within such extended period of time as the Commission in its discretion may authorize, the Grantee shall file with the City Clerk its written acceptance, in form satisfactory to the City Attorney, of the franchise together with the Letter of Credit, bond and insurance policies required hereunder, and its agreement to be bound by and to comply with and to do all things required of it by the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.428 - Sec. 28. 
VIOLATIONS. 
(A)  From and after the effective date of this Ordinance, it shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or to carry on the business of operating a cable television system unless a franchise therefor has first been obtained pursuant to the provisions of this Ordinance, and unless such franchise is in full force and effect. 
(B)  From and after the effective date of this Ordinance, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or maintain within any public street in the City, or within any other public property of the City, or within any privately owned area within the City which has not yet become a public street but is designated or delineated as a proposed public street on any tentative subdivision map approved by the City, any equipment or facilities for the purpose of operating a cable television system unless a franchise authorizing such use of such street or property or area has first been obtained pursuant to the provisions of this Ordinance, and unless such franchise is in full force and effect. 
(C)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to make any unauthorized connection, whether physically, electrically, acoustically, inductively or otherwise, with any part of a franchised cable television system within this City for the purpose of enabling himself or others to receive any cable television service without payment to the owner of said system. 
(D)  It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of the owner, to willfully tamper with, remove or injure any cables, wires or equipment used for distribution of cable television services. 
(E)  Neither the Grantee hereunder nor any shareholder of the Grantee shall engage in the business of selling, repairing or installing television receivers, radio receivers, or accessories for such receivers within the City of Mount Clemens during the term of this franchise; and the Grantee shall not allow any of its shareholders to so engage in any such business. 
(F)  Violations of any provisions of this Ordinance shall be punishable as a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or for a term not to exceed ninety (90) days or both. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.429 - Sec. 29. 
CONFLICT RESOLUTION. 
    In the event of a conflict between any of the terms and conditions of a franchise granted pursuant to this Ordinance and the provisions of this Ordinance, the franchise agreement will control and prevail over the Ordinance in all respects. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend eff. Jan. 16, 1997; amend. eff. March 28, 2002) 
25.430 - Sec. 30. 
SEVERABILITY. 
    If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this Ordinance is held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, such infirmity shall not affect the validity of the Ordinance; and any portions in conflict are repealed. In the event that the Federal Communications Commission declares any section invalid, then such section or sections shall be renegotiated by the City and the Grantee. 
(ord. eff. June 16, 1983; amend. eff. March 18, 2002) 
25.450 - CABLE TELEVISION RATE REGULATION AND ENFORCEMENT ORDINANCE CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN code eff. Oct. 15, 1993 

25.451 - Sec. 1. 
TITLE AND DECLARATION OF PURPOSE. 
    The following shall be known as the Cable Rate Regulation and Enforcement Ordinance. This Ordinance is being adopted for the purposes of implementing a system of rate regulations on basic programming consistent with the provisions of the Cable Consumer Television Protection Act of 1992, as amended, together with the rules or regulations adopted by the Federal Communications Commission in compliance with that Act. These rate regulations shall remain in effect as long as the cable television system is without effective competition as defined by Federal Law. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.452 - Sec. 2. 
DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purposes of implementation of this Ordinance, the following definitions shall apply: 
1.  Basic Cable Service, or Basic Service shall mean the lowest level of service provided by the Grantee. This shall include all broadcast channels, public, educational and governmental access channels, together with any additional channels or services the Grantee provides on this service level. 
2.  Cable Television Commission shall mean the body duly constituted and appointed by virtue of the Cable TV Ordinance, City Code Sections 25.401 et seq. and sometimes referred therein as the Cable Television Committee or Cable Communications Commission. 
3.  Cable Television System shall mean the equipment, materials and programming used by the Grantee to deliver television and similar signals to persons. The term "television and similar signals" shall include broadcast and satellite signals, as well as all public, educational and governmental access channel signals, whether such transmissions are provided in analog or digital form, together with any other signals transmitted along with same wiring by the Grantee as the television signals. 
4.  Chief Administrator shall mean the officer as designated pursuant to City Code Section 25.419(D). 
5.  City shall mean the City of Mount Clemens in its present incorporated form or as it may be changed by annexation. 
6.  City Clerk shall mean that official appointed by the City Commission on either a permanent or interim basis, as defined by the City Charter. 
7.  City Commission shall mean the City Commission for the City of Mount Clemens. 
8.  Expanded Basic Service or Expanded Basic shall mean that level of service offered by the Grantee that includes the Basic Service and all other satellite or other channels offered by the Grantee as part of a basic package of service as of April 1, 1993, and not available on that date on a per channel (i.e., "a la carte") basis. 
9.  Federal Communications Commission, or FCC shall mean that agency or agencies duly constituted by the laws of the United States to supervise regulatory implementation of legislation affecting delivery of cable television service. Benchmark rates shall mean those rates as established by the FCC. 
10.  Grantee shall mean the party or parties granted and/or assigned a franchise to operate a cable television system within the City. 
11.  Person shall mean any individual, agency or corporate entity. 
12.  Premium Cable Service or Premium Service shall mean those channels or services Grantee had offered on April 1, 1993, on a per channel (i.e., "a la carte") basis. Premium Service shall also include channels or services offered to persons for single events, feature films, or similar limited viewing (i.e., "pay-per-view"). 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.453 - Sec. 3. 
COORDINATION AND COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    In the implementation of this Ordinance, the City and the Grantee shall adhere to all regulations as adopted by the FCC by way of its obligations to promulgate such regulations under the Cable Act. The enforcement of this Ordinance shall be coordinated through and in compliance with FCC's rules and regulations. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.454 - Sec. 4. 
PROCEDURES FOR THE SUBMISSION OF RATES SCHEDULES TO THE CITY; FORM OF SUBMISSION; RATE DECISIONS. 
A.  Submission of proposed rates. Not later than November 1 of each calendar year, Grantee shall submit to the City Clerk a schedule of proposed rates for Basic Service, equipment and other charges for customer services. In the event November 1 falls on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, then the submission shall be due the first business day in the month of November. Such schedules shall include the following information: 
1.  The date(s) requested for the implementation of such charges. 
2.  A schedule of channels and channel placement being made available to subscribing households, including all levels of available service. 
3.  The designation of each such channel as to whether it is defined in the Grantee's offering as Basic, Expanded Basic or Premium Service. 
4.  The proposed monthly charges requested for the Basic, Expanded Basic and Premium Services, including any discounts available to subscribers. 
5.  The proposed charges for installation, sale and/or rental of any equipment, including, but not limited to, the following items: 
a.  The cost of installation of cable television services and any surcharges or discounts applicable to such installation charges and the reason for such surcharges or discounts; 
b.  The items of equipment to be used for the delivery of such services including coaxial cable, fiber-optic lines, modulators, satellite receivers and descramblers, microwave transmission equipment, converter/descrambler boxes, filter traps, remote control devices and similar equipment. In outlining the proposed charges for the installation, sale or rental of this equipment, the Grantee shall identify the manufacturer(s) and model number(s) of the equipment to be utilized as well as the unit cost to the Grantee to purchase or lease such equipment. The Grantee shall specify what consumer options are available with respect to each item of equipment to be placed in or adjacent to the household, including, but not limited to, the availability of two-way transmission, remote control ability, premium channel de-scrambling ability, digital de-scrambling ability and volume control; 
c.  The late charges or penalties proposed to be charged subscribers and the conditions under which those charges are to be imposed or may be waived; 
d.  The cost for the installation and maintenance of additional or modified outlets; 
e.  The cost for sale or rental or remote control devices; 
f.  The cost of cable guides or other similar publications made available to subscribers; 
g.  The cost of any other equipment or material the Grantee seeks to be considered in the setting of rates. 
6.  The Grantee shall supply a list of the charges to subscribers for the items specified within subsection A.5.a.-g. or comparable equipment/materials used by the Grantee in prior years for the five (5) years preceding the date of submission of the rate schedule, including the percentage increase in cost for such items, or, in the event Grantee's franchise has been in effect for less than five (5) years, then for all years the Grantee has held such franchise. 
7.  Concurrent with supplying the above documentation, the Grantee shall supply the City Clerk with copies of all documents submitted to the FCC with respect to the Grantee's cost of equipment. 
8.  The Grantee shall clearly designate what information it considers proprietary in nature and the circumstances under which the Grantee will not object to the public release of such proprietary information. Grantee may request that the identified materials be treated as confidential and not subject to public disclosure. Such request must be submitted with a statement as to why such information should be considered proprietary and the factual basis for such statement. The City Commission shall grant such request to maintain the confidentiality of the materials if it finds such request consistent with the purposes of the Federal Freedom of Information Act and FCC regulation the procedures for requesting public disclosure. 
B.  Receipt and forwarding of information; publication; proprietary information. Upon receipt of the information set forth within Subsection A. of this Section, the City Clerk shall within fourteen (14) days of receipt of the Grantee's submission: 
1.  Cause the proposed rate schedule for basic and regulated equipment to be published in conformance with the City Charter or as otherwise provided by applicable law. 
2.  Provide the City Commission, Chief Administrator and City Attorney with copies of all information supplied to the City Clerk's offices by the Grantee. 
3.  Take all necessary measures to secure any proprietary information supplied to the City Clerk and advise the Grantee in writing of the measures taken to secure these materials. Such materials shall not be disclosed except as provided herein or as otherwise provided by law. 
C.  Consideration of proposal. Following receipt of such submission from the Grantee, the City Clerk shall transmit to the Grantee, via first class mail, to the address provided by the Grantee, a notification containing the following information: 
1.  The proposed schedule of rates shall become effective thirty (30) days after the date of the submission unless such schedule is tolled pursuant to and in conformity with the applicable FCC rules and this Ordinance. 
2.  The Grantee has the burden of proof in demonstrating that the proposed rate schedules comport with the applicable FCC rules and are appropriate in terms of Grantee's costs. 
3.  A Tolling Order for the implementation of the rate schedule shall be made by the City Clerk upon request by either two members of the City Commission or two members of the Cable Television Commission or such Tolling Order may be issued by the City Clerk in his or her discretion. 
4.  The City Attorney shall advise the City Clerk if any additional information is necessary from the Grantee. 
D.  Obligation of the City Clerk. The City Clerk shall request from the City Commission and Cable Television Commission a determination as to whether additional information is necessary or that a public hearing should be conducted to evaluate the Grantee's proposed rate schedule. In the event the City Clerk is notified by two or more members of either the City Commission or Cable Commission that a public hearing should be held or the City Clerk believes that such a public hearing is warranted, the City Clerk shall issue a Tolling Order to the Grantee, delaying the implementation of the rate schedule for a period not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of the Tolling Order. In the event the City Clerk issues a Tolling Order, he or she shall promptly notify the Grantee in writing, via first class mail, of the Tolling Order and setting forth the length of the Tolling period. The City Clerk shall also advise the Grantee that a public hearing before the Cable Television Commission will occur within thirty (30) days of the date of the Tolling Order. 
E.  Public hearing. Following the issuance of the Tolling Order, the City Clerk shall immediately schedule a public hearing before the Cable Television Commission, to be held within thirty (30) days of the date of the Tolling Order. Notification of the hearing date, time and location shall be transmitted to the Grantee via first class mail. The following provisions are made for public hearings as to a cable rate regulation request: 
1.  The notice of such public hearing shall be in writing and posted as required under the City Charter or as otherwise provided by applicable law. 
2.  At such public hearing, the Grantee shall have the opportunity to present arguments and documentation in person and/or in writing supporting its proposed rate schedule. Following this presentation, the Cable Commission shall hear arguments and consider documentation as prescribed by the City Attorney, other City officials and members of the general public as to the proposed rate schedule. The Grantee may then be allowed to present arguments and documentation in rebuttal. 
3.  In the event the Cable Television Commission needs additional information, documentation, or materials from the Grantee or any other person, it shall direct that the same be supplied to the Cable Television Commission within fourteen (14) days of the date of the public hearing. Items submitted after the fourteen (14) day period shall not be considered. The Grantee or other person shall supply these materials to the City Clerk and the City Clerk shall process these materials in comportment with Section 4.B. of this Ordinance. Concurrently, the Cable Television Commission shall schedule a second public hearing to be held within twenty-eight (28) days after the initial hearing date. 
4.  Upon receipt of the additional materials, the Chief Administrator shall distribute such materials to the members of the Cable Television Commission. The Chief Administrator shall then prepare a written recommendation as to the proposed rate schedule. In evaluating the rates to be set for services, the Chief Administrator shall allow a fair return on investment, taking into account appropriate costs including, but not limited to, the Grantee's capital costs, basic cable programming, customer service, labor and ancillary costs attributable to obtaining and transmitting signals carried on the Basic Service. Also considered shall be increases in the Grantee's costs as to any franchise-imposed requirements not directly related to the provision of cable television service as well as a reasonable profit to the Grantee. The Chief Administrator shall presume the reasonableness of documented increases and those basic cable costs factors itemized in this "fair return on investment" standard. 
5.  At the adjourned hearing, the Cable Television Commission shall review all information and materials together with the written recommendation of the Chief Administrator. The Commission may adopt such recommendation or, after setting forth a basis for adopting a modification to that recommendation, and considering all factors outlined within subsection E.4. of this Ordinance section, may make and adopt a modified recommendation. Any modification, and the basis for the recommendation, shall be promptly reduced to writing and supplied to the City Clerk and sent promptly to the Grantee via first class mail. 
6.  The recommendation of the Cable Television Commission shall become final and binding upon the Grantee within seven (7) days of the date that the written recommendation is adopted. The Grantee, prior to the expiration of the seven (7) day effective date, may file objections with the City Clerk requesting a hearing before the City Commission. If no objections are filed, the City Clerk shall cause the rate schedule to be published in conformance with the City Charter or as otherwise provided by law. 
F.  Hearing before the City Commission. 
1.  In the event the City Clerk receives objections to the proposed recommendation of the Cable Television Commission, he or she shall transmit to the City Commission the Recommendation of the Chief Administrator, any modified recommendation as made by the Cable Television Commission, as well as written objections of the Grantee. 
2.  At the next available City Commission meeting, the above listed recommendations as well as the objections, shall be reviewed. Additional written materials may be submitted to the City Commission for its review up to seven (7) days prior to the schedule public hearing. 
3.  At the public hearing, the City Commission shall hear comments from the public and the Grantee and may adopt the initial schedule of rates as proposed, the recommendation of the Chief Administrator, the modified recommendation made by the Cable Commission, or direct the implementation of a schedule of rates that the City Commission believes appropriate. The rate schedule as adopted by the City Commission shall be put in the form of a Resolution and executed by the Mayor and City Clerk. The rate schedule shall be final and binding upon the Grantee upon execution of the Resolution. 
4.  Included within the Resolution shall be a full listing of charges, together with the effective date(s) of such charges. The Resolution shall be mailed to the Grantee via first class mail and published in conformance with the City Charter or as otherwise provided by applicable law. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.455 - Sec. 5. 
RULES OF PROCEDURES. 
    The Cable Television Commission shall adopt and implement such rules of procedure in the conducting of public hearings as its consistent with the FCC regulations and due process of law. At all times, the Grantee, at its election, may choose to be represented by counsel. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.456 - Sec. 6. 
REFUNDS. 
    The City Commission and the Cable Television Commission may direct the payment of refunds to subscribers retroactive to the date of submission by the Grantee of its proposed rate schedule. The City Commission or the Cable Television Commission shall direct what means the Grantee will undertake in order to pay any such refunds in accordance with the procedures set forth herein. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.457 - Sec. 7. 
FAILURE TO GIVE NOTICE. 
    Any failure to give notice as provided for herein shall not invalidate any orders, recommendations or decision as set forth under this rule. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.458 - Sec. 8. 
ADDITIONAL HEARINGS. 
    Upon reasonable notice, the City Commission or the Cable Television Commission may schedule such additional hearings as may be necessary in the exercise of their regulatory functions as set forth within this Ordinance or as otherwise provided by law. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.459 - Sec. 9. 
GRANTEE'S FAILURE TO COMPLY; REMEDIES. 
A.  Failure to submit proposed rate schedule. In the event the Grantee fails to submit a proposed rate schedule, it shall, on November 1, reduce its basic rates to seventy-five percent (75%) of the FCC Benchmark of rates and its services/rental charges to those specified within the initial franchise agreement or proposal to provide a franchise agreement or, if no specific charges are listed for the particular service/rental charges, to such amounts as may be adopted by the Cable Television Commission as set forth below. 
B.  Cable Television Commission; Authority to set rates. 
1.  In the event Grantee fails to submit a proposed rate schedule as set forth above, within sixty (60) days, the Cable Television Commission shall meet to review the FCC Benchmark of Rates as well as the charges for services/rentals within the original franchise agreement and the FCC materials regarding the service/rental expenses and issue a rate schedule binding upon the Grantee. 
2.  In evaluating these rates, the Cable Commission shall consider that the Grantee is entitled to a fair return on its investment and shall take into account the appropriate costs including, but not limited to, the Grantee's capital costs, basic cable programming, customer service, labor and ancillary costs attributable to obtaining and transmitting signals carried on the Basic Service. Increases in such costs, and the costs of any franchise imposed requirements not directly related to the provision of cable television service, as well as a reasonable profit to the Grantee shall also be considered. The Grantee may submit written documentation to the Cable Television Commission prior to the meeting date as to any aspects of its costs. The Cable Television Commission shall presume the reasonableness of any documented increases supplied by the Grantee in those basic cable cost factors itemized in this "fair return on investment" standard. 
3.  The Cable Television Commission shall adopt the effective dates that the rate schedule shall be in effect, with the beginning date being November 1 and the ending date being the date provided by subsequent implementation of this Ordinance upon adoption. The Cable Television Commission shall provide a copy of the rate schedule to the City Clerk. 
4.  The City Clerk shall mail the rate schedule to the Grantee and publish the same in conformance with the City Charter or as otherwise provided by applicable law. The rate schedule shall be effective upon its being reduced to writing and executed by the City Clerk. 
C.  Grantee's failure to comply with request for information. In the event the Grantee fails to respond to any request for additional material or information, the City Commission may direct the immediate reduction of Grantee's Basic rates to 75% of the FCC Benchmark for cable subscribers for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days for each violation. The City Commission may also direct the imposition of penalties of up to $100.00 per day for each day that a violation occurs, to be chargeable to the Grantee. The Grantee shall be entitled to demand a public hearing before the City Commission to contest the assessment of penalties hereunder. 
D.  Failure to set rates in comportment with the schedule as adopted. In the event the Grantee fails to adhere to the rate schedule as established by this Ordinance, the City Commission may impose penalties including, but not limited to, the following: 
1.  Termination of the franchise and/or filing suit within the Circuit Court for placement of such franchise in receivership; 
2.  Imposition of fines not to exceed $100.00 per day for each scheduled item of the rate schedule that the Grantee fails to comply with, chargeable to Grantee's Letter of Credit; 
3.  An order directing the immediate roll-back of Basic Service rates to 75% of the FCC Benchmark; and/or, 
4.  An order directing that the appropriate refunds be made to subscribers and the means the Grantee is to employ in making such refunds. 
The Grantee shall be entitled to a public hearing before the City Commission to contest the assessment of the above penalties. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.460 - Sec. 10. 
REQUESTS FOR DISCLOSURE OF ASSERTED PROPRIETARY INFORMATION. 
    Requests for disclosure of any documents Grantee asserts are proprietary may be submitted to the City Clerk by any person. The City Commission shall be the sole authority to authorize public disclosure to alleged proprietary materials. In determining whether any such materials shall be disclosed, the City Commission shall grant the Grantee's request to maintain the confidentiality of the materials only if such request is consistent with the purposes of the Federal Freedom of Information Act and applicable FCC regulation. If a request for disclosure is submitted to the City Clerk, such submission shall be in writing specifying what materials sought to be disclosed to the public and the basis for requesting such public disclosure. The City Clerk shall mail a copy of the request to the Grantee. The Grantee shall have fourteen (14) days from the date of mailing to respond to the request. At its next available City Commission meeting, the City Commission shall review the request for disclosure as well as the response submitted by the Grantee. Any decision of the City Commission as to such disclosure shall become final fourteen (14) days after the City Commission meeting. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
25.461 - Sec. 11. 
ADDITIONAL POWERS. 
    The City Commission and Cable Television Commission's powers as set forth herein should be in addition to all other powers afforded franchising authorities by applicable law or regulation. 
(code eff. Oct. 15, 1993) 
30.000 - STREETS AND PUBLIC WAYS[1] 
CITY OF MOUNT CLEMENS, MICHIGAN 
code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- For City authority to regulate and control the use of streets and public ways, see Char., sec. 11(6). 
State Law reference- See also C.L., 1948, sec. 117.4h(1); Mich. Stat. Anno., sec. 5.2081. 

30.001 - Sec. 1. 
STREET CUTS AND EXCAVATIONS; PERMIT REQUIRED. 
    No person shall make any excavation or opening in or under any street or public place without first procuring a permit from the Department of Public Works. 
(code eff. 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
30.002 - Sec. 2. 
STREET OPENINGS REQUIRED TO BE GUARDED. 
    No person making an opening in a street or public way shall fail to guard the same fully during the period of construction, and no person causing any such opening to be used, nor the user thereof, shall fail to guard or barricade the same while in use, so as to protect the safety of the public. No person using any street opening, or causing the same to be used, shall fail to close the opening in accordance with the directions of the Director of Public Works immediately after use. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
30.003 - Sec. 3. 
BOND REQUIRED. 
    No permit shall be granted until a bond or policy of insurance has been filed with the Department of Public Works. The bond or policy of insurance shall be in the sum of $1,000.00, unless a larger bond shall be required by the City Commission. All bonds or policies of insurance shall be conditioned to pay all damages to the streets of the City and to hold the City harmless of every other damage of every other nature, whether to persons or property, for which the City may be held liable by reason of, or which is occasioned by, the doing of a thing or the exercise of the privilege for which the permit upon which the bond or policy of insurance was based, was granted. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
30.004 - Sec. 4. 
ADDITIONAL CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS. 
    The Department of Public Works may make such additional rules and regulations, subject to the approval of the City Commission, pertaining to the making of openings or excavations in streets as are necessary to secure the health and safety of the public and for the protection of property, and such rules and regulations shall constitute the standards upon which the permit hereinbefore required shall be issued. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
30.005 - Sec. 5. 
STREETS, ALLEYS; PROHIBITED CONDUCT. 
    No unauthorized person shall move, alter, deface, injure or destroy any part or accessory of any street or alley or any sign or barricade erected or placed to protect, warn or guide the public. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
30.006 - Sec. 6. 
MOVING BUILDINGS; PERMIT REQUIRED. 
    No person shall remove, or cause to be removed, or aid or assist in removing, any building into, along or across any street, alley or public way without first procuring a permit as required by the Building Code of the City. 
(code eff. Oct., 1958; amend. Jan., 1978) 
Cross reference- For provisions relative to the City Building Code, see 22.010, sec. 1, et seq. 
30.007 - Sec. 7. 
RESERVED.
